HEADLINE: Fresh Fighting In Philippines; Death Toll Rises to 100 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: JOLO, the Philippines, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
Fresh fighting broke out on Jolo island today, and the death toll in an uprising by guerrillas loyal to a rebellious Muslim governor rose to more than 100, military officials said. The officials said they had used helicopter gunships and World War II vintage bomber planes to attack guerrilla positions. They also said they had sought the help of Malaysia to keep the governor, Nur Misuari, from escaping there by sea. 
 The navy threatened to sink any boat he tried to use. 
 "As per body count and reports from the field, the enemy suffered fatalities not lower than 100," Lt. Gen. Roy Cimatu, the military commander in the south, said. "We know where their hide-outs are, and airstrikes are continuing."
About 7,000 soldiers hunted the governor's fighters, who attacked an army base and four other targets on Jolo on Monday. Charges of rebellion -- punishable by a maximum 40 years in jail -- are to be filed on Thursday against Mr. Misuari and his followers, officials said.
As the chairman of the Moro National Liberation Front, Mr. Misuari signed a peace accord in 1996 after leading a revolt for an Islamic state in the south of the mainly Roman Catholic Philippines for 24 years.
The military said the front's latest attacks were meant to prevent elections on Monday to pick a successor to Mr. Misuari as governor of the Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao. General Cimatu said skirmishes were occurring in Panamao, Patikul and Indanan, mountainous areas on the largely Muslim island.
Military officials said they believed Mr. Misuari was hiding in a village on Jolo, but they were checking reports he might have gone to Sabah, a state in Malaysia. A report from villagers said he had been wounded in the airstrikes, but it was not confirmed, General Cimatu said.
Manila set up the semiautonomous region of four impoverished Muslim provinces and installed Mr. Misuari as governor after the 1996 accord.
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's administration has accused him of mismanaging the region. He has said the region has remained poor because Manila has failed to release funds to develop it.
After talks in Washington with President Arroyo, President Bush said on Tuesday that the United States would increase military and economic aid to the Philippines for its fight against Muslim separatists, calling it an extension of the war against terrorism. He said the United States would give nearly $100 million to help the Philippines combat Abu Sayyaf, another Muslim guerrilla group in the southern Philippines.
The local military has accused Mr. Misuari of entering into an alliance with Abu Sayyaf, which has been holding an American missionary couple hostage for nearly six months. Washington has linked the group to Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network, Al Qaeda.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A boy sat among soldiers yesterday on Jolo island in the Philippines, where troops were sent after rebels loyal to a defiant Muslim governor struck an army base this week. The death toll topped 100 guerrillas, officials said. (Agence France-Presse)

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 9; A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

HEADLINE: On the 104th Floor in Two Towers, a Boyfriend and a Brother Are Lost

BYLINE: These sketches were written by Adam Clymer, Sherri Day, Barnaby J. Feder, Constance L. Hays, Jan Hoffman, Dena Kleiman, Barbara Stewart and Yilu Zhao.

 BODY:
Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

FREDERICK COX
A 'Glutton for Life'
 Climb into that hammock between two trees on an island in Lake Winnepesaukee, N.H. Feel the soft summer stillness. Look up. A tile hanging from one tree reads, ''Do what you love, love what you do.''
 That was Frederick Cox's hammock, his motto, the tile he hung.
 Like his motto, Mr. Cox, 27, was a full-throttle enthusiast brushed by navet.
 Even though he sought the serenity of his family's summer home, he lived a Manhattan life of joyous clatter. Buoyantly confident, with his green eyes glowing with mischief, he made friends easily.
 Who could resist that pied-piper promise of adventure, the courtliness of a Georgia-bred gentleman, the charm of a super salesman?
 Not Annelise Peterson, his girlfriend, who described Mr. Cox, an investment banker at Sandler O'Neill, as a ''glutton for life'' -- a painter, writer, golfer, shopper, food lover. He reminded her of her older brother Davin, a trader for Cantor Fitzgerald. Both were tall, loyal, attentive.
 After Mr. Cox's parents divorced when he was 8, he gave his mother a rose every Valentine's Day. His father, the son said, was his best friend.
 Both Mr. Cox and Davin Peterson, who dined with Ms. Peterson on Sept. 8, worked on the 104th floor at the World Trade Center -- Mr. Peterson in the north tower, Mr. Cox in the south tower.

DAVIN PETERSON
A Gentle Giant
It felt natural to look up to Davin Peterson: he was 6 feet 6 inches tall. But he was also comfortable as a leader and mediator of the four Peterson kids, his mother's stalwart and confidant when the family was cracked by divorce. He was calming, clear-headed, an old soul since childhood, but possessed of an exquisite sensitivity: when one sister was going through a rough time, he wept about it openly at work.
 At 25, he was a trader at Cantor Fitzgerald, although notions of his future were still forming. His travel lust had taken him to Vietnam, China, Scandinavia.
 With a deep interest in human rights, politics and economics, he considered starting a business in an impoverished country.
 Mr. Peterson was also possessed of an antic sense of humor. He cooked anti-Thanksgiving meals -- one year, fajitas, another year, steak.
 He had an elaborate scheme for the secession of his native California, featuring himself as the head of a military coup. And he vowed to leave his life insurance to Rambo, his mother's beloved five-pound Yorkshire terrier.
 Really?
 Ah, got you!
 And whenever he did, Mr. Peterson, enormously pleased with himself, would dance a little jig, a gentle giant with size 16 feet.

RONALD BUCCA
Rescuer and Counselor
Ronald Bucca was nicknamed ''the Flying Fireman'' in 1986 after he fell spectacularly from a tenement fire escape, spun around a cable strung through the backyard and lived to tell the tale. And that was just one of his moments.
 His specialty was rescuing mankind from smoke and flames, but he did not mind scorching certain people with his wit.
 His colleagues collected ''Ron-isms.'' An example: ''This one is as sharp as a basketball.''
 He designed hats for other firemen with details that they found hilarious (but unfortunately, that were not printable).
 A firefighter for 23 years, the last nine as a fire marshal, he was also a nurse and a reservist in the United States Army's Special Forces.
 Mr. Bucca trained as an antiterrorist intelligence expert, and when the planes hit the towers on Sept. 11, he called his wife, Eve, and said he was heading to the scene.
 ''He knew it was a terrorist attack,'' Mrs. Bucca said. ''He had been expecting something like that for a very long time.'' 
 Before that day, his final investigation had involved a young woman who set her former boyfriend's letters on fire and left them to burn in a toilet. He counseled her as a father might.
 ''No guy is worth getting this upset over; don't be too concerned about this guy,'' he told her, said Keith O'Mara, his partner. ''There are a lot of fish in the sea. And if this should ever happen again, think about buying yourself a paper shredder.''

KEVIN DONNELLY
Fun Is the Beach
Fire may have provided Lt. Kevin Donnelly of Ladder Company 3 with his livelihood, but what he loved was water. 
 Born under the hot July sun, he got a job as a lifeguard at the town pool in Wantagh, while still a teenager on Long Island, said his mother, Cecilia. As an adult, he found any excuse to head for the water, even when some other task beckoned.
 ''He kept a bathing suit, a towel and goggles in his car at all times, just in case,'' said his longtime companion, Mary Coughlin, ''and in the summer, he'd add two beach chairs, a towel and a bathing suit for me.'' 
 The two of them might be driving along, on their way to Home Depot or some other store to run errands. And Lieutenant Donnelly, 43, would turn to her, and say: ''You know what? We can do this another time. Let's go to the beach.''
 He was not persnickety about his beaches, though he preferred those on the ocean. He was hoping to become a lifeguard again, on some Long Island strand. North Shore, South Shore. ''He wouldn't have cared what beach he ended up on,'' Ms. Coughlin said, ''as long as it was on the sand and near the water.''

CALIXTO ANAYA JR.
Doing Things Right
Calixto Anaya Jr.'s wife, Marie, remembers the New York City firefighter everyone knew as Charlie as ''very attentive to the little things that keep love alive,'' whether it was taking days off for activities with their three children or showing up with flowers when she did not expect them.
 ''Charlie always wanted to do things the right way,'' Mrs. Anaya said. When they were married in 1990 in a simple civil service, Mr. Anaya insisted that they begin saving for the big church wedding her parents could not afford. Six months later, they marched down the aisle of St. Rita's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.
 Mr. Anaya, a former Marine who re-enlisted when the Persian Gulf War broke out in 1991, believed true patriotism meant flying the American flag, not only in front of their home in Suffern, N.Y., but also wherever the family came to rest on camping trips or jaunts to the beach.
 Mr. Anaya, 35, loved the Yankees in baseball and the Giants in football with similar exuberance. He preserved the hole he punched in his basement ceiling while celebrating the Yankees' World Series victory over the Mets last year.

VIRGINIA M. JABLONSKI
The Early Bird
Virginia M. Jablonski, an assistant vice president at Marsh & McLennan, liked to get up at 5 a.m. and catch an early bus from her home in Matawan, N.J., to her office on the 94th floor of 1 World Trade Center. In recent months, that often meant slipping out while Barry, her husband of 21 years, was enjoying the extra sleep made possible by his recent retirement from Lucent Technologies.
 Fortunately, Mr. Jablonski is an astronomy buff. Having noted that the International Space Station was scheduled to pass directly overhead shortly before sunrise on Sept. 11, he got up with her that morning. He recalls their standing in their garden, marveling at the stars in the clear sky and sharing the feeling that it would be a good day.
 ''She was a bubbly person who was always smiling,'' Mr. Jablonski said. ''Most people wouldn't know if she was angry.''
 No one could miss her passion for cats, though. Mrs. Jablonski, a 49-year-old Brooklyn native, filled their home with cat-themed decorations and doted on her two feline companions, Fred and Bill.

MICHAEL A. TRINIDAD
Staying Friends
When Michael A. Trinidad and Monique Ferrer divorced three years ago, they stayed friends. Ms. Ferrer got the custody of their two children, Thea, then 7, and Timothy, then 6, and it was understood that the children were ''theirs'' -- not ''his'' or ''hers.''
 Every other Friday, Mr. Trinidad would come to pick up the children for the weekend. ''He was like a big kid,'' Ms. Ferrer said. ''He would take them to the park, play ball games, call them silly names and just act silly.'' The three also went apple picking in upstate New York and sun-bathing on the Jersey Shore.
 After the first plane hit the trade center on Sept. 11, Mr. Trinidad, 33, who was working in telecommunications accounting for Cantor Fitzgerald, called Ms. Ferrer to say goodbye. '' 'What goodbye?' I asked him. 'Are you going anywhere?' '' Ms. Ferrer recalled asking him, unaware of the disaster.
 '' 'I love you, and I love the kids,' he said. 'I am not going to make it out.' Then he asked to talk to my husband,'' Ms. Ferrer said. ''Michael asked my husband to be his children's father and love them for him.''

SIEW-NYA ANG
Missing Mommy
It has been at least eight years since Siew-Nya Ang saw an R-rated movie. Ms. Ang relished family time and since her daughters Jeanee, 8, and Winnee, 4, were too young for movies with grown-up themes, she only watched family-oriented films.
 Ms. Ang, 37, also discouraged her husband, Kui-Liong Lee, from doing yardwork when he could be spending time with the family. ''She would say: 'Wake up early in the morning. You can mow the lawn when we're asleep,' '' Mr. Lee said. 
 On weekdays, Ms. Ang left for her job as a technical analyst at Marsh USA while her family was sleeping. But every morning around 8, she called home to make sure her girls were properly equipped to handle a day of school and dance, piano, ice skating or gymnastics lessons.
 Since Sept. 11, the girls say good night to a picture of Ms. Ang, which hangs on the bedroom wall. Some nights, they complain to it, too. ''Sometimes I have to let them know that Mommy is in heaven and other than that I just don't know what to say,'' Mr. Lee said. ''Sometimes if they say 'I want mommy,' I can't do anything.''

ANTHONY STARITA
Relaxing With a Cigar
Cigars were a necessary accessory for Anthony Starita. He had one in his mouth when he went to beach, when he puttered around his backyard in Westfield, N.J., and when he relaxed on his deck every night after dinner. ''He liked the flavor,'' said his wife, Diane Starita. ''He didn't always actually smoke them, but he would just have one in his mouth to sort of chew on.''
 Mr. Starita, 35, also chewed on coffee straws, mostly when he got nervous about a deal at his job as a government bond trader at Cantor Fitzgerald. ''When he got a little nervous he put the straws in his mouth and he would start wiping his hands with napkins,'' said Eddie De Castro, Mr. Starita's longtime friend and former trading partner. ''Those were his two things.''
 Last year, Mr. Starita gave up his full-time golf membership at a country club so that he could spend more time with his wife and two children, Kaila, 6, and Jason, 3.
 After the terrorist attacks, Mrs. Starita told the children that their father had gone to heaven. Kaila wondered why ''does he have to be with God?'' Mrs. Starita said. ''My 3-year-old wanted to know if we could call Daddy in heaven.''

MARGARET CONNER
Sailing Toward Renewal
When Margaret Conner wanted to escape the chaos of everyday life, she fled her home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and headed for her daughter's boat on Candlewood Lake in Brookfield, Conn. It did not matter that Mrs. Conner was prone to seasickness and could not swim. Sailing on the lake brought her peace and tranquillity. 
 Back home, Mrs. Conner, 57, was the gatekeeper at Cantor Fitzgerald, a receptionist who was the first person people saw when they got off the elevator on the 103rd Floor of 1 World Trade Center. For many young women at the office, she was a relationship therapist.
 ''She was just very open and very eager to be there for anyone,'' said her daughter, Corrine Bounty.
 Mrs. Conner and her husband, Frank Conner, were married for 13 years and spent nearly every moment of their free time together, often frequenting Broadway plays and dining out. Every day they recorded and watched Mrs. Conner's favorite soap opera, ''The Young and the Restless.''
 Mrs. Conner was also committed to her daily Bible study. On Sept. 11 her study passage was about the healing and renewal of God. 
 ''I read this passage the next day and was furious with God,'' Mr. Conner said. ''After rereading the passage, I realized that God had fulfilled his message to her. She is now in a place where His ever-renewing life is coursing throughout her body.''

JANE JOSIAH
Have Friends, Will Travel
Last year, Jane Josiah began a series of visits to far-flung family and friends that did not end for nearly a year. She did not begin looking for work after being laid off last winter. Instead she flew from Texas, where she had moved seven years earlier, to Seattle to see her brother and sister-in-law. 
 Soon after, she went to Washington for a few weeks with Jennifer and Kelly, her daughters. Then she stayed with friends in Philadelphia and Long Island.
 Ms. Josiah, 47, had a gift for making friends, loving them and kicking up her heels with them, said Debra Potash, who knew her 20 years. 
 The visiting culminated with Ms. Josiah's 30th high school reunion in Levittown, on Long Island, where old friends persuaded her to come home. After one found her a job at Fiduciary Trust, she drove north to Mrs. Potash's home on Long Island. Her first day was Aug. 27.
 All the traveling had made Ms. Josiah's daughters a bit impatient. ''It was supposed to be a month,'' Jennifer said. ''Then two months. Then four.''
 Now, she said, the months her mother spent with the people she loved seem like an unmatchable gift.

MARK BAVIS
Scouting Hockey Talent
Mark Bavis, a hockey scout, was on his way to work on Sept. 11, flying west for the Los Angeles Kings training camp, where he would be checking on the progress of players the team had drafted on his advice. He took United Airlines Flight 175 from Boston.
 Mr. Bavis, 32, had starred for the Boston University Terriers from 1990 to 1993. He was ''a great defensive forward and a real smart playmaker,'' said his coach, Jack Parker.
 The coach used Mark and his twin brother, Mike, as a team to kill penalties. ''The Bavi, we called them,'' Mr. Parker said. ''They were always together.''
 Mike Bavis, an assistant to Mr. Parker, agreed. ''We were very close,'' he said. ''But we were competitive.''
 The scouting job, after a few years in minor league hockey and turns as assistant coach at Brown and Harvard, delighted his brother because of the travel it involved. ''He really enjoyed some of the finer places in our country and loved to have a good time,'' his brother said.

RALPH GERHARDT
A Dream Fulfilled
He delighted in bungee jumping and feeding sharks. At 6 feet 2 inches tall, Ralph Gerhardt enjoyed playing the part of daredevil and strong man. He had an impish sense of humor and a reputation for practical jokes.
 Still, he was an affectionate son, who called his parents in Toronto every day. 
 He had grown up in Toronto, the son of German immigrants, but New York had always been his dream.
 And so last February -- when Mr. Gerhardt, a 34-year-old bond trader, was transferred by Cantor Fitzgerald to the 105th floor of the World Trade Center -- was one of the happiest times of his life. 
 He was eager to show his parents that life -- ''my New York'' as he was so proud to call it.
 His parents came often to visit so he could show them the apartment he was fixing up on Lexington Avenue and 26th Street, the bicycle he liked to ride over to Central Park, the woman from Staten Island he had met at work, the many museums and monuments he prided himself on knowing, as well as the best tour guides.
 ''It was the pinnacle,'' said his father, Hans Gerhardt, who last heard from his son at 8:48 a.m., moments after the plane hit. ''He said: 'Something just happened. I am O.K. We are evacuating. I will call you later.' ''

FLORENCE M. GREGORY
The Stylings of Disco Flo
Seated in what she thought was too formal a restaurant last winter at Christmas, Florence M. Gregory announced to companions that she was going outside to ask the Salvation Army band on the corner if they knew a certain song. Moments later, the band arrived at the restaurant, took the table next to hers, and played songs for everyone.
 ''That was my sister,'' Maureen Petronis said. ''She could break the ice anywhere.''
 Miss Gregory, who was known as ''Disco Flo'' because of her taste in music, loved people. ''She was always smiling and laughing and joking,'' Mrs. Petronis said. ''People were drawn to her.''
 When she was not working at Aon, where she was a specialist in marine insurance, Miss Gregory, 38, could be found golfing, fishing, cooking, traveling and spending time with her two nieces and three nephews. A longtime resident of Breezy Point in Queens, she was one of three children of Florence and John Gregory.
 She was an excellent cook and took particular pleasure in preparing meals for family and friends. Her favorite holiday was St. Patrick's Day, when she would pull out all the stops with corned beef and cabbage.
 ''She was a fabulous aunt,'' Mrs. Petronis said.

The Confirmed Dead
 Following is the name of the person most recently confirmed to have died in the World Trade Center disaster, according to the New York City medical examiner's office, which said the victim's family had been notified.

GRAY, James Michael

HEADLINE: SPARE TIMES 

 BODY:
 ATTRACTIONS

Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. "Pearls," an exhibition on the history of pearls, through April 14. "Meeting God: Elements of Hindu Devotion," through Feb. 24. "The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter," featuring 400 to 500 live and flying butterflies from the Americas kept in a walk-in vivarium, is on view through May 27. The main auditorium, where Imax films are shown, will be closed for renovations through the spring. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Friday and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission to "Pearls" is by timed-entry ticket only, available on the half-hour beginning at 10 a.m.; tickets, which include suggested museum admission, are $15; $11 for students and 60+; $9 for children 12 and under; under 2, free. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and 60+; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200; www .amnh.org.

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. On display is the society's exhibition of new acquisitions for 2001, which includes United States gold coins from the wreck of the S.S. Central America, which sank in 1857; a rare drachma from Catania, Sicily; and glass weights dating to medieval Egypt. Through January. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 234-3130.

FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM, 54 Pearl Street, second floor, Lower Manhattan. The museum, in a former tavern, is dedicated to the study and interpretation of early American history and culture. One of the period-room displays is the Long Room, the site of Washington's "farewell address." Exhibitions include "Colonists, Revolutionaries, Builders: Freemasons in America," with material relating to Washington, Paul Revere, Benjamin Franklin and Lafayette; "Washington at War," with a look at Washington's battle experiences; and "The Societies of the Sons of the Revolution," devoted to the patriotic deeds of the 28 state societies. Other permanent exhibitions are the Clinton Room, named for George Clinton, the first American-born governor of New York, and a re-creation of an early-19th-century private dining room. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4:50 p.m.; closed Sundays and Mondays. Suggested admission: $3; $2 for students, children and 65+; children under 6, free. Information: (212) 425-1778.

HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. Dedicated to Hispanic culture, with fine and decorative arts of the Iberian Peninsula from prehistory to the present. "Splendor of Alcora: Spanish Ceramics of the 18th Century, Part 2" (1749-1798), through Dec. 16. The permanent collection is on view. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 926-2234.

MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. On permanent display are "Where Is Home? Chinese in the Americas," a collection of photographs and other artifacts; "Family Portraits," photographs of Chinatown residents; and "Chinatowns in North America," a CD-ROM installation featuring photographs by William Chu. "Not on the Menu: From Asian/ Pacific Islander Roots to American Reality," photographs by Corky Lee, through next Friday. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed Sundays, Mondays and holidays, including today. Admission: $3; 62+ and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free. Information: (212) 619-4785.

MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FINANCIAL HISTORY, 28 Broadway, at Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. "Morgan," a biographical exhibition about the business life of J. P. Morgan, through December. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $2 suggested donation. Information: (212) 908-4110.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. "Emanuel Ringelblum and the Hidden Archive of the Warsaw Ghetto," an exhibition of Jewish life in Nazi-occupied Poland, featuring photographs, essays and artwork; through Feb. 18. "War Against the Jews," on events from 1933 to 1945, and "Jewish Renewal," on postwar life. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and 55+, $5; children 5 and under, free. To reserve tickets: (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street, Manhattan. "New York Sept. 11 by Magnum Photographers," photo essays depicting the World Trade Center attacks, through Feb. 25; "75 Years of Holiday Magic: Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade," including photographs, drawings, videos and models, through Feb. 17; "Manhattan Unfurled," drawings and conceptual studies focusing on the Manhattan skyline, with a centerpiece of two continuous 37-foot-long pen-and-ink line drawings by Matteo Pericoli, through Jan. 6; "The British in New York," an exhibition that examines the business, cultural and political ties between Britain and the United States, part of the UK With NY festival, through Jan. 13; "The Rosenbergs Reconsidered: The Death Penalty in the Cold War Era," an exhibition that includes documents from the case as well as magazine covers, posters and other items that reflect public opinion at the time, through Jan. 6; and "John Koch: Painting a New York Life," a retrospective, through Jan. 27. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; children and 62+, $3. Information: (212) 873-3400.

Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. "Brooklyn and Beyond: The Panoramic Photography of Jerry Dantzic," an exhibition of urban and rural landscapes around the country, on view through Jan. 6. "Arnold Kessler: Real and Imaginary," an exhibition of photographs of flowers. Suggested admission: $3; $1.50 for students and 65+ (free for 65+ on Fridays); free for children 15 and under; free for all on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Bronx River Parkway at Fordham Road, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Fall blooms include chrysanthemums. "Momijigari: The Japanese Autumn Garden," an outdoor exhibition that incorporates a traditional Japanese garden with autumn blooms, through Sunday. "Conifers: Treasured Works of Living Art," a tour of the firs, pines and spruces growing near the conservatory, tomorrow at 2 p.m.; "An Urban Geographer Looks at the Holiday Train Show," a tour led by Jack Eichenbaum on Sunday at 2 p.m. "Holiday Train Show," the annual model train display, opens today and is up through Jan. 6. Also opening today and remaining on view through Jan. 6, "Holiday Reflections: A Festival of Light." Conservatory admission: $5; students and 62+, $4; ages 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Grounds admission free on Wednesdays and 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Parking: $5. The best way to see the garden is with a Garden Passport, which grants admission to the grounds and includes a tram tour: adults, $10; students and 62+, $7.50; ages 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Grounds hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (718) 817-8700 or www.nybg.org.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES 

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr 

 BODY:
Trading Britain For America
 Tom Wilkinson's face, along with some of his other parts, is probably best known to American audiences from the film "The Full Monty," in which he played an unemployed foreman in an English steel factory who joins five of his buddies in a troupe of male strippers. 
 That primary identification is likely to change as of today with the release of "In the Bedroom," a somber domestic drama that gives Mr. Wilkinson his first leading role in an American movie (review, Page 25). In the film, directed by Todd Field from a short story by Andre Dubus, Mr. Wilkinson and Sissy Spacek play the New England parents of a college-age son (Nick Stahl) who is involved with an older woman (Marisa Tomei). Tragedy strikes, and with it, Mr. Wilkinson and Ms. Spacek achieve some stunning moments of actorly intensity. 
"I thought it would be good for me to do," Mr. Wilkinson said of his trans-Atlantic venture. "I read it and I thought, this is a wonderful piece. It's intelligent; it's got a beginning, a middle and an end. It fits together, and it's got certain resonances which are only now clear to me, having seen the movie. Of course, a script is merely a blueprint; it's not the finished article. So I thought it would be good for me to do, just from the simple level of it'd be good to play an American, it would be good to be a lead in an American movie, it would be good to work with Sissy."
For Mr. Wilkinson, "the tradition of English screen acting is, on the whole, versatility," he said. "John Mills, who is a fantastic actor, could do anything. He could play good guys, bad guys, weaklings, strong guys, working-class characters, upper-class characters. He could do anything he wanted to. I wouldn't put it as that strictly technical mastery. And I worked with John Gielgud, and he wasn't technically very accomplished. I mean, he had a wonderful voice, but that came from a profound understanding of what it was that he was saying. He believed in the text."
Mr. Wilkinson learned his trade at Britain's National Theater and the Royal Shakespeare Company, but he finds his continuing inspiration closer to home. "I think the clue to how I work is that I like watching children play," Mr. Wilkinson said. "I've watched my daughters -- I mean, they're older now, they're 13 and 10 -- but watching them during their heyday of play, which is about when they're 8 and perhaps a little bit younger than that, you see how they can immediately step into the reality of the game that they've set up and, quite unself-consciously, improvise endlessly.
"I've still got that," Mr. Wilkinson concluded. "I've retained it."

That Magic Touch
So now that "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" is old news, what's up with David Heyman, the young British producer who presciently acquired the rights to J. K. Rowling's novel before it was published?
"We've been shooting the next film for three weeks already, doing second-unit work on Harry and the flying car for 'Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets,' " Mr. Heyman said during a visit to New York last week. "The full-fledged principal photography begins on Monday."
The Monday in question was Nov. 19, the day after "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" opened over a record-breaking $93.5 million weekend. This is a new world for the soft-spoken Mr. Heyman, who worked for many years in the United States, producing action films like "Juice" and "Blind Justice" before returning to England and opening his own production company.
"I wanted to go home after being away for 17 years," he said. "And I decided to acquire some books, as a way of getting in business with people I might not otherwise be able to get in business with. People in my office knew I was looking for children's books, so Nisha Parti, my secretary, took 'Harry' home for the weekend and came in Monday morning and said: 'I read this book. I'm not sure about it, but there's something in it I quite like.' I took it home that night, began reading and read the whole book. I fell madly in love with it."
"It was about so many things -- themes of loyalty and friendship and family, about belonging and finding a family at Hogwarts that Harry had never had," Mr. Heyman said. "I thought it was really a universal piece." He optioned the rights to the first novel and has a deal to film the subsequent books in the series.
"I knew it was something special, but I would be lying if I said I knew what would happen," Mr. Heyman said. "I thought I was making a small- or medium-budgeted film, but as the book reached No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list, I knew we were on to something. Then books one and two became one and two on the best-seller list, and then when we had one, two and three on the list, that's when I really knew that it was something that had stepped beyond what I had dreamed."
The film of "Sorcerer's Stone," directed by Chris Columbus and written by Steve Kloves, has been faulted by some critics, including Elvis Mitchell of The New York Times, for staying too close to the source material, and by some audience members -- the young, hard-core Harry fans -- for not staying close enough. "It was a conscious decision to be as faithful to the book as possible," Mr. Heyman said. "The challenge was to condense what could have been a six- or seven-hour film, if it had had all the details down, to a manageable script."
"We were damned if we did and damned if we didn't," Mr. Heyman said, "but in the end, I think we would have got more criticism for departing from the book. More people would have been disgruntled if we had departed from the books than would have been disgruntled if we were too faithful."

An Editor's Education
Six Oscar-nominated film editors, including Tim Squyres ("Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon"), Carol Littleton ("E.T."), Craig McKay ("The Silence of the Lambs"), Andrew Mondshein ("The Sixth Sense"), Alan Heim ("Lenny") and the venerated Dede Allen ("Bonnie and Clyde," "Dog Day Afternoon") have been enlisted by the American Museum of the Moving Image in Queens for the inaugural program in a new master class series. Each Saturday and Sunday afternoon from Dec. 1 to Dec. 16, a different editor will be present for a screening of a representative film and an extended discussion. Also scheduled are master class series devoted to other crafts, including sound, special effects and cinematography. Information: (718) 784-0077 or www.ammi.org.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Officials Predict Upturn in Unstable South Korean Economy

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 22 

 BODY:
The volatile South Korean economy is perking up, new forecasts showed today, just as pessimists were predicting a prolonged slump aggravated by the worldwide economic downturn after the terrorist attacks in the United States.
 The country's two most influential economic officials both forecast significant economic growth next year, while the Bank of Korea said that gross domestic product for the third quarter was 1.8 percent higher than in the period a year earlier. 
 The Bank of Korea governor, Chon Chol Hwan, and the finance minister, Jin Nyum, predicted that the economy would grow by 4 percent next year amid slow recovery from this year's relatively stagnant performance. The economy for the year, according to the central bank and the finance ministry, is likely to grow 2.5 percent. 
Mr. Jin said, however, that the government would not be able to balance the budget for at least another year while battling to ensure that economic measures put in place in recent months would have more than a short-term effect.
Instead, Mr. Jin told business leaders, "it will be beneficial to allow the budget to play a role in helping expedite economic recovery rather than sticking to the original target of achieving a balanced budget in 2003." Optimism about the economy was generated by the realization that growth in the third quarter was higher than expected.
Third-quarter growth, Mr. Jin said, "was driven mostly by increases in construction and services due to government measures." The most important has been a $5 billion public works program highlighted by road and railroad building to shore up the sagging construction industry, a bulwark of economic growth ever since the Korean War.
The growth in the third quarter compared with an increase of 1.2 percent in the second quarter, when the country appeared in danger of a slump reminiscent of the economic crisis that swept the nation and the region in 1997 and 1998. The economy shrank 6.7 percent in 1998, its worst year in more than a decade, before rebounding in 1999, when it grew by 10.2 percent.
Amid signs of slipping, the economy still managed to grow by more than 8 percent last year before a reversal that played a role in the falling popularity of President Kim Dae Jung. Mr. Kim's opponents have frequently accused him of spending too much time pursuing reconciliation with North Korea while glossing over his own country's problems. 
Today, however, Mr. Kim's economic team defied the critics despite concerns about declining exports and the gloomy prospects for the electronics industry, one of the mainstays of the economy.
Chung Jung Jo, a director of the Bank of Korea, cited "strong domestic demand and construction" as "the pillars that propelled growth in the third quarter." He predicted still greater growth in the fourth quarter and full recovery by the middle of next year, in parallel with recovery in the United States.
The upturn in the economy has paralleled a surge in the stock market, which has risen more than 30 percent over the last two months, closing at 624.56 today, after having dipped below 500 earlier this year.

HEADLINE: 'Made in America,' and Never Mind the Gas Mileage 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Andrew Serkanic has been a patriot since he was 7 -- "from the first time I saw the flag," he said.
 Not that the other parents picking up their grade-schoolers at the Pines Lake School in Wayne, N.J., could doubt it. Mr. Serkanic's choices in apparel sometimes include T-shirts with Osama bin Laden's face surrounded by the words "Wanted Dead or Alive." Mr. Serkanic's business is God Bless America Meats, and he says that Kate Smith sings on the company's answering machine. And then there is his car, part ornate chariot and all political megaphone: a white Ford Explorer with gold trim, its tailgate and tinted windows emblazoned with the flag and "God Bless America." 
 "It gets 12.8 miles per gallon that I love to pay for," Mr. Serkanic said, beaming. "It's made in America, or at least half of it anyway." 
For Mr. Serkanic and many others like him in this part of North Jersey, there is no contradiction between patriotism and driving a gas guzzler. Some talk-show commentators and op-ed page writers may be connecting the dots between oil and terrorism, but few people in this area seem to have heard the idea -- and fewer still believe -- that individual Americans, by buying more fuel-efficient vehicles, can make the United States less dependent on Middle Eastern countries and others that so many of them now rage against. 
And they give little credence to the notion that the United States has earned the enmity of many Arabs and Muslims because it refrains from criticizing the corruption and human rights violations in oil-producing countries. 
"In my simple mind, this has nothing to do with oil," Mr. Serkanic said.
Indeed, there is less these days to remind Americans about the relationship between their gasoline use and global politics than at times in the past when war or the threat of war roiled the Middle East. 
The retail price of gasoline in the United States has been falling, after a steeper drop in the commodity price of crude oil. And with the Big Three automakers offering zero-percent financing on many purchases, car dealers around Wayne, like their counterparts nationwide, have been selling record numbers of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks. The country's best-selling vehicles last month -- Ford's F-Series trucks, the Chevrolet Silverado and the Ford Explorer -- on average get about 16 miles to the gallon, according to government figures. 
"Gas mileage concerns haven't been slowing sales down," said Robert Singh, sales manager at Fette Ford, on Route 46 in Clifton. "We've been selling S.U.V.'s like crazy."
At the Costco parking lot down the road, Cindy Goldstein acknowledged, laughing a bit abashedly, that her six-year-old Land Rover devours gasoline, and then she pondered where that fuel came from. "I don't know how we get it from the Middle East," she said recently, the American flag on her sport utility vehicle fluttering in the breeze like others in the lot. "I think there's some oil in Texas."
Once she heard the concept of how American dependence on oil may in a variety of ways help nurture terrorism, her laughter died off. "I never thought of it that way," Mrs. Goldstein said -- "that we should be conserving more."
Sue Smith had already heard the theories, and she dismissed them entirely. "I don't think it's unpatriotic to use so much gas," Ms. Smith said, loading her silver Chevy Tahoe with groceries. "It's very patriotic. It's our way of life."
And what of the consideration that the American way of life means that a country with less than 5 percent of the world's population uses 25 percent of the world's crude oil? "Why should we cut back?" Ms. Smith, 40, asked. "We're an affluent society. Should I hate my neighbor because she has a better house, a better car, more money?" 
Though a smaller percentage of United States oil imports come from the Persian Gulf region than 30 years ago, the nation imports more of its oil than it ever has, leaving it vulnerable to sharp swings in prices.
For Ms. Smith and many others here, the answer to that vulnerability is not reducing demand or developing alternative fuels, but drilling at home. (Few people realize that the United States has only 3 percent of the world's proven oil reserves.) "We should go on living the way we're living," Ms. Smith said. "And we should think about the wacko environmental groups that are forcing us to get oil someplace else."
In the gathering twilight, at the park-and-ride lot on Route 46, Robert Boesch, 64, a textile designer, walks to his Chevrolet Blazer after returning on the bus from work in New York. Mr. Boesch is aware of how dependent the United States is on foreign oil, but he has no plans to change his driving habits or to stop leasing sport utility vehicles, as he has for eight years. 
"We don't have an alternative right now," Mr. Boesch maintained, "and I don't see our government jumping to the fore on this issue."
That may change. Senate Democrats are drafting an energy bill that would call for increasing the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks; the Ford Motor Company has pledged a 25 percent improvement in the fuel efficiency of its sport utility vehicles by 2005, and both General Motors and Chrysler have promised to match Ford. 
S.U.V. owners, especially women, say they picked their vehicles because they make them feel safer. But when pushed a bit, most say that they simply love being in huge vehicles that make them feel powerful on the road. 
Sheila King, 27, a teacher from Clifton, came one evening to look at what she called "a big monster" sport utility at the McGuire Auto Group on Route 46 in neighboring Little Falls. "It's as much about road rage as anything else," Ms. King said. "You don't want others to do more damage to you than you can do to them."
Ryan McGuire, the dealership's general manager, was not enthusiastic about having a reporter discuss gasoline mileage with his customers. "Because that will get them thinking about it," he said, "and we don't want that."
But relatively few people in this area seem to be thinking about gas mileage, and the circumstances that would prompt Americans to opt for more fuel-efficient vehicles have not yet shaken the country.
"What would get people to stop driving S.U.V.'s?" Ms. Smith said earlier in the day. "If God came down from heaven and said, 'You can't drive S.U.V.'s anymore.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Serkanic in Wayne, N.J., with his vehicle of choice and tattoo. He and others doubt that buying a fuel-efficient vehicle would make the United States less dependent on foreign oil exporters. (Emile Wamsteker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Europe Stocks Rise, Nudged by Oil and Telecommunications 

BYLINE:  Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 22 

 BODY:
European share prices inched up today, propelled by telecommunications and oil companies in tepid trading reflecting the closure of Wall Street for Thanksgiving Day.
 In the 12-nation euro zone the Euro Stoxx-50 index was up 1.07 percent, to 3,769.9. 
 In London, the FTSE-100 index gained 32.1 points, or 0.61 percent, to 5,345.9. 
The CAC 40 index in Paris also finished stronger, adding 0.96 percent, to reach 4,599.80 points, while in Frankfurt the DAX index gained 0.74 percent, to finish at 5,124.54.
Investors on the London exchange appeared unmoved by third-quarter data showing that the British economy expanded at a rate of 0.5 percent compared with the similar period in 2000 and was up 2.1 percent for the year.
The results were slightly weaker than initial estimates for the quarter.
The market was sustained by telecommunications and later in the day by the petroleum sector after an announcement by Norway that it was prepared to trim production by up to 200,000 barrels a day if other crude producers did likewise.
BP rose 2.1 percent, or 11 pence, to 535.5 while Royal Dutch/Shell gained 0.91 percent, or 4.5 pence, to reach 497.
Among telecommuncations issues, Vodafone added 1.8 percent, or 3.35 pence, to finish at 184.5. Cable and Wireless was also up 2.03 percent, or 8 pence, to 357.
In Paris, technology and telecommunications were the star performers. France Telecom bounced back from a loss on Wednesday to gain 2.37 percent to end the session at 46.60 euros.
Cap Gemini rose 2.77 percent, to 76 euros while Vivendi Universal gained 2.34 percent to finish at 59 euros.
In Frankfurt, investors were confronted with contrasting pictures of the German economy. While growth turned slightly negative in the third quarter, inflation was reported to be well in check.
Trading on Asia's major stock exchanges was cautious, with sentiment affected by holidays in the United States and Japan.
Among the region's main indexes, Tokyo, Hong Kong and Seoul made gains while Sydney, Singapore and Taipei fell in mostly lackluster trading with investors sidelined amid the holidays. Tokyo will be closed for its own public holiday Friday.
The Nikkei average of 225 leading issues on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed up 35.74 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,696.82.
Hong Kong stocks rose 0.7 percent on the back of technical gains in China Mobile and China Unicom, but sentiment was also cautious.
The Hang Seng index gained 79.38 points, to 11,253.30.
Ross Cheung, an analyst with Tanrich Securities, said market turnover dropped substantially as many investors were sidelined ahead of the American holiday.
Bolstered by a technical rebound, China Mobile and China Unicom provided the major support to the Hang Seng index, dealers said. The two mainland mobile operators had dropped substantially over the last two days on concerns over the possible entry of a third mobile phone operator in the mainland market.
The Australian market fell 0.3 percent, with the All Ordinaries index down 10.1 points to 3,262.40, while the SP/ASX 200 dropped 12.1 points, to 3,324.20.
Singapore share prices closed 1 percent lower.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Thai Oil Stock Offering Is Much in Demand

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Nov. 22 

 BODY:
Despite analysts' expectations, foreign interest is strong in the initial public offering of Thailand's oil and gas company, reviving hopes that the country's long-stalled privatization program is back on track and that investors may be returning to Southeast Asia.
 On Wednesday, Thailand sold about one-third of the state oil and gas company PTT, raising 32.2 billion baht, or about $725 million. Analysts had expected that foreign investors would give PTT a wide berth, but orders from abroad far exceeded the shares PTT had allotted for foreigners. When the stock begins trading on the Bangkok exchange on Dec. 6, investors from Europe, the United States and elsewhere in Asia will own 12 percent of PTT, one of Thailand's largest companies. 
 For the better part of two years, investors have shied away from the Southeast Asian region, deeming it risky because of political instability and the sluggish pace of economic change. The global slowdown has worsened the trend.
But evidence is mounting that foreign investors are slowly regaining their appetite for bargains in emerging markets as uncertain results on their home markets leave them seeking higher returns elsewhere.
"Two percent just doesn't cut it when you're used to 10," said Deborah Schuler, senior analyst at Moody's Asia Pacific in Singapore. "You're willing to take more risk to get more return." That is welcome news for Southeast Asian governments, which plan to sell more assets as they try to spend their way out of an economic slowdown that has crippled exports.
Privatization in Thailand was part of the terms of a $17 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund in the Asian financial crisis that began in 1997. Economists and the I.M.F. have urged such sales in countries like Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines as a way to invigorate private business, rekindle investor interest and replenish government funds.
Thaksin Shinawatra, the telecommunications tycoon who became prime minister in February, has pledged to push privatization forward to reduce the government's debt and budget deficit. But as share sales failed to materialize and antiforeign measures proliferated, foreign investors came to question Mr. Thaksin's sincerity. Some said that Thailand, like Indonesia, was giving in to nationalism and vested interests that opposed selling stakes to foreigners at a discount.
Last month, for example, the Thais enacted a law limiting foreign shareholdings in their telecommunications companies to 25 percent. So far this year, foreign investors have pulled 2.75 billion baht, or $61.9 million, out of the Thai stock market.
Though PTT's offering price was far below what the government had hoped for, the sale could represent a turning point, analysts said. "It shows that they're serious about their privatization program," said Kenneth Ng of ING Barings in Bangkok, "and that they're not fiddling around just because the price isn't there."
To be sure, the latest foreign investment is a trickle compared with the flood of money into the region before the financial crisis. And foreigners so far seem to be selecting only the most conservative investments.
Part of their return is based on world politics. Southeast Asia is home to a large part of the world's Muslims. Some investors are betting that recent pledges of aid from Washington to Indonesia and the Philippines are signs that President Bush is unwilling to allow economic instability to feed anti-American religious sentiment.
And with interest rates worldwide generally lower, international investors are searching for higher returns. That, analysts say, has helped drive up prices in recent weeks for dollar-denominated Southeast Asian government bonds, which offer relatively higher yields as well as the region's lowest risk. Government-linked companies are also benefiting from the trend. Singapore Telecommunications and Singapore Airlines, both of which list the government among their largest shareholders, were able to sell more than $2.8 billion in bonds this month amid foreign interest that took underwriters by surprise.
Similarly, bankers say, demand has proved strong for Indonesia's stake in one of its largest banks, Bank Central Asia. Largely relieved by the government of the bad debts that plague many Southeast Asian banks, Bank Central Asia now earns money not from lending but by using its low-interest-bearing deposits to invest in higher-yielding government bonds. Its stock, therefore, is the next best thing to a government-guaranteed bond, bankers say.
Not all foreign fund managers are ready to jump back into Southeast Asia.
"They still have severe corporate governance problems," said J. Mark Mobius, president of the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund. Templeton chose not to invest in PTT's stock offering, he said.
So did OUB Asset Management of Singapore, according to William Cheng, a fund manager. Even after the share sale, Mr. Cheng said, PTT remains heavily indebted and faces potential problems at several subsidiaries. "The internal capital allocations are still a little bit murky to us," he said, "and the Thai government has strong interference into the company's management."
PTT said its executives had allayed concerns among foreign buyers about transparency and the role of the government, which still owns about two-thirds of the company.
To some investors, PTT also presented a conservative move into stocks. The company, which changed its name in September from the Petroleum Authority of Thailand, said it would use part of the share sale proceeds to repay its debt.
PTT also has a secure source of profits: along with oil exploration, petrochemicals and retail fuel sales, it has a monopoly on the transmission of natural gas, Thailand's largest source of fuel for electricity. Most of its gas contracts lock in profits for up to 30 years.
PTT's shares were also priced to move, analysts said. At 35 baht, PTT shares offer a dividend yield of 6 percent, making them more lucrative now than interest on Thai bank deposits.
That, the analysts said, helped explain why local investors lined up for hours last week to apply for shares. Analysts say slumping Asian stock prices have turned up similarly high dividend yields that are likely to attract domestic savers seeking better returns.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
German Economy Shrinks, Edging Closer to Recession
Germany moved closer to a recession, and may already be in one, because new statistics show that its economy, Europe's biggest, contracted slightly in the third quarter.
 Though the contraction was only 0.1 percent, it was worse than German officials had predicted, and the news is already sending out shock waves across the rest of Europe. While Germany's economy was officially flat in the second quarter, it actually declined 0.03 percent. A recession is usually defined as at least two quarters in which the national output of goods and services contracts. Page C2. 

South Korea's economy is perking up, new forecasts showed, just as pessimists were predicting a prolonged slump. C2.

Drug Venture Using Cows Hits Snag
On a farm near Madison, Wis., are cows that have been genetically engineered to produce pharmaceuticals in their milk. Some biotechnology executives think such animals may be the pharmaceutical factories of the future. But the cows face an uncertain fate because the company that created them, Pharming Group, has filed for protection from creditors. C5.

Crude Oil Rises on Potential Cuts
Crude oil jumped more than 6 percent and neared $20 a barrel after Norway said that it would cut output and Russian oil executives signaled that they would also lower supply if ordered to by the government. C3.

ABB Chairman Hints at Revamping
A day after the chairman of ABB, Europe's largest electrical engineering group, resigned unexpectedly, his successor, Jurgen Dormann, acknowledged that the company had lost "the credibility of the market" after a series of reorganizations failed to prevent a drastic slide in its share price or produce profits. Mr. Dormann also urged a review of the company's activities to "focus on a smaller number of businesses and make them grow." C2.

Thai Offering Draws Strong Interest
Despite analysts' expectations, foreign interest is strong in the initial public offering of Thailand's oil and gas company, PTT, reviving hopes that the country's long-stalled privatization program is back on track and that investors may be returning to Southeast Asia. C3.

Japanese Banks Post Weak Results
Two of Japan's largest banks -- UFJ Holdings and Sumitomo Trust and Banking -- reported bleak earnings for the first half of the fiscal year as sinking stock prices and mounting nonperforming loans pummeled their balance sheets and forced them to announce further restructuring plans. C3.

Financial Markets to Close Early
Most United States financial markets, which were closed in observance of Thanksgiving, will reopen today for abbreviated sessions. The stock markets will close at 1 p.m., and the bond market will close at 2 p.m.

HEADLINE: Since Attack, More Landlord-Tenant Clashes Downtown 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
Tensions between landlords and tenants of buildings close to ground zero in downtown Manhattan have led to more rent strikes and threatened evictions in the last week, with several cases to go to mediation in Housing Court over the next month.
 Angered by what they say are lagging cleanup efforts and inadequate rent reductions and rent credits after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, hundreds of tenants have organized themselves and decided to withhold rent from landlords. 
 "You have to understand the level of upset here," said Sudhir Jain, an information technology consultant and representative for his fellow tenants at 50 Battery Place, where he said about 60 of 200 tenants are withholding rent. "We've all gone through a traumatic event. Now to go through the court system with legal proceedings -- it's adding another layer to everything that's happened and it's like a slap in the face." 
The first case to go to Housing Court mediation will deal with apartment buildings at 32 Pearl Street and 88 Greenwich Street. Some tenants in each building have been withholding rent for two months, said their lawyer, Jack Lester. The case is scheduled to be heard on Thursday. 
Housing Court mediations are not binding, "but the emphasis is to resolve disputes," Mr. Lester said. "From a practical standpoint, the fact that we have a mediation conference scheduled may set a framework for settlement, which may obviate the need for litigation in other buildings." 
Tenants' complaints focus on cleanup and air quality as well as transportation and shopping difficulties since the attack. 
The tenants who have organized themselves at 32 Pearl Street are typical of unsatisfied tenants downtown. They say they want to be compensated for hardships that resulted from the Sept. 11 attack or have the option to leave without penalty. 
The landlords of 32 Pearl Street have offered a 10 percent rent reduction for the term of the lease. They also offered tenants with medical concerns or children under 19 the option of breaking a lease on 30 days' notice without penalty. Everyone else is required to give 60 days' notice and would have to forfeit their security deposit, said Richard Breton, one of the owners of 32 Pearl Street.
"We're struggling to deal ethically and humanely with our tenants, but we're constrained by the economic factors of operating our buildings," Mr. Breton said. "We're trying to help the tenants and work with them, but they can't expect landlords to provide 100 percent of the relief they seek. We know they're suffering and feel depressed." 
Katherine Mogg, president of the tenants' association at 32 Pearl Street, said about 60 percent of the tenants in the 21-unit building are on a rent strike. (Most of the units are two-bedroom apartments and rents average $3,200.) 
"We're dealing with fairly major adjustments to our lifestyle," Ms. Mogg said, citing the dearth of transportation and shopping options. "The landlords' response was quite disappointing." 
Ms. Mogg said that for weeks after Sept. 11 the tenants found it impossible to communicate with the building's management. Eventually, they organized and wrote the landlords a letter outlining their complaints about failures to clean up and monitor air quality, and the absence of rent credits and reductions.
From the landlords' point of view, the tenants' letter was a "laundry list of demands" about a building that is a quarter-mile from the disaster site, and one not badly damaged in the attacks. 
"We've been one of the least affected buildings," Mr. Breton said. "We didn't lose utilities or phone service and were not required to close by any government office." He said he was surprised that the tenants rejected his offer and decided to go on a rent strike.
The level of discontent and disagreement between landlords and tenants seems to be spreading. The number of buildings where tenants are staging rent strikes has grown from two in Battery Park City to at least seven in downtown neighborhoods. 
At 88 Greenwich Street, the tenants' association president, Kate Webber-Pitcock, said the building was "full of people who've never not paid a bill in their lives, and who are loath to withhold money." She added, "It is symbolic of how difficult it is to live here that these people would do something like this." 
But landlords say they are struggling just to pay operating costs and other expenses, which have not declined since Sept. 11.
"We would like to reach an amicable settlement with our tenants," said Kevin Singleton, the senior vice president of Rockrose Development, which owns two buildings in Battery Park City where tenants are withholding rent. "But their demands in our view have to be consistent with the marketplace." 
Mr. Lester said he was optimistic because he believed that the Housing Court hearings offer "an excellent opportunity to mediate settlements." 
Mr. Lester said he hoped that a framework would come out of the proceedings that would create a precedent for other tenants living near ground zero.

HEADLINE: Survey of Small Businesses Finds Outlook Gloomy 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 22 

 BODY:
Owners of small businesses in New Jersey are more pessimistic about their prospects for the coming year than they have been in any year since the early 1990's, according to survey results by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. But their gloom is not nearly as deep as it was a decade ago.
 About two-thirds of the 1,600 small-business owners who participated in the association's 43rd annual Business Outlook Survey said their industries had entered a recession or were heading into one, twice as many as said so last year. According to results released this week, almost half of those surveyed said they expected New Jersey's economy to worsen in the first half of 2002, twice as many as those who said last year that they expected a weaker economy at the beginning of 2001. 
 Joe Gonzalez, the association's president, said owners' collective projections for sales, profits and employment had reached their lowest levels since New Jersey emerged from the recession of the early 90's.
Still, he said, things do not appear as bleak as they were back then.
"The pessimism expressed in our survey can at best be characterized as moderate," Mr. Gonzalez said. "Even though these are not good times, in comparison with the early 90's, these are golden days."
Eighty-three percent of those who responded to the survey in 1990 said they thought New Jersey's economy would weaken in the first half of 1991, twice as many as those who said this year that they expected a worse economy. And 62 percent in 1990 said they thought their own industries would weaken, compared with 33 percent this year.
The association sent the survey to its 17,000 members on Sept. 5 and tabulated its results from the first 1,600 responses, almost all from owners of businesses with fewer than 100 employees. There were no statistical differences between the responses the association received before and after the terror attacks, Mr. Gonzalez said.
"The outlook is grounded in disappointing business conditions that preceded the horrible events of Sept. 11," he said.
Philip Kirschner, the association's executive vice president, said most respondents named health insurance costs as the biggest problem they face in the coming year, followed by property taxes.

HEADLINE: Albany Slow to Divide Millions for Charities 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 22 

 BODY:
A month after the State Legislature voted to distribute about $200 million among scores of charities that provide social services, lawmakers have still not decided how to divide the money, and some organizations have been forced to lay off workers in the meantime.
 The Legislature's slowness to act has sown chaos among the many nonprofit groups that provide everything from lawyers for indigent families facing eviction, to counseling for people dying of AIDS, to treatment for drug addicts. 
 The Haitian Women's Program, a social services center in a storefront in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is typical of the small charities struggling with a steep drop in state support this year.
The director, Gabrielle Kersaint, said that on Oct. 31 she finally had no choice but to lay off a social worker who helps people dying of AIDS make arrangements for their children because the state had not renewed the $100,000 annual grant for the program. Two other experienced social workers moved on to other jobs, she said, because they feared their positions would disappear. 
"This kind of craziness really destabilizes a small agency," Ms. Kersaint said. "It does anger me, because we were already struggling and now it's even worse and there is no guarantee the money will be restored."
Assembly and Senate leaders say they are bogged down in a tedious and politically charged game of triage. The Legislature normally distributes $300 million to $500 million in grants to charities across the state. But this year, lawmakers faced a fiscal crisis and a governor determined to cut costs in the wake of the September terror attack and a slumping economy. In the end, they appropriated only $200 million for the charities, and said each house would decide how to spend half of it.
"It's like trying to squeeze a watermelon into an acorn," said Charles Carrier, a spokesman for the Assembly's Democratic majority.
Instead of giving each member a certain sum, the leaders asked lawmakers in both houses to submit lists of their favorite programs, and the leaders are trying to determine which are most deserving of help. Under the budget agreement hammered out last month, Gov. George E. Pataki is required to approve their choices before money is released. 
The winnowing has proved difficult, lawmakers say. To begin with, Mr. Pataki left dozens of programs for the poor out of his January budget proposal on the assumption that Assembly Democrats would want to restore them and would, therefore, give him something in trade. 
But the political winds shifted after Sept. 11, and with a fiscal crisis looming, the governor refused to restore any of the Democrats' pet programs. 
As a result, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, is seeking to use some of the $100 million under his control to keep alive programs intended to fight AIDS, prevent domestic violence, provide legal services to the poor and house the mentally retarded, among other things.
At the same time, Assembly members have asked Mr. Silver for their usual wish list of projects in their districts -- known as "member items" -- which are of immense political importance and in recent years have cost upward of $170 million. The staff of the Ways and Means Committee has been wading through that roster, trying to single out indispensable services with no other financing. 
The Ways and Means chairman, Herman D. Farrell Jr., said his staff was pressing charity directors to find out how long they can stay in business with the least amount of state help. "It's triage," he said. "It will look like it has no pattern, but the pattern will be based on how can we spread that $100 million to keep them for another day."
On the Senate side, the Republican majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County, has given more control over his $100 million to his fellow Republicans, aides said. Each senator has been given a spending cap and has been asked to submit recommendations to Mr. Bruno, who said he intended to sift through them and make a final cut. 
"It has to be scrutinized even more carefully this year," said a spokeswoman for Senator Bruno, Marcia White. "We have to be very careful. It's difficult to make a determination about who's needy and who's not needy."
When the $200 million was appropriated, Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver said the bill would lay out strict criteria for charities to be financed, limiting them to those that provide "direct human services or emergency relief services." 
But the final version of the bill broadened the criteria to encompass any program financed the previous year that might have to lay off workers if it did not get money again this year. Some critics say the watered-down language opened a loophole to let less critical programs, like youth sports leagues, get a piece of the pie.
The selection process is also murky, lobbyists for social service agencies complain. The decisions are being made without public hearings.
Lobbyists say that because of the late budget, many charitable groups were already running on fumes before Sept. 11. Some have already trimmed staffs, making it harder for them to resurrect services if they do receive money.
"The question is how many programs will close in this interim period while they decide who to fund," said Ron Deutsch, the executive director of the Statewide Emergency Network for Social and Economic Security, which represents hundreds of social service agencies. "It's not like a water faucet. You can't just turn it off and turn it on."
Groups providing legal services have been particularly hard hit. For instance, Legal Services for New York City, which receives money from both the federal and state governments to represent the poor in court in cases involving domestic violence, welfare eligibility, tenant-landlord disputes and Social Security benefits, had been scheduled to get $3.5 million from Albany this year but has received nothing so far.
It has laid off 21 lawyers and paralegal workers in the last week, most of them in Brooklyn. An additional four lawyers quit in anticipation of being laid off, said Ghita Schwarz, the president of the union representing the legal staff. It has closed its office in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Another office has stopped representing people in housing court.
"It's a horrible loss," Ms. Schwarz said. "New York's poor didn't vanish when the twin towers collapsed. For many of these people, their economic circumstances worsened."

HEADLINE: Adapting To a World Less Ready For a Party 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
Deborah Williamson and Mary Wible left special event and public relations jobs at Conde Nast Publications almost two years ago, using cash investments from friends to start a small business planning parties in Manhattan.
 It was risky, to say the least. "There have been lots of scary moments," Ms. Wible said. 
 The bet more than paid off. Their business, Swell Productions, opened a four-person office in a loft on Franklin Street in TriBeCa. They were able to make an operating profit within eight months, pay back some of their investors and watch the business continue to grow even as the economy began to slump earlier this year.
But recently, Ms. Williamson and Ms. Wible have had more of those scary feelings. The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the economic slowdown have hurt corporate and individual entertainment budgets, causing people to postpone, tone down and in some cases cancel extravagant and expensive parties. 
And the attacks added another troubling element to the equation for a party: figuring out the appropriate colors, decorations and hors d'oeuvres has become as complicated of late as drumming up new business.
"To say that we are not worried would not be honest," Ms. Wible says now. "There is no one in this business that is not worried. I think in this industry, in every industry, it is a troublesome time for everybody. Our world has really changed."
In many ways, Swell Productions' situation is similar to that of other party planners, catering companies, florists and others in the business of facilitating fun. 
A recent survey by a group called the Meeting Professionals International Foundation concluded that the business of parties was at a 10-year low in Manhattan, although the group acknowledged that this was an estimate based on anecdotal information. The foundation, an industry trade group, was formed after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center with the help of NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors' bureau, and the ailing events and meetings industries.
"The threat is to the smaller businesses in our industry, the balloon blowers, the florists and other small companies," said Richard Aaron, the president of BizBash, a Manhattan consulting company for event planners and other companies involved in the party business. "They are the ones that can be put out of business when shows get canceled."
BizBash officials, too, say there are no hard numbers for how much the cancellation of parties has contributed to the tens of thousands of layoffs in the restaurant, catering, hotel and planning businesses. The attack has taken hundreds of millions of dollars already this year from a $4 billion industry when meeting, party and convention planners; catering companies; and sites are included, according to BizBash. 
Among the companies that Swell works closely with, several people have been laid off and business has slowed down.
At one of those companies, Avi Adler Design, a floral and decor outfit in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, the two partners have made big cuts in their own salaries, laid off 2 of their 10 employees, sold storage space across the street and instructed workers to make fewer calls on their cellular telephones and not to take toll bridges and tunnels into Manhattan.
In the week after the attack, at least four shows the firm was designing floral arrangements and decorations for were canceled, including a large party for the clothing designer Hugo Boss that was supposed to take place in an empty loftlike space within the cavernous Starrett-Lehigh Building on West 26th Street. 
"It was really weird during the first few weeks, not just the financial end of it," said Avi Adler, one of the two partners. "The trucks were loaded up and ready to go, and all of a sudden there were no parties. People wanted to just stay home." 
Mr. Adler, a former painter, gives the example of a Glamour magazine "Woman of the Year" event for which his company handled the decorations and Swell handled planning. The event, which was postponed after the attack and then rescheduled for Oct. 29 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, turned out to be decidedly less glamorous than had originally been planned.
"After Sept. 11, when we realized the event was taking place, we totally changed our original concept of coloring everything," Mr. Adler said. "Originally, it was going to be sexy. The main color was going to be red. And eventually it became very beautiful and soft white and cream tulips and roses and orchids, and the lighting was very soft."
The Glamour party also added patriotic themes. Several women, including those struggling to expand women's rights in Afghanistan, were honored. 
Even caterers -- like Tentation, a French company that handled the Glamour event -- have also adapted. The company has had to cut back on its temporary workers and is using "comfort" foods, including miniature hamburgers, macaroni and cheese, hearty winter stews and "I Love NY" cookies.
"People are much more careful and are keeping in mind what is in good taste," said Martha McGuinness, a Tentation spokeswoman. "They don't want to do things that are garish or frivolous." 
It is hard to tell when or how this business will begin to rebound, but there are some positive signs. At least Ms. Wible and Ms. Williamson are optimistic.
On the morning of Sept. 11, Ms. Wible had a full calendar for the next two weeks. That night they were coordinating a Conde Nast Traveler party at a chic French restaurant for the magazine company's all-star issue and a new book by the photographer Brigitte Lacombe. On Sept. 12, they were supposed to handle a private 100th-anniversary celebration for House & Garden magazine at Sotheby's. During the next week, they had Gourmet magazine's 16th-anniversary party at the Whitney Museum and the Yahoo Internet Life Magazine at the Hammerstein Ballroom.
Hours after Ms. Wible watched the second plane slam into the south tower as she walked to work on West Broadway, the calendar was empty. 
Conde Nast Traveler canceled its event and gave the money it had planned to spend to a relief fund. Yahoo Internet Life has not been able to find a date that will accommodate the celebrity singers and bands that were supposed to appear. And House & Garden has not figured out what to do.
But one bright spot came recently for Ms. Wible and Ms. Williamson. Gourmet decided to reschedule its party for December.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a slowdown in the Manhattan party planning business misstated the anniversary being observed by Gourmet magazine, which postponed a party. It was the 60th anniversary, not the 16th.

NATO Urges Equal Voice For Russia on Some Issues
NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, proposed to give Russia equal status with the alliance's 19 permanent members in devising and executing some policies, a change that would bring Moscow into the center of NATO deliberations on terrorism and other issues. The proposal implies that Russia would have veto power over certain alliance decisions, he said. A1

Five Palestinian boys were killed on their way to school when an explosive detonated beneath them at the crest of a sand dune in the Gaza Strip, near an Israeli settlement. Palestinians said the boys, all related, were killed by a tank shell lingering from recent fighting in the area, but Israelis said that a Palestinian explosive might be to blame. A3

Prime Minister Tony Blair, less than six weeks before much of continental Europe adopts the new notes and coins of the euro single currency, is pressing his compatriots to jettison their traditional skepticism toward European integration and see it instead as an opportunity to extend their nation's influence.
