HEADLINE: Medellin Journal; 
A Coffee Icon Rides His Mule Off Into the Sunset

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: MEDELLIN, Colombia 

 BODY:
Carlos Sanchez saw it coming. Nevertheless, he still had a lump in his throat when, just a few days ago, he received the news: Juan Valdez, the tradition-bound coffee farmer Mr. Sanchez has played in countless American commercials, would soon be shelved. 
 One of advertising's most successful fictional characters, Juan Valdez -- the mustachioed farmer, a poncho over his shoulder and trusty mule at his side -- helped make Colombian coffee world famous. But with coffee prices plummeting to a 30-year low, the Colombian growers group that bankrolled the advertising has been forced to slash its costs. 
 "I still did not think that things would turn out like this," lamented Mr. Sanchez, 66, who has been playing Juan Valdez since 1969. "I thought maybe I would get too old, or I would be replaced, or something."
But for Colombian coffee growers and millions of consumers worldwide is there any replacing the actor or the icon? In the world of marketing, Juan Valdez is considered one of the most successful pitchmen ever -- on par with Mr. Whipple and the Pillsbury Doughboy. Awareness of Juan Valdez in the United States stood at 60 percent last year, with logo identification of Cafe de Colombia reaching 85 percent, ahead of Nike and Michelin. 
Yet Juan Valdez -- unlike those marketing icons -- is a real person: Mr. Sanchez, the second man to play the role, once grew coffee himself but has dedicated most of his life to painting and raising a family.
Youthful for his age, Mr. Sanchez is described by those who have worked with him as the perfect spokesman: patient, diligent, loyal and never too tired to don his farmer's hat and coffee pouch for commercials or to shake hands at sporting events.
"There are few live spokespersons who have had such an endurance," said Peter le Comte, president of DDB Worldwide Marketing, the New York advertising agency that dreamed up Juan Valdez. "There's not many that are like him and are real, that are an actual embodiment of an individual." 
While Juan Valdez has clearly helped sell Colombian coffee -- the advertising meant a $1.6 billion premium for growers in the 1990's -- perhaps his biggest contribution has been to counter the image of Colombia, battered by more than 30 years of guerrilla insurgency, as a cocaine-infested battlefield. 
"I presented the image of the Colombian coffee grower, an honest man, hard-working, traditional," explained Mr. Sanchez, sitting on the porch of his home in Medellin, as a hummingbird buzzed about. "Juan Valdez would get up early, pick coffee, and what happened in time is the character became mythologized."
Despite the icon's success, the crisis in coffee prices brought on by a worldwide oversupply of beans has forced the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia, which markets Colombian coffee, to cut its free-spending ways.
The 73-year-old federation has responded by slashing its work force by 60 percent to 1,500 employees in the last decade, shedding ownership of a bank, and cutting subsidies that built schools and paved roads in coffee-growing regions.
With assets falling to $739 million last year from $1.6 billion in 1997, the federation also ended costly price subsidies to farmers. But the most visible cuts are to advertising, especially abroad, where Juan Valdez has successfully hawked Colombian coffee since 1959. 
Indeed, at Harvard University, first-year marketing students study Juan Valdez, not only because he is an advertising success but also because he made tangible contributions to Colombia's economy, said Rohit Deshpande, a professor of marketing at the Business School.
"This is not just a story about how you get a better price at Safeway," Mr. Deshpande said. "It's an even bigger story about what this means to the people who grow the product."
Created by a Madison Avenue advertising man at Doyle Dane Bernbach -- DDB's forerunner -- Juan Valdez was first used to educate Americans about the origins of Colombian coffee. So early ads showed Juan Valdez, with his mule, crisscrossing fog-shrouded mountains, picking the "richest coffee in the world," as a narrator explained. 
The advertising strategy later showed Colombian coffee drinkers as discerning consumers, so a plane would turn around in midflight after the crew realized the Colombian coffee had been forgotten. The Colombian coffee logo -- Juan Valdez and his mule -- would then appear.
With American coffee consumption falling to 54 percent from 77 percent in 1950, more recent print advertisements pitched Colombian coffee to the young, with Juan Valdez shown hang-gliding or surfing. The commercials' slogan was, "take life by the beans."
In all, the federation spent more than $1.3 billion on advertising in 41 years. But annual spending has dropped from $44 million in 1987 to $16 million last year. This year, $5 million will be spent, just enough to cover contractual obligations.
Carlos Sanchez, as Juan Valdez, will still go to sporting events sponsored by the federation, but big-ticket advertising will largely dry up.
Advertising experts agree that Colombian coffee's competitiveness will be hurt, since consumers increasingly have a potpourri of high-grade coffees to choose from. 
"They lose the essence of the campaign, which creates meaning for the brand," said Mr. Deshpande, the Harvard professor.
Federation officials said they realize the danger. "The publicity is wonderful, and it produces a premium, but if there is no money, how do we pay?" said Andres Lloreda, the federation's publicity director.
For Mr. Sanchez, the development means more time at home with his wife of 43 years, Alma, and two grandchildren. Still, he is rueful.
"Juan Valdez is an integral part of Carlos Sanchez," he explained. "So if Juan Valdez ceases to exist, well, naturally it is like losing a limb."

Mr. Sanchez, above, at home with a granddaughter, Maria Jose, was once a farmer himself. In a spot from the 1990's, left, he was a hard-working farmer with a hat, pouch and trusty mule. HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Art Exhibition to Help Holiday Appeal

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN CARROLL 

 BODY:
These are tough times for many, including charities. The economy is contracting and Wall Street is in a slump, shrinking potential donations. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates 10 times this year, whittling away at the interest income crucial to charities with endowments. In addition, some charities fear, the public's spirited reaction to the terror attacks on Sept. 11 could divert attention from enduring problems. These are tougher times for those in need of help in New York City. Last month, 79,000 jobs disappeared. Next month, 32,800 families will reach the five-year federal limit for cash welfare assistance. They can still receive money for rent and utilities through the state, but must reapply. 
 "There's plenty of hardship at any time, but now -- we're just holding our breath," said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 In recent years, good times and fat wallets have fueled donations to the fund, as readers respond to articles that appear daily in The Times during the fund's annual holiday appeal.
For the first time in the fund's history, a party will be held to draw attention to its efforts, Mr. Rosenthal said. In mid-January, the foundation will be the host of an exhibition in a Manhattan gallery where a dozen works -- by artists including Francesco Clemente, Chuck Close, Roy Lichtenstein, William Kentridge and Nam Joon Paik -- have been donated by the artists or their estates.
The total amount raised so far this year, about $2.4 million, is down roughly $500,000 from last year. Mr. Rosenthal attributed $350,000 of that difference to a decline in interest income. Still, 22 days into the fund's 90th appeal, donations are filling Post Office Box 5193. 
Readers all over the country responded in great numbers to an article in The Times on Nov. 4 about Robert Tucker, a 60-year-old homeless man who struggles to fit a night of sleep into a long subway ride. Many of his meals are supplied by Project FIND, which last December received a $10,000 grant to provide lunches to elderly people from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund. 
Jane Clair Ellison of Oakland, Calif., sent a check for $50 and wrote, "I am retired, in my mid-60's, single and consider myself very fortunate to have a pension, health care and a home. Granted, my family and circumstances allowed me to prosper, which was not the case with Mr. Tucker. I am mindful, though, that life can play rough with one, and we all could be in trouble."
Hong-Ngoc Nguyen Pham of Silverdale, Wash., donated $30 and wrote, "I was very troubled by Mr. Tucker's story. With the tears I shed, I realized that many people in desperate need are all too often ignored. I hope that what little I can give will provide these individuals with a little more comfort, care and peace." 
Todd Anderson of Washington, D.C., sent a heartfelt letter along with his $10 donation. "I lost my job as a project manager for a high-tech company in May 2001 and ever since then have been struggling to make ends meet," he wrote. "Through either dumb luck or an unwillingness to give up, I've been able to keep my head above water. I felt moved to send a check to help out Robert Tucker and others in situations similar to his. Plus, given my current situation, I'm scared to death that one day, I'll be like Robert Tucker."
Sherry Greenberg of Austin, Tex., gave $200. Her letter read: "I hope The Times will continue to help people understand how important it is to continue to acknowledge the people before 9/11 and after that struggle to live in the city with some attempts at dignity. I hope this helps."

HEADLINE: Facing Decreased Demand for Coins, Mint Starts Layoffs 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
The United States Mint is laying off workers because the softening economy has sharply reduced demand for new coins.
 Mint officials say they will make only 15 billion new pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters next year, instead of the 23 billion they had planned just last summer. 
 As a result, a spokesman said, the mint has begun laying off 357 workers nationwide, including at major coin-production plants in Philadelphia and Denver. 
"When people are spending less money, there's less transactions out there," the spokesman, Michael White, said.
The drop in demand for new coins is staggering, said James Benfield, executive director of the Coin Coalition, a Washington lobbying group that supports the dollar coin.
Mr. Benfield and others speculate that the glut is being compounded by the return of many coins to circulation after months or years on dresser tops and in shoe boxes.
But a spokeswoman for Coinstar, a company that operates 9,300 coin-changing machines in supermarkets, said the company was not seeing an increase in use of its machines.
The machines count a shopper's coins and exchange them, minus a service charge, for cash or groceries. Coinstar estimated that Americans have $7.7 billion in spare change at their homes.
For the mint, lower production means lower profits because it charges the Federal Reserve for the full face value of a coin, though it costs less to manufacture.
For example, it costs 4.5 cents to make a quarter, but the mint charges 25 cents. The mint sends the balance to the United States Treasury to pay for other government operations. But when demand drops, the mint has to cut costs just like a private company, leading to layoffs.
The mint, which also has operations in San Francisco; West Point, N.Y.; and Washington, plans to eliminate about 12 percent of its 2,861 employees.
Coins for Eastern states are made in Philadelphia; coins for the West are made in Denver.

HEADLINE: Mexico to Ignore A Trade Ruling 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
The Mexican government said today that it would ignore a World Trade Organization ruling to lift duties on high fructose corn syrup, turning instead to the North American Free Trade Agreement to protect sugar producers. 
 A World Trade Organization panel ruled last month that Mexico broke trade laws by imposing tariffs of up to $176 a ton on corn syrup imports from United States companies like Archer Daniels Midland and Cargill. 
The panel said Mexico had not proved sufficient damage to local producers or shown how much the imports damaged local sugar producers. 
 By not lifting the duties, Mexico lays itself open to United States reprisals under the rules of the trade organization. However, Mexico is betting that the United States, its top trading partner, will allow it to use NAFTA rules to set new tariffs and to leave the current ones in place. 
The United States took the case to the W.T.O. after Mexico set the tariffs in 1998.

HEADLINE: Delta Town's Hopes Are as Scarce as Inmates 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: TUTWILER, Miss., Nov. 21 

 BODY:
With all the jobs it promised upon opening less than two years ago, the $35 million Tallahatchie County Correctional Facility seemed the salvation of the flat and tattered Mississippi Delta town of Tutwiler, population 1,364. But the prison, encircled by cotton fields and shimmering coils of razor wire, has left the town little better off than it ever was.
 "Everybody thought it was going to help business," said Janie S. Downs, who is 82 and runs a gas station less than a mile away from the prison. "It didn't help anything." 
 Like hundreds of rural communities that have lost factories, farm jobs and population, Tutwiler, about 70 miles south of Memphis, looked for salvation in a prison. The one here can hold 1,104 medium-security inmates and employ 300 workers. These days, though, the prison houses 20 to 125 khaki-clothed men and women.
The concrete one- and two-story prison opened in April 2000 with 351 inmates -- all but 29 from Wisconsin -- and 208 workers. That is as far as it got.
In March and April this year, Wisconsin moved its inmates to prisons closer to home, leaving few inmates and a work force of 40. 
"How proud they were to have the facility in Tutwiler, to see their family working and have a trade so they could earn a good living," said Don Grant, warden of a prison 35 miles down Highway 49 in Greenwood and owned, like the one here, by the Corrections Corporation of America.
When the Wisconsin inmates left, said Sister Maureen Delaney, a Roman Catholic nun who manages a social services organization in town, "people said, 'We can't even keep a prison.' They said it in a joking manner, but there was pain in it, too." 
Tutwiler sits in the core of the Delta, one of the poorest parts of America. Built while a get-tough-on-crime philosophy led to inmate overcrowding and a construction boom, the prison here has fallen prey to developments that have stalled the growth in the numbers of men and women locked up in state and federal cells.
For eight years the nation's crime rate has declined. And as budgets tighten, many states are questioning the cost of incarceration -- like the $40 a day Wisconsin paid for each of its inmates here -- and the utility of locking up nonviolent offenders. After doubling in a decade, the number of state and federal prisoners steadied last year at about 1.4 million.
In recent months, at least seven states have postponed construction and openings of prisons. Michigan has closed one. Ohio, facing a budget deficit and a drop in the number of inmates to 44,700 from 49,000 in 1999, is "looking at the feasibility of closing one or two facilities," said a spokeswoman for the Ohio Department of Corrections.
Some prisons run by private companies are especially exposed. The Corrections Corporation, which owns or manages 70 prisons, closed one in Youngstown, Ohio, that it opened only three years ago after losing the inmate contract from the District of Columbia. The company has stopped construction of a nearly completed prison in Lumpkin, Ga., while another in McRae, Ga., has stood empty for more than a year.
Tutwiler, with a population that is 87 percent black, has roots in cotton and song. In 1903, W. C. Handy is said to have first heard the music he proclaimed the blues at the town's former railroad depot. "An unknown musician was singing while sliding a knife blade down the strings of his guitar," the inscription on a mural there reads. Aleck Miller, a harmonica player also known as Sonny Boy Williamson, is buried here. At his grave visitors have left harmonicas and a bottle of Canadian whiskey.
Except for cotton, there has never been much to Tutwiler's economy. People drive an hour to work in poultry and chicken processing plants for less than $7 an hour, or they work casinos in Tunica, an hour to the north, or at other Delta prisons. Tutwiler's mayor, Robert Grayson, is a guard at the state penitentiary in Parchman. 
Tutwiler has no drugstores, clothing stores or restaurants. Its grain elevator and bank closed last year. Rumors abound that the cotton gin at the edge of town will be next. 
Much of what sustains Tutwiler, where all the churches are Protestant, are the health and community services run by its seven sisters -- Catholic nuns -- and their staff.
The sisters maintain Aleck Miller's grave. They provide the site for town meetings and voting. A sister from Washington, Anne Brooks, is the area's only physician and director of the town's thriving health clinic. Sister Delaney, from California, directs outreach programs for children and the elderly. This month the sisters opened a gymnasium worthy of a university and paid for by faraway donors. 
With little beyond charity to keep Tutwiler afloat, community leaders chose three years ago to accept a prison. "We were sort of scraping the bottom of the barrel," said Otey Sherman, president of the county's Industrial Development Authority.
The city built a new water tower and sewage lagoon; the state and county agreed to pay half the cost of training prison guards. 
Then came the cuts. "People quit jobs somewhere else, got trained, started working for C.C.A. and then got laid off," Mr. Sherman said.
With three children at home, Elizabeth Martin, 31, had been unwilling to apply for the few jobs she could find because they were so far away. Last year, she got work as a prison guard. It paid $8.23 an hour, a good wage in the Delta. Her job was watching the grounds. "I went around in a truck with a gun," she said. Let go in April, she is still unemployed. 
Inside, the prison is a precision machine of motorized gates, surveillance cameras and control booths. With classrooms, a medical center and a six-hoop basketball gym, "it's a warden's dream," said Neva Yarbrough, the warden.
But entire cell blocks stand empty. The library has no books, the classrooms no chairs. Construction of the baseball field has been halted. 
The prison still helps the economy. It pays Tutwiler $5,350 a month for water and pays the county $600,000 a year in property taxes. But the payroll -- the money workers can spend -- has dropped to $80,000 a month from $467,000. 
The Corrections Corporation says it is beating the bushes for inmates. "Everybody is working to obtain a contract," Warden Yarbrough said. "We're going to get a contract." 
She had better be right, said Joseph Smith, president of the Tallahatchie County Ministerial Alliance, an association of Baptist ministers. "The only future we have," he said, "is getting that prison system open."

HEADLINE: Pataki Paints By Numbers To Create Dim Picture 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has tried hard in recent days to paint a spectacularly bleak fiscal picture for New York State, saying that because of the Sept. 11 attack the state faces the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.
 The governor and his top aides have repeated over and over that state tax revenues dropped off $1.3 billion from July through September, a 15 percent decline from the same quarter last year and the steepest quarterly decline since the 1960's, and that the loss in revenue this year and next could total $9 billion. The budget director, Carole E. Stone, said the damage to state revenues was "of a magnitude never before seen in this state." 
 But a review of the actual receipts and expenditures recorded in the state comptroller's office show that Mr. Pataki has exaggerated the problem somewhat. 
Over all, tax collections for the first seven months of the fiscal year are down about 2 percent, or $430 million, compared with last year. And since the governor let many city taxpayers postpone their September payments in light of the attack, it will not become clear until mid-December just how much revenue the state actually lost last quarter.
The governor, a Republican, might be forgiven a bit of hyperbole, for there is not only considerable truth in what he is saying, but a political strategy in saying it loudly and often.
Mr. Pataki, after all, is entering an election year, and how he publicly presents and politically tackles the economic crisis could be vital to his success.
For Mr. Pataki and the state, even flat revenue growth will mean politically unpopular cutbacks. But by painting an extremely dire picture, Mr. Pataki is setting himself up to play the role of the tough fiscal conservative riding to the state's rescue in a time of crisis. He could insulate himself somewhat from Democratic charges that he is in part to blame for the crisis because of his handling of budget negotiations.
The budget deal Mr. Pataki eventually negotiated with legislative leaders after the attack did not hold the line on spending, despite some reductions in service. It allowed a rise of about $4.4 billion, or 5.6 percent growth, to $84.3 billion. At the same time, Mr. Pataki's budget analysts now predict general state tax revenues will drop at least $2 billion from the $42 billion collected last year, a contention even the most sanguine Democrats say is quite possible.
That means that if spending from the state's general fund were to grow at the present rate, Mr. Pataki would have to deal with a shortfall of at least $4.3 billion in the next budget.
To make matters worse, Mr. Pataki's appeal to Congress to give him some money to offset state tax losses has apparently fallen on deaf ears.
The $9 billion in federal disaster aid Washington has already approved for New York will likely be earmarked for cleaning up and repairing the devastation in Lower Manhattan.
After his request received a cool reception in Washington last month, Mr. Pataki outlined a series of cutbacks to save about $1 billion over the next 18 months -- a hiring freeze, a buyout for senior state employees and refinancing some debt. He has also asked his department heads to come up with $2 billion more in savings, but those measures have yet to be spelled out.
Perhaps most distressing for the Pataki administration, however, is the loss of the annual surplus. Because of the previously booming economy and the administration's conservative revenue estimates, the governor has ended each of the last three years with a sizable cushion of unspent money. 
But budget officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said they feared that this year Mr. Pataki would have to spend most of theavailable $3.5 billion surplus to make up for the expected $2 billion drop in state tax revenues. That means Mr. Pataki, in his next budget, will have to close a multibillion-dollar gap with little or no surplus.
This is an executive's election-year nightmare. Because of built-in inflation in salaries, medical costs and school aid, the budget will grow on its own unless it is pruned.
Mr. Pataki's budget officials base their dire predictions on several factors. For starters, the national economy has ceased to grow and is now shrinking. In New York, several independent forecasts have suggested that the city will eventually lose about 100,000 jobs because of the terrorist attack.
So far, about 60,000 jobs have disappeared statewide between Sept. 1 and Oct. 31, the State Labor Department reports. New unemployment claims are up to about 25,000 a week, from about 12,000 a week before Sept. 11. The state cannot expect much from Wall Street either. The main securities industry trade group is now projecting that year-end bonuses for stock and bond traders will drop between 50 percent and 60 percent, which would translate into about $1 billion less in tax revenues than the state collected last year.
Capital gains on stock and bond trades are also expected to drop about 35 percent in the current bear market, according to the Congressional Budget Office and the United States Treasury. Capital gains accounted for about $60 billion in taxable income for the state last year. Finally, business taxes on Wall Street firms and taxes on tourists and hotels are expected to drop off markedly.
Even if these predictions turn out to be too pessimistic, Mr. Pataki faces politically difficult decisions in his budget for next year. The two biggest state expenses are for Medicaid and aid to local school districts, neither one of which a politician wants to cut just before an election.
His Democratic opponents for governor, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Andrew Cuomo, the former secretary of Housing and Urban Development, have already attacked the governor for the current year's spending plan. They have faulted him for a lack of "leadership," which in Albany means a subtle combination of arm-twisting, threats and deal-making to get one's way.
After six months of impasse and delay, the Democrats complain, the governor finally negotiated with legislative leaders a flawed budget that grew at twice the rate of inflation but still cut $150 million for environmental programs, added too little to school aid and shortchanged hundreds of charities that provide social services. This at a time when the reeling economy is impoverishing more people, putting more strain on the social safety net.
"This budget keeps the state running, but that's all," Mr. McCall said this week. "The bottom line is the budget was seven months late, acted on in the middle of the night with no public input, and fails to address the state's pressing needs, many of which have worsened in the wake of Sept. 11."
For his part, Mr. Pataki maintains that it was the stubborn refusal of Democrats in control of the Assembly to accept his economic predictions that produced the current budget. His aides like to point out that had Mr. Pataki given in to the demands of Assembly Democrats in April for $1.7 billion in additional school aid, the current budget would have grown even more and the cuts he would now have to make would be deeper. In addition, they say, had Mr. Pataki not built up the $3.5 billion surplus over the years, the state would be slashing programs now.
Finessing the fiscal disaster, then, will likely tax Mr. Pataki's formidable political skills. The key for the governor is to convince voters that the terror attacks and not his management are to blame for the crisis and to trumpet the idea that things could be worse had he not been so prudent for the last seven years.

HEADLINE: For Holiday Shoppers, Sale Is the Only Thing 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Lured by sales and discounts, consumers kicked off the holiday shopping season and ventured to stores yesterday in most parts of the country with rekindled appetites. The potentially sparkling start to the season was dulled, however, by sluggish sales in the nation's shopping capital, New York, and by fear that consumer interest could be sustained only with profit-demolishing prices. 
 Post-Thanksgiving giveaways are now part of the holiday landscape. But this year retailers came into the season scared, and discounts are both widespread and deep. Roughly 15 percent more merchandise in stores is marked down than last year, according to John D. Morris, a retail analyst for Gerard Klauer Mattison, who keeps a sales rack index. 
 Economists and merchants alike are watching closely to see if American consumers will help pull the economy out of recession. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's domestic output, and the holiday season is when consumers spend the most and have the greatest effect on economic growth. 
Though stores around the country were full yesterday, shoppers seemed focused on the ubiquitous sales, and many said they planned to spend less this year than last. 
Even those whose shopping bags were full seemed to strike a note of restraint. "We're trying to tone it down a little," said Barbara Ruane, of Annandale, N.J., who was buying a white hooded sweater for her daughter Megan, 18, at the Bridgewater Commons mall in Somerset County. This year, Mrs. Ruane said, she is buying only "things on sale and only things that everyone needs, nothing frivolous." 
Some who braved the lines before dawn said they were motivated by patriotism. "I want to go shopping to help the economy," said Steve Wood, 29, a sales representative from Colbert, Ga., who already had a shopping cart of toys at 6:15 a.m. at the Toys "R" Us store in Athens, Ga., including an Easy Bake Oven marked down to $9.99 from $19.99,
Still, most consumers were there because they sensed a deal. Judy Bannister of Boston's South End said she usually avoided stores on the day after Thanksgiving, but she could not resist an offer she saw on full-size comforters: $20 each. Yesterday she walked out of Macy's in Boston with four of them.
Edward Osgood, 49, of Bourne, Mass., who was waiting for his wife outside the same store, thought the bargains were so good that he felt compelled to point them out to passers-by. "Look, you pay a quarter, and you get $10," he said, pointing to a $10 off coupon for Macy's in a local newspaper. "I've got two of them."
The day after Thanksgiving is known as Black Friday because it is the start of the season that usually moves retailers from the red into the black. So it is a widely monitored gauge of the health of the retail industry in this make-or-break season. 
Predictions for holiday sales tended to be on the grim side. Some of the most optimistic predictions came from the National Retail Federation, which said apparel and general merchandise purchases -- everything from furniture to music CD's -- would increase as much as 3 percent. Others were decidedly less ebullient. The annual retail survey by American Express, for example, found that consumers planned to spend 7 percent less than last year.
In recent weeks, American consumers have received a lot of help in the pocketbook department. Fuel prices have dropped, low mortgage rates on houses have touched off a wave of refinancing, and the last of the federal tax rebate checks arrived. The question now is whether such gains will offset consumers' fears of layoffs.
"The customer has the means. What we are watching now is do they have the will," said Carl Steidtmann, chief economist at Deloitte Research, who remains pessimistic.
Certainly the state of the economy was on the minds of many shoppers yesterday. 
Anne Miller, 32, an occupational therapist and mother of two from Littleton, Colo., said that although she was not directly affected by layoffs, she was concerned about her husband's job in construction. "I was a little more reserved this year," she said. "I know what my limits are."
The obsession with the economy is not good news for New York, which is known for indulging the world's most cosmopolitan and well-heeled shoppers rather than the most cost-conscious. The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 have devastated tourism, the source of much retail spending in the city, and layoffs on Wall Street are dampening the enthusiasm of other affluent shoppers.
The city's troubles are bad news for already embattled department store chains like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's, whose fortunes depend heavily on sales at their Manhattan stores.
There were markdowns in New York, of course. At Bloomingdale's, large rectangular red and black banners hanging from the ceiling announced savings of 20 to 50 percent throughout the store. Brooks Brothers, near Rockefeller Center, had an offer: buy one shirt and get a second one 40 percent off. At Kenneth Cole, customers were given 30 percent off and more on selected items -- a creamy brown leather jacket, normally $460, was reduced to $299.90. Still, the hordes of shoppers were nowhere to be found. 
"The New York business is really difficult," Michael Gould, the chief executive of Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores, said with a sigh. "You still have the problem of the tourists not coming."
Denise Rivera, a Kenneth Cole sales associate, agreed. "This time last year I wouldn't have been able to talk to you," she told a reporter.
Kristy Lamont, 23, who was shepherding guests from out of town who had come in for the shopping, noted, "The city seems dead." 
If the department stores were taking it on the chin, discount stores were clearly benefiting in the cost-sensitive environment. The discounters were hot even in September, when most other retailers' sales were decimated in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, and the discounters were still hot yesterday.
Although the big discount chains will not post sales numbers until Monday, their stores were full early yesterday as shoppers searched for toys like this year's holy grail, a Harry Potter Hogwarts castle, or electronics like the Olympus C-300 digital camera.
"The day started with a bang, and it continues to go strong," said Tom Williams, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Stores, which usually sells well in excess of $1 billion in merchandise the day after Thanksgiving alone.
In Florida, crowds even stood in the rain before dawn waiting for Target stores to open. "We've had big crowds lined up around the block everywhere," said Douglas Kline, a spokesman for Target, where, he said, shoppers were stuffing their baskets with traditional toys like Monopoly and Nutcracker Barbie.
Traffic has been down sharply at many malls this fall as shoppers stayed away in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. But for some shoppers, the desire for bargains trumped their fear of terrorism. Renee and Dan Stanton drove about 30 minutes to shop at the Park Meadows Mall in suburban Denver. Mrs. Stanton, who is five months pregnant, said she did have some anxiety about being in a mall.
"I thought, the day after Thanksgiving is so busy, it would be a day they would probably do something," she said. "But then I thought, 'What are they going to do, bomb every single mall in the world?' "
She added: "So I'll shop, but I won't fly."
The question in the remaining weeks of the holiday shopping season is whether the markdowns will entice people to put aside worries about the economy and spend more than last year.
Cindy Hayes, 34, from Englewood, Colo., who was at a Best Buy store outside Denver to pick up children's software for $3.99 and music CD's for $7.99, is emblematic of the challenge. "I'm hitting the sales in order to spend less," she said.

HEADLINE: The Arbiters Of Recession Stand Ready 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
It's almost official: the economy is in recession, ending the longest uninterrupted expansion in American history.
 The official dating of the recession, the 10th since World War II, is expected to come as early as Monday from the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., long considered the arbiter of economic contractions and expansions. 
 The six members of the recession-dating committee discussed the issue in a conference call yesterday. The economists on the committee agreed not to talk about the decision, but an announcement is scheduled for Monday and a few now say that they think the economy is in a recession. They had indicated earlier that the most likely starting date for the recession is March. 
"My personal opinion is that a recession has begun," Jeffrey Frankel, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, said after the conference call. But he declined to say when he thought the recession had started or what the committee had decided.
But even before yesterday's discussion, some new economic data, including a surge in October retail sales and a decline in initial jobless claims, had led a number of forecasters to predict recently that the recession would be relatively mild and less severe than they thought earlier. This shift in attitude has helped push interest rates higher, as many investors are now behaving as if the Federal Reserve will soon stop cutting short-term interest rates so aggressively.
At the same time, stocks have rallied in anticipation of a recovery. The Dow Jones industrial average is up nearly 21 percent since its post-attack low on Sept. 21, while the Nasdaq composite index has jumped 33.7 percent since its low.
Still, many economists are convinced that the economy may remain bogged down for a while and that any recovery might also be relatively modest.
"There is some weakness left to come," said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He expects a 3.5 percent decline in the economy in this quarter, much sharper than the consensus view.
Americans have not experienced a single full quarter of contraction in the total economy since early in 1993, and then the dip was just 0.1 percent. The last recession, as the research bureau defines it, ended in March 1991 after starting in July 1990.
The official announcement of the latest recession will come as no surprise. Before the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, many economists already thought the economy was in a recession or on the verge of one. The attack and its aftermath made that opinion nearly unanimous.
The committee is expected to date the beginning of the recession as far back as March of this year, when the growth in employment, one of the research bureau's four main economic indicators, peaked. If that is the date, then the record expansion lasted almost exactly 10 years. If this recession ends in the second quarter of next year, which many economists are forecasting, then it will last about a year, average for recessions since the end of World War II.
The dating of recessions is always done cautiously. The research bureau's Business Cycle Dating Committee, as it is known, usually waits until it has at least six months of data beyond what the committee determines to be the onset of a recession. The dating of the start of the last recession was announced on April 25, 1991, more than a month after the recession was already over.
As a simple rule of thumb, many people define a recession as two quarters of consecutive decline in the gross domestic product. While not official, that rule has proved to be a pretty good barometer.
Based on the latest G.D.P. data, the economy fell in the July-to-September quarter at an annual rate of 0.4 percent. In the spring quarter, economic output grew at an annual rate of 0.3 percent, while in the first quarter, which ran from January to March, the economy grew at a 1.3 percent rate.
On average, economists polled by Bloomberg News expect the economy to contract at a rate of 0.8 percent in the current quarter.
The dating committee does not look at G.D.P. data because those data are quarterly, subject to major revisions, and because it dates recessions by the month. The four main indicators the panel considers are employment; personal income, minus government transfer payments like welfare; industrial production; and manufacturing and trade sales.
Before yesterday's meeting, the committee had indicated in its most recent analysis of current conditions that only personal income was still rising. Its other main indicators for determining a recession had already experienced declines similar to those in past recessions.
"The data continue to show substantial declines in real activity in manufacturing, the sector reflected in the industrial production index and in real manufacturing and trade sales," the committee said in a report on Nov. 9. "Aggregate employment has fallen substantially, as well, by about two-thirds of the amount typical of earlier recessions. Among the four indicators, only income has behaved differently from recession averages over the past seven months."
But in the end, Mr. Frankel noted, it all comes down to the collective judgment of the committee.
"There is no firm rule," he said.

HEADLINE: Parents Say Proposal for College-Preparatory School on Upper East Side Falls Short 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
A group of Upper East Side parents who have been fighting for a college-preparatory high school in their neighborhood say the Board of Education is offering them a watered-down version they cannot accept, a high school that would have a weak curriculum and be open to students from outside the neighborhood. 
 The parents want a high school that would serve students who plan to go to college but who cannot get into New York City's examination-based high schools, and one that would be a natural transition from the neighborhood's elementary and middle schools, which have been rejuvenated in recent years. 
 Now, just as the Board of Education is to vote -- on Wednesday members have to approve a lease for the building, a former Sotheby's warehouse on East 76th Street -- the parents are urging board members to reject the school in its current form. 
They say their vision has been stolen away by board officials who believe a high school with strict neighborhood boundaries and a rigorous academic curriculum would be elitist and exclude minority students, since the Upper East Side is predominantly white. 
"We got used," said Jeanne Kassler, one of the leaders of the high school movement, called Partnership for an Upper East Side High School. "Nobody is willing to understand the underlying issues." 
She said the school proposal, as it now stands, calls for a curriculum in which students would study a small number of subjects in depth and be judged by portfolios of work. 
"I want to hear calculus, Latin, economics, I want a broad traditional curriculum," Ms. Kassler said. 
Students could apply for admission from all over District 2, which runs from the Upper East Side to the Battery and includes parts of the West Side, including TriBeCa and Chelsea. 
But Shelley Harwayne, superintendent of District 2, which would run the school, said the curriculum was still flexible and would be decided by parents, teachers and the principal. 
The school is expected to have about 500 students. Ms. Kassler said she calculated that it would admit only about eight students a year from the three Upper East Side ZIP codes. 
"I guess I'm just sick of the idea of being called 'elitist,' " Ms. Kassler said. "What am I trying to do, keep out TriBeCa? Keep out Chinatown? These are kids who are certainly matched in terms of demographics." 
"I want them to vote the school down," she added. 
At the same time, however, there is a split in the ranks of the parents, with some parents who previously supported the idea of an Upper East Side school now saying it would be a mistake to turn down the chance to start a new school, even if it served more than one neighborhood.
Clara Hemphill, an Upper East Side parent, sent a letter to the board pointing out that District 2 already runs other high schools with districtwide admissions. 
"I believe it would be unfair to permit Upper East Side children to apply to all schools in the district," Ms. Hemphill said, "while refusing to permit children from Chinatown, TriBeCa and Chelsea to apply to a new Upper East Side School." 
Ninfa Segarra, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that Wednesday's vote concerns only the lease, not the educational or zoning plans, which must be approved at a later date. 
If the Board of Education votes against the lease, she said, the school could lose the building and could also lose a special capital budget allocation from the City Council and the mayor, to support the school. 
But Ms. Segarra said that she was sympathetic to the parents' complaints, and that she hoped the board and Chancellor Harold O. Levy would reconsider the curriculum and zoning of the school if the lease is approved. 
"I contend that when you have parents fight this hard to get the school, you try to make whatever adjustments are appropriate, " Ms. Segarra said. 
"I think it's a good thing that middle-class families wanted to create a public school and keep their kids in public school. 
"We did it in Riverdale," she said, "and we've done it in other parts of the city. The broader the base of support for the school system, the better." 
Ms. Segarra said it was predictable that District 2 would favor a school with a progressive curriculum that admits students from the entire district, because that is the way many of its schools are structured. 
One alternative to the current districtwide zoning, she said, would be for the Board of Education to take over the administration of the school. 
Anthony Shorris, a deputy chancellor, said yesterday that the discussion of zoning was premature, and that the important thing was to secure a lease for the building. If the lease is not approved, he said, the whole issue would become moot.

HEADLINE: Hard Times in Borough of Airports; 
As Airlines Cut Back, Queens Loses Jobs and Business

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
John Dupre, a mechanic for United Airlines, moved out of his apartment in Queens this month after his job at Kennedy International Airport was eliminated. The airline was transferring him to Indianapolis, and he said he had no choice but to go, leaving behind his friends and his favorite haunts on Metropolitan Avenue.
 "If I don't take Indianapolis, which I don't want, that means I'll get laid off," he said. 
 Mr. Dupre's departure has left his five roommates in Kew Gardens, flight attendants who have already lost two other roommates to airline layoffs, scrambling for replacements and doubting they can afford next month's rent. 
He is leaving a neighborhood that traditionally housed so many airline workers it was nicknamed "Crew Gardens," and where pizza parlors, dry cleaners and pubs may lose hundreds of customers by the time the airline industry completes a huge round of layoffs.
It is a story that can be heard in almost every corner of the borough as the industry's economic troubles, brought on by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, ripple through Queens, home to two airports that are a major source of employment and are crucial to large corporations and tiny businesses alike.
The plane crash in Queens last week may chase away even more passengers. Economists and airline industry experts say, however, that it is too early to tell whether the crash, of American Airlines Flight 587 in Belle Harbor, will hurt the borough's job market the way the terrorist attacks have.
The job losses in the airline industry itself are expected to have a staggering effect on the borough, where more than 41,000 people work for airlines or other businesses at La Guardia and Kennedy Airports. Queens may lose 5,000 to 8,000 jobs because of cutbacks by the major airlines, according to the latest estimates. 
But those figures do not reflect the full impact of the airline industry's economic crisis on Queens. 
In addition to those 41,000 jobs -- most of them held by Queens residents -- there are 20,000 jobs in businesses that depend on air travel, like aviation fuel companies, travel agencies and parking lots. 
For every 1,000 air transport jobs lost in Queens, 470 in those related industries will go, too, according to the Queens County Overall Economic Development Corporation, which has been tracking the impact of the World Trade Center disaster on the borough's economy. 
That does not count the losses expected in still other industries that do travel-related business, like hotels and caterers for in-flight meals, which are expected to eliminate hundreds of jobs by the end of the year, according to recent estimates.
Food-service companies based in Queens that make meals for the airlines have already laid off 600 workers since Sept. 11, according to an analysis by the Fiscal Policy Institute, partly because meals have been cut from many domestic flights. The institute, a nonprofit research organization, also said that hotels were expected to eliminate 240 jobs by the end of the year.
"The whole outline has changed," said Marie S. Nahikian, the executive director of the Queens economic development group. "The ripple effect is going to be significant." 
In East Elmhurst, the Luggage Doctor Repair Center, a small business that repairs suitcases damaged by the airlines, has only half as many bags to mend.
Over in Flushing, Chocolates Unlimited lost a lucrative monthly order from a major airline company for employee gift baskets filled with chocolate-covered pretzels and caramels.
Miles away in Kew Gardens, the pizza shops that once delivered pies galore to pilots and flight attendants are taking hardly any calls from apartments -- known as "crash pads" -- that were once crammed with airline employees. Kew Gardens lies halfway between Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, and many airline employees share rental apartments there to be close to the airports they report to, even if they also live in other cities with their families. 
"It's been very bad," said Mike Bosco, the owner of Casa Bosco, a pizzeria on Metropolitan Avenue in Kew Gardens. "A lot of my customers from the airlines have been coming in to say goodbye, at least 20 in the last few weeks, and those were just the ones who said something."
While the air transport sector ranks fourth as an employer of Queens residents after retail, health care and manufacturing, no other industry in the borough is suffering losses as great as the airline sector's, economists and labor experts say.
The situation is the worst for businesses in the neighborhoods closest to the airports and most dependent on air travel.
The airline industry has announced reductions so far that would eliminate as many as 100,000 jobs nationwide.
The precise impact on Queens is still unknown because many of the layoffs are still coming, but officials with the New York State Department of Labor said this month that up to 8,000 air transport jobs could be lost in New York City, almost all of them in Queens.
Based on a survey of the airlines and labor unions, the Fiscal Policy Institute estimated that 5,000 air transport jobs in Queens would be eliminated by the end of this year.
Another study released this month, by the Center for an Urban Future, a public policy group, examined the impact of the airline industry's troubles on businesses like parking lots and in-flight caterers, and reported steep losses for many of them. 
The experience of Jim Sparro, the owner of Air Park, which operates two parking lots, one near Kennedy and the other near La Guardia, is typical for many of those businesses, according to the center's report and interviews with dozens of business owners across the borough. 
Mr. Sparro, who said he had parked 150 cars at each of his lots before Sept. 11, said he was now parking an average of 65 cars a day and had to apply for a small-business loan to pay his bills and stay open. He said that he had laid off 10 of his 30 employees and that the others were working an average of one day fewer a week. 
"We're pretty much taking it on the chin," Mr. Sparro said. He added that although business nearly disappeared altogether in the two weeks after the attacks, he had expected it to bounce back by now. 
Juan Carlos Lopez, who runs the Luggage Doctor with his father in East Elmhurst, near La Guardia, said that business was brisk before Sept. 11 and that the two were planning to double the size of their operation and move it near Kennedy.
"It was working well. We even had plans to move out and expand a little," said Mr. Lopez, who opened the business two years ago. "But everything had to stop, and we're just going to see what happens."

HEADLINE: With Ban Loosened, Some Small Aircraft Return to Manhattan Skies 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Helicopters and small airplanes, banned from flying over New York City since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, are once again taking to the local skies, case by case. 
 After weeks of public complaints by business owners, the Federal Aviation Administration in recent weeks began granting waivers to its ban on small aircraft, including helicopters, from flying closer to the city than 18 nautical miles. A helicopter charter company said the ban was costing it hundreds of thousands of dollars in lost revenue. News agencies complained that it restricted their ability to cover stories. 
 Earlier in the week, a WABC-TV helicopter flew over parts of Manhattan, and on Thursday and again yesterday WPIX-TV had its copter in the air to tape the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade and deliver live traffic reports.
A spokeswoman for the F.A.A.'s eastern region, Arlene Salac, would not say why the agency began issuing the waivers.
The F.A.A.'s new guidelines call for flight towers within 18 nautical miles of Manhattan to track all aircraft by radar, Ms. Salac said. Most small carriers are licensed under so-called visual flight rules, which have patterns that are not tracked easily by radar. Under the regulations, which will remain in place indefinitely, pilots on small carriers are issued special radar codes so that air traffic controllers in the towers can identify them. The codes tell the name of the pilot and the destination. 
Small aircraft may not hover over bridges or traffic jams like in the past. 
Officials of Liberty Helicopters, one of the city's largest aerial tour companies, said that before it was granted a waiver about two weeks ago, business had fallen about 90 percent, forcing them to lay off an undisclosed number of workers. 
Although news of the waivers was greeted with relief by those whose businesses were hurt by the ban, there also appeared to be some confusion about the F.A.A. policy. Some flights face tighter restrictions than others.
A helicopter cameraman, Al Cerullo, who captures images of the Manhattan skyline for major films -- including "Six Degrees of Separation," "Armageddon" and "The Siege" -- said that he had lost about $200,000 in business. He added that he was not certain just what the waiver, which he learned about this week, would mean.
"I've made some calls," said Mr. Cerullo, who had not received clarification as of late yesterday. "I have a lot of questions, but it's hard to get answers. I am happy to have the waiver, although September and October are usually my busiest times of the year. It's always crisp and clean. It's always the nicest time to shoot. You don't have a lot of haze, and the city really looks golden, especially in the early morning and just when it's turning dark."
While helicopter tour companies and aerial filmmakers complain about the economic impact of the ban, news organizations had another complaint: restrictions on freedom of speech. 
"The F.A.A. severely restricted news reporting," said Barbara Cochran, president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association in Washington. "We're not sure if they were able to see that, but we are really glad to be back in the air, if even on a limited basis."
The news helicopter for WPIX-Channel 11 covered the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday. The crew was so excited that members wore costumes. Robert C. Wilson, the cameraman, dressed as a turkey; Melinda Murphy, the reporter, dressed as a pilgrim; and Ray Rivera, the pilot, dressed as a Native American.
"It was like coming back to your house after you've been away for the summer," Mr. Wilson said.
While news helicopters just received waivers to fly, some tour companies received them several weeks ago, but they cannot fly directly over Manhattan, especially ground zero. They must show the city sites from the New Jersey side, said Alvin S. Trenk, president and chief executive of Liberty Helicopters, which operates from the 30th Street heliport. He said that his company used to conduct 100 tours a day before the attack. Now, he said, he is lucky if he conducts 10 or 12, and the tours are not even over the city. The average tour costs about $80 for up to 12 minutes.
The regulations have also had a major impact on Fortune 500 companies. Executives who used to be able to take a company helicopter across town at a moment's notice must now file flight plans. "We are hopeful that we can wait this out," said Matthew S. Zaccaro, a special advisor and past president of the Eastern Region Helicopter Council, a trade organization representing about 100 companies. "If there was ever a time when companies needed to use their aircraft, this is it."
Mr. Cerullo is not the only one in the film industry who is feeling the pinch. Even before the attack, the city had been whipsawed by a paucity of film production, because of the threat of a strike by Hollywood writers earlier this year. Although the writers settled before the strike deadline, most of the film production occurred in the city before June. 
Patricia Reed Scott, commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theatre, and Broadcasting, said she did not expect the city to reach the $2.5 billion the local film industry has earned annually in the past four years. But she does hope to see some major films come to the city early next year.
"We've looked into the pipeline and it looks good," Ms. Scott said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEGAL FRONT; 
SPAIN SETS HURDLE FOR EXTRADITIONS

BYLINE:  By SAM DILLON with DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: MADRID, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
Spain will not extradite the eight men it has charged with complicity in the Sept. 11 attacks unless the United States agrees that they would be tried by a civilian court and not by the military tribunals envisioned by President Bush, Spanish officials said today.
 The officials said the United States was informed this week of the Spanish stance, and several experts predicted today that other countries in the 15-nation European Union would balk at handing prisoners over to the Americans without similar guarantees. 
 Mr. Bush's announcement that the United States could use emergency military courts in terrorism cases has stirred criticism in Europe, and the arrests last week in Spain of eight Islamic extremists could provide an early test of foreign cooperation with the administration.
"Military trials would be the worst of all possible worlds if you wanted to get people back from Europe," said Geoffrey Robertson, a British human rights lawyer. 
A senior European Union official who asked not to be identified said he doubted that any of the 15 nations -- all of which have renounced the death penalty and signed the European Convention on Human Rights -- would agree to extradition that involved the possibility of a military trial.
In Washington, a senior law enforcement official described the development today as "a setback." But the official said investigators were hopeful that Spanish investigators would share with the Americans any information about the eight Islamic extremists' dealings with the suspected ringleader of the Sept. 11 hijackings, Mohamed Atta.
Government officials and legal scholars interviewed today in London, Berlin, Paris and other European capitals cited a series of objections to the American tribunals that the president's Nov. 13 order would allow for foreigners charged with terrorism. The objections include the secret nature of the hearings, suspects' inability to choose their defense lawyers, and the potential bias of the United States officers who would sit as judges. 
The use of hearsay evidence, which would be allowed in the tribunals under Mr. Bush's order, would not trouble some European nations, but would raise hurdles in the United Kingdom and Ireland, where it is forbidden, the senior European Union official said.
"In Europe, we're very suspicious of special courts," said Marie Elisabeth Cartier, a professor of criminal justice at the University of Paris. "Everybody stands behind the U.S., and we understand that these events are exceptional. But we'd rather have normal procedure, one that is not military."
The United States has not yet lodged an extradition request. But a Spanish investigative judge, Baltasar Garzon, formally accused the eight Muslim defendants last Sunday of helping to prepare the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. 
If American law enforcement officials determine that the evidence backs Judge Garzon's accusations, the defendants would be subject to prosecution under American law.
In a meeting here on Wednesday between senior Spanish prosecutors and American diplomats, including a representative of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the prosecutors warned that any future American extradition request would run into trouble because a military tribunal would not meet European standards for judicial proceedings, one of the prosecutors said today in an interview.
"No country in Europe could extradite detainees to the United States if there were any chance they would be put before these military tribunals," said the prosecutor, who is helping to coordinate the criminal procedures against the eight men, whom prosecutors believe to be associates of Osama bin Laden.
A spokesman for Spain's Foreign Ministry confirmed the prosecutor's account today, saying Spain could extradite detainees only to countries that offer defendants the legal guarantees provided by Spanish courts.
"And if we're talking about a tribunal in the United States with summary procedures and military judges, then these are not the same conditions that would characterize a trial in Spain or France or England or anywhere else in Europe," the Foreign Ministry spokesman said. "Extradition would be impossible."
The law enforcement official in Washington said that Mr. Atta was believed to have made two visits to Spain this year, and that Washington was eager to know more about those trips.
"All we could get from the Spanish authorities is he rented a car each time and put 1,000 kilometers on the car each time," the official said, referring to 600 miles. "So we'd like to get a better idea of what he was doing in Spain, and who he met with."
The debate about the American tribunals comes as antiterrorism cooperation between the United States and the European authorities, especially in Spain and Germany, is accelerating. Three times this year, Spain has rounded up Arabs accused of preparing terrorist acts, and arrests have been made in Belgium, France, Britain and Germany. American law enforcement and intelligence officials have been working closely with their European counterparts, exchanging information that has advanced investigations on both sides of the Atlantic. 
The United States is used to negotiating certain conditions -- like promising that prosecutors will not seek the death penalty -- in order to extradite suspects in criminal and even in terrorist cases. In one recent case, the United States made such a promise to German officials to secure the extradition of Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, who now faces trial in New York on charges of charges of taking part in a terrorism conspiracy led by Mr. bin Laden. 
It is not known whether American officials would be prepared to promise that suspects extradited from Europe in the Sept. 11 attacks would not face the military tribunals mentioned by Mr. Bush.
The European Union already has a policy stating that no member nation must extradite a suspect to a country unless it gets believable assurances that the death penalty will not be asked for or applied.
So far, the extradition questions posed by the administration's plan appear to have been faced only in Spain, and have not been discussed formally by any European Union institution.
The issue appeared to take the officials of several European governments by surprise. Officials of the British, German, Dutch and Italian governments declined comment and the acting spokeswoman for the American Embassy in Madrid, did not return phone calls.
"We are just starting our reflection on this case," said a spokeswoman for the French Foreign Ministry. "We have no official position."
Germany has a long practice of extraditing to the United States in capital cases only if it receives assurances that conviction will not bring a death penalty, a legal expert at the German Max Planck Institute for Comparative Law said. Were the United States now to request extradition of a suspected terrorist, a German court would have to examine whether the proposed military trial in the United States would be "contrary to the rule of law."
"And that could be a problem," the German expert said.
Mr. Robertson, the British human rights lawyer, said the proposed American tribunals fell "far short of the fair trial standards" required by a key passage in the continent's basic legal affairs treaty, Article 6 of the Convention on Human Rights.
"Military officers in the pay of the U.S. government are not regarded as independent or impartial," he said, adding that European treaties require public, not secret, trials.
"In effect, there would be little or no chance of extraditing from Europe," Mr. Robertson said.

HEADLINE: 'Delicate Balance' Awaits Buyer of Brooks Brothers 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
Can the button-down set survive into the dress-down 21st century? The new owner of Brooks Brothers thinks it can.
 Marks & Spencer announced today that it was selling Brooks Brothers, the 175-year-old clothing chain, to Retail Brand Alliance Inc. of Enfield, Conn., for $225 million in cash. That is about a third of the $750 million that Marks & Spencer paid for the business in 1988. 
 Mark Shulman, the chief operating officer of the new owner, called Brooks Brothers' conservative styling and history as the United States' oldest retailer "an American icon." 
"It's certainly the classic look that we are going to maintain," Mr. Shulman said in a telephone interview. "The delicate balance is how you are going to revitalize the brand for the 21st-century customer without alienating the core customer."
Indeed, said Claudio Del Vecchio, Retail Brand's chief executive, who controls the privately held company, "the button-down older person will remain a Brooks Brothers customer, but the offerings in the store will still appeal to someone younger who works in Wall Street or a lawyer's office and needs to present himself in a particular way."
"It'll be an updated look," added Mr. Del Vecchio, 44, "but still traditional, and we still have a good opportunity to serve the same customer over the weekend as well as during the week."
Marks & Spencer, the onetime flagship of British Main Street retailing, sold Brooks Brothers for much less than the prices being talked about before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks damaged prospects and chased away potential buyers.
The price "is somewhat lower than perhaps expected, but in light of Sept. 11, that's not surprising," said Matthew Taylor, an analyst at UBS Warburg in London. "Sales have fallen since Sept. 11, and a number of buyers that were interested before Sept. 11 have fallen away."
But as Marks & Spencer senses a recovery after three years in the doldrums, its main strategic goal has been to shed investments in Europe and in the United States, where the sale of Brooks Brothers is expected to be followed soon by the sale of its Kings supermarket chain, based in Parsippany, N.J.
"It was probably worth getting it done and dusted," Mr. Taylor said, particularly because investors would prefer to see Marks & Spencer make a deal rather than haggle over a price that is "just not seen as big potatoes."
The sale has refocused attention on Brooks Brothers' split identity as the custodian of conservative men's styling pressed by the changing times into offering casual and women's clothes. Casual clothing is a strong suit at Retail Brand Alliance, which already owns the Casual Corner women's apparel chain, with 1,000 stores, and has expanded into the women's jewelry and sportswear businesses.
"Our company is built around specialty stores," Mr. Shulman said. 
Its outlets cater, for instance, to women looking for smaller- and larger-size clothes in its Petite Sophisticate and August Max Woman chains. 
Highly acquisitive, Retail Brand Alliance also bought the Carolee Signature women's boutiques and plans to introduce a chain of 15 stores next fall under the Adrienne Vittadini designer name.
Mr. Shulman said Retail Brand Alliance had been considering an offer for Brooks Brothers since Marks & Spencer announced its plan to sell it eight months ago. Since then, Brooks Brothers has gone through rocky times.
Earlier this month, Brooks Brothers reported a first-half operating loss of $:800,000 ($1.1 million), in contrast to a profit of $:2.5 million in the period a year earlier. Marks & Spencer attributed the slump to the economic slowdown and the attacks on Sept. 11, which affected the flagship Brooks Brothers store in Lower Manhattan.
But there was a deeper problem. "This is a company that's been struggling for many years and is going to need a lot of work," Mr. Del Vecchio said in a phone interview.
As was the case with its British stores in recent years, Marks & Spencer never seemed to know precisely where to position Brooks Brothers. As it did in Europe with its own brand, Marks & Spencer rushed to expand Brooks Brothers, which has 80 stores and 72 outlets in the United States and 77 shops in Asia. That identity crisis meant that "they didn't gain new customers and lost some of their old ones," Mr. Del Vecchio said.
"Customers are a little confused about what Brooks Brothers means, and the No. 1 job will be to eliminate that confusion," he said.
Mr. Del Vecchio acquired Retail Brand Alliance after Luxottica S.p.A. of Italy, which is controlled by his father, bought the U.S. Shoe Corporation, which included Casual Corner. Luxottica, which owns Ray Ban eyewear and the Sunglass Hut chain, is based in Milan, and is not involved with Retail Brand Alliance, Mr. Shulman said.
Nonetheless, there were some questions today about whether Mr. Del Vecchio would turn an American emblem into an Italian name.
"I have been asked today: Do we want Brooks Brothers to remain an American icon or become an Italian brand?" Mr. Del Vecchio said. "And my answer has been that we see Brooks Brothers as a great international brand to appeal to Americans or Italians."

PERSON: Wendy J. Chamberlin 

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMBASSADOR; 
U.S. Envoy to Pakistan Thrust Into Limelight

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
Like so many other Americans, Wendy J. Chamberlin, the United States ambassador to Pakistan, found herself in a changed world on a late-summer day 10 weeks ago -- a world that transformed her, in an instant, from envoy to a country in a diplomatic deep freeze to occupant of one of America's most important ambassadorial postings.
 In the early evening of Sept. 11, as perfect a day in Islamabad as in New York, Ms. Chamberlin was walking from her office in the sprawling embassy complex to her residence. As she entered the marbled hallway, one of her two daughters, Chynna, 14, called from the television room upstairs, "Mummy, come here!" 
 More than nine hours westward, the first hijacked plane had struck the World Trade Center, and the second struck shortly after Ms. Chamberlin began watching. That it was terrorism was certain, and that it had momentous implications for the United States' strained relationship with Pakistan seemed just as clear -- at least to American officials like Ms. Chamberlin, 53, whose experience in counterterrorism made Osama bin Laden an immediate suspect.
"My personal objective when I got here in August was to work very hard to improve Pakistani-American relations, with the aim that at the end of my three years here we could lift American sanctions on Pakistan," Ms. Chamberlin said in a recent interview. "I could never have dreamed that we'd have accomplished it in my first three months."
For the role she has played in enlisting Pakistan's support for American military operations in Afghanistan, and rewarding Pakistan with an economic aid package that makes it the United States' third-most favored ally after Israel and Egypt, Ms. Chamberlin has been a figure of light and dark to Pakistanis: admired by those who favor Pakistan's move back to the American camp, disparaged as an "imperialist" by Islamic militants who support the Taliban.
But while the militants' hostility makes hers a potentially hazardous assignment, Ms. Chamberlin has remained highly visible, turning up for diplomatic events she could have avoided on security grounds.
The only ambassador in Islamabad who has cut a larger figure has been the Taliban's envoy, Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, whose daily news conferences mixed allegations of United States "genocide" with conflicting statements about the whereabouts of Mr. bin Laden. 
But Ms. Chamberlin, after fuming for weeks, eventually persuaded General Musharraf to ban the Taliban news conferences. This week, after more American pressure, the mullah was told to close his embassy for good -- a fate unlikely to win much sympathy from Ms. Chamberlin. "He told a pack of lies," she said. 
Since the Muslim holy month of Ramadan began last week, the ambassador has made another widely reported gesture, announcing that she will fast like devout Muslims from sunup to sundown each day for 30 days. "The whole point of Ramadan is to share the plight of the poor," she said. "I just felt, with so many Afghans facing famine, that I should show a sense of solidarity."
When Ms. Chamberlin arrived here this summer, Pakistan's relations with the United States were at their lowest ebb in 50 years. In 1998, under a civilian government, Pakistan conducted nuclear tests in retaliation for India's own tests. Both countries were subjected to severe American sanctions. In October 1999, after a military coup in Pakistan, even tougher American sanctions were applied. 
Pakistan's support for the Taliban, and by inference for Mr. bin Laden and the terrorist organization, only made things worse. 
One measure of the chill was that Ms. Chamberlin waited until Sept. 13, a month after her arrival, to present her credentials to President Pervez Musharraf, the general who heads the government. The official explanation was that August was too hot for the horses that draw the ceremonial carriage that bears new ambassadors to the presidential mansion. In earlier times, when Pakistan was a crucial cold war ally for Washington, a month's wait would have been unthinkable.
But from that first meeting with General Musharraf, everything changed. Since then, Ms. Chamberlin has seen the relationship thaw, to the point that Pakistan, denied all American aid for much of the last decade, has been promised $1 billion in economic support by the Bush administration. All American sanctions have been lifted.
Most remarkable has been the shift in American perceptions of General Musharraf. "He's my kind of man -- very direct, genuine and extremely personally honest," the ambassador said. Contrary to reports suggesting that the 58-year-old general wavered at first on switching Pakistan's support from the Taliban to the United States, she recalled him as having been firm from the moment the two first met after the Sept. 11 attacks. "He said 'yes' immediately, he said he was with us, and he said his support was 'unstinting,' " she said. 
America's report card was not always so approving. As recently as June, when General Musharraf appointed himself president, State Department officials all but mocked him for his grandiosity. And in March 2000, when President Bill Clinton stopped in Islamabad for six hours after a five-day trip to India, Pakistan's traditional foe, he lectured the Pakistani leader on democracy, and refused to be photographed with him. 
Although some Pakistanis chuckle at the American turnaround, others say Ms. Chamberlin has had the fortune to be ambassador at a moment when Washington, prompted by the attacks, has adopted a policy towards Pakistan that suits its long-term interests, if not wholly its democratic ideals. In this view, the American tilt towards India from the mid-1990's on underweighted long-term stresses between the two countries as much as it ignored long-term affinities between the United States and Pakistan.
In Ms. Chamberlin's view, much the same could be said for General Musharraf -- that Sept. 11 gave him an opening to shift Pakistan away from its tilt towards Islamic militancy and back to an embrace with the United States.
"I'd almost say he was liberated by Sept. 11, terrible as that Was," she said. "In so many ways, he's seen what happened as an opportunity to realize his vision for Pakistan: first, to put the country back on a stable financial footing; second, to use the new sources of financial assistance to address some of the important human development issues, such as education and job creation; and third, to tackle the corrosive effects of domestic terrorism."
Even if events have been more decisive than diplomatic skills in forging the new alliance, Ms. Chamberlin gets high marks from Pakistani officials for her part in the realignment. But embassy officials say that the hardest part of the job has been that Ms. Chamberlin, like other American diplomats here, was ordered to send her children back to the United States after Sept. 11 for security reasons.
Previously married to John Houston Hawes, a senior diplomat, she came here as a single mother, and will be separated from her daughters until Washington judges it safe for families to return.

FAMILY: Divorced, two daughters.
