HEADLINE: Practical Traveler; 
To Europe, On the Cheap

BYLINE:  By SUSAN STELLIN; SUSAN STELLIN writes frequently for The New York Times.

 BODY:
DISCOUNT air fares to Europe this time of year are nothing new; fares to Europe usually drop markedly between November and mid-March, with some exceptions for the holidays around Christmas. But this fall, with trans-Atlantic travel in a slump, there are more seats available at these low fares and fewer time restrictions. 
 "The fare level that you see now is nothing totally out of the ordinary for November travel," said Einar Gustavsson, chairman of the European Travel Commission and director of the Icelandic Tourist Board. But, he said, there are fewer restrictions and fares are valid closer to Christmas. 
 Most major domestic airlines announced sales in late October that include round-trip fares to Europe under $400. Several international carriers have similar deals. 
Some routes and travel dates may no longer be available. In general, tickets to cities abroad must be bought by Dec. 4 for travel through March 20; the lowest fares usually apply Monday through Thursday and require a Saturday night stay and a 14-day advance purchase. 
Here is a roundup of typical fares from domestic and international carriers, plus some savings on ground travel. Only one fare includes taxes and surcharges, which may add another $30 to $50 to the ticket price. And most of the airlines are offering an additional 10 percent discount for booking online.

Discounts From U.S. Airlines
American Airlines, (800) 433-7300 or www.aa.com, is running a Great American Get-Together sale that includes discounts to many European cities. Round-trip fares from New York to London start at $238; other fares are Boston to Paris for $278 and Los Angeles to London for $338. 
United Airlines, (800) 241-6522 or www.ua.com, is having a Get Away for the Holidays sale, with round-trip fares starting at $298 from Chicago to London, $398 from San Francisco to Amsterdam, $278 from Boston to Paris and $238 from New York to London. Tickets must be bought seven days in advance. 
Delta Airlines, (800) 221-1212 or www.delta.com, has round-trip fares from Atlanta to Amsterdam starting at $377, Boston to London for $248, San Francisco to Madrid for $446 and New York to Milan for $308. These fares are valid for travel on any day of the week through March 14 (although they are not available for some flights from Dec. 14 to 24). 
Continental Airlines, (800) 523-3273 or www.continental.com, is having a Friends and Family sale with round-trip tickets from Newark to Paris starting at $278, Newark to London at $238, and San Francisco to Brussels at $406. 
US Airways, (800) 428-4322 or www.usair.com, and Northwest Airlines, (800) 225-2525 or www.nwa .com) are offering similar discounts. Last-minute travelers may find even better deals by subscribing to e-mail bulletins offered by these and several other airlines. The e-mail messages list highly discounted fares to selected domestic and international destinations, usually for the next weekend or within 10 days.

International Deals
Several European airlines are also offering discounted fares to Europe, in some cases matching the sales announced by U.S. carriers.
On Alitalia, (800) 223-5730 or www .alitalia.com), passengers can fly round trip from Boston or New York to Rome or Milan for $298 Monday through Thursday through March 14 ($25 more each way on the weekend). Tickets must be purchased by Dec. 4 and prices are higher for travel from Dec. 12 to 24. 
Air France, (800) 237-2747 or www .airfrance.com, has round-trip fares from New York or Boston to Paris (or five other cities in France) for as low as $278, for Monday through Thursday departures through March 16. Tickets must be purchased at least 14 days before departure but no later than Dec. 4. Air France has similarly discounted fares to other European cities, including London, Athens, Madrid and Brussels. 
On Lufthansa, (800) 399-5838 or www.lufthansa.com, a round-trip ticket between New York and Frankfurt is as low as $271; San Francisco to Paris is $426 and Washington to Amsterdam is $258. Tickets must be bought by Dec. 4 for travel through March 21. Lufthansa is also offering a free companion ticket to anyone who buys a round-trip economy class ticket by Feb. 15 for travel through March 24 (subject to some restrictions and blackout dates). A sample fare that qualifies for the "2 for 1" offer is a round trip from New York to Frankfurt for $546.73, including tax.
British Airways, (800) 247-9297 or www.britishairways.com) is also offering a free companion ticket to anyone who buys a full-fare economy ($1,366 for two between New York and London) or premium economy class ticket ($2,076) by Dec. 31 for travel by Jan. 31.

On the Ground
Americans in Europe can benefit from a strong dollar and a variety of discounts on hotel rooms, train travel and car rental. The European Travel Commission's Web site, www .visiteurope.com, lists a few offers from partners, including a 20 percent discount on car rentals from Hertz. The site also features three-night packages from British Airways Holidays, which include hotel and round-trip air fare to six European cities for as low as $390. (These packages must be booked by Nov. 30 for travel by Dec. 31, though prices are higher Dec. 19 to 23.) 
As for hotels, Mr. Gustavsson said that prices in Europe are about 25 percent lower this year than they would normally be. 
And for those interested in traveling by train, there are a handful of discounts available; all must be purchased in the United States before departure. BritRail (877) 677-1066 or www.britrail.net, is offering 25 percent discounts on passes for travel in Britain purchased and used by Feb. 28. A four-day BritRail FlexiPass, which can be used on any four days within two months, costs $176 for an adult in standard class and $262 in first class. Destination Europe Resources (800) 782-2424 or www .der.com, and Rail Europe (888) 382-7245 or www.raileurope.com, are offering discounts on the Eurostar train between London and Paris, and London and Brussels beginning in January. A leisure round-trip ticket between London and either Paris or Brussels is $178 when purchased 14 days in advance, or $120 when purchased 60 days in advance. These tickets are nonrefundable and cannot be exchanged. (The regular fare is $278.) Rail Europe is also discounting first-class French rail passes for two or more people traveling together through March 31. A first-class, four-day France Saverpass for two to five people is $147 a person, down from $201. 
Travelers who buy a Swiss Pass, (877) 456-7245 or on the Web at www.myswitzerland.com, can get an extra day at no extra cost before Dec. 31. A four-day Swiss Pass, plus a fifth free day of travel, costs $245 in first class and $160 in second class. Passes can be used up to six months from the date of issue and are good for between four days and one month of unlimited rail travel.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Westerleigh, Staten Island; 
Where Flags Fly Outside Historic Homes

BYLINE:  By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
FLAGS have always been flown on American holidays on Burnside Avenue in the Westerleigh neighborhood of Staten Island, but since Sept. 11, more houses are flying flags supplied by one neighbor -- John Nappi, a 77-year-old veteran of World War II -- and they're out every day. "Driving down that block," said Michael Morrell, president of the Westerleigh Improvement Society, "makes you feel like you're in a procession."
 This is not surprising in a neighborhood that celebrates a holiday that it calls Patriotic Sunday, held annually on the last weekend in June at Westerleigh Park. The community comes together, listening to stirring marches played by the South Shore Band from Tottenville High School, picnicking and drinking birch beer provided by the Improvement Society, which has been in existence since 1893 and has 720 member families and businesses. 
 Westerleigh, which is on the north shore of Staten Island, was started in the 1880's by people fervent about temperance; three streets around the park are named after presidential candidates from the National Prohibition Party. Today, its residents are similarly passionate about their country, their neighborhood and their houses. 
When Mark Anderson, a historic preservation architect, moved with his wife, Nancy, and their 18-month-old son, Erik, into a 1903 turreted Victorian four-bedroom house in Westerleigh in June, he knew he was coming home -- in two senses: he had lived in the community until he was 4 years old and returned through the years to shop at the family's favorite delicatessen (the Westerleigh Deli) and bakery (the Cake Chef), and he is eager to bring his workplace skills to his turn-of-the century home. 
He also plans to write articles for the Westerleigh Improvement Society's newsletter to try to help other residents who may be working on their own century-old houses. "I look forward to including some of the technology we are using on restoring the landmarked interior of McKim, Mead & White's Gould Memorial Library at Bronx Community College for upcoming articles on stained glass and plaster restoration," said Mr. Anderson, a vice president at Facade Maintenance Design.
The Andersons like the neighborhood's mix of young families -- "there are five on my block with children under 5, including my own" -- middle-aged couples and older lifelong residents. "My next-door neighbor has lived on the block, Jewett Avenue, for over 50 years," he said.
THE community is brimming with historic houses, including at least one dating back to the 1700's: the Houseman Homestead, a New York City landmark, which is still used as a private home. But it is Victorian homes built from the 1880's to the 1920's that attract the most notice. Their original elements include chestnut trim, oak floors, wraparound porches at street level and small porches or balconies on the upper floors. Many of the homes contain parlors, libraries and formal dining rooms.
"What creates a neighborhood like Westerleigh are its non-cookie-cutter houses," said George Wonica, a Westerleigh native who owns Wonica Realtors. Housing built after 1920 includes Dutch colonials, Cape Cods and ranches.
The average prices for one-family detached homes range from $260,000 for a three-bedroom house built in 1925 to $369,900 for a four-bedroom home built in 1974 to $585,000 for an eight-bedroom house with a fireplace and in-ground pool built in 1931, according to Connie Profaci, owner and broker at Connie Profaci Realty. Two-family houses that sold recently include a five-bedroom built in 1925, which sold for $350,000, and a four-bedroom house built in 1970, whose price was $410,000.
Although about 95 percent of the buildable area was constructed before 1960 and, therefore, before the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened, there is still room here and there for some new building. Two semidetached homes have recently been built on Kingsley Avenue. Craig and Angela Recca and their two daughters -- Bianca, 9, and Priscilla, 12 -- have moved into one of them: 324 Kingsley Avenue, a three-bedroom, three-bathroom house with a finished basement that they purchased for $300,000. 
The girls attend St. Rita's Catholic Elementary School, which lies just outside of Westerleigh. Other private elementary schools in the area are Blessed Sacrament, a Roman Catholic school, and St. John's Lutheran School, both on Manor Road.
Many Westerleigh children receive their elementary schooling at Public School 30, a two-story school that was dedicated on April 28, 1905, with additions since. Of the 900 students at P.S. 30, 67 percent are reading at or above grade level and 66 percent are at or above grade level on the standardized math tests. This compares with the overall city scores of 34 percent at or above grade level for math and 39 percent for reading.
Robert Turetsky has been principal there for two years. "There's such a rich tradition here -- grandparents who attended the school come back to attend assembly programs," he said. "Enthusiasm and caring resonate throughout the building."
Students go on to attend Intermediate School 51, also known as the Edwin A. Markham School, named for a poet who resided in Westerleigh. In standardized reading tests, 39 percent of the 1,600 students at I.S. 51 are at or above grade level; in math, the number is 27 percent.
The school is coping with an abundance of students. "Our school was built for 1,100 students, so we are in double session, with the sixth and seventh grade starting at 7:40 a.m. and leaving at 2 p.m. and the eighth grade attending school from 9:15 a.m. to 3:27 p.m.," said Arnold Raffone, the principal. 
In a sign of the times, when his woodworking teacher retired and he could not find another, he hired Anthony Gargiso, who has a master's in photography; bought 15 digital cameras; and with 16 computers set up a photo lab. Today, 350 students take the digital photography course. 
At Port Richmond High School, with 2,500 students, 75 percent of recent graduates went on to four-year colleges and 4 percent to two year schools. About 375 students participate in the Collegiate Academy, an honors program -- students are required to maintain an 85 percent average -- with such advanced placement courses as calculus, government and economics. A sister program, College Now, lets students take college-level courses in subjects like communications and sociology at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.
In sports, the girl's softball team won city championships the past two years, as well as in 1995 to 1997. "The team has been in the playoffs for 11 of the past 12 years," said the coach, Nancy Cena. 
WHILE most Westerleigh students attend Port Richmond High, about 25 percent go to Susan Wagner High School, which has 2,600 students; 70 percent of its graduating seniors went on to four-year colleges and 12 percent entered two-year schools. 
Among special programs at the school are the Scholars' Program, for honors students; the Odyssey Program, which works with ninth graders to ease the transition into high school; and a vocational program that helps special-education students find employment after graduation through part-time jobs while attending school. Nicole Klimuk, 19, daughter of Martha Klimuk, president of the P.T.A., is in the special ed program. Legally blind and neurologically impaired, Nicole works at Seaview Rehabilitation Hospital, visiting patients.
Westerleigh was originally called Prohibition Park. Beginning in 1887 it was carved from the existing farms and forests as a meeting place for supporters of the temperance movement. The National Prohibition Party purchased land in the area for its summer headquarters, setting aside lots for campsites. As the area's prominence grew, a permanent meeting site was erected: an auditorium called University Temple. To accommodate visitors, a large hotel and two small hotels were built. The area attracted William Jennings Bryan and other notables.
But by 1898, interest in temperance had begun to wane and the large hotel, Park Hotel, was torn down. P.S. 30 was built on the site. The Prohibition Park company turned to real estate, selling lots for houses to people who were not Prohibitionists. 
Most homes in the neighborhood are one-family detached houses, although there are some newer semidetached homes and limited development of town houses. One development is on Vogel Loop, opposite the firehouse on Jewett Avenue, which was built in 1988-89. Its 62 town houses were built on property where one large house stood. This mobilized the Improvement Society to call for lower-density zoning, and in 1989 the law was changed to allow only detached and semidetached homes to be built. The area has no condominium or co-op projects. But there is a garden apartment complex on Ravenhurst and Jewett Avenues, with rents ranging from $800 for a one-bedroom apartment to $1,100 for a two-bedroom.
Today, another "down zoning" is in the works. A proposal from the departing borough president, Guy Molinari, would rezone Westerleigh to be even more restrictive, , preventing semidetached developments and allowing only fully detached houses, one- and two-family, on 40-foot frontage. The application for rezoning is subject to approval by the Department of City Planning. The call for lower-density zoning is coming as more old large houses are seen as being at risk of being replaced by multifamily housing developments.
The commercial strips in the neighborhood run along its northern border, Forest Avenue, with its Forest Avenue Shoppers Town, which has a T. J. Maxx clothing store and a Hometown Buffet restaurant, and along its southern border, Victory Boulevard, with its Reiman's Hardware and Goodfellas pizza.
A focal point of the neighborhood is Westerleigh Park, a 2.9-acre square with a band shell that was refurbished in 1990. Another recreation area is the 4.2-acre Northerleigh Park, where the Westerleigh Little Guys and Gals little leagues play baseball. The private Westerleigh Tennis Club, which has a pavilion clubhouse and three clay courts, is on College Avenue. A one-year single membership costs $200.

FARMS, MINES, HOUSES: Before the temperance movement discovered Westerleigh, it was a mixture of farms, forests and mines. A thriving iron ore business, the Richmond Iron Mining Company, operated from 1864 to the mid-1880's. Twelve tons an hour were excavated by German and Irish laborers who used candlelight for illumination and earned $1 to $1.25 a day, according to "Westerleigh: The Town That Temperance Built," by Lawrence Dover, a hardcover book published last year through the Westerleigh Improvement Society with grants from local businesses. There were several iron mines occupying 66 acres. The ore had to be transported over cobblestones and dirt roads to barges at the foot of Port Richmond Avenue, directly north of Westerleigh. A railway was proposed to move the ore to market, but it was never built. The land proved more attractive for real estate development.

HEADLINE: Postings: Guidelines Board's Annual Publication; 
Analyzing Rental Market

 BODY:
Offering insights into the rental market, from what a landlord should pay for a pushbroom to the economic factors that make Manhattan different from the rest of the city, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board's annual publication, "Housing NYC: Rents, Markets and Trends 2001," is now available.
 "It's more than a clearinghouse of arcane information such as the price of pushbrooms and the change in the cost of boiler repairs, which is in there," said Anita Visser, executive director of the rent board. 
The 140-page book, Ms. Visser said, "is a comprehensive snapshot of the rental market: what it's like to develop, own, manage, live in and afford rental housing for the last year." The readership is diverse, she said: real estate professionals, academics, experts, lenders, housing advocates, policymakers. Readers could discover that the price index of operating costs, a measure of goods and services used by buildings, rose by 8.7 percent last year, Ms. Visser said, and "that we had a big spike in dwelling units completed during 2000, just under 13,000, or 44 percent more than the year before." 
 For the first time, the book separately surveys statistics for Manhattan below 96th Street. "Core Manhattan has a very different economic profile," Ms. Visser said, "so the study illustrates a tale of two cities." The book costs $23, not including tax and shipping. Information: the Citystore (212) 380-8246.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
A Struggle Over an Empty Store

BYLINE:  By DIANA MARSZALEK 

DATELINE: LARCHMONT 

 BODY:
CVS/PHARMACY is moving forward with its plans to open a third store here, despite opposition from neighbors who say they want a grocery store instead.
 Representatives of the Rhode Island-based pharmacy chain say they plan to turn the former Grand Union supermarket site in the heart of the village's commercial district into a CVS pharmacy unless a viable grocer gives them a better option. 
 Mike DeAngelis, a CVS spokesman, said company leaders were aware of neighbors' opposition to their plan -- especially after about 150 people showed up at a Village Hall meeting to voice their opposition last month.
Despite residents' demands for a grocery store, however, no viable food store has offered to absorb or share CVS's lease on the property, Mr. DeAngelis said. The lease to the Larchmont property was one of 10 that CVS obtained from Grand Union when the company closed its stores earlier this year. A CVS spokesman said the company filed its plans with the village last week. If the approval process goes smoothly, the store will open within four months. 
"We are certainly willing to talk to interested parties," said Mr. DeAngelis, adding that CVS remedied a similar situation in Woodstock by opening a store that shares its space with a grocery. "But right now in Larchmont it appears that we can't find anyone interested and it's just going to be a CVS."
Opponents of a CVS store say they will continue their own efforts to find a grocer for the site.
Larchmont and its neighboring communities, they say, already have more CVS outlets than they need. 
"We're not against CVS," Wendy Weinstein Karp, an opponent, said. "We shop there and we support it. But enough is enough."
She and others argue that there is a clear need for a full-service grocery store in the heart of Larchmont.
"It's vital to the health of any community to have a neighborhood supermarket," said Liz Feld, another opponent. "It's a social and cultural hub of a community."
Other area supermarkets are outside the center of Larchmont's village and are reached primarily by car.
Ms. Feld, who started a community group to bring new businesses to Larchmont, said she has already has talked to local grocers about leasing the Grand Union site. The owners of the nearby Larchmont Meateria, a small specialty butcher and food store, and DeCicco's Marketplace, a four-store business, are two of the grocers Ms. Feld said she wants to encourage to use the site.
But the owners of both the Meateria and DeCicco's said that while the idea sounds good, it may not be economically viable.
Joe DeCicco, a DeCicco's Marketplace co-owner, said that while the Grand Union site offers a prime location, taking over CVS's lease would cost about $15,000 a month for the 10,000-square-foot store, Mr. DeCicco said. That, along with stiff competition from area superstores that average 60,000 to 70,000 square feet, makes the Grand Union site a tough sell, he said.
"We love the idea, but when we checked the numbers out we realized it would take years to start showing a cash flow," Mr. DeCicco said. "This is not a profitable business."
The existing DeCicco's stores, which range from 7,500 to 22,000 square feet, have been able to make money because their rents are as low as $9,000 a month, Mr. DeCicco said. 
Victor Ciampi, owner of the Larchmont Meateria, agreed.
"Everyone would like to expand," Mr. Ciampi said. "But it's very expensive and very hard."
Village officials say there isn't much they can do to stop CVS from proceeding.
Mayor Cheryl W. Lewy said CVS was within its rights to use the site, as long as it goes through the village's approval process and complies with village law.
"The village's position has been the same all along," Ms. Lewy said. "The business district is zoned as a commercial area."
One village trustee, however, said there would be a range of factors for both the village and CVS to consider, which could influence the final decisionits outcome.
An issue that will inevitably arise is whether the village wants to continue letting the tenant of the former Grand Union site use the entire parking lot adjacent to the property, even though the village owns a portion of it, said the trustee, Ken Bialo.
The philosophical question of whether a CVS is the best use for the site -- the largest currently available in the village -- will also surely be discussed, he said. 
"We have a lot of agitated and angry residents and I'm sympathetic to that," Mr. Bialo said. "But it's also a matter of CVS's business judgment whether it makes sense to open a store that their own customers say they don't want."
In the meantime, CVS representatives said they would continue working toward a new Larchmont store.
"We are always willing to work with the community, but we are moving forward with obtaining the proper zoning and planning permits," Mr. DeAngelis said. "We see this site as an attractive location."

HEADLINE: Smoke Out: A Lesson Before Lighting Up 

BYLINE:  By ALIX BOYLE 

 BODY:
ANTHONY COVINGTON looked appalled and emphatically shook his head when asked by a visitor whether he smoked cigarettes. Anthony, a fifth-grader at the Harry A. Conte West Hills Magnet School in New Haven, is one of thousands of students across the state who is learning what tobacco can do to the body through a program called Science, Tobacco and You.
 During a recent science lesson, Anthony, 10, was using an interactive CD-ROM program to study how smoking burdens the heart, lungs and circulatory system. 
 "It makes me not want to smoke because you won't be able to get enough oxygen to breathe and you'll run slower," said Anthony, who also plays football.
Anthony and his classmates broke up into groups to conduct experiments like jogging in place and measuring heart rates. They learned that a smoker's heart rate will be higher and will take longer to return to normal than a nonsmoker's. 
"I have asthma and if I smoke it would be worse," said 10-year-old Breiana Stanley during a break from the heart-rate experiment.
The lesson is one part of a statewide effort to keep children from becoming smokers that includes a Web site, TobaccoFreeCT.com, spot checks of stores that sell cigarettes to be sure that they're not selling to minors, and education from science teachers and police officers. 
The Web site, a billboard campaign, and Science, Tobacco and You cost $1.25 million and were financed by a portion of Connecticut's share of money from the settlement of lawsuits against the tobacco industry, said Maraide Sullivan, project director of the anti-tobacco grant administered by the State Office of Policy and Management.
Despite all these efforts, children as young as 9 and even 8 are lighting up, said Suchitra Krishnan-Sarin, a psychologist and researcher with the Center for Nicotine and Tobacco Youth Research at Yale University School of Medicine. The Connecticut Youth Tobacco Survey released last spring by the State Department of Health reported that 13.1 percent of middle school students and 32.4 percent of high school students have used tobacco.
"Adolescent smoking is a huge problem and schools are doing the best they can with prevention and education programs, but there are really no good cessation programs out there in the schools," Ms. Krishnan-Sarin said.
According to the TobbaccoFreeCT.com Web site, smoking is prohibited in all areas of public school buildings, without exception, while school is in session or student activities are taking place. Students are suspended if they are caught smoking and the police are often called to issue a ticket to a student who smokes at school, Dr. Krishnan-Sarin said.
"It's O.K. to suspend a student, but that alone is not sufficient," Dr. Krishnan-Sarin said. "We need to provide treatment options. You have to take into consideration that they are addicted and they need help."
Part of the problem is that nicotine substitutes like patches and gum are generally not available to children and adolescents who smoke. Adult cessation programs don't work well with teenagers, so new methods must be developed.
"I believe that cessation programs haven't been successful because people have jumped into programs without understanding the science," Dr. Krishnan-Sarin said.
Why do teenagers smoke? Mainly as a coping mechanism to deal with school and home stress, and they continue smoking because they are addicted to nicotine.
Why do they start? Peer influence and because their parents smoke. Parents who smoke are more likely to tolerate it in their children.
In her research over the years, Dr. Krishnan-Sarin has learned that three out of four teenagers have tried to quit more than once and that two out of three teenagers who smoke wish they had never started.
Researchers at Yale recruit teenagers who want to quit smoking to a three-day in-patient hospital program. The researchers study the smokers' mood and cognitive changes. With this knowledge, future smoking cessation programs can be tailored to the teens' needs.
According to the state youth tobacco survey, middle school students get their cigarettes by borrowing them or having someone else buy them. Teenagers buy cigarettes at convenience stores and from vending machines. 
It is illegal to buy tobacco if you are under 18 and it is illegal to sell it to minors. The state has been fining stores if they sell cigarettes to children. Children can also be fined $50 on their first offense and $100 thereafter.
"Federal law requires that states enforce the tobacco laws by doing random unannounced inspections," said State Senator William A. Aniskovich, a Republican from Branford. "If we don't, we will lose our federal block grants for substance-abuse services. Back in 1996, Connecticut had one of the worst compliance rates, but that's improved substantially."
Not only is it illegal to sell tobacco to minors, but owners of vending machines can be fined if anyone under 18 is caught buying cigarettes from their machines. Selling "loosies," cigarettes out of the package, is also illegal.
"Our culture is uncomfortable with stricter enforcement of tobacco laws because many people believe that this is still in the purview of parents," Mr. Aniskovich said. "But even parents who care don't know what their children are doing every minute and there is still a need for enforcement. It's a public health issue like requiring people to wear bike helmets. It gives parents one more tool and enables them to say, 'It's the law.' " 
State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said that in spot inspections, minors were able to buy cigarettes 70 percent of the time in 1996; it was reduced to 18 percent in 2000. 
Last year the State Legislature passed a law allowing towns to ban vending machines and so far, Orange has succeeded in banning them. Mr. Blumenthal supports all towns getting rid of vending machines. However, a bill banning smoking in public buildings failed, but will be redrafted next year, Mr. Aniskovich said.
Mr. Blumenthal's office recently sued R. J. Reynolds for continuing to advertise in magazines that appeal to teenagers in violation of the original tobacco settlement, he said. Mr. Blumenthal said that Connecticut was one of the first states to file suit against the tobacco companies.
About 1,200 teachers were trained in the Science, Tobacco and You tobacco curriculum last year, Ms. Sullivan said. The use of the curriculum varies from school to school, but teachers give from 12 to 20 one-hour lessons on the effects of tobacco.
Jo-Anne Escandon, a fourth grade teacher at Race Brook School in Orange said that her class was particularly impressed when they saw the tar that was pulled out of a lung during an autopsy. Ms. Escandon also has her pupils write letters to parents or grandparents, imploring them to stop smoking. As a result, one of the mothers of a student quit smoking.
"We target the children in fourth and fifth grade before they develop bad habits," Ms. Escandon said. "Once they do their experiments, they say 'I'm never going to smoke.' "
Some parents, however, said they believed that the anti-smoking campaign begins at home. Jessica Shore of Guilford said that her twin boys view smoking as unhealthy and disgusting. Although she taught Ethan and Gabriel, both 10, that smoking is addictive, harmful and would interfere with playing sports, she believes that her example of not smoking is the strongest message of all.
"I think it's not what you say, it's what you do," Ms. Shore said. "If you smoke, you're sunk."

Above, Steven Price checking his pulse. Inset, a device simulating the respiratory system. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Conservation-Minded Housing in Indiana 

BYLINE:  By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind. 

 BODY:
The story of American housing development is told in lyrical names -- Golden Meadows, Redgrove Orchards, Wildwood Acres -- that are usually the sole remnant of what was wiped off the land once the sewers, roads and houses were built.
 That is not true, however, at the 170-acre Tryon Farm, an environmentally sensitive farm-based development in northwest Indiana that takes advantage of a growing demand for community, kinship and distinctive homes amid wide-open natural spaces. Tryon Farm, at the eastern edge of Michigan City, a rust-belt town experiencing an economic revival, is also distinguished by a novel business plan that is satisfied with a much slower home construction and sales pace than conventional subdivisions. 
 That's due in part to the fact that Tryon Farm is really a family enterprise, conceived by a Chicago-based architect, Edward J. Noonan; his wife, Eve Noonan, a marketing specialist; their oldest son, David, a lawyer and developer in New York; and his wife, Susan, who founded and oversees an 80-person public relations firm. 
The Noonans oversee and gain revenue from virtually every aspect of ownership, architectural design, financing, land management and home construction. "We're trying to weld all aspects of development together," said Edward Noonan, a third-generation Chicago architect whose father, T. Clifford Noonan, a member of the famed firm of Graham, Anderson, Probst & White, was the chief architect for the State Department building in Washington. "It seemed to me that developers were always treating architects like children, sending them from the room when they talked about money. My response has always been: Well if they can go to the bank, so can I."
So far, it's working. In 1990, the Noonans invested $510,000 and bought one of the last farms within Michigan City's borders, five miles from downtown, vowing to honor agricultural character and heritage. More than a decade later, there is still a farm at Tryon Farm, along with a barn that houses livestock, working farm fields, thick forests, restored wildflower meadows, acres of wetlands and permanently protected open spaces. This natural bounty -- most of which has existed since the farm was first cut from the Indiana woods 141 years ago by the Tryon family -- serves as a featured amenity, like the fairways in golf developments or waterfront in lakeside units.
""We call this a rehab job," said Eve Noonan, who is obviously lavishing the same reservoirs of energy to this family project that she once devoted to raising her five children. "It was a dairy farm that for a century was a terrific place to live. It's still a farm. The original farmstead is here. The original barns and outbuildings are here. What we've tried to do is fit the homes into the landscape without intruding."
The design of Tryon Farm's master plan mimics the Middle West landscape of the 19th century, when prairie farmsteads were surrounded by numerous outbuildings. In the Noonans' design, groups of 8 to 20 homes are clustered close together in eight "settlements," each separated from the others by expanses of field, woods or meadows. More than 120 of the farm's 170 acres are permanently off limits to construction. 
Buyers own their own homes and a small skirt of land around the building, but the rest of the land is shared in common ownership for which residents pay a monthly fee of roughly $90 to a homeowners' association. Trails wind under the forest canopy and through the meadows, and on warm days the place feels much more like summer camp than a housing development. 
One of Tryon Farm's settlements, near the original farmstead, is completed, and a second in thick hardwoods is under way. Prices range from $100,000 for free-standing 650-square-foot lodges to $400,000 for 2,400-square-foot four-bedroom homes. So far 25 homes have sold, including eight this year. 
The project, which was approved under the planned unit development provision of Michigan City's zoning code, is allowed 150 homes on the property. The Noonans, who have invested $1.5 million to date, think that it will take 10 more years to complete Tryon Farm and that when it is fully built out, it will be valued at $40 million.
One resident is Paula Hardin, a teacher and author from Chicago, a 65-minute drive or 80-minute train ride away, from a station that is a five-minute drive from Tryon Farm. Ms. Hardin bought her cozy home two years ago. From the outside, her home and the others in the Farmstead Settlement look like traditional Midwest farmhouses. 
The interiors, though, are airy, light-filled and often distinguished by dramatic two-story living rooms, with lofts and balconies. Some have flying bridges that serve as second floor walkways linking bedrooms on one side of the home to the other. Ms. Hardin quickly learned that her guests naturally gravitated at night to her home's outdoor deck. "They'd bring out their sleeping bags and lie there for hours watching the stars," Ms. Hardin said. "We don't have street lights here, so we can really see the stars."
At Tryon Farm, homeowners can also see goats, herds of deer in the meadows, alfalfa in working fields and rare green herons prancing stoically in restored wetlands. 
"It's not that we have some ideology or philosophy," she said. "People who live here like the simplicity of nature. There are professors here, artists, professional people, families who don't have to have a swimming pool or a golf course."
Such conservation-minded developments, which in the Midwest include Prairie Crossing in Grayslake, Ill., and Fields of St. Croix in Lake Elmo, Minn., gather homes, streets and parks in much closer proximity while leaving a substantial portion of the land undeveloped and often wild. Buyers say they are also attracted by the opportunity to establish more traditional neighborhood relationships than they can develop in conventional and sprawling large-lot subdivisions. Tryon Farm, though, goes several steps further than other alternative housing developments in encouraging both fealty to nature and community.
The development's design was produced by Chicago Associates Planners and Architects, Mr. Noonan's eight-member architecture firm. Mr. Noonan, who credits his partner Thomas Forman with conceiving the site's land plan and another partner, Michael Newman, for overseeing architectural details, describes the design goal as "understanding the whole relationship between privacy and community."
He added: "Modern subdivisions aim everything at the big spaces inside -- fancy kitchens, bigger bathrooms -- and the private backyard. The sequence of arriving at a modern subdivision home is to drive into the garage and walk directly into the house. There is very little chance of connecting with your neighbor. 
"What we're trying to do here is to educate ourselves and others to understand what you really need to live well in a country setting."
Even though homes are close together, Mr. Noonan ensured privacy by designing the windows of Tryon Farm's homes to overlook the open fields and not the neighbors. Most houses have terraces and gardens enclosed by fences. 
But to encourage neighbors to get to know each other, Tryon Farm established a community garden, and cars are parked in a common area near a row of mailboxes. That means neighbors coming and going will have the chance to run into each other. 
There are also features of the development that the most ardent environmentalist would admire. One of the most ambitious is that waste water from homes is treated not in septic systems or carried away in a city sewer but cleansed in a series of constructed wetlands that also serve as habitat for wading birds that flock to the farm. 
The well-understood technology, which deploys plants to absorb nutrients, has been used successfully to treat waste water in Arcata, Calif., and many other communities. There is no smell at all, and water emerges thoroughly cleaned of contaminants and is used to irrigate the alfalfa. By developing the natural system, the Noonans also avoided thousands of dollars annually in the cost of financing an expensive city sewer connection.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tryon Farm may eventually have 150 houses, but more than 120 of its 170 acres will remain as open space. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times) Map of Michigan City, Indiana

HEADLINE: The Slide Begins 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
MORE than 10 weeks after terrorists leveled the World Trade Center, statisticians have begun to measure the shock waves from the attack as they reverberate through Long Island's economy.
 There were big jolts like the $27.1 million drop in sales tax revenues collected in Nassau County for September and October compared with last year's receipts for the same time, and the $45 million loss in hotel receipts across the Island for the two months. There were smaller bumps too, like a real estate market that came to a virtual standstill immediately after Sept. 11 before rebounding, and an unemployment rate that grew from 2.9 percent in October 2000 to 3.5 percent last month. 
 The news was not all bad, though. The Long Island jobless rate was still well below the nation's 5 percent rate and New York City's 6.2 percent. And some sectors shone. Many hotels on the East End stayed busier than usual, thanks to a warm fall but also to more people deciding to put off air travel and opting to stay closer to home. Many restaurants also reported booming business as Long Islanders filled neighborhood haunts rather than heading into the city for a show and dinner. And as the nation continued its war on terrorism, companies in the Island's vestigial defense industry sought to fill dozens of new jobs and anticipated more openings to come. 
Like the national and regional economies, Long Island had started to see signs of a downturn even before Sept. 11, and the decline seemed to accelerate in the immediate aftermath of the attacks. But while the city lost some 79,000 jobs after Sept. 11, the Island actually saw an increase of 10,900 jobs between October 2000 and last month.
Though the pace of job creation declined by a third from pre-Sept. 11 levels, economists and business leaders expressed a cautious optimism, saying the Island had been buffered from the more severe downturn experienced by New York City and the rest of the nation. They said they believed Long Island's economy would recover significantly by year's end.
"Long Islanders were clearly frozen in their tracks in the days immediately after Sept. 11," said Irwin Kellner, an economics professor at Hofstra University and the chief economist for North Fork Bank and CBS MarketWatch. "But there are a lot of signs that things returned to normal in October."
Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, said Long Island's economy "is slowing, but not dramatically so." She said that while the sales tax revenues reflect a big blow to consumer confidence after the World Trade Center attack, "the fact that the labor market has held up as well as it has is a good sign."
Housing values on Long Island have also held up, she said, "and that creates a wealth effect that means people will be inclined to spend, and once the shock of the attack has worn off, consumer spending will rebound to normal levels."
The sales tax revenues for September and October, as provided by the state Department of Taxation and Finance, were the biggest indicators of an economic slowdown on the Island. In Nassau County, sales tax receipts plunged 16.9 percent in September compared to September 2000 and dropped 8.8 percent in October. In Suffolk County, the sales tax revenues edged down less than one percent in September, but then fell 10.1 percent in October.
The drop in sales tax receipts could translate into additional budget cuts or tax increases in both counties, where sales taxes are a major revenue source. The 2002 spending plan that Suffolk legislators approved earlier this month included a 13 percent county property tax increase, prompted in part by an estimated loss of as much as $57 million in sales tax revenues from Sept. 11 through the end of next year. In order to close a potential budget gap of $38 million, the Suffolk legislators also approved a controversial 1.5 percent increase on the sales tax for home heating fuels, a move that will generate about $14 million in additional revenues next year.
Suffolk's approved budget also included $10 million in fee increases that still face public hearings and must be formally approved by the Legislature before January. The increases include a rise in bus fare from $1.50 to $1.75, an increase in vehicle registration fees from $4 to $5, and increases for park services such as beach parking and camping, greens fees and marina dock fees.
Nassau County legislators face an even more onerous task, as they must meet a Nov. 28 deadline to erase up to $45 million in gaps that state monitors found in the budget originally proposed by the retiring county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, and revised by the county Legislature. Members of the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, the state-appointed board that stands poised to take over the county's finances if the legislators fail to come up with a balanced budget, have voiced concerns that recent losses in sales tax revenues could significantly worsen the county's financial outlook.
The budget currently calls for a 5 percent property tax increase. Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive-elect, has floated the notion of an additional 10 percent tax increase, and members of the Democratic majority in the Legislature have pushed for a combination of spending cuts and additional revenue increases. But the Republican minority opposes any more tax increases.
But even though the sales tax figures for September and October signal a slowing economy, Dr. Kamer said the relatively strong sales tax revenues for the earlier part of the year would help soften the blow. She predicted that the Island would see an overall sales tax revenue increase of about 2 percent for the entire year -- a figure that is much lower than the 6.2 percent growth experienced in 2000 and the 6.7 percent growth in 1999, but growth nonetheless.
"I think we'll see a gradual recovery in consumer spending, but people will probably be more careful and postpone big-ticket items." she said. "The go-go days of the last several years won't be returning anytime soon."
Rebecca Demicell, a Garden City resident, personified that caution last week as she shopped at the Nordstrom's at Roosevelt Field. Like many other Long Islanders, she stayed away from the malls for weeks after the tragedy. "You just re-evaluate your priorities after something like that," she said, adding that she would probably spend much more conservatively this holiday season because of the uncertainty of the times. "It's also just really hard to get back in the Christmas spirit," she said.
Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau and Sports Commission, said that with hundreds of businesses canceling meetings and conventions scheduled to be held on Long Island, the Island's hotel industry lost $30 million in anticipated revenue in September and another $15 million in October.
"We expect the rest of the year is going to be slow as well," he said. "We're still dealing with the fact that even though we didn't have the attack here, a lot of the people that got hurt are from here. As they continue to recover bodies, Long Island will still be holding funerals and memorials. So it's hard to stop thinking about it and to move on."
The Hampton Inn in Commack, for example, fielded scores of calls from people canceling their hotel reservations in the first few weeks after the attack. "Every time the phone rang, it was another cancellation," said Bill Mullaney, the general manager. Most were from business travelers who instead were opting for conference calls, but there also were wedding guests who canceled because they just didn't want to fly.
Angelo Auricchio, president of the Long Island Restaurant Association, said catering halls across the Island lost 10 to 12 percent of their business as the number of out-of-town wedding guests diminished. "We usually hold people to a minimum guaranteed number of guests, but you can't do that under these circumstances," he said. "Everybody's got to take it on the chin a little bit."
Restaurants, on the other hand, have seen an increase in business after an initial lull right after Sept. 11. At Waterzooi in Garden City and its sister restaurant, the Victory Oyster Bar and Smokehouse, for example, Saturday night waits have increased from an average 45 minutes to an hour and a half. "I guess it's that people have to move on with their lives," said Ed Davis, one of the co-owners. "But they're still hard pressed to make it into the city."
Tom Neeley, chairman of the Hamptons Visitors Council, said interest in the Hampton Jitney's day trips into the city for Broadway shows and museums has plunged. "People just aren't taking the casual trips to New York City they might have taken," he said.
At the same time, East End hotels have filled many more rooms long beyond the usual summer season and local attractions have enjoyed record turnouts as people have headed east to get away from the city. The Southampton Inn has even booked some business conferences, as well as rooms for crews doing fashion photo shoots that had originally been planned for more distant locales like Hawaii and California.
Employment figures for Nassau and Suffolk Counties show another area where the Island has fared better than the city. Although the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate grew to 3.5 percent, the total number of jobs from October 2000 to October 2001 still grew by 10,900. The previous month's job growth was stronger, registering 16,300 more jobs from September to September using a survey taken before Sept. 11.
Gary E. Huth, a labor market analyst with the state Department of Labor, said much of the decline could be attributed to commuters who lost jobs in lower Manhattan, but also to cutbacks at LaGuardia and Kennedy Airports, which employ many Nassau County residents. "We certainly have been affected by Sept. 11," he said. "But we've done better than the rest of the country."
Mr. Huth said Long Island held relatively steady because other parts of the nation suffered heavy losses in manufacturing jobs, the kinds of jobs Long Island lost in the earlier downturn of the 1980's and early 1990's. "The diversification of the economy after that protected Long Island a little this time around," he said. "A lot of the companies that made it through that painful period also became much more competitive, leaner and meaner than before."
LIA Staffing, a subsidiary of the Long Island Association, the island's largest business organization, has scheduled workshops in response to the rising unemployment rate. "Things have changed so significantly in the last six months, people need a little help figuring out where to go," said Scott Passeser, president of LIA Staffing. The defense industry, for example, is going strong right now. "Long Island may not make the fighter planes anymore, but it's still supplying the communications systems and making new electronics for them," he said.
Telephonics Corp., in Huntington, makes radio and radar equipment for some military airplanes and has about 50 job openings, mainly for engineers. Northrop Grumman Integrated Systems in Bethpage, which produces computer systems for military planes, expects to hire up to 500 more people over the next three to five years. 
A renewed emphasis on the defense industry, along with other areas where Long Island has shown growth in recent years, such as the biomedical and health care industries, are all good signs for the Island, said Dr. Kellner, the Hofstra economics professor.
"The truth is we were slowing down long before Sept. 11, just like the rest of the country," he said. "But building on these industries where we're strong is going to lead us out of the recession and we'll start to see signs of recovery by early next year."

HEADLINE: FILM; 
The City Of Our Dreams

BYLINE:  By NANCY RAMSEY; Nancy Ramsey's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about Eisenstein's "Que Viva Mexico" on DVD.

 BODY:
ON a clear, crisp November morning, Betty Comden and Adolph Green are seated side by side in Ms. Comden's sunny apartment near Lincoln Center, high above the Hudson River. Finishing each other's sentences, adding a gentle correction here, a quick clarification there, the two 80-something writers, who have been collaborating for more than 60 years and still meet daily, moved easily through fond remembrances of their days working with Leonard Bernstein, Rosalind Russell, Judy Holliday, Gene Kelly.
 Three of the films Ms. Comden and Mr. Green wrote -- "On the Town" (1949), "The Band Wagon" (1953) and "Auntie Mame" (1958) -- will be featured in "A Wonderful Town: New York in Film," a series beginning on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. The series is made up of 13 films produced over 70 years, from Buster Keaton's "The Cameraman" (1928) to Jim Fall's "Trick" (1999), and includes "42nd Street" (1933), "It Should Happen to You" (1954) and "Manhattan" (1979). 
 A conversation with Ms. Comden and Mr. Green about "On the Town," which was a Broadway musical before it was a film, naturally led to talk of the team's days and nights as part of the Revuers, a five-person cabaret and comedy act at Max Gordon's Village Vanguard in the late 1930's. 
"I was surprised at how it took off," said Mr. Green, who still merits the description dapper.
"But you remember, Adolph," said Ms. Comden, petite and elegant. "We didn't play well out of town."
Well of course not. Theirs was a witty and wry commentary on the events of the day; they assumed in their audiences a certain urbanity, a knowledge of literature and the arts, and a willingness to join them in sending up characters who needed sending up.
The story of Comden and Green is a quintessential New York tale fit for the movies -- she came from Brooklyn and he from the Bronx, and with talent, perseverance and luck, they saw their work move to Broadway and the movies. Laurence Kardish, senior curator in the department of film and media at the Museum of Modern Art, said that Comden and Green "helped define New York for the rest of the country with their lyrics and imagery, their perennial youthfulness, their intelligence, their humor."
The "Wonderful Town" series was conceived in response to the events of Sept. 11, and there will be no "Sweet Smell of Success," no "Mean Streets," no "Taxi Driver." (The darkest film in the series is "All About Eve," which, Mr. Kardish said, he couldn't resist including because "the wit is so New York.") Instead, the films present the New York of E. B. White, who in his 1948 essay "Here Is New York" wrote of three cities: those of the commuter, the native and the settler. The greatest was the last, he wrote, "the city of final destination, the city that is a goal. . . . Commuters give the city its tidal restlessness; natives give it solidity and continuity; but the settlers give it passion."
It is the city of "42nd Street," where Ruby Keeler is plucked from obscurity to fill the tap shoes of a leading lady -- "You're going out a youngster, but you've got to come back a star"; of "On the Town," where three sailors pack a year's worth of romance and adventure into 24 hours; and of "The Cameraman," where Buster Keaton lives out a fantasy of playing ball at Yankee Stadium -- hitting, pitching and scoring a run, all solo. It is a place of serendipity and possibility, where a kindly elderly gentleman who takes a seasonal job at Macy's does turn out to be Santa Claus (the 1947 "Miracle on 34th Street"); where the working girl played by Jean Arthur rides an open-air double-decker bus one morning along Fifth Avenue and a fur coat falls on top of her ("Easy Living," 1937); where Judy Holliday sees her name above Columbus Circle and finds true love with an earnest young Jack Lemmon ("It Should Happen to You"). In a town of consummate elegance, Rosalind Russell ("Auntie Mame") descends a grand circular staircase and dazzles her young nephew with her banter and eccentricities, and one evening in Central Park, Fred Astaire and Cyd Charisse step out of a hansom cab and into one of the most graceful dances ever performed on film ("The Band Wagon").
When filmmaking left the back lots and sound stages of Hollywood for the actual streets of New York, the effect was just as magical. Mention early independent filmmaking in New York and the name Morris Engel immediately comes up; Francois Truffaut, in fact, said that France's New Wave "would never have come into being if it hadn't been for the young American Morris Engel, who showed us the way to independent production with his fine movie 'Little Fugitive.' " While "Little Fugitive" is not included in the series -- there is more tension and anxiety than the curators thought appropriate for "A Wonderful Town" -- his "Lovers and Lollipops" (1955) is. (Mr. Engel collaborated on both films with his late wife, the photographer Ruth Orkin.) "We wanted to do 'Lovers and Lollipops' as simply and economically as possible," Mr. Engel recalled recently, in his Central Park West apartment. "I didn't believe in tripods or lights, and I had limited experience dealing with actors." The story is spare, the dialogue minimal -- a little girl resists her widowed mother's new romance -- and New York, in intimate mini-portraits of Central Park, Chinatown and the Bronx Zoo, is a central character.
For the director Ang Lee, "New York is a city of endless angles. You could make 100 movies in New York and still find 100 more angles," he said by telephone from Los Angeles. In "Pushing Hands" (1992), also included in the series, a retired tai chi master from Beijing comes to live with his son and daughter-in-law in a suburb north of Manhattan and rediscovers his identity not in his family circle but in New York's Chinatown. At New York University in the early 1980's, Mr. Lee recalled, he made student films by first scouting locations, deciding which places he wanted to film, and then writing a narrative. Now working on an adaptation of "The Incredible Hulk" in Hollywood, he said he still feels "like a New York filmmaker, independent in spirit and youthful cooperation," and he plans to return to New York for post-production. "Mixing, sound, editing -- it's all along the No. 1 train." 
Location, location, location, and who needs color? In the late 1970's, New York was emerging from a fiscal crisis, but Woody Allen's neurotic writer, Isaac, in "Manhattan" opened his narration with a love letter to the city, "still a town that existed in black-and-white and pulsated to the great tunes of George Gershwin." In the film, Isaac writes: "He adored New York City. He romanticized it all out of proportion. . . . He thrived on the hustle and bustle of the crowds and the traffic. To him, New York meant beautiful women and street-smart guys who seemed to know all the angles. . . . New York was his town. And it always would be."
Just as New York will always be a town of aspiring Broadway composers and stars, of small towns within the larger metropolis, of intimate clubs in one neighborhood, then another, then still another. Mr. Fall's "Trick" is an updated, boy-meets-boy romantic comedy set in the West Village: an aspiring songwriter and a go-go dancer spend a night trying to find a place to sleep together.
"Even though I was way beyond romanticizing the city when I made my movie, it was still a magical place for me," Mr. Fall said by telephone from Los Angeles, where he now lives and works. "I very much wanted to make a movie that represented how I felt about the city and that specific niche, the piano-bar cabaret scene in the 1990's."
It's a scene that doesn't exist in the same way in Los Angeles, and for Mr. Fall it's difficult to pinpoint just how the cabaret scene there comes up short. More integrity in the New York performances, he wondered? More real wit?
Hard to say, but then, Comden and Green's revue didn't play well in Los Angeles, Chicago, Cincinnati, Pittsburgh. "You need the right spot, the right audience," said Mr. Green.
"At nightclubs people are talking, drinking, playing footsy," Ms. Comden said. "Or maybe it was the material, Adolph. It was rather sophisticated." 
"Oh, Betty," said Mr. Green, "you know it was sophisticated."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Cyd Charisse and Fred Astaire dancing in a sound-stage Central Park in "The Band Wagon." (Photofest)(pg. 11); From left: Frank Sinatra and Betty Garrett, Jules Munshin and Ann Miller, and Gene Kelly and Vera-Ellen in "On the Town." (MGM); Diane Keaton and Woody Allen in Mr. Allen's "Manhattan." (Museum of Modern Art, New York)(pg. 19)

HEADLINE: Going From Surplus to Deficit in One Year 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
LAST June, the state had a surplus of $644.8 million, left over from fiscal year 2001. The General Assembly held a special session to decide what to do with the money as they approved the 2002 budget.
 Yet in a sobering turn of events, legislators earlier this month were back in special session, buried in bitter partisan debate over how to fill a projected $300 million hole in the state's general fund $12 billion budget this year. 
 After three days of debate between legislative leaders and Gov. John G. Rowland, a compromise was reached on Nov. 16 when the General Assembly sent a bill to the governor that would reduce $200 million of the deficit. The remainder is to be addressed in February when the General Assembly convenes. 
Yet Mr. Rowland, who can reduce up to 5 percent of the budget without legislative approval, warned that he might need to make additional cuts if forthcoming economic data reveal a worsening deficit.
How did it happen? Blame it on the poor economy, state budget analysts said. Connecticut, like most of the country, has been hit hard by an economic downturn that began as early as last March and gathered steam following Sept. 11.
For each month since June, revenue from sales, income and business taxes has dropped off or not met projections, resulting in a projected $300 million deficit. In addition, the $644.8 million surplus legislators toyed with in June, turned out to be $612.9 million in September when the budget books were closed out.
"There were indications as early as March that revenue was not as robust," said Thomas Fiore, revenue chief for the State Office of Policy and Management. "Sept. 11 exacerbated trends already under way. There was slower revenue growth, but it was nothing like we experienced in the early 1990's."
Between May and September, residents lost 15,900 jobs, contributing to a slowdown in revenue from withholding tax.. An anticipated revenue growth of 6 percent from withholding tax was instead 1.1 percent between March and September. Sales tax revenue from June to September is down 2 percent from the same period last year. 
Gloomy though it seems, Connecticut doesn't have it as bad as other states. New Jersey, for example, is facing a deficit of almost $2 billion. In Connecticut, the projected deficit represents about 2.5 percent of the overall budget. In the recession of fiscal 1991 referred to by Mr. Fiore, the state faced a 14 percent deficit, or was $965 million in the red. By that time, the state had spent the entire budget reserve fund, also known as the Rainy Day Fund. By law, the state must maintain a budget reserve fund equal to 5 percent of its general fund appropriations each year. The governor has made it clear that the $594.7 million Rainy Day Fund was off limits for the current crisis. Instead, he pressed for cuts.
"It's drizzling, it's not pouring," Mr. Rowland said at a news conference in October where he nonetheless made the case for a special session of the legislature. Democratic leaders resisted the idea.
Democrat Kevin B. Sullivan, president pro tempore of the State Senate, proclaimed a special session "would be a disaster" and urged the governor to leave the topic of revenue shortfall for February, the regular session of the legislature. Yet there was no denying the numbers. The Democrats conceded that when State Comptroller Nancy Wyman, a Democrat, sent a letter to the governor saying she too believed the deficit should be addressed sooner rather than later.
The governor urged the legislative leadership of both parties to create a deficit reduction package in preparation for the special session on Nov. 13. He had already cut about $30 million under his authority. When the leadership hadn't reached a compromise by Nov. 12, Mr. Rowland threatened to lay off state employees if an acceptable plan were not reached by Nov. 16, the end of the special session. Some Democratic legislators criticized him for the remark.
"We don't think it's a great idea in a time of economic crisis to tell people they're going to lose their jobs," Mr. Sullivan said.
The finger pointing was just beginning. Over the course of four days, the budget battle was waged strictly along party lines. The Republicans lobbied for steep cuts across the board following the governor's lead to put "everything on the table."
"The pain should be shared," said Robert M. Ward, Republican Senate minority leader.
Meanwhile, the Democrats hatched their own plan, one that Mr. Sullivan said, "pinches more than pains." It called for the long-term borrowing of about $107 million for various projects, including $50 million to make interest payments on local school projects, projects that would have been paid for in cash out of the surplus prior to the deficit. The plan also proposed about $133 million in cuts, skimming from programs and finding savings in energy accounts where actual costs turned out to be less than projected.
The Republicans balked. Mr. Rowland called the budget a "scam full of gimmicks." The real savings amounted to about $84 million; other cuts were for one-time rather than on-going programs costs or to departments already operating at a deficit, said the governor's budget chief, Marc S. Ryan.
The Democrats, who control both houses of the General Assembly, nevertheless drafted a bill of the plan at midnight on Nov. 14 and vowed to pass it. Dean Pagani, the governor's spokesman, mentioned the word veto and countered that the governor had a veto-safe margin in the House.
"It's a fiscally prudent plan that found savings with the minimum of damage to programs," said Moira K. Lyons, speaker of the House. Mr. Ryan lambasted the Democrat's plan.
The next day, moments before a House vote, Mr. Rowland requested a meeting with his budget director, Republican leaders, Ms. Lyons and Mr. Sullivan. What emerged was a compromise that reduced long-term borrowing to $63.6 million and made deeper, across-the-board cuts totaling $136.5 million. The rest of the deficit would be addressed, legislators said, in February. The bill passed by 121-17 in the House and 24-11 in the Senate. Several Republicans couldn't bring themselves to sign it.
"Only in government can you leave a $100 million hole in your finances and call it a solution," said Senator Louis C. DeLuca, a Republican from Woodbury and Senate minority leader. "Where I come from, when you don't have enough money to cover your expenses, you reduce your spending; you don't turn around and put everything on a credit card."
The Democrats said programs were safe and what's more, Mr. Rowland guaranteed no layoffs.
The session fell short by $100 million in addressing the deficit, but Mr. Rowland said, "I'll take two-thirds of a loaf any day."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Jugglers as Idiots
 Gyro, Pyro and Walter, jugglers known as the Flaming Idiots, will give two performances today at 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. at Fairfield University's Quick Center for the Arts. 
 Rather than keeping plates, clubs and balls aloft as most jugglers do, they toss swords, fire and each other with abandon. Some of the gags will be appreciated by adults more than the children (from 4 to 10 years old) for whom the show is recommended. Tickets are $10, children $8. 
"The Mystery of King Tut," a colorfully mounted performance by Theatreworks/USA about Howard Carter, discoverer of the boy king's tomb, is scheduled tomorrow at 10 a.m., suitable for children in grades 2 through 7. Tickets are $5.
Reservations and directions: (203) 254-4010.

Bushnell Expansion
The Bushnell in Hartford, one of New England's largest and best known performing arts centers, has completed a $45 million expansion, which opens tomorrow.
Adjacent to the existing 2,800-seat William H. Mortensen Theater, a new 90,000-square-foot addition has been built, containing the 907-seat Maxwell and Ruth Belding Theater, a cafe, a gift shop, classrooms, restrooms, private dining and public reception space.
An open house is scheduled on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. when the public may take free guided tours of the building and attend performances by more than 60 arts groups.
Celebratory events scheduled throughout the week begin tomorrow with an exhibition of archival photographs and posters tracing the history of the building and its extraordinary contribution to Connecticut's cultural life.
Since 1930, the Bushnell has housed a myriad of programs from lectures to P.T.A. meetings, from children's theater to political conventions and cooking classes. But its role in playing host to world-class concerts, theater, grand opera, dance and comedy has been its forte.
On Thursday at 8 p.m., the Connecticut Forum will present "The Power of Music," a panel discussion with Beverly Sills, coloratura soprano of the Metropolitan and New York City Opera Companies and current chairman of Lincoln Center; Bob Weir, co-founder of the Grateful Dead; Nicholas Payton, the award-winning trumpeter, and Trey Anastasio, the lead vocalist, guitarist and composer for Phish. Call (860) 509-0909 for tickets priced from $25 to $50.
Information (860) 987-5900 or www.bushnell.org.

Antiques This Weekend
Antiquarius, sponsored by the Historical Society of Greenwich, is Friday and Saturday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is $15. Lunch and tea will be served daily from noon to 4 p.m.
In addition to paintings, prints, jewelry, European, American and Asian furniture and decorative accessories, visitors to the Greenwich Civic Center on Harding Road will also see woolwork portraits embroidered by sailors at sea, Quimper ware from France, English library furniture, fine leather bindings, opalescent glass curtain pins with pewter shanks and Chinese Canton enamel shell dishes.
A gallery tour of the more than 40 booths will be conducted on Friday at 9:30 a.m. by Johanna McBrien, editor-in-chief of the Catalogue of Antiques and Fine Art Magazine. The $25 ticket includes a continental breakfast.

Woodham Exhibition
Jean Woodham of Westport, sculptor of modernist forms in welded steel, brass and bronze is having an exhibition of her work through Dec. 9, indoors and outdoors at the PMW Gallery on 530 Roxbury Road in Stamford. Ms. Woodham will be present at a reception today from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.

Understanding Russia
Senior State Department officials and local experts in the worlds of business and academia will participate in a town meeting titled "The New Russia: Its Role in World Peace and Security, in Business and Economic Development, and its Ties to the United States."
The event, sponsored by the United States Department of State, the World Affairs Council and Saint Joseph College in West Hartford where it will take place, is scheduled on Wednesday from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m.
Admission is free but registration is required: (860) 594-4100.

Gay Men's Chorus
The music of Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" provides the background for "Martha Stewart's Christmas Party," and "Away in a Manger," presented in the manner of Lawrence Welk, becomes "The Manger Polka" in the hands of the Connecticut Gay Men's Chorus.
The two numbers are part of the group's holiday presentation titled "I'll Be Home for Christmas."
Performances are on Saturday at 8 p.m. at Ives Auditorium of Western Connecticut State University in Danbury; next Sunday at 2 p.m. and 5 p.m. at Cheney Hall in Manchester; Dec. 8 at 8 p.m. at the Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven, and Dec. 9 at 4 p.m. at the Quick Center for the Arts at Fairfield University. Tickets are $20 and $25. Information: (800) 644-2462.

Life of the Puritans
Harsh winters and the stark life of the Puritans will be recreated on Friday from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. at the Henry Whitfield State Museum in Guilford.
The three-story, post-medieval style house, built of granite in 1639, is said to be the oldest in the state, containing many 17th-century furnishings from England and New England.
In addition to touring the house, visitors will view an exhibition called "Feast, Famine and Fable: The Real Story of Thanksgiving, Christmas and Winter in Puritan New England."
Apparently Thanksgiving was not the celebration it is today, nor was it held annually if at all in some years. Warm apple cider will be distributed to visitors who may browse the gift shop. Admission is $3.50 for adults, $2.50 for people over 59 and college students, $2 for children 6 to 17. Information: (203) 453-2457.

Yale Opera Class
Sherrill Milnes, the renowned Metropolitan Opera baritone and international opera star, will conduct a public master class presented by Yale Opera tomorrow in New Haven.
The class begins at 7 p.m. at Trinity Lutheran Church at Orange and Wall Streets. Admission is $8, students $5.
Music by David Lang, co-founder of New York's Bang on a Can Festival of new music, will be performed on Thursday at 8 p.m. in Battell Chapel on the Yale campus. The So Percussion group will present his "So-Called Laws of Nature," and his "Fire and Forget" will be performed by Yale music students.
A retrospective of Martin Bresnick's work and that of other Yale composers will also be heard. Admission is free.
Information and directions: (203) 432-4158. ELEANOR CHARLES
