HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Waterfront Projects Planned North of Jersey City

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
TIMES may be uncertain, but Steven J. Pozycki says he is sure. His company, SJP Properties, is going to build a 550,000-square-foot office building on the Hoboken waterfront on speculation that the property and location will attract corporate clients.
 He has reason for his optimism. The new building will be the twin to one nearing completion at the site that leased up rapidly, luring the venerable publisher John Wiley & Sons from Manhattan. 
 Meanwhile, Emanuel Stern, president of Hartz Mountain Industries, is moving forward with plans to build five office buildings of various sizes, a parking deck and a hotel at its Lincoln Harbor development on the waterfront in Weehawken by the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel. While Mr. Stern is not ready to put a shovel in the ground without an anchor tenant for each building, all he needs is to lease 40,000 square feet of space to get the smallest of his office projects under way. 
Although Jersey City remains the largest location for office buildings on the west bank of the Hudson River, the 14-story buildings in Hoboken and the plans in Weehawken, where Hartz already has 1.8 million square feet of office, retail and residential space, indicate that locations to the north are attracting attention as well.
TRANSPORTATION problems between Jersey City and Lower Manhattan as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center may help to make projects farther up the coast more attractive, observed Donald Eisen, executive managing director of Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey, a part of the brokerage and services company. The attack closed the direct connection between Jersey City and the Trade Center via the PATH tubes, forcing commuters to take ferries or roundabout routes on the remaining PATH route and city subways.
"Those projects may benefit from the closing of the last PATH station in Jersey City," Mr. Eisen said.
But he added that the great rush to find space since Sept. 11 has passed and that companies are thinking further into the future before making commitments to occupy space. "We are in a more thoughtful time," he said. "If people can delay making a decision, they will delay."
Given the location of Waterfront Corporate Park -- a short walk from the Hoboken rail, PATH and bus terminal -- Mr. Pozycki likes to talk about transportation. Rail lines from across northern New Jersey converge at the Hoboken terminal, with the remaining PATH lines providing access to Midtown Manhattan and a ferry available for trips to downtown. 
The project also sits near the Hudson-Bergen light rail line, which is scheduled to reach Hoboken from Jersey City next summer, adding north-south transportation of the existing east-west infrastructure. SJP Properties executives say they expect New York Waterway, the operator of existing ferries across the Hudson River, including one to Lincoln Harbor, to add to its service from Hoboken to Midtown once the new office buildings are occupied in the winter of 2002. Construction of the second building is already under way.
Mr. Pozycki argues that transportation on the surface of the Hudson is a better answer to the region's commuting problems than trying to find billions of dollars to build an underwater tunnel. "Water transportation can be added to quickly in response to need," he said. "You add bigger boats or faster boats as the demand grows."
The renewed emphasis on ferry service is also an indication of how New Jersey has reconnected with the river along a stretch where decaying docks formerly separated people from the water. In the compact city of Hoboken, the waterfront revival has transformed a drab industrial ruin to an attractive residential area, replete with restored houses, shops and restaurants.
Decades ago, River Street on the waterfront was lined with bars where dockworkers and others met, drank and fought. "This place was the Barbary Coast in the 1950's," Mr. Pozycki said.
Now, the two office buildings will be at 111 and 121 River Street and will be connected to the river by a tree-lined pedestrian walkway. Jutting far out into the river is a pier that has been rebuilt by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as an urban park. Another pier to the north is being dismantled and will be replaced by a second park. "The city is rediscovering its waterfront as a result of the quality of the investments by the Port Authority," Mr. Pozycki said.
The two piers and the waterfront walkway total 15 acres of parkland in front of the building and, not incidentally, assure tenants excellent views of Midtown Manhattan. The attractiveness of the site and the transportation links are reasons Mr. Pozycki and his partner on the project, the Newark-based Prudential Insurance, are willing to build on speculation, at a time when the economy is clearly slowing. "There is no place else in the region where I and my partners at Prudential would be willing to spec a 500,000-square-foot office building," Mr. Pozycki said.
As Mr. Stern of Hartz Mountain likes to point out, it was his company that started redeveloping the New Jersey waterfront when it began Lincoln Harbor in 1982. He said he is prepared to move forward on the final phase of the project as soon as he signs some tenants. 
Those plans call for two connected office towers totaling 855,000 square feet, a separate 200,000-square-foot building and another that will have 90,000 square feet of space. Also part of package are a 135-room all-suites hotel that is positioned so that it will not interfere with the view of Manhattan that is available to motorists on the highway that twists down from the high bluffs of Weehawken to the Lincoln Tunnel.
Mr. Stern said two of the proposed buildings -- one of 450,000 square feet and another of 405,000 -- have been granted final approvals and could be ready for occupancy in a year. "Lincoln Harbor's new phase can be delivered within 12 months of lease signing because the buildings have been designed, engineered and approved, whereas a project of this nature would normally take up to two years to complete," he said.
"Lincoln Harbor is a seven-minute trip from Midtown Manhattan by ferry and it is a refreshing trip," said Michael T. Cohen, president of the Williams Real Estate Company, which has been hired to market the project. He said he expected the riverside buildings to be a lower cost alternative to Manhattan tenants who have been squeezed by rising rents in recent years.
He said tenants faced with rates between $50 and $70 a square foot in Midtown could expect to save 10 to 15 percent by crossing the river.
Midtown was the relevant market to look at because of its proximity to Weehawken, he said. "Our site is for overflow from Midtown, just as Jersey City was for the overflow from the financial district downtown."
BECAUSE many of the tenants displaced from downtown have resettled -- often as subtenants -- in Midtown, the New Jersey office building may not find tenants until normal growth resumes, Mr. Eisen said.
"A lot of people from downtown went to Midtown, which buoyed the Midtown market but does not leave much room for growth," he said. "If growth resumes, it favors the waterfront."
Mr. Stern describes Lincoln Harbor, which has office space, residential buildings, an existing hotel, restaurants and other retail space, as a "mixed use, low rise, urban campus." He said the ferry link between the development and Midtown Manhattan had grown in importance since Sept. 11, given restrictions on tunnel traffic. 
"The ferry works," he said. "They have become a permanent part of life since Sept. 11."
And, although no one wants to appear to be profiting from the attack and its aftermath, said Mr. Stern, whose company has investments in New York City as well as in New York, it was almost inevitable that many workers who had been downtown will not want to return because of frightening memories and fears of further attacks.
"Many of the people who worked there on Sept. 11 do not want to go back," he said. "That is a problem and an opportunity for the city of New York."

HEADLINE: The Smart Set Wastes Brainpower on Socializing 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Viewed from my 25 years as a Mensa member, "Hanging Out With the Smart Set" (Nov. 18) is an apropos title for the New Jersey chapter, or indeed of the national organization. "Hanging out" indicates that our predominant interest is in social gatherings. 
"Smart" applies to our cleverness in games and puzzles. 
 What has been disappointing to me and a very small minority of members is what seems to be a lack ofwhat we had expected to be a forum for intelligent and constructive debates about the tough problems facing the nation and the world.
The Times article ends with a Mensan saying "we have our priorities straight. We're searching for happiness." Fine, but just as as individuals and as a nation, we feel impelled to divert a small portion of our wealth to the welfare of the less fortunate, should not Mensans divert some small portion of their brainpower to working on solutions to the many serious problems facing the nation and the world in this century? Is there a way to avert the predictable ill effects of global warming without damaging our economy as our politicians fear? Are there measures in addition to our military actions that we should be taking to address the root causes of the terrorism that is a hazard to our well-being? With a finite planet can we continue with an never ending growth of population and utilization of natural resources? It is regretful that Mensan brain power is dormant on such matters.

JOHN BURTON
Washington

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; 
A Shelter Plan Wins in Court, But Residents Aren't Swayed

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
Pigeons roost in rows along the yellow brick building at 89-111 Porter Avenue in eastern Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Sea gulls murmur. But this is a deceptive calm.
 Last fall, the Doe Fund won a 22-year, $176 million city contract to transform the building, an abandoned knitting factory, into a 400-bed shelter for homeless men. The plans have been tangled in legal and political turmoil since. But now, the Doe Fund, a nonprofit organization for helping the homeless, is finally free to start building. 
 On Nov. 14, State Supreme Court in Brooklyn dismissed a case brought by a coalition of residents, politicians and businesses to block the development on the ground that the impact on the neighborhood had not been adequately assessed.
George T. McDonald, founder and president of the fund, said he expected to start construction in two months and to open the shelter in early 2003.
But Martin S. Needelman, a lawyer representing the coalition, said his clients were considering an appeal. Residents say their neighborhood has little to offer the homeless. "There's no place for them to come out and have a snack," said Douglas McKinnon, who has lived in the area since 1990.
The site is surrounded by large, low buildings that belong to candy makers, bakeries, tortilla factories and import-export companies. The nearest shopping strip is about a mile away. "Can you imagine 400 men down on their luck coming to an area like this and thinking life would get any better?" said Donna Hoffman, an owner of a soft drink bottler that has been in the neighborhood since 1946. 
Mr. McDonald, however, said the shelter would not depend on local amenities. "We have everything that everybody needs inside of the facility," he said.
Residents of this largely low-income, Latino area also worry about protecting what to them is a fragile peace. "We have enough problems keeping the prostitutes from around here," said Mr. McKinnon, who has three sons.
Local business owners said the shelter would hinder the economic progress of the area, which the state designated as an economic development zone in 1998. They are mainly concerned about a lack of parking spaces and increased foot traffic that could disrupt the careful choreography of trucks and forklifts that currently dominates the sidewalks.
Since the court spurned their claims, both Ms. Hoffman and Sanford Wiener, an owner of a candy maker that employs 75 people, said they were considering leaving.
"We hear their concerns," Mr. McDonald said. "We are very willing to work with them."
He maintained that the shelter would be a boon to the neighborhood. 
"We'll help clean it up," he said. "There are prostitution and drugs there now. That won't be there when we get there."
It will also help the city. The shelter would replace roughly half the beds at the 30th Street Men's Shelter near Bellevue Hospital, which the city needs to relocate before New York University can use the land for its planned East River Science Park.
 ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photos: An abandoned knitting factory on Porter Avenue would be outfitted with 400 beds for homeless men. (Shannon Stapleton for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; 
A Raised Voice by a Noted Feminist, This Time Over Rental Politics

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Kate Millett, the feminist author and artist, is not a creature of the night by choice. She believes that city agents are stationed outside her door, ready to boot her from her outsized loft at 295 Bowery.
 "The city dogs are waiting for me," Ms. Millett said last week in her fifth-floor walk-up, between Houston and East First Streets, decorated very much like the bohemian womb one would expect. "But they don't work after-hours, so I only go out at night." 
 For three years, housing officials have been trying to evict Ms. Millett from her 2,400-square-foot home, where the city moved her some 30 years ago after condemning her rental across the street. Her rent, about $600 a month, covers both her loft and a third-floor art studio, which also has 2,400 square feet.
"This is about comparable space," Ms. Millett said between drags of cigarettes, her mood alternating between warm laughter and cold rage.
Once the darling of women's studies programs, Ms. Millett, whose books include "Sexual Politics" and "Mother Millett," eludes the spotlight these days. But at 67, she remains as strident as ever -- this time as the last holdout against the city's effort to raze her home in the name of urban renewal.
The two other artists who live in the building have accepted the city's offer to relocate to nearby lofts. Ms. Millett is fixing up her studio for coming gallery shows. "The day they wreck it, I'll be swinging on the wrecking ball," she said.
Plans to develop the largely vacant area have been on the drawing board for decades. With support from community activists, the city is on the verge of making final the Cooper Square Urban Renewal Project.
The project, approved this month by the City Planning Commission, calls for building about 700 market-rate and low-income apartments, ground-floor stores, and a community center with a pool and gymnasium. Final approval by the City Council is expected by the end of the year.
But before any demolition can begin, Ms. Millett must first be evicted. The city has offered her a 1,700-square-foot loft at 59 East Fourth Street, less than three-eighths the size of her current space. The rent would remain roughly the same.
"That's nothing to sneeze at, when you consider that there are many people moving into 400 square feet for $1,700," said Steve Herrick, executive director of the Cooper Square Committee, an advocacy group formed by residents in 1959.
But Ms. Millett said her books alone could probably fill a small East Village apartment. She has also amassed a large archive of artwork and personal papers, including an unpublished manuscript about 295 Bowery, a former brothel where a half-dozen demimondaines are said to have committed suicide more than a century ago. 
"It's really impossible to fit everything into that space," said Ms. Millett, who has hired a lawyer to fight the eviction. "We're going to hold out." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; 
A Neighborhood Beacon Gets a Last-Minute Rescue

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MATLOFF 

 BODY:
For the people of West Harlem, the Hamilton Grange Library, at 145th Street and Amsterdam Avenue is not just a place to borrow books.
 For a neighborhood with many illegal drugs and few bookshops, the imposing 96-year-old limestone building is more like a safe haven. Parents know that their children will stay out of trouble there. Lonely elderly residents know that there they escape from unheated apartments. Students use the computers for research. It is an oasis for avid readers who cannot afford books. 
 On Dec. 14, the library will close its doors for much-needed renovations, which could last up to two years. Money for a temporary site had been in the city budget. But a month ago, residents learned that the money was eliminated because of budget cuts after the Sept. 11 attack. City officials said they could not even afford to put a trailer on an empty lot as an interim measure or provide a shuttle bus to take residents to another branch.
"Losing the library was of serious concern," said Daryl G. Bloodsaw, president of the 146th Street Block Association. "It would have been terrible for people here."
Led by Community Board 9, local leaders quickly swung into action to find an 11th-hour solution. They organized a search in which local residents went door-to-door, canvassing churches and landlords in pursuit of an affordable spot. Some residents even offered floors in their brownstones.
An unlikely solution finally came on Monday: an empty storefront on the ground floor of a co-op apartment building, 704 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 145th Street.
The space is a tiny 700 square feet, one-third what was originally sought. But as a favor to the community, the co-op that owns the building reduced the monthly rent to below the market rate. (The exact figure is still being negotiated.)
Members of Community Board 9 credit City Councilman Stanley Michels with saving the day by exerting considerable pressure on the city library administration to accept the deal. The city was reluctant to accept the plan because it did not want to spend additional money.
"We're ecstatic," said George W. Goodwill, chairman of Community Board 9. "The library provides a vital service due to the deep economic inequalities here. People don't want their children to fall through the cracks. The library gives them self-esteem and a safe place to do homework with some type of supervision."
The library is scheduled to move into its temporary space in January. The spot requires little work beyond the installation of shelves and lines for computers and telephones.
The renovation of the permanent structure, the first in 30 years, includes installing bathrooms for the disabled, building a new community room with performance space and improving computers and elevators.
 JUDITH MATLOFF

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; 
A Brief Appearance by a SoHo Star Draws Mixed Reviews

BYLINE:  By HANNAH M. WALLACE 

 BODY:
When Joe Amrhein, a Conceptual painter, moved to Williamsburg 13 years ago, the neighborhood was teeming with artists but there were few galleries. A handful of alternative spaces like Brand Name Damages, Minor Injury and Test-Site, came and went. Other galleries like Pierogi, which Mr. Amrhein opened in 1994, stuck around. Today, Williamsburg has about 30 galleries, many of them artist-run. 
 But no one expected a major Manhattan gallery to set up shop. Then, on Sept. 7, the dealer Jeffrey Deitch, who has shown such high-profile artists as Vanessa Beecroft, Damian Loeb and Cecily Brown at his SoHo gallery, Deitch Projects, opened a 4,000-square-foot space on North 11th Street. 
 The opening work, a multimedia installation by the online collective Fakeshop, attracted a large crowd and created a buzz in the New York art world. But before Deitch Brooklyn could make much of an impression, it abruptly closed its doors three weeks after it opened. 
Mr. Deitch said he closed the gallery because of what he described as "problems with the leaseholder" and uncertainty after the Sept. 11 attack.
"I was planning an experimental program that I would've had to subsidize," he said. "After the 11th, I said, 'Let's try this again when we're more confident about the economic environment.' "
Jeff Gompertz, the founder of Fakeshop and the former tenant, said the original plan was for Deitch to rent most of the space. "We had a gentleman's agreement that Deitch would eventually take over the lease," said Mr. Gompertz. "It's still very open for him to do that." 
Deitch's brief star turn in Williamsburg highlights an important local divide. Some artists, proud of Williamsburg's reputation as an alternative art community, saw his arrival as the start of the neighborhood's "Chelseafication," a reference to the sleek galleries that have transformed western Chelsea. Others welcomed Deitch, knowing it would attract important collectors and dealers to smaller, lesser-known spaces.
"Williamsburg galleries serve as cultural centers where artists come to exchange ideas," said Gregory Volk, a critic for Art in America who has lived in Williamsburg since 1987. "The blue-chip Chelsea galleries -- and galleries like Deitch -- use a completely different model. They're focused on selling the art. If that model were to come here, it would be a disaster for Williamsburg."
Others expressed less concern about the arrival of Manhattan galleries. Christian Viveros-Faune, an owner of the Williamsburg gallery Roebling Hall, said he hoped Deitch returned to the neighborhood. 
"The more serious galleries around, the better," Mr. Viveros-Faune said. "The neighborhood is changing, but I'd much rather Jeffrey Deitch than Warsaw," he added, referring to a new local nightclub.
And some artists suggested that Deitch Brooklyn did, at least briefly, bring a new audience to the neighborhood. "It was much more the Chelsea crowd," said Eric Heist, a founder of Momenta Art, another Williamsburg gallery. "People we didn't recognize."
 HANNAH M. WALLACE

HEADLINE: COPING; 
Their Demeanors Don't Betray The Desperation

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
IN her worst weeks, Wai Chun Ng at least had a $50 paycheck. After 40 years of sewing in Chinatown factories, job cuts had reduced Ms. Ng to working as a finisher, earning a penny for every two buttons she cut the thread on. Last month, when Ms. Ng finally lost her job, she turned to the Red Cross to help put food on the table for herself and her retired husband.
 Ms. Ng, a small, soft-spoken 61-year-old woman, told her story as she sat in the Chinatown office of Local 23-25, the union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. Her words were interpreted by Lana Cheung, the local's education director. 
 Ms. Cheung has spent the last two months trying to reassure her local's laid-off workers, trying to teach them about labor law and unemployment benefits. They are mostly Chinese women with children who speak no English, have no formal education and few marketable skills. Or, like Ms. Ng, they face age discrimination after years of low-wage jobs and lives confined to Chinatown.
But Ms. Ng said she was grateful that those years let her and her husband support four children in a government-subsidized Chinatown apartment. "I pay the rent," she said. "I buy the food. Not a luxury life."
Ms. Ng is among the 79,000 people whose jobs have disappeared from the city in the wake of Sept. 11, government officials say, a number higher than almost anyone anticipated.
Many New Yorkers have been noble since Sept. 11. But on Dec. 2, 32,800 families in the city will face the five-year federal welfare limit, even as thousands of twin tower victims scramble emotionally and financially, and yet untold numbers succumb to a faltering economy, creating the possible danger of competing victimhood. Still, possibly, the stories and the faces behind the losses can be a guide, practically and spiritually.
In Chinatown, to pick one place, the garment industry has been severely damaged since Sept. 11, because stores have canceled or postponed orders, workers are unable to endure the foul air, trucks are unable to get through. As many as 7,000 of the 12,000 Chinatown garment workers have lost their jobs, and most of the factories there are running at less than 50 percent capacity, the workers' union says. The average Chinatown garment worker is losing $943 in wages each month. Most of the city's garment workers are immigrants who earn less than $16,000 a year. 
Some qualify for disaster aid, some do not, Ms. Cheung said. Those who qualify must live in Manhattan and have worked in factories south of Canal Street, like Ms. Ng. "Asian people are very shy," said Ms. Cheung, a social worker by training. "We don't want to let our problems out. But we are having a terrible time. The tourists want to see Chinatown, but we need help." 
Ms. Cheung sat with Ms. Ng and Waichee Tang, another laid-off worker, at 193 Centre Street. The bustling sidewalks outside the door were superficially cheerful, stands bursting with fruit, vegetables, fresh fish. Children's silk outfits and toys dangled from the doorways of tiny shops. But the women walking in the door, carrying babies or stooped from years of grueling work, have few prospects. As union members and American citizens, Ms. Tang and Ms. Ng are relatively lucky.
Ms. Tang, 54, said 2 of her 30 co-workers at the textile factory Zoom Zoom in Chinatown who lost their jobs have found work. In her last year of work, as a seamstress and an inspector, she made $400 a week.
Her husband is in bad health and has no medical insurance, and her 25-year-old son, who lives with them in Brooklyn, had lost his computer job even before Sept. 11. 
"It's difficult," Ms. Tang said. "I worry. I am scared."
She, Ms. Cheung and Ms. Ng said they liked the garment industry campaign started last month by business executives and union officials to promote clothing made in New York. A red, white and blue logo saying "Proudly Made in New York" can now be found on tens of thousands of garments sold by the Bill Blass Collection, Nicole Miller, Elie Tahari, Brooks Brothers, Leslie Fay and Lafayette 148. 
Those names are easier to remember than those of Wai Chun Ng, Waichee Tang and Lana Cheung.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
What the Fed Can't Do About This Recession

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
MONETARY policy could not be better. The Federal Reserve has reduced interest rates so aggressively that lenders are almost giving away money. The economy should be rising again in response to so much easy credit. It is not rising, but there is some response, which helps to explain why the current, potentially severe recession is still a mild one. 
 This is an uncommon recession. It has arrived after a period of great plenty and excessive investment; surfeit seems to reign and indebtedness surely does. People turn away from the marketplace unless the offer is truly tempting. Car sales, the most glaring example, would not be booming today, or even above water, without zero-interest loans, which the Fed makes possible. Without its rate cuts, the car companies could not borrow cheaply enough to bear the losses from zero-interest lending for as long as they have. 
 Similar dynamics show up elsewhere, in each case helping to prevent the recession that started last spring from producing more hardship and unemployment. Because of the rate cuts, for example, consumer confidence held up until September, when layoffs finally unnerved the public, according to Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's monthly consumer surveys. 
Home sales and home construction owe their persistent strength to 30-year mortgages at 6 percent interest, unimaginable last fall. As mortgage rates fell, families that already owned homes refinanced them and pocketed the savings from the lower monthly payments. Or they took out low-interest home equity loans and paid off high-interest credit card debt, again freeing money that they either saved or used for another stab at spending -- perhaps the last stab.
Some economists have tried to quantify the benefit to the economy from the Fed's 10 rate cuts since Jan. 1. The gross domestic product, the standard measure of economic activity, contracted in the third quarter at an annual rate of 0.4 percent. Once all the data is collected for that quarter, the rate of decline will probably turn out to be 1 to 2 percent, according to Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist at Deutsche Bank North America.
"That 1 to 2 percent would have been 3 to 4 percent" without the cuts, he said.
The rate cuts have helped in other ways to keep the economy from coming apart. The dollar, for example, has been rising against other currencies, making American products more expensive overseas and thus less competitive. But the rise would have been even greater without the sharp decline in interest rates. Low rates make dollar investments less desirable, so presumably fewer people buy dollars, although in these uncertain times there is still plenty of demand for the safety of America's currency.
Then there is the spread, which provides what may be the most important stimulus from the Fed's aggressive rate-cutting. The Fed manipulates the so-called federal funds rate, the interest that banks and other financial institutions pay to borrow money from each other for the short term. These borrowings are then lent to companies and individuals. With the federal funds rate now at 2 percent, down from 6.5 percent on Jan. 1, the nation's lenders have plenty of incentive to borrow short term at 2 percent and to lend long term at 4.5 percent or higher.
Mortgages offer a particularly juicy spread, and if potential customers hesitate -- because they are nervous about their jobs and about home prices -- then lenders can lure them by lowering mortgage rates a few more notches while still reaping an adequate spread. With the federal funds rate at its current level, the 30-year mortgage can go as low as 4 or 4.5 percent, in the view of Albert Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist.
LIKE many forecasters, Mr. Wojnilower expects the economy to rebound by next summer. The Fed's rate-cutting will help to make that happen, he and others say. But there are two areas where monetary policy normally works to lift the economy out of hard times, yet is not working now. 
Businesses usually take advantage of falling rates to step up investment. That spending normally gives the economy a powerful lift. But in this recession, there is so much excess capacity, thanks to the excesses of the 1990's, that companies resist. They fail to see a gain in profits from new investment, no matter how cheap credit gets. And the shock from the bursting of the high-tech bubble makes everyone a wary and reluctant borrower.
The Federal Reserve, in sum, lacks the power this time to lift America out of recession. Help is essential -- from government spending or lower oil prices or some wondrous new technology or economic revival abroad. And soon, before the federal funds rate gets to zero.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Land Rover Franchise Opens With a Gift to Red Cross

BYLINE:  By Marek Fuchs

 BODY:
Though the economy is retrenching, Thomas Coughlin is not. Already an owner of nine auto franchises, he just opened a 10th: Land Rover Larchmont/New Rochelle, at 1 East Main Street. 
"All of our projects are moving forward," said Mr. Coughlin, who explained that the opening had been in the works for years and, besides, his conviction is to build in slow times to reap the full benefits of the recovery.
 "There is an old concept on Wall Street about weak hands and strong hands," said Howard Mosher, the president of Land Rover North America. "Weak hands give up in hard times, but strong hands don't and it's the strong hands that do better long-term." 
 At the showroom's grand opening, Mr. Coughlin presented the American Red Cross of Westchester with a new Land Rover. 
Mr. Coughlin said that to promote the opening of the showroom, he wanted to donate a vehicle. "For decades and decades the Red Cross has been there for us," he said. "Why not be there for them?" Marek Fuchs

HEADLINE: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; 
A Parents' Party? Make a Wish

BYLINE:  By Bob Morris 

 BODY:
Thanksgiving has come and gone, but I'm still getting over Veterans Day. Two of the most stoic veterans I know, my parents, who have endured marriage despite the odds, got hitched on Nov. 11, 1951. For their 50th wedding anniversary, something elaborate was in order. But what? A surprise party at the Rainbow Room? Nope. We already did that for my mom's 70th birthday -- for 75 guests -- three years ago, when we felt flush with the economy.
 A big festive dinner for 50? Nope. All their best friends have migrated to Florida. Go somewhere warm? Well, Mom's fragile health doesn't allow her to fly, and my dad feels he eats too much on cruises. The old school Greenbrier resort in West Virginia? Too far. The Equinox in Vermont? Too cold. 
 The milestone had become a millstone. 
Who isn't in the middle of something like this these days? Never mind the immense logistics of holiday planning. Anyone with aging parents now has arrived at a place where milestones to be marked are coming up more frequently than jury duty. First, it's a 60th birthday, then a 25th anniversary, and it just keeps going from there into eternity, it seems. 
For the first half of our lives, parents gave us the parties, and now it's time for us to give them back, even if nobody is actually feeling up to it. "I often ask myself, who are these events really for?" said Sonya Friedman, a psychologist who offers advice as "The Party Doctor" on Party 411, a Web site. "Very often, the person you're honoring has a completely different idea of the ideal occasion. You give them a big party and suddenly they're stuck worrying if everyone's having a good time." She suggests thinking more "out of the box" when planning.
It seems like good advice, except for the fact that there are often strident siblings involved, and they might not see it the way you do. I have one friend who thought that renting a house on Cape Cod for the whole family was enough of a way to mark his parents' 50th anniversary. But his sister thought he and his brother also needed to plan a huge dinner party for friends of the family and buy Mom a diamond necklace.
"And my sister's the one who doesn't have a job," he said. 
Another friend has an "extremist" older sister who is tyrannical about family events. "Three years before my parents' 25th anniversary, when I was totally broke," she said, "my sister made all the siblings contribute to a fund in the bank for a surprise party, which wasn't exactly a success, since my mother arrived in a house dress."
Next week, in between shuttling around for all the holidays, her entire family is required to attend the 40th birthday party the extremist sister is giving for her husband in Palo Alto, Calif. "I volunteered to make the centerpieces and got two florists involved," said my friend, a former caterer. "But my sister didn't like what we were planning and fired me."
She's in charge of doing a cheer with pompoms instead. 
Novelty, of course, is always part of the proceedings. Magazines are filled with bossy, time-consuming ideas -- producing a video documentary, for instance, or making a memory quilt or digging up the budget and menu from the original wedding to display.
My favorite "out of the box" option is a comedy cruise departing from Sydney, Australia, which puts the anniversary celebrants through a ceremony in which they are "sentenced" to 50 more years of marriage as padlocks are placed on their fingers and "Yesterday" is played instead of a hymn. 
In her role as party doctor, Dr. Friedman, who used to have a show on CNN called "Sonya Live," and now has a private practice in Birmingham, Mich., monitors a good deal of pre-traumatic stress for families planning anniversary parties. Should there be a Money Tree for guests to help pay for the party? (No.) If one sibling is doing all the organizing, should he or she be allowed to contribute less? (Maybe.) For anniversary couples who don't get along? Invite as many guests as possible to keep spirits high. 
The whole thing really scratches her blackboard. "Give me a facelift instead of a party any time," Dr. Friedman said. 
But what if your unassuming parents would actually like a party? 
A few weeks before the date, after many plans had been scrapped, I booked us a banquet table at Sammy's Roumanian restaurant on the Lower East Side. It isn't the Greenbrier, but it has its own old-school character, with seltzer bottles and chopped liver made with real chicken fat (schmaltz) placed, like a threat to public health, at each table. 
Nothing went right that night. President Bush was in town (not for us) so traffic was horrendous. My brother showed up so late with the elaborate place cards made by my niece that our 20 guests were already seated.
My parents were an hour late, but the Israeli keyboard player didn't know it, and I couldn't get to him in time to make him stop wishing them a happy anniversary, and playing their wedding song. He wasn't playing klezmer music on his accordion, either, though I had negotiated for it at length in advance. And the additional musician I booked to add more old-fashioned flavor to the evening wasn't playing clarinet as promised, although it's my dad's favorite instrument. 
"He'll like the saxophone just as much," he assured me. I almost killed him.
The place was noisy, the food dodgy, the decor totally unacceptable.
Yet halfway through my second vodka and third mini-stroke, I looked up from my plate and saw my parents dancing in the middle of the crowded restaurant, between tables, like two kids slow-dancing at a prom. And despite the fact that my mother struggles to get in and out of a car, she and my dad were totally tickled by the stretch limo we packed too full of guests and Champagne. Later, at my brother's uptown apartment, while I accompanied them on the piano, my little niece and nephew performed a tribute I had written, set, appropriately enough, to "The Battle Hymn of the Republic."
Indeed, the marriage marches on, and the night was a success, mostly because we made it our business to be there and bear witness. No, we didn't rent a castle or have any royals there, but the thing about parents is that their kids are usually royalty enough. 
"The most important thing to remember if you give a party," said Dr. Friedman, "is to let it have heart." Despite the odds, ours did, I guess. 
And that isn't chopped liver. Although we had that, too.

PERSON: David C. Korten 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
A Corporate Believer's Turnabout

BYLINE:  By J. SUZANNE McCOY 

 BODY:
YOUNG David C. Korten would be shocked to see himself now.
 He can still remember how, as a politically conservative undergraduate at Stanford in the 1950's, he believed that American capitalism would save the world from poverty. Now he organizes protests and seminars against what he calls the evils of global corporate expansion. 
 Dr. Korten, 64, has become a leading figure in the antiglobalization movement, the diverse groups who first grabbed the public's attention in a big way when they disrupted world trade talks in Seattle two years ago. 
But he is no bomb thrower. (In fact, during most of the Seattle protest, he said, he was ill in bed and never marched in the streets.) What distinguishes him among the movement's thinkers, friends and critics say, is that he has an extensive background in how business is done in the developing world.
For three decades, after receiving his M.B.A. and a doctoral degree in business from Stanford, he taught at Harvard Business School, trained business managers in Africa and Central America and helped dispense financial aid in Asia.
His metamorphosis into a globalization opponent, he said in an interview, came gradually. But even he is startled by the before-and-after contrast. At Stanford, he said, "I was an active Young Republican." 
Critics call Dr. Korten a misguided idealist whose view of how companies should operate is unfair and outdated. His 1995 book, "When Corporations Rule the World," contends that multinational companies behave with little accountability and hold tyrannical power over the future of undeveloped countries. 
The book has become a bible of the movement -- protesters at a World Bank meeting in Washington last year carried a banner urging people to read it. More than 100,000 copies have been sold, and it is required reading in many college business and political economy courses.
Largely because of that book, Worth magazine listed Dr. Korten in its October 2001 issue as one of the "100 people who have changed the way Americans think about money."
Dr. Korten now devotes much of his time to the International Forum on Globalization, a group that helped to organize the Seattle protest. He also founded two groups, the Positive Futures Network and the People-Centered Development Forum, that advocate changes in global trade policy and corporate conduct. Dr. Korten spoke about his proposals at a conference in New York's Rutgers Presbyterian Church a few weeks ago, as global trade talks were under way in Qatar.
As a psychology major at Stanford, Dr. Korten said the subject of economics interested him because it influenced people's behavior. As a senior, he enrolled in a seminar called "Modern Revolutions" and decided that poverty, not political ideology, caused rebellions.
"I concluded that the best thing I could do was go to business school and bring the secrets of modern American management to the third world," he said. "And from there unfolded a compulsive need to ask questions." 
He established a management school in Ethiopia while he earned his Ph.D., then joined the Harvard Business School faculty to work at the Harvard-backed Central American Management Institute in Nicaragua. In 1978, he and his wife, Frances F. Korten, whom he had met at Stanford, moved to Southeast Asia and administered aid programs for the Ford Foundation and the United States Agency for International Development.
He said the aggressive expansion of American corporations into impoverished countries, going wherever labor was cheapest, increasingly troubled him. He recalled looking out his office window in Manila, where he worked from 1988 to 1992, watching as enclaves of executives flew in helicopters and clogged the streets with cars while the air filled with diesel exhaust. Outside that same window, he could watch people living in shacks atop a garbage dump.
Those disparities were the catalyst for a life change. In 1992, he decided to move to New York, where he thought he could more directly influence industry leaders. He devoted himself to writing his book, giving speeches and encouraging the nascent antiglobalization movement.
His speeches, mostly to environmental groups and antiglobalization teach-ins, drew increasingly large audiences, including representatives of businesses. After a speech in St. Louis in 1997, he was invited to visit Monsanto, a developer of genetically modified foods and a prime target of globalization critics. Dr. Korten began corresponding with Robert Shapiro, then Monsanto's chief executive. They even sent books to each other. But the friendship ended there.
Dr. Korten said that he still regarded Monsanto as "one of the most evil corporations" and that Mr. Shapiro, pressured for profits and a strong stock price, had deluded himself into thinking that genetically modified foods would help the world's poor.
Asked for his opinion of Dr. Korten, Mr. Shapiro said in an e-mail message, "I think he's a thoughtful man with fine intentions and values, but I continue to disagree with some of his premises and most of his conclusions." 
John Cavanagh, a friend of Dr. Korten's and director of the Institute for Policy Studies, a research center in Washington, said Dr. Korten had helped to blunt a major criticism of the movement -- that it lacks a clear analysis of globalization's consequences.
"Amongst economists the line was, 'Globalization is inevitable, get with the program,' " Mr. Cavanagh said. "David has helped change the debate with the argument that this version of globalization isn't inevitable."
But many economists reject Dr. Korten's view that globalization is self-destructive and is incapable of paying attention to side effects like environmental damage. 
"People were talking in the early 19th century about the collapse of capitalism," Dr. Alice H. Amsden, professor of political economy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But during these periods, changes are made, institutional rules are amended and new organizations appear that, in a sense, strengthen capitalism for the next period of economic growth and development." 
Dr. Korten describes his vision of the future as a network of locally and cooperatively owned businesses. The Kortens live on Bainbridge Island, Wash., a spot in the Puget Sound near Seattle that Dr. Korten calls the "land of ecotopia." He can practice some of his suggestions here, he said, like buying wine from producers he knows personally.
He acknowledged his need for some accouterments of the American economy -- flying in airplanes and using computers and e-mail. He thinks a scaled-down economy won't be so dependent on them. "I have no illusion about any of the change process being easy," he said.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
It'sNot Grandma's Clearance Sale. It's Online and Worth Billions.

BYLINE:  By DAVID J. WALLACE 

 BODY:
"EVEN our mistakes are edible" is the slogan at Johnny's Po Boys, a New Orleans sandwich shop. Other retailers make mistakes, too, and they hope to make them more palatable to consumers by using the Internet to unload their returned, refurbished, damaged or overstocked merchandise.
 Clearance sales have moved online, with more rapid sales at better prices and with fewer middlemen, allowing retailers and manufacturers to recoup more on such goods than they could a decade ago. And with the economy weak, consumers who are short of cash may prefer returned goods in plain brown cardboard boxes over brand new, more expensive merchandise in shiny packages. 
 Billions of dollars in returned goods, close outs, overstocks and other orphaned merchandise are now for sale on the Internet. Consumers benefit from low prices and their computers' ability to sort through piles of merchandise quickly. Although some products retain their manufacturer's warranties, others do not, so a "buyer beware" caution is important.
The options are many, for both retailers and consumers. An online retailer may sell returned goods that have been tested for quality. Some sites offer auction areas, generally for merchandise that is in good condition, often carrying a warranty.
At the other end of the spectrum, dissatisfied consumers can use eBay or Yahoo auctions as their returns desk of last resort, where caveat emptor is the rule.
Then there are the online sellers of equipment that is slightly used but still serviceable and new merchandise that is past its season.
Computer equipment and consumer electronics are among the most popular goods rejected by their first buyers. For consumers seeking the latest merchandise, returned goods often sell at discounts.
Retailers, manufacturers and even liquidators have set up Web sites to reach consumers. One Web site, ReturnBuy.com, relieves the retailer and the manufacturer of the trouble of dealing with returns. The company's warehouse in South Carolina accepts returned products on behalf of the seller or manufacturer, and sells on consignment through online auctions. "No one wants these goods back," said Jeffrey Rogers, co-founder and chief financial officer of ReturnBuy. "It's a marketing, sales and logistics problem all rolled into one."
ReturnBuy currently sells its merchandise via eBay and Yahoo auctions. Employees rate goods from one star to five stars -- on appearance, packaging condition and other criteria -- so shoppers have an idea of what they are buying. Products are tested for performance, but all sales are final, unless the consumer receives the wrong shipment. Mr. Rogers would not disclose revenue or profitability for the company, which is privately held, but he said computers made up 60 percent of its sales.
"Electronics are commodity items and there aren't enough of them on eBay," he said. "For a Sony Vaio laptop with certain specifications, we know what words to put in the description, when to start the auction, when to end it. We can post something in one day and sell it within three days. For hot items, we'll get close to retail."
Returns are rare for flawed large appliances, because the manufacturer often finds it less expensive to send a repair technician than to pay to have the product sent back. Consumer electronics average single-digit return rates, while up to half of apparel may bounce back because of fast-moving fashion trends and seasonal timing.
Televisions are particularly popular clearance items, said Walt Mulvey, the chief executive of goodguys.com, an online electronics seller. Their specifications or prices can be compared quickly and easily.
"It's a great opportunity for consumers," he said. "There's so much information about products that a search engine makes it simple. Consumers can accomplish a search for a clearance item in a half-hour online, what might have taken a week in bricks-and-mortar stores."
THE overall market size of returned retail goods is unknown, but Mr. Rogers estimates that $62 billion in consumer goods are turned back annually. Definitions of returns vary widely across industries, depending on merchandise and consumer protection laws. Some products might be in sealed boxes. Others might be opened but unused or cosmetically flawed, so they might not be sold as new.
On the other hand, consumers may be buying a proverbial lemon that no one else wants. Buyers are advised to look closely at a product's details. Some people might sell merchandise like car seats or toys online despite a manufacturer's recall. 
Still, the Internet is likely to make returns more crucial to shoppers and sellers, said Randy Covill, the senior retail analyst at AMR Research in Boston. "It's a change in mind-set," he said. "This used to be a loss -- a cost of doing business. But in the multichannel world, maybe a good result can come of it."

HEADLINE: Chinatown's Ordeal 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Battered by Sept. 11, Chinatown Economy Remains Crippled" (front page, Nov. 21) highlighted the difficulties experienced by the Chinatown community in getting assistance after the World Trade Center attack. 
It showed that the need for relief is not limited to the area below Canal Street. 
 The devastating effects of Sept. 11 on working-poor families are seen and felt daily in the Chinatown community and do not magically disappear north of Canal Street. To heal the community as a whole, it is simply insufficient to define those in need based on their geographic location; we must examine the suffering on the ground.

CHRISTOPHER KUI
Executive Director
Asian Americans for Equality
New York, Nov. 21, 2001

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Peter F. Spano; 
Preferred International Value Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
PETER F. SPANO named his firm, Mercator Asset Management, for Gerardus Mercator, the 16th-century cartographer whose world map helped sailors navigate the globe.
 "Our business is making global projections as well, in terms of companies' earnings growth rates, which drives our investment process," said Mr. Spano, who also manages the $166 million Preferred International Value fund. 
 The fund returned 4.1 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, compared with a 1.1 percent loss for its foreign stock group, according to Morningstar Inc. It lost 7.9 percent in the last 12 months, versus a 21.7 percent decline for its group, Morningstar said. 
Mr. Spano, 58, is founder and general partner of Mercator, which manages about $2.5 billion for institutions and is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mercator runs the fund for Caterpillar Investment Management, a subsidiary of Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment maker. The subsidiary provides investment advisory services for the Preferred Group of Mutual Funds.
Mr. Spano describes himself as a "relative value" investor. "We're willing to pay a little more than deep-value investors when we see good earnings growth going forward and catalysts for change," he said.
He works with five analysts to pick about 50 stocks from among roughly 2,500 companies outside the United States with market capitalizations of at least $800 million.
Every three months, they rank the stocks based on multiples of price to earnings, cash flow and book value over the last three to five years, and on projected five-year earnings growth. After this screening, Mr. Spano does further research, reviewing the company's prospects, industry and economic environment. He also prefers companies with little debt. On average, the companies in the portfolio have projected earnings growth of 11 to 12 percent for the next three to five years.
He trims a holding when it exceeds 5 percent of the fund's assets or if the earnings outlook deteriorates.
To control risk, Mr. Spano aims for a diversified portfolio spanning about 15 countries and 25 industries. Emerging-markets investments are limited to 10 percent; they are at 5 percent, all in South Korea, where, he said, the government is stable, the currency is strong and there are undervalued blue-chip companies.
Mr. Spano bought shares of Samsung Electronics, the South Korean electronics giant, in January at an average price of 195,550 won, worth $154 at the time, including transaction costs. They closed on Friday at 216,000 won, or $169.08. Samsung, which offers a broad range of products, including memory chips, televisions, and microwave ovens, "has technological leadership and joint ventures with other electronics companies that hopefully will ensure strong demand" for years, he said. Its strong balance sheet will provide a cushion during the economic slowdown, he added, projecting earnings growth of more than 20 percent a year for the next three to five years.
The ebbing fortunes of the automobile industry prompted him to buy shares of DaimlerChrysler in July at 55.56 euros, then worth $44.82, including transaction costs. On Friday they closed at 47 euros, which he valued at $41.32, including costs.. He expects long-term annual earnings growth of 16 percent based on factors like cost-cutting at Chrysler in the United States and new, lower-priced automobiles from Mercedes in Germany. "The way the market is valuing the company," he said, "you can buy Daimler-Benz and get Chrysler for nothing."
In August, he bought shares of Abitibi-Consolidated, a newsprint producer based in Montreal, at $11.54 (Canadian), or $7.20 at the time. They now trade at $10.76 (Canadian), or $6.72. The stock price is depressed, he said, because of reduced demand as a result of the economic slowdown. But he expects long-term earnings growth to average 18 percent a year for the next three to five years. The company has closed higher-cost production sites, decreasing its capacity, he said, adding, "We think the company will be well placed to benefit from the future upturn in advertising volume and demand."

HEADLINE: Dot-Com Is Dot-Gone, And the Dream With It 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
MARK LEIBOVICH recalled the day in 1999 when he showed up early for an appointment at a Washington dot-com. Mr. Leibovich, a reporter for The Washington Post, was there to interview the company's executives. "I got there just in time to see the C.E.O. himself wheeling a foosball table into the lobby" to give the impression that the high-tech firm possessed the desired quantum of wackiness that its Silicon Valley counterparts are famous for.
 That is so over, and so much more over, even, than before. The popular obsession with the dot-com revolution, fading for more than a year, seems to have simply winked out since mid-September, as firemen and warriors have become the new heroes, and e-commerce's whiz kids are consigned to the cultural boneyard. 
 Not much more than a year ago, boosters of the New Economy and their true believers in the press were claiming to have changed all the rules. Not just in tech-fetish magazines like Wired, but in self-styled cultural arbiters like New York magazine, which declared the 1990's the "e-Decade." In a 1999 cover story, the essayist Michael Wolff -- himself a failed dot-com executive -- announced a brave new world. "There is, at the elusive center of the e-experience, the fantasy that we might become free of economic laws," he wrote. "All it takes to make otherworldly riches is the will and desire." It wasn't enough to make money. They had to make history.
Now they themselves are history. Each day, the old idols seem to fade further into the dim past, barely recollected in a country where the languages of "revolution" and "warfare" are no longer just business metaphors. This is the next step after the bursting of the dot-com economic bubble -- the bursting of the cultural bubble, the end of the nerd as a crossover hit, of the I.P.O. zillionaire as role model to college students.
The changing of the guard can be seen in little things. Like Henry Blodget, the industry analyst who became famous for predicting early that Amazon.com would reach $400 a share, announcing that he is taking a buyout and leaving Merrill Lynch at the grand old age of 35. 
Like the growing wave of books that focus not on the dot-com path to riches but on the wild plunge into the abyss. Having failed to sell their dreams, they are now attempting to sell their failure. A documentary of the rise and fall of a Silicon Alley company was chronicled in "Startup.Com" by Sebastian Nokes, released last winter. Books by former dot-com executives are arriving in stores. Two of the first are "A Very Public Offering: A Rebel's Story of Business Excess, Success, and Reckoning" by Stephan Paternot, founder of Theglobe.com, and "Dot.bomb: My Days and Nights at an Internet Goliath," by J. David Kuo. Another is coming soon: "Boo Hoo," the chronicle of the spectacular failure of Boo.com, the luxury fashion site that burned through $185 million of its investors' cash and had an online life of just six months, told by its profligate founders.
Did we mention that Mr. Blodget is writing a book?
For the most part, however, the flood of dot-com failure stories is being met with a national yawn. The tell-all books have bounced around the Amazon.com rankings without making inroads into best-seller territory. And why not? Because former idols have feet of clay. In "A Very Public Offering," a book written as amateurishly as the company was run, did we need the image of Mr. Paternot dancing the night away in plastic pants? 
Ellen DeGeneres's new sitcom, "The Ellen Show," is built around the notion of an executive returning to her hometown after the collapse of her dot-com, but the show sits at the miserable ranking of 93rd for the season -- behind "Emeril," the celebrity chef comedy -- despite Ms. DeGeneres's own considerable appeal.
To Amitai Etzioni, a sociologist at George Washington University, the country is experiencing an abrupt cultural shift away from the libertarian, individualistic values that were expressed in the celebration of the New Economy and toward more old-fashioned values in the wake of the terrorist attacks, when government is not The Problem and people are not The Market. "There's been a sea change," he said. The surge in charitable giving and blood donations after Sept. 11, he said, underscores "the sense that you're willing to give priority to the common good, to public safety and public health." 
Paulina Borsook, the author of "Cyberselfish," a critical look at dot-com values published last year, said: "People really crave a reminder of human bonds that have to do with sacrifice and fellowship and getting to know each other over time. It's not about changing jobs every six months and getting stock options."
In the 90's, college students hoping to emulate Marc Andreessen of Netscape and other geek stars migrated to Silicon Valley or New York's Silicon Alley with thin resumes and visions of Testarossas dancing in their heads. That's all changing, said Thomas T. Field, director of the Center for the Humanities at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. "Many of the young adults that I see coming to campus now say they want fulfilling jobs, not just ways of earning money," he said. "Sounds awfully familiar, when you come from the 60's generation." 
Professor Field suggested that protests over globalism, and the sense of security that flourished during the boom, made young people more willing to question the status quo and to take chances. During the I.P.O. frenzy, he said, students could not wait to get out of school and begin earning. This year, many of his students have chosen to study abroad in China, Nepal, India and Egypt. 
The country is in dot-com denial, Ms. Borsook said, adding, "No one wants to admit that they were caught up in it," an attitude she calls "I don't want to think that I drank the Kool-Aid."
Good riddance, said Thomas Frank, the author of "One Market Under God: Extreme Capitalism, Market Populism and the End of Economic Democracy." The book is a withering attack on the ideas underlying the selling of the New Economy, which he says co-opted hipness and the language of populism to serve greed and gain. The book has come out in paperback with a new afterword. "It's going to take some time for it to sink in," Mr. Frank said. "The Dow isn't going to go to 36,000, and the dot-coms aren't going to come back -- and a lot of people lost a lot of money."
Though dot-com executives might seem irrelevant these days, the technologies they sold, by and large, are not, pointed out Paul Saffo, an analyst at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "People haven't stopped using the Internet," he said. "The fact is that it is changing the world, and it has changed the world." People now expect to be able to buy a book or make an airline reservation in the middle of the night, "and it's washed into the rest of their lives."
Kevin Kelly, who as a longtime editor of Wired magazine helped create the heroic ethos surrounding dot-com entrepreneurs, acknowledged "it came tumbling down with the towers." But Mr. Kelly insisted that these people would rise again. The generation of tyro executives who crashed and burned "got better business education than they could if they had gotten a Harvard M.B.A.," he said. "They didn't set out to learn, but, boy, they are much smarter now." He predicts that the last decade has been the "layup" for a true cultural revolution to come -- he could not be specific, and his words may strike many as more dot-com hyperbole.
It takes a special kind of gall for the same people who argued that the "long boom" suspended the laws of economics, and even unraveled the cycles of history, to fall back now on analysis of historical cycles to support their arguments. 
But to believe any less goes against the American grain, argued Jason McCabe Calacanis, the editor of the now-defunct Silicon Alley Reporter. The dot-commer, seen today as a scam artist, will be reborn, he said, smarter and tougher, because he represents optimism itself. "It's the belief that the future -- the individual's future and the future of the economy -- are going to be better in five years than they are today."
But still. Take a look at the book "Radical E" by Glenn Rifkin and Joel Kurtzman, which offers "Lessons on How to Rule the Web" after the bust. It extols companies that truly understand how to marry the World Wide Web to business. "After five tumultuous years of hype and hysteria," the authors promise, "the real advent of the Web and e-business is now."
One of the book's chief examples of a company that does it right, Enron, has been in the news a lot lately, though not because of astute exploitation of e-commerce. No, Enron -- which trades energy via the Web -- has seen its stock collapse 90 percent.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the end of the cultural fascination for the dot-com revolution referred incorrectly to "Startup.com," a documentary film on the rise and fall of a Silicon Alley company. It was directed by Jehane Noujaim and Chris Hegedus, not Sebastian Nokes. Mr. Nokes is the author of a similarly titled book, "Startup.Com," whose subtitle is "Everything You Need to Know About Starting Up an Internet Company." The book and film are unrelated.

HEADLINE: Increase Foreign Aid 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Mrs. Bush Cites Women's Plight Under Taliban" (news article, Nov. 18): 
 Laura Bush hopes to ensure dignity and opportunity for the women and children of Afghanistan. 
That is commendable. But it would be a tragedy if our zeal to improve the situation in Afghanistan led us to overlook equally needy women and children in other parts of the world. 
 An important first step to help these women and children would be to increase the amount of money that the United States allots for foreign aid: only 0.1 percent of gross national product, of which an infinitesimal amount goes to the health and education programs that directly benefit women and children. A second step would be for the United States to abandon its conservative positions on women's reproductive rights in foreign policy and United Nations negotiations.

ELLEN SWEET
V.P., Public Affairs, International
Women's Health Coalition
New York, Nov. 19, 2001
