HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Getting What You Pay For; 
Now, Uncle Sam Wants You

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
FOR the first time since the Reagan years, a president has formally recognized that the federal government is a more appropriate employer than the private sector in a host of areas where the public good is the primary consideration.
 That may not have been President Bush's intention in signing the airport security bill last week, but in nationalizing luggage screening he signaled that some jobs should be protected from market forces -- and even removed from the private sector if necessary. 
 "The principle seems to be that if the service you are concerned about is not going to be profitable to private business, then private business is not going to hire the best people to do the job," said Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton University economist.
That failure to hire the right people for airport security has economists scrambling to sort out who should work for government and who for the private sector -- or who should work for the private sector but with government rather than market forces setting standards and pay levels. While they differ on the details, nearly every economist embraces the notion that higher pay buys skill and dedication in workers, and that these are often necessary attributes in public service. 
Recent research has confirmed that correlation, and the airport security act, embracing these findings, arbitrarily sets pay for security personnel at $17 an hour and up -- double what most of the 28,000 privately employed workers earn to screen passengers and luggage. 
"We don't have much experience in successfully mandating the right wage for a job," said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute. "What we do know is that the market sets too low a wage for quality for child care and teaching, to cite two examples, and for airport security, which helps to explain why there is so much turnover in these occupations."
Before Sept. 11, most executives and some economists insisted that the private sector was the more effective employer in every field. That was the justification for privatizing prisons in several states, and for outsourcing other services once performed by higher-paid government employees. 
THE pressure from customers for quality never seemed to be sufficient to keep school bus or ambulance drivers, for instance, on public payrolls. In the case of airport security, the airlines did not reap profits from paying private contractors to screen luggage. So they paid as little as possible. And until Sept. 11, airline customers did not demand greater quality or were not willing to pay much for it in airfares.
Apart from pay, the fear of terrorism is forcing a debate over who should work for government. Soldiers, police, fire fighters, prison guards -- all these should be government employees, many economists agree. All these jobs require heroism, the use of force and a culture of sacrifice. "We know from the past that mercenaries switch sides or walk away," said James J. Heckman, a University of Chicago economist and a Nobel laureate.
What's more, government is perceived to be more likely than the private sector to spend whatever is necessary to get the job done during crises, which explains why the airport security act sailed through Congress and was quickly signed by the president, although he had expressed a preference for private employment, with government as supervisor and regulator.
That is Mr. Heckman's preference, too. Narrowly focused tasks like screening luggage or driving school buses are best left to the private sector, he argues. The government would let the contracts, not the airlines or some other intermediary. Government would set standards and pay -- as it now does for construction workers on federal projects -- and it would monitor performance. The private employer, meanwhile, has greater incentive to fire poor performers and cut labor costs through automation. 
"I am not saying that government employment will fail," Mr. Heckman said. "I am saying that it is not needed and it is probably counter-productive."
But it is needed, says Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Columbia University economist and also a Nobel laureate. In airport security, government employment is more likely to achieve uniform standards in all the nation's airports, he says, and avoids tensions with private contractors who have an incentive to cut costs in, say, worker training, and thus fatten profits. 
"There is also an intrinsic reward in government employment," Mr. Stiglitz said. "People are often more highly motivated because they believe they are performing a public good. You see this in the National Park Service, which some people have wanted to privatize."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FALLOUT; 
Pakistan's Anxiety Grows as Taliban Collapse

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24 

 BODY:
A senior Pakistani official watched in dismay today as the television in his office showed Taliban fighters, streaming out of Kunduz, Afghanistan, to surrender to the Northern Alliance. 
 "I am sorry to put it in this way," he said, switching off the set, "but Rumsfeld's been extremely callous." 
 For two weeks, Pakistan has been mesmerized by the situation at Kunduz. There were reports that as many as 1,500 Pakistanis were with the Taliban garrison at Kunduz, and that extremists in the Taliban were threatening to execute any who tried to surrender. People across Pakistan feared a blood bath that would reverberate in every mosque in this nation of 140 million Muslims. 
Pakistan's worst fears appear to have receded with the news tonight that many of the fighters surrendering were Pakistanis. Now, the concern will shift to the safety of prisoners in the hands of the alliance, which Pakistan has never trusted.
Still, few here seem likely to forget that when Pakistan appealed for American intervention to work out an arrangement in Kunduz, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld responded, in effect, that the Pakistanis would face the choice of all defeated soldiers in war, surrender or death.
The Kunduz drama has captured the frustration and anger of many Pakistani officials who entrusted their interests in Afghanistan to the United States after Sept. 11, when the Bush administration demanded that Pakistan join in the war against terrorism.
The corollary, as stated and repeated by President Pervez Musharraf, was that Washington would see to it that all of Pakistan's essential interests in Afghanistan were protected.
From the American perspective, the war has gone a long way toward achieving its objectives, with the Taliban driven from power in all but one city, Kandahar, and Al Qaeda terrorists on the run. But from the Pakistani perspective, things have gone badly wrong, and the Americans have not delivered.
Only 10 weeks after General Musharraf pledged his "full support" to the United States, enraging Islamic militants in Pakistan and Islamic hard-liners in the army, the sense that the United States has failed to keep its side of the deal is rife, from the bazaars of cities to the offices where senior aides to General Musharraf ponder how to extricate Pakistan from the problems the war has caused. 
Pakistan's gains have been substantial, especially financially, with the removal of American economic sanctions and the giving of fresh aid and help in debt payments. But strategically, the war has been a disaster in the minds of most Pakistanis. 
Two weeks ago, when President Bush and General Musharraf met in New York, Mr. Bush pressed the Northern Alliance not to capture Kabul. But when the general returned home days later, he arrived just in time to see alliance troops pouring into the Afghan capital. 
Northern Alliance leaders are contemptuous of Pakistan for supporting the Taliban before the Sept. 11 attacks. Another division is that the alliance draws its support, including its arms and much of its financing, from three countries regarded as potentially hostile to Pakistan: India, Russia and Iran.
Next Tuesday, the United Nations will convene a conference in Germany at which Northern Alliance leaders will sit down with opposition leaders from the Pashtun tribal group that dominates southern and eastern Afghanistan. The Pakistanis have low hopes for that meeting, believing that alliance leaders will begin a process of endless negotiation that will leave the alliance as the de facto government in Kabul. 
Ever since Pakistan came into being in 1947, a primary goal has been to ensure that it keeps a friendly government to the west, in Afghanistan, since it already faced the unfriendly state of India, to the east. With the alliance in Kabul, the risk of having unfriendly governments on either side look real. 
With the German meeting coming up, General Musharraf has said little about the situation, other than repeating his "expectation" that the talks will begin the process of establishing a provisional government with strong Pashtun representation that would be friendly to Pakistan. But privately, Pakistani officials say, the general is deeply skeptical that alliance leaders will keep their promise, especially to cede military control of Kabul to a force comprising Pashtun units.
General Musharraf has bitten his tongue, hoping that the Bonn meeting will prove his worst fears wrong, Pakistani officials suggest. He does so knowing that his own standing in Pakistan would be seriously undermined if he were to say that the United States has broken a promise to him.
"But the fact that he's not saying anything right now does not mean that he's calm," one official said. "Privately, he's telling people that if the alliance hold on Kabul is not broken, his position could become untenable."
President Musharraf took a considerable risk supporting the Americans, letting them use Pakistan's airspace, providing them with intelligence and leasing several airfields for use by American spacial operations troops.
President Bush's emissary to the rival Afghan political groups, James F. Dobbins, met with alliance leaders this week and later said he had told them that the West would withhold billions of dollars in reconstruction aid for Afghanistan until a "broad-based government" was set up. "It's a big carrot," he said.
But many Pakistanis with experience of dealing with Afghanistan have concluded that American policy is naive, or else cynical. Those holding the latter view contend that the Bush administration sees itself within reach of accomplishing its goals in Afghanistan and cares little about accomplishing Pakistan's.
In this view, the United States will accept a Northern Alliance government in Kabul if it has to, because the only means of removing it would be to go to war with the alliance. But if the alliance is left in control of Kabul and other cities, these Pakistanis say, the United States will have set the stage for a new civil war.
"If Sept. 11 was a tragedy, there is a bigger tragedy ahead,", said Lt. Gen. Hamid Gul, who was director-general of Pakistan's military intelligence agency, Inter-Services Intelligence, when the withdrawal of Soviet troops in Afghanistan gave way to a civil war and who is regarded in Pakistan as having strong sympathies for Islamic militants. 
Even among aides to General Musharraf, there are officials who agree, and one senior policy maker said Washington could witness a devil's choice of a new civil war against Pashtuns or taking back the capital from the alliance. 
"If the Americans are not very careful with that ambitious little lot, they will find themselves in an unholy mess," he said. "Right now, peace in Afghanistan hangs by a thread."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
How Much Of a Surge For Security Stocks?

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
AMERICANS spend a lot on protection. David Hale, chief economist at Zurich Financial Services, estimates public and private sector spending on security at $250 billion a year. That excludes the Pentagon. 
 In the aftermath of Sept. 11, those numbers are likely to rise. Mr. Hale, for one, figures that the spending could increase 10 percent to 20 percent over the next two years. Prices of some security products and service company stocks have soared since the attacks. 
 Jeffrey Kessler, a business services analyst at Lehman Brothers, took some time last week to discuss the prospects for the companies he covers. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Historically, what has been the growth rate of the security industry?

A. The entire industry is a mid-single-digit grower, somewhere between 5 percent and 7 percent.
 That includes a mix of very low-growth businesses like locks and fences, a more stable monitoring alarm business and a guard business that grows about 3 percent to 5 percent a year. Then there are a whole host of areas like radio frequency identification, electronic article surveillance, closed-circuit television access control systems and biometrics. 
Depending on the technology, those businesses are growing anywhere from 10 percent to 50 percent annually.

Q. In a recent presentation to analysts, Tyco International said that there were more than 13,000 independent alarm companies. How many security companies do you cover?

A. Among the first companies I covered on Wall Street in 1983 were ADT and Sensormatic Electronics. Tyco now owns them both. Of the 16 companies I cover, about one-third are security companies. It used to be two-thirds. That is all because of consolidation in the business.

Q. Are events stemming from Sept. 11 likely to change the growth outlook for security companies?

A. There are parts that have changed dramatically since Sept. 11. The consulting business, for instance, has begun to boom. Companies like Kroll Inc. and Armor Holdings Inc. have seen a huge pickup in inquiries. We won't know for a little while whether this will produce lasting revenues.
On the biometrics side, we have seen a surge in inquiries for secure area access for high-profile facilities like airports and sensitive corporate facilities. Companies like Identix Inc. and Visionics Corporation are getting lots of calls. So are bomb-protection companies like InVision Technologies. 
But in the past, interest in these companies goes up every time there has been an incident. We won't know until January or February, when these companies release their fourth-quarter results, if the most recent events are going to translate into sustainable revenue events.

Q. Some very big companies, like Tyco International and Honeywell, have sizable security service businesses. Are those stocks a more prudent way to invest in the industry?

A. It is fair to say that security has become about one-third of Tyco's business, so there is enough in there to make it a proxy for a safe method of investing in the industry. Honeywell's security business is much smaller. In the case of smaller alarm and alarm monitoring businesses like Pittston Brinks Group, which is in the process of selling its coal assets, security represents just about all of the operating income.

Q. You seem skeptical that attitudes have changed about spending on security. How, if at all, does the airport security bill that President Bush signed into law alter that view?

A. You have to realize that security is a negative sell. It is very similar to insurance.
Up until Sept. 11, I had completely given up on this society being willing to pay up to $2.50 per ticket for airport security equal to that provided in Israel and Europe. Now we have that. Eventually, we will also pay more for more ubiquitous technology as well, be it bomb detection or biometrics. 
We can find the money to pay for more security. But it may take longer to shift attitudes toward greater security and less privacy than merely paying for it. The immediate runup in the price of some of these security stocks, which in some cases more than tripled in price, indicates we are not going back to the state of grace we had before Sept. 11.

Q. Which stocks are you recommending?

A. Our most speculative stock, either boom or bust, is Identix. We would buy Armor Holdings and Pittston on weakness. We have an outperform rating on Checkpoint Systems, another antitheft provider. And we have an outperform ranking on Symbol Technologies Inc., the leading provider of bar code and data gathering systems through bar codes.

HEADLINE: Near Ground Zero, A Medical Gap 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "For Downtown, Vacant Offices and Lost Vigor" (news article, Nov. 19):
 As a family physician practicing four blocks from the site of the World Trade Center, I can attest to the fact that people are not only conducting far less business downtown, but they are also forgoing routine and preventive health care. 
This is a consequence of several factors: relocation of families and workers from the vicinity, a reluctance of people to travel near the scene of the disaster for doctor visits, and, sadly, extensive layoffs that have hit downtown businesses. 
 With a further deterioration in the economy and additional layoffs, the city may face a health care crisis: a large population of uninsured individuals who are unable to afford medical treatment.

MARK E. HOROWITZ, M.D.
New York, Nov. 19, 2001

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Hucksters or patriots? You be the judge. It's again time for 20 questions on Madison Avenue.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media, in this instance a special edition that could be called "The selling of Sept. 11."
 *Will more consumers clip coupons found in Sunday newspaper inserts distributed by Valassis Communications now that they carry abstract versions of the American flag and the words "Liberty and justice for all"? 
 *Will it put off patriotic shoppers to find that the "America the Beautiful pave compact" that is part of the Holiday Compact Collection sold by the Estee Lauder Companies is decorated with "Austrian crystals"?
*After the loss of business suffered by many retailers after Sept. 11, is it still necessary to promote "Customer Appreciation Day" sales because every day now ought to be customer appreciation day? 
*How many consumers will be wooed to shop on the Staples Web site by a banner ad promising free "American Flag Post-it Notes" with every order of $150 or more?
*Will the Democratic National Committee attract more contributions after sending appeals in envelopes with American flags above the words "Printed and mailed with pride from the heartland of America Green Bay, Wis. U.S.A."?
*Was it necessary for the Fox Broadcasting Company division of the News Corporation to run promotional spots for the series "Dark Angel" promising that it "takes fear to a whole new level"?
*If so many marketing experts predicted that after Sept. 11 advertisers would avoid making claims that assail competitors by name because consumers would consider them unseemly, why are there so many ads lately like the one for Swanson Chicken Broth, sold by the Campbell Soup Company, carrying this aggressive headline: "Swanson gives you more chicken flavor. College Inn chickens out"?
*Is it a coincidence that the Bradford Exchange, a company known for so-called collectible products, is suddenly selling a figurine called "Angel of Protection" showing a firefighter standing behind a winged angel, and another figurine called "Heroes at Work," showing two firefighters posed next to a Maltese cross, the traditional symbol of American firefighters?
*Is anyone surprised that the ads for the figurines make no mention of donations of any portion of the $39.95 price of either -- plus an additional $5.99 for postage and handling for each figurine ordered -- to any charities on behalf of firefighters?
*Did ads for USA Today, published by the Gannett Company, carrying the headline "One nation. One newspaper" not complete that thought by including the phrase "indivisible, with liberty and justice for all" because USA Today is usually divisible into four sections?
*Is anyone ordering from newspaper ads run by a California company named Heavy Hitter Industries a 36-inch baseball bat with "a deep-carved U.S.A. red, white and blue logo," which is being sold for $79.95 ("plus an additional $10 for shipping and handling") under the headline "Going to Bat for America"?
*Did the editors of The Ladies' Home Journal, published by the Meredith Corporation, consult with a soothsayer, a palm-reader or a crystal-ball gazer in deciding to wait until April to publish a special issue called "The Best of America"?
*Will tourists be more or less willing to visit vacation spots like the United States Virgin Islands that play up their American roots and heritage in ads?
*How many buyers of the "American Freedom Flag Collection" ($14.95, "plus $4.95 postage and handling") from a company called Publishers Choice or the "America Unites" flag collection ($39.95, "and $5.95 shipping and handling") from a company named the American Historical Society will actually ever fly, display or hang any of the flags for which they are (over)paying?
*Of all the collections of patriotic music being sold after Sept. 11, how many could match "American Spirit," a compilation of "35 timeless American classics" being sold through television commercials by a company called Razor and Tie Direct, which includes a version of "God Bless America" sung by the King himself, Elvis Presley?
*With all the tributes to firefighters that have appeared in the last two months, was it counterproductive for Diamond Brands to run a newspaper ad urging shoppers to buy American-made goods that was illustrated with samples of its best-known product, Diamond Strike On Box Large Kitchen Matches?
*How come Frederick's of Hollywood could donate to charities all the profits from the sale of the "limited edition Patriotic (Thong) Panty," which was decorated with an American flag and the words "America the Beautiful," and many other ostensibly more respectable retailers gave little or nothing?
*How many people will rush to buy a collectible product called "Proud and Free," a sculpted eagle's head being sold for $39.95 ("add $4.99 for shipping and handling") by a firm called Hamilton Collection once they learn from the fine print of the ads that it is "beautifully crafted of sparkling crystalline"?
*Will a print ad for travelers checks sold by the American Express Company, which shows a check torn in half next to the word "Indestructible," make readers uncomfortable because it may evoke images of the torn papers found in Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center towers fell?
*Will Henry Kissinger pause as he runs the bases at Yankee Stadium or Woody Allen stop making figure eights at the Rockefeller Center skating rink or Yogi Berra take five from conducting the "Phil Harmonic" to tell an advertising columnist, "You ask a lot of questions for someone from Brooklyn"?

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
The time may have come for a national corps of technology experts to protect and repair vital information systems.

BYLINE:  By Amy Cortese

 BODY:
IN the aftermath of Sept. 11, a new spirit of civil service is sweeping the country. Volunteers and donors have swamped the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and other agencies with offers of help. Seizing on the national mood, President Bush has called for the creation of a civil defense service that would supplement security efforts by the police, fire departments and public health agencies. That call to civic duty mirrors a bipartisan Senate proposal that would quintuple the size of AmeriCorps, the domestic Peace Corps initiated by President Bill Clinton.
 But even with those efforts, there is a sense that something more is needed. National security is no longer just about patrolling borders and securing airports, bridges and ports; it is also about protecting the nation's information infrastructure. 
 "There is a big hole to be filled in an expanding national service system," said Will Marshall, president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a Democratic research center in Washington. "The more we become dependent on the information backbone, the more we need to be prepared." 
To be sure, the nation is increasingly reliant on technology -- communication systems like cellphones, e-mail and broadcast television, and computer networks that run everything from bond trades to hospitals to the power grid.
Yet, as the terrorist attacks showed, a physical attack can have wide-ranging reverberations: the obliteration of the antenna on top of the World Trade Center left hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers without television broadcasts, and the damage to Verizon telephone switches took out much of the city's phone network. Cellular phone networks, though undamaged, were overloaded. 
Though overshadowed by the rescue mission, volunteers, large and small, have come forward to aid the technological relief effort. Companies like Accenture, AOL Time Warner, I.B.M., and Cisco donated personnel, equipment and money to help restore business operations and to cobble together databases, communications networks and support systems for victims and relief agencies. Local organizations pitched in, too: Webgrrls, a group of 4,000 women in new media, volunteered its services to the Red Cross. Group members worked around the clock building databases to help manage the influx of offers of help and creating a Web-based system to collect and organize volunteer applications.
Yet some people are asking if these ad hoc efforts could have been handled better. Could an organized group of professional volunteers culled from the nation's high-technology companies help aid the recovery of future disasters -- or even prevent them? Is there a need for the technology equivalent of a National Guard?
These questions have been floated in high-technology circles and on Capitol Hill. Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, is championing a proposal for a National Emergency Technology Guard, or NetGuard, and plans to hold hearings on the issue in December. "Technology and science is the one area that has not yet been mobilized to achieve its maximum potential," said Senator Wyden, who is chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Science and Technology. 
At issue is how best to use the nation's technology sector, with its approximately 14.5 million workers. 
The idea behind NetGuard is to create a national volunteer force, drawn initially from the nation's top high-technology concerns, that could mobilize quickly in the case of an emergency. Its role would be to repair downed communications systems, restore computer operations and create new systems to aid support and recovery efforts. These volunteers would receive training periodically, as do members of the National Guard, and would have a clear chain of command to coordinate efforts. In addition, NetGuard would be responsible for maintaining a strategic reserve of equipment -- like cellphones, switches, computers and satellite dishes -- that could be deployed on short notice.
Many officials warn that areas of the country without New York's density, leadership and access to the resources of so many large corporations could have faced an even more daunting recovery. "You wonder how other areas would be able to handle something like this without that technology and expertise and preparedness in place," said David Moskovitz, a partner at Accenture. 
A technology volunteer corps could also help with prevention. It has become clear that better sharing of information is needed, whether among local and federal agencies or the private sector and the government. A technology corps could help build and maintain a database that tracks volunteers and their expertise -- doctors with knowledge of smallpox, say, or technology professionals who are experts on computer viruses, said Andrew Rasiej, a New York entrepreneur and chief architect behind NetGuard. 
Perhaps most important, a technology corps could help bridge the gap between the high-technology sector and the new mission of domestic security. America's high-technology prowess and creativity are unmatched in the world, yet many government agencies are lacking in technological skill and knowledge. "The information-technology community needs to lead the way," Mr. Rasiej said. 
NetGuard is just an idea at this point, and many issues must be resolved, including how such a corps would be organized. But perhaps the biggest obstacle is persuading members of the technology community to work together. 
"The key requirement here is leadership to inspire people to put aside their parochial day-to-day differences and realize that this is in the national interest," said Scott Cook, chairman of Intuit, a maker of accounting, tax and small-business software, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif. For an idea like NetGuard to succeed, he said, it must be driven by the highest levels of government, much the way President John F. Kennedy pushed forward the Peace Corps. 
The first step will be Senator Wyden's hearing, scheduled for Dec. 5, which is expected to include relief agencies and technology concerns. Senator Wyden says he has discussed the issue with and received encouragement from technology leaders like Intel's chairman, Andrew S. Grove, and McCaw Cellular's founder, Craig O. McCaw. 
"There is a tremendous array of talent and energy in the private sector that would like to help here," Senator Wyden said. "We're going to look at how private sector companies can make the most useful contribution in a crisis situation."
No matter the outcome of the hearing, it is clear that the ingenuity of the country's high-technology talent is sorely needed. "The real power and creativity lies out there in the private sector and in the community," said Mr. Marshall of the Progressive Policy Institute. "We're in an era now where we have to respond as a society."

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
Professors Study Method for Doing Well on EBay

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Trying to put markets for everything under the sun -- think groceries and pet food -- on the Internet was a demonstrably bad idea. But clearly, there are some markets made for the online medium, like the virtual auctions managed by eBay. Price discovery, in economic terms, is easy and open, a wealth of data can be presented, and transaction costs are low. 
 Those very characteristics work to the advantage of researchers, especially those like Charles Wood, an assistant professor of management at the University of Notre Dame, who was a software developer before joining academia. Mr. Wood wrote a nifty little Java program, called eDrill, to automate the collection of data off the Web. He and Robert Kauffman, an associate professor at the University of Minnesota's graduate school of management, then embarked on a study of coin auctions on eBay, from 1999 to 2001. 
 The pair chose auctions of mostly 19th century coins because there is a brisk trade in them, and the coins have a standard price-list value -- a good market, they figured, for valid comparisons of buying and selling behavior online. Besides, Mr. Wood said, "I'm a coin collector."
Their conclusions? It is said that a picture is worth a thousand words, but in Internet auctions it is worth about 12 percent, according to the professors. That is, if two coins of the same type, age and condition were auctioned on eBay, the one accompanied by a picture sold for 12 percent more than a text-only offering.
Equivalent coins sold for 2 percent more on weekends that during weekdays. The effect held up for the same bidders and the same items. The weekend effect, Mr. Wood said, was a little surprising. But he speculated there was a "comfort factor" when people had time to consider a purchase over the weekend. "No matter what economists might think, not everyone is a calculating machine," Mr. Wood said.
Next month, Mr. Wood will present a paper on online shilling, the practice of pumping up the price of your own merchandise, either yourself or through an intermediary. Mostly, he said, "they run up the bid early, and they drop out," rather than risk being left holding the final bid. STEVE LOHR

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Europe Plans a Constellation of Satellites

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
Around the world, countries are mobilizing to build independent satellite navigation networks, troubled that the Global Positioning System, the only functioning worldwide network, is run by the United States military and controlled by the government.
 In the last decade or so, the continuous signals emitted by a constellation of orbiting satellites have allowed users to compute time, location and speed with high accuracy, calculations that play an increasing role in everything from firing missiles in Afghanistan to guiding ships at sea to flashing directions in rental cars. As the American technology becomes a worldwide standard, foreign governments are wary that that dependence raises issues of strategic and economic security. 
 The United States government sees its Global Positioning System, or G.P.S., as a resource freely available to the world. Even foreign militaries use it. It is managed by an interagency board, but is operated by the Defense Department, a fact that raises qualms around the world. 
But other countries see the system as an American monopoly, intent on reinforcing its dominion. "Europe cannot accept reliance on a military system which has the possibility of being cut off," said Rene Oosterlinck, head of the navigation department at the European Space Agency, fairly summing up the emotions G.P.S. elicits abroad.
In response, Europe will spend billions assembling a civil satellite system called Galileo, scheduled to be in operation by 2008. By the end of this year, Europe is expected to have allocated 1.1 billion euros ($966 million) to Galileo, with another 450 million euros expected to be approved by the European Transport Commission next week.
China, which hopes to build an independent satellite navigation system within the next decade, launched two experimental positioning satellites last year. The Beidou navigation satellites, named after the Northern Ladle, or Big Dipper in Chinese, sit in an orbit over China. The government uses the systems for things like urban traffic control and earthquake monitoring.
Russia has said it will launch three satellites before the end of the year to resuscitate its ailing Global Navigation Satellite System, a military-operated system known as Glonass. It was first designed with 24 satellites when it went into operation in 1993, but aging satellites dropped out of service as Russia's economic health declined. Only six satellites are now running; new satellites would bring the total up to nine.
Galileo has the most momentum of the alternative satellite projects, and has sparked interest in countries outside Europe. Canada has been financially involved in the early stages of the project. Russia has lent technical expertise and is looking for a bigger role. China has shown a strong desire to participate. And other countries, including Israel, India, South Africa and Australia, have expressed interest.
The United States has promoted G.P.S. as a global standard. In addition to its military and transportation applications, G.P.S. is used because it provides a relatively inexpensive and highly accurate time signal for synchronization. The time synchronization is used in networks like power grids, telecommunications and banking. Disruption in G.P.S. would cause those networks to slow down, but not necessarily fail.
Galileo arose from Europe's concerns about falling behind the United States technologically. At an estimated cost of 3.6 billion euros (about $3.16 billion) for design and deployment, Galileo would be the most significant infrastructure project by the European Union to date.
In the long run, the European Union envisions Galileo as a private-public partnership. But some question the economic wisdom of spending billions of euros, expecting private support and then charging for a certified signal when the G.P.S. signal is free, reliable and a worldwide standard. 
"Galileo is a very confusing system, at least to my American mind," said Pete Brumbaugh, a spokesman for Garmin International, which makes G.P.S. receiving equipment. "There is already this really equitable system. There are already receivers that provide incredible accuracy to users worldwide."
An independent study released by PricewaterhouseCoopers last week, however, predicted that Galileo would have considerable economic benefits. Europe also wants a larger share of the billions of dollars made in maintaining and making satellite navigation equipment. Right now that business is dominated by the United States and Japan.
The European Union says that the United States cannot guarantee the reliability and availability of the G.P.S. civilian signal, as United States national security needs could potentially trump any other needs. In contrast, Galileo proposals describe a free public signal as well as certified services available for governments or paying subscribers.
Analysts see an advantage to having a system separate for G.P.S. in case of any sort of disruption. "It provides a lot more accessibility, redundancy, robustness," said Glen Gibbons, editor of GPS World, a satellite navigation trade publication. 
The emphasis on homeland defense since Sept. 11 has increased support for redundant satellite systems, Mr. Oosterlinck said.
The G.P.S. system, which gained prominence during the Gulf War, was originally developed for the United States military. The system was made available for public use in 1993, with a separate, intentionally degraded civilian signal that provided less accurate positioning as a built-in obstacle to anyone using the system for criminal or rogue purposes.
Last year, however, the United States stopped degrading the civilian signal because advances in technologies -- like jamming -- now allow the military to selectively interfere with signals wherever it wants to -- for instance, in arenas of armed combat like Kosovo or Afghanistan. On Sept. 17, the United States reiterated that it had no future intention of degrading the public signal. But these statements have only slightly soothed international concerns.
Minor friction has emerged between the United States and Europe over the development of Galileo, and American officials have expressed skepticism about the relative costs and benefits of the project.
As Galileo continues to move forward, the United States has voiced concerns about trade, security and technology standards. The last diplomatic meeting on Galileo and G.P.S. took place in late October. At the meeting, the two sides began serious discussions about the text of fundamental principles for Galileo, said Ralph Braibanti, head of the Galileo and G.P.S. negotiating team for the State Department.
Some officials in the Defense Department are concerned about an independent satellite system that could erode their military advantage. While it is cooperating in creating shared standards, the United States has insisted that Galileo not interfere with the parts of the spectrum used for American military signals.
In addition, the United States government fears Europe may impose regulatory restrictions that give European industry technological advantages over its American counterpart. As an example of such past regulations, American officials point to a proposed restriction on jet engine mufflers, called hushkits, which was seen as an attempt to protect European aviation industries by disproportionately affecting American aircraft and equipment manufacturers.
Another technology developed under the American military which has since passed into wide international use is the Internet. But whereas G.P.S. is strictly under American control, the Internet was intentionally designed with no central authority. 
The ultimate implications of Galileo will only be sorted out in the minutiae of negotiations. Politicians, industry executives and trade representatives are wrangling over what type of institutions and structures should manage a dual-use technology that transcends borders and oceans. 
"It really is a global utility and it's a new one," said Mr. Gibbons, of GPS World. "People are still trying to get their minds around what it all means."

HEADLINE: Telecommunications Entrepreneur With a Colorful Resume 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J. 

 BODY:
From the living room of his home in a gated community here, Gary Breshinsky is plotting his return to Afghanistan.
 Spread on the floor are political and physical maps he acquired from the Shah M. Book Company in Kabul. Entered into speed-dial on his telephone are the cellular numbers of Northern Alliance representatives. Hanging in the closet is traditional Afghan garb ready to be donned at a moment's notice. 
 "My aspiration is to be part of Afghanistan's reconstruction," said Mr. Breshinsky, a tall, burly 53-year-old with a nasal inflection that reveals his Long Island upbringing. "I would like to put my skills to use." 
Defining those skills more precisely, Mr. Breshinsky lets loose a torrent of autobiographical detail, describing an odyssey that took him from the suburbs of New York to hot spots in the Middle East, Africa and Central Asia before returning to the United States with his wife, who is Swedish, and their triplet daughters to settle down in New Jersey.
At the top of Mr. Breshinsky's resume-cum-life story is his experience setting up a telecommunications network in Afghanistan in the late 1990's. Together with investors from the United States, Britain and Sweden, Mr. Breshinsky struck a deal with the Taliban to establish the Afghan Wireless Communication Company, whose network has emerged largely unscathed from bombing raids in recent weeks.
Mr. Breshinsky said he left the venture after the United States imposed trade sanctions against Afghanistan in 1999, but Afghan Wireless, with about 9,000 customers, remains afloat. That number of customers not may sound like a lot, but in a country with only about 40,000 telephone lines for a population of 26 million, it is one of Afghanistan's most important links with the rest of the world.
Now, with the nation's power structure in flux, Mr. Breshinsky is hoping to return as an executive at the company or in another capacity to help manage Afghanistan's telecommunications system. 
Mr. Breshinsky's ambition of returning to Afghanistan could be viewed as a reflection of a midlife crisis or a yearning to make money in a far-flung foreign venture. But the explanation of his interest in Afghanistan is derived from something more fantastical, if not entirely absurd.
According to Mr. Breshinsky's own account, he first became interested in Afghanistan when he went there as "a concerned private citizen" in the early 1980's to fight with mujahedeen against the Soviet Army. His involvement there came after forays to other flash points in the 1970's.
After graduating from Fairleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey with a degree in psychology, Mr. Breshinsky said, he moved to Europe, where he developed an interest in the psychology of kidnappers and terrorists after a spate of hijackings and bombings occurred.
It is at this stage that Mr. Breshinsky's story becomes murky. Through contacts at the Central Intelligence Agency, he said, he began advising European officials on how to negotiate with terrorists. 
With the C.I.A.'s support, Mr. Breshinsky said, he formed an organization whose mandate was to work against terrorists and their supporters through blackmail, depletion of funds through offshore banking operations and, at times, assassination.
Mr. Breshinsky said he had coordinated the group from a small base in Cyprus. The work was grueling, however, and it took its toll, he said. After suffering an injury in an operation, he said, he felt burned out, so he took a break and moved to southern Spain. He lived a playboy's existence there, he said, complete with a red Maserati and several beautiful girlfriends. 
According to Mr. Breshinsky, the jet-setting life did not last long, and work soon took him to places like Angola and Afghanistan. But by the mid-1980's, after the birth of his daughters, Mr. Breshinsky decided to retire as an antiterrorist operative. 
Mr. Breshinsky acknowledges that the tale of his experiences before he became a New Jersey satellite telephone salesman in the 1990's and then, in 1997, became involved in the Afghan venture, sounds outlandish. 
But he said he could not provide proof of his activities because photographs and written documents related to his time as an antiterrorist operative had either been lost or stolen in burglaries.
Without such evidence, it would seem that Mr. Breshinsky's account is the product of a vivid imagination. The C.I.A. declined to comment on his claims, and the F.B.I., which Mr. Breshinsky said he had briefed about his recent business dealings in Afghanistan, also declined to comment.
He has his detractors, including Lord Michael Cecil, one of the investors in Telephone Systems International, the New Jersey company that carried out the investment in Afghanistan. 
"Mr. Breshinsky was an employee of T.S.I. and not an investor," Lord Michael said. "It would be quite amazing if any intelligence agency had ever employed or worked with Mr. Breshinsky or anyone remotely like him." Others have a different view.
"Gary is one of the most fascinating people I have ever met," said Len Sherman, whose company, ECG Films of Phoenix, has acquired the movie rights to Mr. Breshinsky's life story. "I honestly don't know if every detail of what he says is the truth. What I do know is that this guy has been through a lot in his life."
Relatively little can be easily confirmed about Mr. Breshinsky, aside from information in real estate, court and voting records. Fairleigh Dickinson does not have any records of his attendance or graduation. 
His only living relative, he said, is his brother, Jeff, also of Hacketts town. The brothers went into business together in the early 1990's with a venture to sell satellite telephones and other telecommunications products; that was shut down earlier this year. Jeff Breshinsky declined to be interviewed.
Nearly all of the available public information on Mr. Breshinsky is the result of a bankruptcy filing he made in 1988. 
He was born on Dec. 23, 1947, and is registered as an independent voter. He has owned the comfortable, if sparsely furnished home where he lives with his family since 1995. His Social Security number was also used by a man named John Canepa who died in 1990. He is fairly litigious, having been involved in nearly a dozen lawsuits in the last decade as a debtor or a plaintiff.
Some outlandish-sounding accounts from Mr. Breshinsky have been verified. For example, in Kabul, he said, he stumbled upon evidence of trade, or perhaps contraband, between the Taliban and Iran, in the form of telephone switching equipment designed by Siemens, the German electronics company, with writing on it in Persian. 
Siemens confirmed Mr. Breshinsky's claim. Through its office in Tehran, Siemens sold the equipment to Iran's national telephone company, only to have the customer report it missing after a few months.
When a team of Siemens officials from neighboring Pakistan went to Afghanistan in 1998, they saw the missing equipment in Kabul being used as part of the Taliban-controlled telephone system.
"We cannot tell you how it got there, but it was there," said Bud Grebey, a Siemens spokesman. "Breshinsky's information was correct."
Other claims are harder to confirm, like the meeting Mr. Breshinsky said he had in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in early 1998 with Mullah Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, a Taliban official, and Osama bin Laden. At that meeting, Mr. Breshinsky said, Mr. bin Laden gave the telecommunications project his blessing.
"Bin Laden was a weird guy with a facial twitch," Mr. Breshinsky said. "His presence was less than impressive."
Mr. Breshinsky said he was talking openly about his life of international intrigue in the hope that he could improve Afghanistan's infrastructure while collecting a steady salary. 
He needs the job. Aside from some part-time marketing work for Federal Goose Control, a Flanders, N.J., company that rids corporate campuses of Canada geese, he has been unemployed since leaving Telephone Systems International more than two years ago. Since then, his wife has been supporting the family.
So far, it seems, his strategy for generating publicity seems to be working. His exploits have been described in Talk magazine and he has been interviewed by the Fox television network. But it is not clear whether Mr. Breshinsky's career will be helped. He said his negotiations with Northern Alliance representatives were proceeding slowly. 
"Gary is a vivid example of the extremes of international business," said Ted Rose, a New York-based writer who has researched Mr. Breshinsky's life. "If he was once a player in Afghanistan, there's no reason why he couldn't become one again."

HEADLINE: Patents; 
Using a seaweed to counteract a fungus that can harm cattle but is needed to help the grass grow.

BYLINE:  By Teresa Riordan; Patents may be viewed on the Web at www.uspto.gov or may be ordered through the mail, by patent number, for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

 BODY:
VIVIEN GORE ALLEN and her colleague Korinn E. Saker have come up with a novel way to keep cattle healthy: just sprinkle a pasture with seaweed.
 According to Professor Allen and Dr. Saker, cattle are often afflicted by a disease called fescue toxicosis. That is because tall-grass fescue, the predominant grazing grass in the United States, is widely infected with a microscopic fungus. Cattle that eat the fungus are inclined to loll about in shady mud holes at a time when cattle ranchers would prefer them to be out grazing, fattening themselves up. 
 The main reason the diseased cattle prefer to cool themselves rather than eat, says Dr. Saker, a veterinary nutritional immunologist at Virginia Tech, is that, inexplicably, they never shed their winter coats. So in the middle of summer, when they are supposed to have a shiny, thin coat of hair, they have a thick, dirty, shaggy coat that causes a persistently high body temperature. 
"It's a major economic problem in the livestock industry," said Ms. Allen, the Thornton distinguished professor in plant cell science at Texas Tech. Indeed, it costs at least $600 million a year in lost cattle or low carcass weight. 
But getting rid of the fungus is not an option. The fungus protects the fescue against all manner of disease; in exchange, the fungus -- which grows between the plant's cells and which is not visible to the naked eye -- gets food and shelter from the plant. Try to break up this cozy friendship, and it "opens up a Pandora's box for the plant," Professor Allen said. "If you get rid of the fungus, the fescue is exposed to a lot of stress," she said. 
In researching the disease, Dr. Saker and her colleagues discovered that the animals were deficient in copper. Speculating that a copper deficiency might trigger the toxicosis, they first tried administering a copper bolus. "Essentially it's a big old capsule that you shove down their throat and it sits in their stomach and breaks down over time," she said. Copper supplements did perk up the cows, she said. 
But then they simply tried fertilizing the grass with Ascophylum nodosum, a brown seaweed found off the coast of Nova Scotia.
Professor Allen and Dr. Saker, working with several colleagues, discovered that animals fed the seaweed-fertilized fescue were protected against toxicosis even though the grasses they grazed upon harbored the fungus. "We got a more long-lasting effect when we used seaweed," she said. Moreover, it was cheaper and less labor-intensive than the copper bolus.
The fortified forage, it turns out, is full of antioxidants like copper, vitamins C and E, superoxide dismutase, and glutathione reductase. "The turf work has shown repeatedly that we're getting this increased antioxidant activity and our suspicion -- we don't have direct proof of this -- is that this is what is affecting the animals' immunity," Professor Allen said.
The research, which was based on a study of about 250 cattle over three years, was published earlier this year in the Journal of Animal Science. According to that research, the blood samples taken at different periods showed increased immunity for seaweed-nourished cattle. The cattle also gained more weight than other cattle and, once they were slaughtered, the meat from their carcasses had a longer shelf life.
These findings may have big commercial repercussions. This month, Professor Allen and Dr. Saker and colleagues received patent 6,312,709, which is the third patent to be issued covering this seaweed supplementation. Several more patents are pending and the entire patent portfolio has been licensed to Acadian Sea Plants Ltd., based in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia.
"They have been field-testing this extensively in two large commercial feedlot operations and we're very close to getting a significant market for this," said Walter Haeussler, director of technology transfer and intellectual property for Texas Tech, which along with Virginia Tech owns the technology. "We've had to do a lot of research to determine the correct dosage and timing of feeding of seaweed to cattle to get certain effects. If you give too much you can actually get less than maximum benefit. It's not a matter of 'if a little bit works then a lot works better.' "
Dr. Saker speculated that the seaweed would not only make the cattle healthier but might also result in beef that is rich in antioxidants and thus more healthful for consumers. "We're making the assumption that if it can happen in cattle it can happen in poultry, in swine, in eggs and in milk," she said.
Does this research mean that health-conscious Americans should themselves start bingeing on seaweed, which is a common ingredient in Asian diets?
"This has very potent physiological effects, whether it's a plant or an animal," Professor Allen said. "But we've got to know more about the long-term impact before we recommend it to a human being. There are many different types of seaweeds -- brown, red and green seaweeds -- just as there are many different kinds of dogs or trees. Will other seaweeds do it? We don't know, because we haven't had the opportunity to test them."

HEADLINE: Canada's Global City (Not Toronto) 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER 

 BODY:
Call it the un-Toronto.
 Vancouver, Canada's third-largest city, is giving the country a new international face, and anyone asked about it seems eager to explain why it will be nothing like Toronto's. 
 Toronto may have the largest proportion of what Canadians call "visible minorities," mostly immigrants from Asia, Africa and the Caribbean, but Vancouver has the more cosmopolitan look, an Asian-Pacific look to be exact.
A quarter of metropolitan Vancouver's people list Chinese -- usually Cantonese or Mandarin -- as their mother tongue. South Asians, speaking Punjabi, Hindi and Urdu, are close behind. Any number of European nationalities and Brazilians, among others, are also in the mix. 
Toronto is establishment. Vancouver is hipper, looser, livelier and more relaxed. 
Ian Hanomansing, the anchor of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's main evening news program -- which, significantly, was moved to Vancouver last year -- said he remembered going to hockey games in Toronto and finding the stadium full of "a lot of middle-aged men, a lot of suits."
When Mr. Hanomansing , who grew up and went to school and college in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, moved to Vancouver more than a decade ago, he was stunned by the difference in the ambiance at the hockey arena.
"It was a shock to see such a different crowd: young people, and much more ethnically diverse," he said. Mr. Hanomansing, whose family is of Caribbean-South Asian descent, also noted that unlike Toronto, this town certainly does not die at the end of office hours.
Heir to a West Coast hippie culture shared with California -- there is a still a neighborhood known as Hemp Town -- Vancouver is more like Seattle than any place in Canada, said Kerry Gold, who writes on pop culture and the night scene for The Vancouver Sun.
"Out here, being a workaholic is not cool," she said. Toronto is full of them, she added. She once lived there, and fled. "Like Seattle, we have a real appreciation of underground amusements and we like little art galleries and speakeasies. Big things tend to fail more."
Gay, straight or neither, people of all kinds seem to find the climate good and the atmosphere tolerant, residents say. Ms. Gold tells the story of an Indian who spends part of the year on traditional fishing grounds with his tribe and the rest of the time performing as a well-known drag queen.
And then there is absinthe. The drink that addled the brains of 19th-century European intellectuals is enjoying a revival here. "Absinthe is very big in Vancouver," said Ms. Gold, the city's unofficial night owl. "It's been big for a year."
Among the places to find the drink in abundance is an underground restaurant called the Hunger Hut, which technically does not exist -- no license -- but where it takes six months to get a reservation.
Toronto has banks. Vancouver has money. Real estate prices are the highest in Canada, in part because of the influx of money from Taiwan and then Hong Kong in the mid-1990's, when that former British colony was facing a return to Chinese rule and people felt uncertain about the future. But affluence, or at least a love of spending, seems to cut across ethnic lines.
The downside is that clubs catering to this spoiled crowd are pushing old bistros out of existence.
Ms. Gold, in an interview in a coffeehouse where the chairs are still upside down on the table tops at noon and nobody was moving much, said that when she ventured out in daylight, she saw many of what she called "a mean generation" tooling around fashionable neighborhoods in S.U.V.'s.
"Who are all these people?" she asked. "Don't they have jobs?"
No, actually.
James Ho, who owns a predominantly Chinese-language radio station, CHMB, and is bidding to open Vancouver's first multiethnic television channel, said in an interview in his boardroom that certainly among Asian-Canadians, many rich people merely use the city, framed by snow-covered mountains and blue Pacific straits, as a part time suburban residence.
They are not the working-class Chinese of Toronto or other Canadian cities, or even of Vancouver's older, economically depressed downtown Chinatown.
"We have a lot of people who really don't have to work -- literally," he said. "There are a lot of self-made millionaires. A lot of them spend their summers in Vancouver and the winter in the Far East."
They are, he added, big consumers. They buy luxury goods. They travel a lot. They invest.
Some families from Hong Kong, feeling more confident of that city's future, have been returning there, often leaving their children in schools here, and in big houses with little supervision and a lot of money to spend.
"Kids are much more internationalized," said Mr. Ho, who came here from Taiwan for schooling while still in his teens and never left. Interest in Asian cultures is strong among the young, often born in Canada -- stronger than among older immigrants, who felt the need to conform to a Europeanized Canadian mainstream, he said.
"But they're not just studying their own culture," he said. "They're also comparing, accepting, exploring."
Mr. Hanomansing, the CBC news anchor, said that, unique in Canada, Vancouver's immigrants over a decade or more have been arriving "with money and with the ability to go right into the mainstream." He calls Vancouver "nonchalantly diverse" as a result.
Charlie Cho, a radio producer and editor of an Asian-Canadian cultural magazine, Rice Paper, said a confident younger generation in Vancouver could reject the old, earnest credos of multiculturalism.
"At this stage it's all this big exciting thing," he said, "in which we're less interested in preserving culture or talking about heritage and all that sort of stuff. What we find really interesting is that contemporary culture is a hybrid." 
Mr. Cho was among those who last year turned Rice Paper from a magazine with academic overtones to an irreverent, pan-Pacific publication that now bears as its subtitle "A Slanted Point of View."
Another Vancouver magazine, a new Asian-inspired publication called Banana, says it chose its name to signify something yellow on the outside and white inside.
This year Mr. Cho, who was born in British Columbia, teamed up with Alexis Mazurin, an Afro-Canadian, and J. J. Lee, whose background is Asian, to create a CBC radio program called "Pass the Mike." 
"We wanted to move diverse programming beyond the standard multicultural feel-good kind of stuff to something with a bit more contemporary edge," Mr. Cho said. "So we created a program that looked at interesting contact points between different cultures."
They ride city buses. They set up their mikes at places like the Lion's Den, a Caribbean-Japanese restaurant. They scorn traditional ethnicity. "We can't have a chopsticks motif," Mr. Lee said. "We're not going to start with dim sum."
They are now putting together an ambitious show about ethnic humor, "Schtick, Spiel and Spin," which will feature three wildly different comedians: a black woman, an indigenous Canadian and a Chinese comic. They're going to record it at a gay cafe with attitude, and an appropriate name. It's called Elbow Room.

Lee -- discussed microphones over breakfast at the Elbow Room cafe. Their program looks at contact points between different cultures. At right, midafternoon shoppers on trendy Robinson Street in downtown Vancouver. (Photographs by Bayne Stanley for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economy Puts Schools in Tough Position 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 19 

 BODY:
Nearly all 600 students at Carl Harvey Elementary School arrive for class for the first time speaking Spanish, not English, which is why the school's three-hour after-school literacy classes have been so critical.
 But with substantial budget cuts coming from the state and the local district, and the prospects of federal help uncertain, Harvey Elementary's principal has already projected that after-school enrollment will have to be cut in half, if not more, by next fall. 
 "There was a window of opportunity here," the principal, Christine J. Anderson, said of the classes, which the school has given for the last two years, "and that is closing."
Having capitalized on a swelling economy to initiate new programs aimed at improving student performance, schools across the country like Harvey Elementary are now being asked to curtail those very efforts because of the nation's shrinking economy. In response to budget cuts, schools from New York to California are undertaking such measures as increasing class sizes, trimming bonuses for good teachers, putting off purchases of faster computers, postponing monetary rewards for high test scores and, as is the case here, scaling back after-school classes. 
For the schools, the timing could not be worse: at the very moment that states and school districts are demanding greater academic performance, particularly by insisting that students make the grade on an array of new standardized tests, the states are asking students and teachers to make do with less. 
In New York City, where a substantial part of a $400 million school budget shortfall is a result of tax losses since Sept. 11, administrators have pared Saturday sessions for struggling students, extra training for thousands of new teachers and art classes.
In Las Vegas, which has one of the nation's fastest-growing school systems, district officials have cut alternative education programs for elementary school students with disciplinary problems. 
School administrators in Fairfax County, Va., have delayed some textbook purchases and placed limits on teachers' salary increases, all to help the state absorb an estimated $80 million in education budget cuts. In Memphis, schools have been told to prepare to delay all but the most pressing classroom repairs, as the state government tries to wean itself from dependence on dwindling sales tax revenues.
In California, which was already experiencing a costly electrical power shortage before the economy turned downward, Gov. Gray Davis on Nov. 14 announced plans to delay support for poorly performing schools, cut assistance for novice teachers and reduce after-school programs like those here in Santa Ana, which is among the poorest districts in the nation. Those cuts are expected to exceed $800 million.
All told, the Education Commission of the States, a nonpartisan research organization, has identified education cuts of more than $3 billion in at least 15 states. Those are among the cuts detailed in another report, by the Council of Great City Schools, a coalition of the 60 biggest districts. 
"It's the poor schools that are so badly hit," said Delaine Eastin, the superintendent of education in California. "They were starved for a quarter-century. They were just starting to come back."
If there is a silver lining for the schools, it is that Senate Democrats have taken note of the states' retrenchment on education spending, and are trying to use the schools' plight to wring more money from the Bush administration and the Republicans who control the House of Representatives.
Senate and House leaders have been deadlocked for months over how much to spend on elementary and secondary schools in the next year. House leaders have agreed to spend nearly $30 billion, an increase of about $5 billion over the current year. But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, has called that figure at least $10 billion too low.
To buttress his argument, Mr. Kennedy's aides released their own study of state education budgets on Nov. 16, which predicted that states will spend $11 billion less on schools this academic year than is needed, when inflation and enrollment growth are taken into account. 
Representative George Miller, a California Democrat whose staff worked with Mr. Kennedy's, said, "The faltering economy is putting at risk the advancements that many states are making to improve the quality of their educational systems."
Given the realities of the economy, few districts have sought to challenge the state and local governments that are often ordering the cuts.
"What are we going to say?" said Anthony Shorris, the deputy chancellor of the New York City Board of Education. "This is a terrible catastrophe that hit New York. Our goal is to live with what we've got, and still help our students meet these new demands."
In California, the more than $800 million in school budget cuts identified by Governor Davis have jolted systems that had grown accustomed to receiving more money from Sacramento each of the last few years.
Ms. Anderson, the principal of Harvey Elementary, a wood-beam-and-stucco building that is crammed to four times its intended capacity, said she was sometimes inclined to agree with those researchers who have found that more money does not necessarily lead to improved student achievement. But, she said, the $300,000 the school spent on its afternoon literacy program in each of the last two years -- it now serves 150 students, most of them Mexican-American -- was followed by a relatively steep rise in reading scores. 
Last year, the school's students, who are among the most disadvantaged in the state, exceeded the overall scoring target set for them by state officials by a factor of five. Driving that improvement were the school's fourth graders, 25 percent of whom were found to be reading above grade level last year, compared with 7 percent three years ago.
Amy McDonald, a third-grade teacher who sends 16 of her 19 students to the intensive after-school program, said that the impact on their English in just three months this year had been remarkable. She said that her students arrive in class in the morning eager to discuss what they learned the previous afternoon.
Lizbett Mejia, 9, whose mother was born in Mexico and can barely communicate in English, said she had become hooked by her after-school teachers on a popular collection of books known as the "Little Sister" series.
"I didn't know that much of reading," Lizbett said. "Now I know how to read more."
By replacing certified teachers with local college students, Ms. Anderson said, she believes she can keep this year's after-school program running at full capacity. But when the proposed state cuts, including those to badly needed subsidies for school electrical payments, are combined with anticipated reductions in public and privately financed grants, Ms. Anderson estimates that she will have no more than $90,000 to spend next year on the program, which would probably cut enrollment in half.
"These last few years have been heaven," she said. "Hopefully we've learned enough to be able to sustain what we think works, without having the money we thought we needed to pay for it."

HEADLINE: Parking Garages Suffering From Manhattan's Single-Driver Restrictions 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Although it is unlikely there is a celebrity telethon in the works to support them, parking garage operators in Manhattan say that in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack they, too, are suffering. 
 Business is off by as much as 40 percent in Midtown since Sept. 11, and 80 percent in Lower Manhattan, according to a spokesman for the industry. The operators say their woes are related not so much to terrorists or the economy as they are to the measures imposed after the attack, namely the ban on cars with only one occupant. 
 For security reasons, the city has banned driving alone into Manhattan at the Lincoln, Holland and Queens-Midtown Tunnels during the morning rush, from 6 a.m. to 10 a.m.
"The effect has been disastrous," lamented Jerry Gottesman, chairman of Edison Properties, which operates 30 garages and parking lots in Manhattan. 
As a result of the ban, Mr. Gottesman said, many people are forgoing trips to Manhattan altogether. Revenue at his garages has fallen by a third, mostly because of a drop-off in drivers who park before 10 a.m. At the Hippodrome, a prime garage at West 43rd Street and the Avenue of the Americas, he said, daily parking volume is off by 44 percent over all, and he has had to close the third floor of the building.
Joel Stahl, executive director of the Metropolitan Parking Association, which represents the owners of nearly 900 parking garages and lots, acknowledged that there might not be much sympathy for an industry that routinely charges $25 to park in a 200-square-foot space for two and a half hours. But he tried to put the situation into context, saying that if people are not using parking garages it means they are not going to the city's restaurants, theaters, hotels and department stores.
"Garages are only one part of the economy," Mr. Stahl said, "and let's be honest, not always a sympathetic part of it, but it's indicative of what's happening all over. We know theaters and retailers are down. The people who come and park are big spenders."
The operators want the traffic restrictions ended. 
Mr. Stahl acknowledged that it is difficult to separate the effects of a slowdown in the economy from those of the ban. But, he said, when suburban drivers give up on Manhattan the ban becomes another roadblock to an improving economy.
"We're not crying as we go to the bank," said Monroe Carell, chairman of Central Parking Corporation, the largest garage operator in New York. "We still have to meet payrolls and pay rent. We're going to take some licks this year. But some people are probably going to fail as a result of it."
Not everyone finds the argument convincing. The anticar lobby, as the garage operators refer to it, likes what it describes as the "car pool rule," a more positive-sounding description of a policy that it says encourages drivers to round up passengers.
"It's working well to reduce congestion in the city," said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a lobbying group. "Until we come up with an alternative, like putting tolls on the East River bridges and variable pricing for on-street parking, the car pool rule has to stay in effect."
Besides, Mr. Kaehny said, the rule affects "only a very small number of people." And it does nothing to prevent drivers from coming into Manhattan after 10 a.m.
Iris Weinshall, the city's transportation commissioner, said that she expected the traffic limits to remain in place at least through the end of the year, if not longer. The restrictions on solo drivers were imposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani after Sept. 11 because of intense traffic congestion south of 62nd Street and the emergency conditions at the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan, where a number of the surrounding streets had been closed.
In recent weeks, Ms. Weinshall said, the city has reduced the number of hours that the ban is in effect.
"We're beginning to slowly open things up," she said. "Still, not all the traffic is moving ideally. If you open the floodgates, you are going to create more gridlock in light of the construction on the streets. I would love to see as many people as possible come back to the city. I'm just worried about bringing them back into a situation where they'll complain even more."
She said that the number of vehicles coming into the city between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m. is down 38 percent, although it is up before and after the restricted hours.
Garage operators, however, say there is a net loss in traffic volume, largely because of the ban and confusion about the evolving restrictions. Like Ms. Weinshall, they point to the traffic flow on the city's bridges and tunnels.
At the Queens-Midtown Tunnel on Nov. 14, 11,180 vehicles flowed into Manhattan between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m., down 3,357 vehicles, or 23 percent, from the same day a year earlier, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But there was no corresponding surge in volume on the alternative route for solo drivers crossing the East River: the Triborough Bridge, which does not have any restrictions. The number of vehicles there was up by only 891 vehicles between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m. Meaning, Mr. Stahl said, there has been a net loss of thousands of drivers.
On Nov. 14, the number of vehicles traveling west through the Midtown Tunnel was also down for the entire day. At the Lincoln Tunnel, 9,778 vehicles passed from New Jersey to Manhattan during the restricted hours on Nov. 14, down 9,759 from a year earlier, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. But traffic was up only slightly on the George Washington Bridge, which does not have the ban on cars with only one occupant.
At the same time, New Jersey Transit reports that the number of bus and train riders going to Manhattan during the restricted hours is up by 3 percent, or 800 people, since Sept. 11. 
"The ban's a big problem," said Raj Pamnani, an investment banker who commutes from West Orange, N.J., to Midtown, where he parks at the Hippodrome garage. "If the ban's not lifted, I'm thinking of relocating my office to New Jersey."
Mr. Stahl pointed out that the garage industry employs thousands and accounts for $200 million a year in revenue for the city from the 18.25 percent tax on parking. 
Jose Rojas, secretary of Teamsters Local 272, which represents 5,000 garage workers, said 300 members of the union lost their jobs downtown because of the attack, while thousands of others have had their schedules cut to 32 hours a week.
Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, said: "The suburbs need to be able to get into Manhattan to fill our hospital beds, restaurants, Broadway shows, hotels, and most of all, to shop. Yet we've created a set of impediments, starting with signs on suburban highways warning motorists to avoid Manhattan and the uncertainty of the rules about getting into and out of Manhattan."
For Greg Susick, senior vice president of Central Parking, which operates 230 garages in Manhattan, the car ban is an attack on something as American as apple pie. The restrictions have had little effect on garages in residential neighborhoods on the Upper East Side and the Upper West Side, but there was a 25 percent drop in revenue at his Midtown garages and a 70 percent drop downtown.
"I think it's destroying the fabric of New York." Mr. Susick said. "People don't drive into New York because they like to. They come here to work and shop. I think it's hurting a lot of people who are trying to make a living."
