HEADLINE: On Campuses, Seeing the Military With New Eyes; 
After Sept. 11 Attack, Students Reconsider Old Perceptions

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
At Seton Hall University, some students who previously ignored the R.O.T.C. cadets roaming around campus now regard their uniformed classmates as -- of all things -- cool. Some have been so inspired that they say they may join the military, too.
 At Bronx Community College, where military service has always been an attractive avenue to win a scholarship, some students who had previously thought of joining the military now say they won't. They are too scared. 
 At Columbia University, where students have for decades shared a liberal disdain for all things military, some students say they have had a change of heart. A small group has even formed a new, pro-military organization. 
In ways large and small, the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 have altered how college students regard the military, the prospect of military service and their peers who decide to join. The reaction varies from campus to campus, but what emerges from interviews on three distinctly different campuses in the New York area is a complex and sometimes surprising portrait of students who are rethinking their views of the military -- or for the first time thinking about the role of the military in American life.
Even with the war effort seemingly going well, few students believe that the military buildup will suddenly subside. Most say they would serve if asked, though some say they are afraid to die. Few challenge the reasons of those who do join. And while some students, particularly at Columbia, oppose the war in Afghanistan, few question whether one should be loyal or patriotic.
"Growing up, I was very anti-establishment, anti-American government," said Margot Schulman, a Columbia junior and premed student. "But since Sept. 11, I have softened my views about everything."
Of the three campuses, Seton Hall, a private Catholic university in South Orange, N.J., has witnessed the greatest display of patriotism among its students, who are generally conservative.
After the attacks, dozens of students either called military recruiters or talked to resident advisers about joining the military. When R.O.T.C. students conduct their exercises on campus, more classmates seem to notice.
"People come up to me and are extremely interested in the military," said Colin Kelly, a Seton Hall senior and economics major who is the student leader, or battalion commander, of the campus R.O.T.C. "Usually they'll say that it's cool that you do it."
Aubrey Carpe, a sophomore journalism major, reflects the changes.
Mr. Carpe said he used to worship anti-establishment punk-rock groups like Anti-Flag, "but I feel totally weird listening to that now." A fan of Neil Young, Bob Dylan and other icons from the 1960's, he finds the lyrics of protest, suddenly, to be off-key.
"It's cool what they're saying, but this is not Vietnam at all," he said. "This is terrorism." Now he says he admires the patriotism of his friends in R.O.T.C. 
Even dovish students said they were not opposed to the military, per se. Jonathan Ernesto, a sophomore business major at Seton Hall who participated in a recent event promoting tolerance called Circle of Unity, said that he hoped civilians would not be hurt in Afghanistan, and that he had developed an interest in joining either the Navy or the F.B.I. 
After one recent late-afternoon Mass on campus, Junno Arocho, a freshman from Newark, said that he was now contemplating a stint in the Army.
"With everything that's happened, it's made me think," said Mr. Arocho, who is studying diplomacy. "What am I going to do with my life? Being part of the U.S. is not just being a citizen, it's being able to defend life and defend the existence of mankind as we know it."
That gung-ho enthusiasm is less evident at Bronx Community College, part of the City College of New York. Sure, there is an Army Reserve site opposite the campus entrance. Sure, many students have long considered the military because of its scholarships.
But for many students, joining the military has usually meant exchanging the hazards of a tough neighborhood for the economic benefits of a relatively safe military life.
"I don't want to fight in a war; I'd rather go to jail," said Paul Brown, 21, a Bronx native and radiology major. "I might have a chance in jail, but if I go to war, I might be dead in 0.5 seconds."
Randy Rampersaud, 19, said that he once thought about joining the military. But because his family is of Indian descent, via Guyana, he worries that he might be viewed with suspicion. As a result, he said would serve only if there was a draft or a great need for enlisted men.
More than half of the student body at Bronx Community College is foreign-born, including 32 percent from the Dominican Republic alone. And generally, immigrants volunteer for military service more readily than the natives, partly because they are eager to prove their patriotism.
But most students sound like Edward Polanco, 26, who came from the Dominican Republic six years ago. At first, he wanted to join the American military to emulate his older brother, who was an army sergeant in the Dominican Republic. But then came Sept. 11.
"Before, I was thinking that it would be good for my resume, because anywhere you go, you say, 'I was in the Army,' they give you a job easily," said Mr. Polanco, a computer science major who works part time as a security guard. "But now it's scary. Everyone I see, they are scared. They don't want to go. My family doesn't want me to go."
For decades, antipathy toward the military has never been in short supply at Columbia, where students protesting the Vietnam War once occupied campus buildings. And in response to the current crisis, some students, particularly those active in recent antiglobalization protests, have formed a new antiwar group called People for Peace.
One member, Yvonne Liu, a junior who is a neuroscience major, said: "It's definitely something that I'm not comfortable with. It's like sending the poorest and most marginalized people in our nation to be killed in the name of corporate interests."
But Columbia is also the birthplace of another student group, Students United for Victory, founded after the attacks to support the military.
"I was expecting people to confront me and try to provoke me, because this is a college campus in a liberal city, and Columbia has a history of antiwar protests," said Lovinsky Joseph, a freshman from Linden, N.J., who is the group's spokesman."But I've never received anything like that. In fact, I would say that two-thirds of the students have been supportive."
One student who once considered joining the Navy, Carly Burton, a junior from Austin, Tex., said that a few friends had considered volunteering after Sept. 11 because "they don't want to sit back, 10 years, 20 years from now, and say, 'I wasn't a part of it.' " But she decided against it. Ms. Burton says she believes that she could contribute more to society by becoming an investment banker.
Some students acknowledge that they feel somewhat removed from the military, because they have the luxury of cocooning themselves in academia. Even so, most say that they no longer view the military as something alien and distant from their lives, and they expect that the military will be a looming presence for some time to come.
"Before, the military was like the little place in Times Square where you could sign up, and I never knew anyone who did it," said Jennifer Lynn Stermer, a junior and an English major from Manhattan. "Now, I feel -- I don't know if respect is the right word -- but I'm thankful that there are people willing to do that."

HEADLINE: Opposition Candidate Is Leading in Honduran Presidential Vote 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 25 

 BODY:
A businessman touting a "zero tolerance" anticrime plan appeared headed to victory today in presidential elections in Honduras, where he opposed a former teacher who promised better education.
 The first official voting results showed the Nationalist Party candidate, Ricardo Maduro, a businessman, winning with 52.2 percent over 44.4 percent for his rival, Rafael Pineda of the ruling Liberal Party, with 23 percent of votes counted. 
 Surveys of voters leaving the polls also showed Mr. Maduro winning. 
Cheering, horn-honking caravans of Mr. Maduro's supporters celebrated in the streets of the capital, Tegucigalpa, waving blue Nationalist banners. Mr. Maduro declared victory, saying "The people voted for a profound reform."
Violence leading up to the elections -- a congressional candidate was killed Friday and gunmen shot at a political party headquarters on Saturday -- underscored the central issue: what to do with a generation of young Hondurans who have grown up with crime and poverty.
A team of international observers reported after the polls closed that the voting had been peaceful and without major incidents.
The ruling Liberal Party, led by President Carlos Flores, has had to govern through some of the roughest times in the history of this Central American country of 6.5 million. 
A devastating hurricane hit the country in 1998, killing thousands and causing billions of dollars in damage.
Mr. Pineda, 71, a former teacher and current head of the country's Congress, said he wanted "to make Honduras one big school," and offered to improve public services with money gained by cracking down on tax evaders.
But many Hondurans said they were voting for Mr. Maduro because of his anticrime program. 
If early results hold, Mr. Maduro is expected to target, in part, the tens of thousands of gang members who frequently stage turf battles and deal drugs. 
But his tough approach has voters like Cinthia Baldin, 25, worried. "A lot of innocent people may get hurt," said Ms. Baldin, a Pineda supporter. "Some young people are in the gangs because they've got no other option."
Mr. Pineda said, "I do believe that education can fight crime, and the problems like social injustice, unemployment and poor public services that give rise to crime." 
Mr. Maduro, 54, whose own son was killed by gunmen in 1997, had built a comfortable lead in polls with his campaign slogan "A Safe Future" and promises to implement a New York City-style "zero tolerance" program on crime. He has cited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's anticrime measures as an inspiration.
Mr. Maduro mourned another death after unidentified gunmen killed Angel Pacheco, 44, a congressional candidate from his Nationalist Party, near the El Salvador border on Friday. The police had no immediate information on motives in the killing.
On Saturday, Mr. Pineda's Liberal Party said gunmen fired from a passing car on its headquarters in the northern city of San Pedro Sula, though no one was injured.
Three other candidates from minor parties were also vying for the presidency, but were expected to garner few votes.
The 3.4 million registered voters in the country -- where minimum wages are around $100 a month -- were also voting for all 128 seats in Congress and nearly 300 mayoral positions.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Bear Market for Personal Finance Magazines

BYLINE:  By DAVID HANDELMAN 

 BODY:
On Sept. 11, the staff of Money magazine was two days away from finishing a special issue recommending 100 mutual funds. When the twin towers fell, the managing editor, Robert Safian, knew the monthly magazine, a publication of Time Inc., did not have the resources to remake the issue completely.
 So Mr. Safian left Money's fund report intact but prefaced it with a 12-page section answering the most pressing questions about investing, the economy and historical lessons. He wrapped it with a new black cover that asked: "What Now?" 
 That question was haunting personal finance magazines like Money even before Sept. 11. During the 1990's, the field was booming, and the distinctions among the publications were blurring. They all cheerfully advised on strategies for investment, tuition and retirement.
But the bear market brought carnage to the field. In 2001, three boom-era publications folded: the Meredith Corporation's Family Money, Consumer's Digest Inc.'s Your Money and the Individual Investor Group's Individual Investor. Advertising is plummeting and newsstand sales are faltering -- even though the editors argue that their publications are more essential in a bust.
"The late 90's was really the rise of stupid stock picking," said John Curran, managing editor of Mutual Funds, another magazine. "The environment has changed, and people have to get smarter."
The attacks on the symbols of American finance only deepened the recession among personal finance magazines. "People tell me their monthly broker statement comes, and they don't want to look at it," said Knight Kiplinger, editor in chief and publisher of the granddaddy of personal finance magazines, Kiplinger's Personal Finance, which has existed in various incarnations since 1947. "They stick it in a drawer."
As 2001 ends, according to Media Industry Newsletter, the four largest personal finance magazines -- Money (1.9 million circulation, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations), Kiplinger's (1.03 million), SmartMoney (809,000) and Mutual Funds (800,000) -- are down in annual advertising pages, by 17.1 percent at Money to 32.8 percent at Smart Money. For December's issues alone, the declines from last year range from 24.9 percent (Money) to 56.7 percent (Mutual Funds). (Other magazines in the category include Worth, at 507,000, and Bloomberg Personal Finance, 340,000.) 
Meanwhile, even before Sept. 11, newsstand sales were hurting, the circulation bureau reports: through June, compared with the first six months of 2000, Money was down 25 percent; Smart Money, 30 percent; Kiplinger's, 42 percent; and Mutual Funds, 43 percent. Mr. Kiplinger says that many of his sales come from business travelers in airports, an audience that has fallen off.
A number of the magazines are redesigning themselves, raising circulation by buying subscriber lists of the defunct publications and trying to distinguish themselves in how they deal with the post-attack world.
The most extensive visual overhaul is at Time Inc.'s Mutual Funds, the driest and most narrowly focused of the four top publications, with no consumer or shopping articles.
The redesigned January 2002 issue has a livelier feel. It has revamped, graphically streamlined front and back sections (on investing and financial planning, respectively) and a new cover and logo by Walter Bernard and Milton Glaser; the cover line "Pick Your Spots" is illustrated with a photo of a Dalmatian.
The first post-Sept. 11 cover of SmartMoney, which is more consumer-oriented, departed from its signature typeface covers with a photo of the World Trade Center with the headline "Our Spirit Will Stand."
The point was, life goes on. "We're still going to think about Christmas, buying new cars, making travel plans, and I wanted the magazine to reflect that," said Peter Finch, the editor in chief. It is owned by Dow Jones and Hearst Communications.
In January, a redesigned cover will carry SmartMoney's rejiggered logo, which puts greater emphasis on its kinship with The Wall Street Journal, and permits more cover lines. The idea is to play up the magazine's spunkiness and its reporting. "What's worked for us in the past has been things like 'Buy These Tech Stocks,' " Mr. Finch said.
Money's January issue will have heavier paper stock, but the real shift is its aggressive response to Sept. 11. After the mutual funds issue closed, Mr. Safian tore up the next issue completely.
"We had things scheduled like best places to vacation and how the Backstreet Boys manage their money," he said, "things people don't care about" now.
Instead, he assembled an issue called "Keep the Faith: Investing in America." The December issue's headline is "Get Back on Track." Its annual "Best Places to Live" feature, forgoing the usual scientific method, puts New York City at No. 1. It also examines the new landscapes of travel, housing and investing. 
Mr. Safian says that Money's main role is to calm people and give perspective. "When things are turbulent or unsettling, you don't rush and make bad decisions," he said.
Kiplinger's has tried to reflect the same even-keel outlook by staying relatively unchanged. Its first post-Sept. 11 cover, for the November issue, was a cheerful "Time to Rebuild" with a hammer and tools. 
"I think if we were in New York City like SmartMoney and Money, we might have taken a more funereal approach," said Mr. Kiplinger, whose magazine is based in Washington. By the December issue, the cover was back to its annual car-buying guide, although there were several newsier articles.
"I'm getting calls from people saying the media is overdoing the gloom," Mr. Kiplinger said.
He feels the same way about his niche's downturn. There is more personal finance guidance in the market now than readers and advertisers can support, he said. But Long-term prospects are strong, he said, citing the retirement of the baby boomers over the next 10 to 15 years.
"I'm very bullish on the outlook of financial publishing," he said.

It has been redesigned inside and out to give it a livelier feel.; AFTER -- The January issue.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: GEOLOGY; 
Nature Made The Perfect Hiding Place

BYLINE:  By KENNETH CHANG 

 BODY:
If Osama bin Laden is hiding in a cave in Afghanistan, as American officials suspect, he has plenty to choose from. The country's varied landscape and geology make it ideal for caves.
 The area that is now Afghanistan started to take shape hundreds of millions of years ago, when gigantic rocks, propelled by the immense geological forces that continuously rearrange the earth's landforms, slammed into the landmass that is now Asia. Much of the rest of today's Afghanistan was still under water, yet to be formed. 
 Rocks deep inside the earth, heated to thousands of degrees and crushed under tremendous pressures, flow like taffy. Just like the air masses in thunderstorms, the warmer rocks rise and the cooler ones sink, setting up Ferris wheel-shaped circulations of magma that drag along the crust above them.
Over time, these forces broke off several pieces off the southern supercontinent of Gondwanaland -- the ancient conglomeration of South America and Africa -- and carried them north toward Asia.
"All that stuff got rafted in and stitched together in Afghanistan," said Dr. John F. Shroder, a professor of geology at the University of Nebraska at Omaha who is an expert on Afghanistan's complex geology.
The limestones of Afghanistan's natural caves were once part of a shallow tropical ocean known as the Tethys. Organisms in the sea -- corals, clams, plankton -- were compressed into limestone. "All those limestones were produced in an oceanic environment somewhere south of present-day Afghanistan," Dr. Shroder said.
In a last mighty collision of tectonic plates 45 million years ago, India, sliding north from Antarctica, jammed into Asia. The ocean floor in front of India slid beneath the Eurasian plate.
"India is the last piece that rafted in and pushed up the Himalayas," Dr. Shroder said.
Minerals from the ocean floor, melted by the heat of the interior, then flowed back up near the surface, forming rich deposits of copper and iron (minerals that could someday finance an economic boom in Afghanistan). The limestone along the coasts of Asia and India buckled upward, like two cars in a head-on collision. 
Water then ate away at the limestone to form the caves. Though arid today, Afghanistan was once warm and wet. Carbon dioxide from decaying plants dissolves into water to form carbonic acid, and in water-saturated underground areas, the acid hollowed out the limestone to form the caves, some several miles long.
Afghanistan's fighters find shelter in the natural caves. They also make their own, often in the mountains of crystalline rock made of minerals like quartz and feldspar, the pieces of Afghanistan that were carried in by plate tectonics. Dr. Shroder says those rocks are twice as hard as limestone. 
"This kind of rock is extremely resistant," Dr. Shroder said. "It's a good place to build bunkers, and bin Laden knows that." Dr. Shroder said he believed that Mr. bin Laden's video in October was taken in a region with crystalline rocks like those south of Jalalabad.

HEADLINE: Shoppers' Solid Start Makes Retailers Cautiously Hopeful 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Deep discounts on things like CD's and turtleneck sweaters lured shoppers back to the malls over the Thanksgiving weekend, but consumers did not swell the crowds the way they did last year, and it is still unclear whether they will spend robustly enough to pull the economy from its downturn.
 Even this tepid start to the season gave analysts and investors cause for cautious optimism, however, because in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, industry analysts had worried that this holiday selling season could be a debacle. Stocks of retailers rallied on Friday. 
 While plenty of Americans rose at dawn on the Friday after Thanksgiving to snap up hot items like electronics and Harry Potter products, the number of visitors to shopping malls was down 8.1 percent compared with the figure on that day a year earlier, according to the RCT National Retail Traffic Index. 
The decline, while sharp, put foot traffic at malls this year just slightly behind traffic levels in 1999, which, along with 2000, was a particularly strong season. "Put in perspective, these numbers look relatively strong," said Jim Martin, vice president of RCT Systems, in a written statement.
For Saturday, traffic was down 6.8 percent compared with the day a year earlier, which was also seen as a good sign.
"Though traffic was down versus 2000, the traffic trends show shoppers continue to return to the malls in 2001 -- and their numbers are increasing at a faster rate than in 2000," Mr. Martin said.
On another cautiously positive note, sales in stores open at least a year rose 2.4 percent on Friday compared with sales on that day a year earlier, according to TeleCheck Services, the world's leading check acceptance company. The TeleCheck Retail Index is based on a comparison of the dollar volume of checks written by consumers at 27,000 stores, comparing the amounts at each outlet with those a year earlier.
When the sales are adjusted for inflation, however, unit sales would be flat, said William Ford, a senior economic adviser at TeleCheck, a subsidiary of the First Data Corporation. "It is certainly not what retailers as a group would like to see," Mr. Ford said. "It is also not a doomsday start at all. It is better than a lot of analysts had expected. Retailers should be pleased."
Although the initial sales numbers for the season were more optimistic than expected, there were plenty of reasons for merchants and malls to be wary of how the rest of the season would shape up. For starters, a strong day after Thanksgiving does not ensure a strong season over all. Last year, for example, the season began heartily enough and collapsed suddenly, as if shoppers had run their course in five days.
Another cause for concern was that retailers were practically giving away merchandise to lure consumers from their recent tightfistedness. Although pre-Christmas bargains have become as much a part of the holiday landscape as reindeer and pine wreaths in recent years, this year's desperation caused retailers to cut particularly deep. Whether it was a computer and color printer for $400 or CD's for $7.99 each, deals abounded. It remains to be seen whether the stores can make up in volume what they are losing in profit margins, but most analysts are doubtful.
As has been the trend for some years, the outlook for department stores seemed particularly bleak. They suffered a disproportionate share of the drop in the number of mall visitors, according to RCT. Shopper traffic for department stores dropped 12.4 percent on Friday compared with the figure for the day a year earlier and 11.6 percent on Saturday, according to RCT, and 5.2 percent compared with 1999.
If anyone was set to do more than survive this holiday season, it was the giant discount stores like Wal-Mart and Target. Their stores were noticeably the most crowded this weekend, and Wal-Mart reported sales for Friday of more than $1.25 billion, a single-day record.
"People definitely came and shopped," Peggy Palter, a spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck said late Friday, sounding almost surprised.
Internet merchants also reported good sales over the weekend, something that could be a side effect of having fewer shoppers at the mall. Yahoo reported that the number of shoppers coming through its Web portal was up 60 percent compared with last year. Amazon.com, America Online and Bluelight.com, the Internet arm of Kmart, also reported healthy increases in sales.

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief Sees an Economic Brightening 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 

 BODY:
Faced with the likelihood that the United States is about to be declared officially in a recession, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that the economy was "poised for recovery" and that the outlook for Wall Street remained bright.
 His relatively upbeat comments reflected the Bush administration's public forecast that the slowdown was likely to be brief and mild. But with economists divided over the projected length and severity of the economy's troubles -- and with much dependent on unknowable factors like the course of the war against terrorism -- they also represented a gamble that reassuring words now would not come to be seen as out of touch if the downturn deepened or endured. 
 The National Bureau of Economic Research, the academic body that is widely accepted as the authority on the timing of business cycles, is expected to announce as early as Monday that a recession is under way. Members of the bureau have considered dating the beginning of the downturn to March, 10 years after the start of what became the longest business expansion on record.
Even as it has pressed for a new round of tax cuts to get the economy going, the administration has been careful not to say that the nation is in recession. Administration officials, including Mr. O'Neill, have frequently suggested that an official recession, the first since President Bush's father was in the White House, could still be avoided. Still, most private economists have concluded that a downturn began this summer and is likely to last well into next year.
Asked about the state of the economy today on the ABC program "This Week," Mr. O'Neill hedged, saying it had not met the traditional definition of recession, or two consecutive quarters in which total output of goods and services declines.
In the third quarter, which ended Sept. 30, economic growth declined at a 0.4 percent annual rate. Earlier in the fall, Mr. O'Neill publicly held out hope that the fourth quarter could still be positive, something that few economists now expect. 
The National Bureau of Economic Research does not lock its assessment into quarterly growth figures -- instead using a more flexible definition of recession.
Mr. O'Neill said the bureau "may make the declaration" that a recession has started. But he said that the economy seemed already to have recovered from the shock of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, and that recent data, including strong post-Thanksgiving retail sales, suggested that the worst may be past.
"I think if you look at the data on Sept. 10, we were in the beginning of a recovery phase, and I think we've moved back there," he said. 
"I think there's no doubt we've had a slowdown," he said, "but I think we will see a recovery in the U.S. economy beginning early next year and growing as we move through the rest of the year."
Asked about the prospects for investors, Mr. O'Neill said he was sticking by the forecast he made in mid-September that in 18 months the stock market "would be showing comparisons that were better than the record we achieved in the past."
An official declaration that a recession has started would increase the pressure on Congress and the administration to come to agreement on an economic stimulus package. Negotiations between the parties on Capitol Hill and the White House have stalled.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Chasing Aid: $20 Billion Is Just a Start

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE $20 billion riddle is hereby solved. Well, at least explained:
 The noisy but confusing argument about what New York City deserves in federal aid is not about the $20 billion that President Bush so emotionally promised. No, it is really about the $30 or $35 billion or maybe more that New York's legislators believe the city needs and deserves. 
 The riddle unraveled may sound like just semantics, but definitions in the murky world of Washington turn into real dollars.
The $20 billion swiftly promised by the president at the behest of Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton was to be half of the $40 billion he requested from Congress for the war effort. But only about $9 billion has been earmarked for New York -- $11 billion if the White House's compromise with Republican lawmakers from upstate wins Congressional approval. 
What is really going on? Based on interviews with many budget players over the last 10 days, this:
The White House wants to hold the total payout to New York to $20 billion or less, appropriated over time, perhaps years. And it is trying to include in that total the federal aid that the city and state hope to get from a variety of federal programs.
New York's Democratic legislators want that other aid to come on top of the promised $20 billion, which can happen only if most of the president's promise is paid with new money from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. FEMA is traditionally generous to disaster-struck regions, and in candid moments, some members of New York's Congressional delegation concede that the city could eventually get up to $20 billion from FEMA.
But here is the key to the puzzling argument: the city plainly suffered much more than $20 billion in damage, scores of elected officials and economists have said. So lawmakers adept at the Washington budget game are pressing to get a clean $20 billion FEMA commitment, plus the right to lobby for much more assistance from other federal programs. Not easy, in part because the White House never specified the source of the $20 billion.
"When people say we are not going to get the $20 billion, they sort of miss the point," said one Democratic lawmaker. "The real danger here is not getting other things that we know we will need."
LET'S call those other things Package B and the $20 billion Package A. New York cannot get both if the White House counts Package B as part of Package A. Nor can New Yorkers lobby in Washington for Package B in the coming months if they are still preoccupied with lobbying for the $20 billion they thought was already theirs. 
Package B would include grants to businesses to stay downtown; a 26-week extension of unemployment benefits (13 weeks more than for other states); an expansion of health benefits for the unemployed, and special items in the national stimulus package being sought by Senators Clinton and Schumer, including tax cuts and credits and other incentives for Lower Manhattan. 
If hunks of Package B count as part of Package A, the White House could claim to have kept its commitment. But New York would wind up with much less than it needs. 
Complicating matters are the Balkanized politics of New York. As usual, elected officials are not speaking with one voice, which is hurting even in the Democratic-controlled United States Senate, which is currently considering a stimulus package. "When the Senate sees the governor and mayor not clamoring for money, it gives them plenty of excuses not to be supportive," explained one Democratic aide. 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is surely desirous of friends in Washington as he leaves City Hall, admonishes New Yorkers to respect the president; he says the city cannot spend $20 billion now anyway. True. But critics say the mayor's uncharacteristic placidity undermines the strategy of getting a FEMA commitment now.
Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg wants that commitment, as do Senators Clinton and Schumer, without whom the $20 billion request to Congress would not even exist. But Gov. George E. Pataki, in need of White House support for his re-election next year, has been silent since he was slapped down for asking Washington for $54 billion in aid. His advisers say vaguely that he is working behind the scenes.
So whither the $20 billion? New York may well, in time, get $20 billion, but not necessarily the disaster relief from FEMA that the president seemed to have promised. Call the money FEMA aid, and Congress will be free to appropriate much more. Call it the limit, and New York will have suffered yet another body blow.

HEADLINE: Congressional Countdown 

 BODY:
Congress has only a few weeks left before adjourning for the year. Yet there is still no legislative agreement on measures to boost the economy and improve protections against terrorist attacks. President Bush needs to help break the impasse on both issues, or legislators will go home covered with failure.
 Ideally, Congress should quickly pass a balanced fiscal stimulus bill aiding those who need help most without widening deficits in the years ahead. An appropriate homeland security measure would spend more than the $8 billion the administration wants and give New York City the money to speed its recovery from Sept. 11. 
 Right now there are two competing stimulus bills, and the one supported by most senators is by far the better. It would channel tax breaks and spending to those most hurt by the economic downturn, whereas the bill pushed by House Republicans would cut taxes disproportionately for the rich and for big corporations. But there is also some common ground in the two approaches. 
Congress could reach a financially responsible compromise if Republicans dropped their worst ideas -- a speed-up of the tax cuts enacted earlier this year for the wealthiest Americans and a separate measure to make it easier for big corporations to pay no taxes at all. The final bill could then focus on tax breaks, tax refunds and health benefits for the poor and the working poor, while helping small and medium-sized businesses with adjustments in write-offs for depreciation and expenses.
As for homeland defense spending, Tom Ridge told The Times last week that the nation's law enforcement and public health authorities needed more money to combat terrorism at home. Inexplicably, however, Mr. Ridge, the director of homeland security, argued that Congress can wait until next year to appropriate the money. But if more resources are needed, they should be mobilized now.
Before Thanksgiving, Senate Democrats tried without success to add $15 billion of spending for homeland defense needs. A separate proposal pending in the House is freer of pork-barrel spending than the Senate version. Sponsored by David Obey, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, it would spend $7 billion on health facilities, ports, borders and infrastructure to protect against terrorist attacks. The plan will have to overcome some parliamentary obstacles before it is voted on, but legislators from states with ports or international borders would be wise to support it. 
In a separate fight, New Yorkers want to add another $9 billion in spending this year for Lower Manhattan. In September, President Bush promised that at least $20 billion would be made available to help the city recover from the terrorist attacks. But only about $9.5 billion for direct cleanup costs is estimated as likely to be spent this year. As a result, New York legislators are asking for the balance to be spent on other measures that would help the area around ground zero. Senators Charles Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton have proposed setting aside about $5 billion for tax breaks to keep businesses in Lower Manhattan. Another $5 billion could be spent on grants to businesses, reconstruction and help for those displaced by the terrorist attacks.
Bush officials correctly point out that over the next several years the government will probably be spending more than $20 billion for emergency recovery efforts in the ground zero vicinity alone. But every day's economic data reinforces the fact that the city's needs are enormous and immediate. It would be best for an initial $20 billion to be spent this year. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki should get behind the New York delegation's efforts to lock up the money now.

HEADLINE: A Hunger Emergency in New York 

 BODY:
One of the first big challenges the Bloomberg administration will face is dealing with the crowds of people who are surging into food pantries and soup kitchens. The lines of hungry New Yorkers were already growing noticeably longer before Sept. 11, when terrorist attacks combined with the already faltering economy, costing the city nearly 80,000 mainly low-income jobs in the month of October alone. 
 The next statistical snapshot of the welfare rolls is due out early next month. However, recent figures from the city's two most important food-pantry groups suggest that the news will not be good. Food-distribution groups have seen a dramatic increase in the number of New Yorkers who seem to be putting what money they have toward the rent and relying on charity to feed their families. In a startling report issued earlier this month, Food for Survival, the city's largest supplier of emergency food, estimated that more than a million New Yorkers were relying on soup kitchens, food pantries and shelters to avoid going hungry. The New York City Coalition Against Hunger, which represents about 1,000 kitchens and pantries, reported a similar upsurge in demand. Unless more food becomes available, the coalition's members say they will be forced to turn away hundreds of thousands of hungry people. 
 Dealing with this crisis will require an about-face at City Hall, which actively discouraged people from applying for food stamps and welfare benefits during the Giuliani years. Food stamps, which are paid for solely out of federal funds, are a crucial tool in fighting hunger among the working poor. For starters, Mayor-elect Michael Bloomberg should work to ensure that every New Yorker who is eligible for food stamps actually gets them. Beyond that, City Hall needs to encourage individuals and businesses that have the means to replenish the shelves of the charity organizations that feed the poor.

HEADLINE: The Wrong Time to Fight Iraq 

 BODY:
The surprisingly swift successes of the American military campaign in Afghanistan have spurred talk about military action to oust Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. The world would be a safer place with Mr. Hussein's cruel dictatorship removed. At this point, however, there are no good short-term options for getting rid of him. The Bush administration would make a serious mistake by moving to wage war in Iraq. 
 One reason is that America's mission in Afghanistan is far from accomplished. Osama bin Laden and many top aides remain at large, Taliban fighters still hold out in the countryside and a few urban redoubts, and the creation of a stable post-Taliban government has barely begun. Until these basic objectives are achieved, Afghanistan will remain a potential base for international terrorism. 
 Finishing the job in Afghanistan requires holding together the international coalition Washington has skillfully assembled. War in Iraq at this juncture would almost certainly shatter that coalition. While some Arab leaders have no love for Mr. Hussein, public opinion in the Arab world would not allow them to support American military action against him, at least in the absence of clear evidence linking Baghdad to the events of Sept. 11 or subsequent bioterrorism. The American and British governments could quickly find themselves alone in any military campaign against Iraq.
War in Iraq would also undermine whatever possibility now exists for damping violence between Israelis and Palestinians and restarting efforts toward a lasting peace. Progress in the new peace initiative announced by Secretary of State Colin Powell last week might make it easier to ratchet up the pressure on Baghdad at a later date. Moving militarily against Iraq now would hobble America's power as a Mideast peacemaker.
Diplomacy aside, the military challenges of war in Iraq are far more formidable than anything yet seen in Afghanistan. Mr. Hussein can count on the loyalty of a large army, equipped with more modern and lethal weapons than the Taliban ever had. The center of his power, Baghdad, is a sprawling metropolitan area unsuitable to the kind of special operations American troops have conducted in Afghanistan. In another crucial difference, the United States would be operating without any effective local allies like the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan. The Iraqi National Congress, the umbrella opposition group supported by Washington, is a feud-ridden collection of exiled politicians who command no combat forces.
Without ground fighters, American air power cannot prevail. The only military option with any realistic promise of success would be sending in an overwhelmingly large American ground force. It takes months to transport and build up such forces, and, unlike the situation prior to the Persian Gulf war, Washington could not count on the use of staging bases in Saudi Arabia. 
Even if these military obstacles could somehow be overcome, Washington would still be faced with the problem of putting together a new Iraqi government. The country is sharply divided between Sunni and Shiite Muslims and between Arabs and Kurds, and there is a real risk of its disintegrating into weakened fragments, easily manipulated by more powerful neighbors like Iran. 
What Washington should do now is intensify its efforts to build up a more serious internal Iraqi opposition. While Mr. Hussein's security forces are fearsomely effective, there are hundreds of thousands of discontented Iraqis. Many can be found among the southern Shiite and northern Kurdish minorities that took up arms against Baghdad in 1991, only to be abandoned by Washington, and probably also among the ruling Sunni Arab group of central Iraq. An effective internal opposition could develop into a potential fighting force and perhaps the nucleus of a future government.
Meanwhile, Washington should put maximum diplomatic and military pressure on Baghdad. It can use its improved ties with Russia to enact more sustainable United Nations economic sanctions and to press for an early resumption of international weapons inspections. More than two decades of experience suggests that Saddam Hussein is unlikely ever to become a respectable international citizen. The challenge of removing him is best left for a day when the United States can count on the strong and effective support of opposition forces in Iraq.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 The Manhunt

ON THE GROUND -- Hundreds of marines landed at a makeshift airfield near the southern city of Kandahar in the first major infusion of American ground troops into Afghanistan. Their arrival began what Pentagon officials said would be a period of sustained assaults against Taliban and Al Qaeda forces. A1

THE DIE-HARDS -- The deputy defense minister of the Northern Alliance, Atiqullah Baryalai, said his men had captured the city of Kunduz, overrunning the last Taliban stronghold in northern Afghanistan. While the claim could not be verified, the situation in and around Kunduz clearly has worsened for the Taliban, after days of mass defections and intense American bombings. A1

A P.O.W. REVOLT -- Surrendered Taliban troops staged a revolt at a prison where hundreds of them were being held under the control of the Northern Alliance. American warplanes bombed the prison, outside Mazar-i-Sharif, to help quell the uprising. An unknown number of people died; at least one was reported to be an American. If true, that would be the first known American combat death in Afghanistan since the attack on Taliban forces began on Oct. 7. A1

So Many Hiding Places

THE CAVES -- If Osama bin Laden is hiding in a cave in Afghanistan, as American officials suspect, he has plenty to choose from. The country's varied landscape and geology make it ideal for caves. B4

OUT OF SIGHT -- The caves, tunnels and bunkers that worm their way under Afghan soil are devilishly complex and easy to hide within. As even the Pentagon admits, the most heavily fortified parts, where Osama bin Laden may be concealed, could well be invulnerable to the most powerful conventional bombs known. B4

After the Taliban

OPIUM FIELDS -- Now that the Taliban are gone, so is their ban on growing opium poppies. Barring an unexpected turn of events, Afghanistan can be expected to regain its status as the world's leading source of heroin in a year or two. B1

BONN CONFERENCE -- For Afghans, talks in Germany this week sponsored by the United Nations could determine whether their country reverts to civil war or unites for a new era of stability. For the rest of the world, it will take longer to determine whether the American commitment to stabilize Afghanistan is real, and whether the United Nations has become more adept at peacekeeping after a series of failures in the 1990's. B1

A DIPLOMATIC WOMAN -- Amina Safi Afzali, the only woman among the 11 Northern Alliance delegates who will attend the talks in Bonn, said she hoped women would play a more prominent role in Afghan society in the post-Taliban era. For two decades, Ms. Afzali has been a leading figure in the Afghanistan Women's Islamic Movement. The talks start Tuesday. B5

AT THE MOVIES -- For the first time in six years, hundreds of teenage boys enjoyed an afternoon at the movies in Kabul. The print of the movie, "Elan," an Indian action movie, was outdated, blurry and damaged, and none of the boys understood the dialogue. No one cared. B5

REFUGEES -- Near the border with Iran, at least 150,000 Afghans, and possibly as many as 300,000, live in a refugee camp that has no hospital, no schools and no roads. They were pushed from their homes not by war but by a drought heading into its fourth year. B5

Atrocities Recalled

MAYHEM -- In the summer of 1999, in the strategically important Shamali Plains north of Kabul, the Taliban went on a rampage meant to forever drive off tens of thousands of villagers they deemed sympathetic to the Northern Alliance. The few survivors who have ventured back have been stunned by the devastation. B2

The Nation's Mood

CHURCHGOING -- After the terror attacks, stunned Americans flocked for prayer and comfort not only to their local houses of worship, but also to sports stadiums, public plazas and convention centers. But now the evidence from churches and synagogues, combined with several polls, indicates that for most people, the spiritual storm has passed -- except perhaps in New York, where the pain of the attack is most intense. A1

FULL CIRCLE -- A flag covered with tributes to the police officers who died on Sept. 11 is being sent to Afghanistan as an inspirational and emotional memento to American troops. B1

THE MILITARY ON CAMPUS -- In ways large and small, the terror attacks have altered how the current generation of college students regards the military, the prospect of military service and their peers who decide to join. What emerges from dozens of interviews on three campuses in the New York area is a complex and sometimes surprising portrait of students who are rethinking their views of the military -- or for the first time thinking seriously about the role of the military in American life. The Biological Threat

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FUTURE; 
Afghans Wait For Portents In Bonn Talks

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 25 

 BODY:
With the Northern Alliance suddenly dominating much of Afghanistan, the effort to define the country's future is beginning to turn from a military phase to a political one. 
 While the Taliban home base of Kandahar and the hunt for Osama bin Laden will continue to be the focus of American attention, a vast majority of Afghans will be watching negotiations that start in Germany on Tuesday and that could determine whether their country reverts to civil war or unites in a new era of stability. 
 For the United States and its allies, the rest of the year will show whether the American commitment to stabilize Afghanistan is real, and whether the United Nations has become more adept at peacekeeping after a series of failures in the 1990's.
Afghanistan today, on one level, resembles Somalia at the onset of the United Nations intervention there in 1992, a point that pessimists often point out. United Nations diplomats, armed with peace proposals and backed by peacekeepers, tried to get the country's warring clans to agree to a settlement. The failed mission eventually ended after 18 American peacekeepers were killed and dragged through the streets of Mogadishu. Similarly, in Afghanistan, the rivalries, feuds and grudges left after 23 years of conflict, when many factions changed sides repeatedly, could lead to a resurgence of civil war. 
But United Nations officials said that the amount of international attention to the country now, and the proposed multibillion-dollar reconstruction effort, is unprecedented. If attention remains focused on Afghanistan, they argue, the country can heal.
"The difference now," said Francesc Vendrell, the United Nations deputy envoy to Afghanistan, "is that there is a great deal of international commitment -- far more than there was in the early 90's here or in Somalia -- to really address these problems."
On the streets of Kabul, the people are remarkably unified about what they want. In almost pleading voices, they express an utter exhaustion with war here. People from all major ethnic groups recite the same wishes for peace, a multiethnic government and, finally, economic development.
"What people here want is a broad-based government," said Jamakhan, an ethnic Tajik, referring to one that would represent many ethnic groups -- something quite different than the current situation. "Speaking frankly, we hate these people with guns," he said.
The first stage of the political process that could generate such a government begins on Tuesday in meetings outside Bonn. 
Delegates from four different Afghan opposition groups will meet with United Nations and American diplomats for the first round of talks on forming a provisional council that could rule the country.
The council would rule until a Loya Jerga, or grand council, could choose an interim head of state and government. 
With the aid of the United Nations, the interim government will administer the country for two to three years. Then elections would be held.
One of the interim government's main duties would be to create new, ethnically diverse police and military forces.
The Northern Alliance, which consists of eight different political groups and is dominated by ethnic Tajiks, Uzbeks, Hazaras and other minorities from the north, will be one of the two largest delegations at the meeting. 
The other will be a group of Pakistan-based opposition leaders who are ethnic Pashtuns, known as the Peshawar group. Smaller delegations will represent the deposed king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, who lives in Rome, and a group of exiled intellectuals known as the Cyprus group.
The meeting will be an early indication of the various groups' ability to reach a compromise. The provisional council's members will have early power and influence in the country. The council's members will enter the grand council, for example, in a strong political position. 
Whether the Bonn meeting devolves into deadlock or quickly agrees on its membership will be an early sign of what is to come. No strong leaders exist among the many factions. Younger leaders, like the head of the Northern Alliance delegation, Interior Minister Yunis Qanooni, insist that a new generation that has learned from the infighting of the past is ready to take power. Diplomats say an agreement must come quickly.
"We have a window of opportunity that the 11th of September opened," Mr. Vendrell said. "It's narrow, and it's not going to last forever."
But the same forces that pulled Afghanistan apart in the early 1990's remain in place here. The crushing poverty that turned political competitions into desperate scrambles for power and resources still exists. Thousands of armed men who helped fuel lawlessness a decade ago still roam the countryside.
In addition, neighboring Pakistan, Iran, Russia and Uzbekistan, which all backed different Afghan political factions and helped fuel the civil war, remain eager to exert their influence. "No one has given up their traditional values and interests," one Western diplomat said, referring to Afghanistan's neighbors.
But a large difference between the current situation and the past one is the incentive being offered to Afghan political leaders and warlords. Last week, the United States and other countries agreed to spend billions of dollars to reconstruct Afghanistan. Officials privately put the figure at $10 billion, a number that dwarfs the United Nations efforts to rebuild Kosovo and East Timor. 
The government that emerges from the grand council will also be the first chosen in a quasi-democratic method in the last 20 years, Mr. Vendrell said. That popular support should bolster its power and discourage those thinking of challenging it.
"The root cause of the conflict in Afghanistan over the last 20 years is the lack of popular legitimacy of successive Afghan governments," Mr. Vendrell said. "The lack of legitimacy raises challenges, which leads to conflict." 
Western diplomats arriving here said that focused American and European diplomatic pressure should be enough to persuade Pakistan and other countries not to interfere in Afghanistan. There is also a far larger international commitment to deploy an effective peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, they said, than in the failed United Nations missions in Rwanda, Bosnia and Somalia. Diplomats said they would prefer a force similar to the ones that intervened in Sierra Leone and East Timor, but the security council has issued no clear plan yet.
United Nations officials acknowledged that if a Northern Alliance commander, for instance, refuses to respect the authority of the provisional council, there would be few mechanisms for bringing him under control. But Mr. Vendrell said the combination of funding, popular opinion and diplomatic pressure should be enough to win cooperation.
"There should be enough incentives for the Afghans to move forward and not repeat the mistakes of the past," he said. "If this is not enough, I don't know what it's going to take."

HEADLINE: Robots Learn Soccer (and the Game of Life) 

BYLINE:  By YUDHIJIT BHATTACHARJEE 

 BODY:
Tucker Balch is an unusual kind of soccer coach.
 He rarely cheers from the sidelines, and he never gets angry with his players. Instead of shouting or pummeling the air, he leans forward every once in a while to punch commands into a computer. 
 But then, his team is unusual too. The players are all robots. And while Dr. Balch, a robotics researcher at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, sees no great future for robotic soccer stars, his experiments could provide surprising insights into the workings of human society. 
The robots in Dr. Balch's experiments are nothing more than a few lines of software code, gradually taught to play soccer on a computer screen. They are computer simulations of physical robots built by Dr. Balch -- shoe-box-size machines that he has entered in robot soccer tournaments.
Dr. Balch plans to reproduce his experiments using the real robots, work that he says will bring his findings closer to the realm of social reality.
On the computer, the robots learn to play soccer by executing a random sequence of basic moves -- running toward the ball, kicking it, moving behind the ball, blocking it. For every sequence, a computer program either rewards or punishes the robot with a digital signal telling it whether the sequence made sense and whether it should be repeated. 
Dr. Balch divides his robots into two teams, represented by little circles on the computer screen. Robots on a control team are able to pass the ball, defend and attack from the starting whistle; the test team must learn by trial and error as the game progresses. And it turns out that the test team behaves much differently depending on whether its members are rewarded as individuals or as a group.
Under the first scheme, a reward signal is sent only to robots that score a goal. As the match progresses, every team member ends up learning the same sequence of behaviors -- going after the ball in a solo effort to score. As a result, the circles on the screen bunch around a single point -- wherever the ball is -- leaving the rest of the field open to attack. 
Under the group-based reward scheme, all members in the learning team receive a reward whenever any of them scores a goal. After several learning loops, some of the robots ended up with behavioral sequences that made them good defenders. Others in the team evolved into forwards. "Group rewarding produced greater diversity," Dr. Balch said, "and that made the team a winning combination." 
The results may be surprising to those who believe that the pursuit of individual rewards -- as in capitalism -- encourages people to develop a diversity of ideas, points of view, goals and strategies to achieve them.
Dr. Balch is not rushing to extend his findings to human societies, and he acknowledges that human complexities -- including traits like motivation and jealousy -- are hard or impossible to reproduce in robotic systems. But he says the experiments show that robot studies can serve as a window for understanding human behavior. 
"Robots can learn and plan and communicate," he said. "They are probably the best model we have right now for controlled experiments on social systems." 
Dr. Ross Burkhart, a political science professor at Boise State University in Idaho, who has studied the relationship between economic freedom and democracy, says there are interesting parallels between the robot studies and the way economies work. 
"The goal in capitalism is for individuals to make as much money as they can," he said. "Whatever strategy brings one person a lot of wealth will inevitably become the strategy used by most people." 
Would a group-based reward system in a corporation make its employees specialize in different roles like the soccer-playing robots did under the socialist scheme? Dr. Andrew Schotter, an economist at New York University, laughs at the comparison. 
"Some employees would probably stop working," he said. "You can't eliminate free riding among office colleagues like you can in a team of robots. There will always be some people who will take advantage of the fact that their individual performance does not really matter." 
If employees are rewarded individually, Dr. Schotter argues, they can maximize their rewards by specializing in a certain role and carving a niche in the organization. 
Dr. Roger T. Johnson, who studies cooperative learning at the University of Minnesota, believes that competition for rewards pressures people to become similar.
"Cooperative reward systems often encourage diversity," Dr. Johnson said, "because a group can be more productive if its members have different perspectives. They offer a wider choice of ideas for problem-solving and doing things efficiently." 
Still, Dr. Schotter said there were too many differences between robots and human beings to justify any parallels. For one thing, people don't just work for money; they also work for fun.
"Also, people don't care only about what they are making individually," Dr. Schotter said. "They also worry about how much the person in the next cubicle is making." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Tucker Balch is conducting experiments with soccer-playing robots. He says such studies can aid in the understanding of human behavior. (Robin Nelson for The New York Times); (Courtesy of Tucker Balch)

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
Sunshine for Windy Dreamscapes

BYLINE:  By MARK DERR

DATELINE: FORT PIERCE, Fla. 

 BODY:
Wind-bent palm trees, sand, surf, billowing clouds and vivid sunsets were the essentials of Florida landscape painting that emerged following World War II. Occasionally moss-draped cypress trees in the still water of a marsh presented a more contemplative view, while a royal poinciana in full, flaming red bloom or a storm-tossed shore provided dramatic relief. 
 From the late 1950's into the early 80's these colorful landscapes were ubiquitous decorations in Florida homes, offices, restaurants and motel rooms. They shaped the state's popular image as much as oranges and alligators. 
 Little known, however, is that such paintings were largely the creations of a loose-knit group of self-taught, African-American artists from what was called Blacktown in the little east coast city of Fort Pierce, about 55 miles north of Miami, said Gary Monroe, professor of visual arts at Daytona Beach Community College. (The writer and folklorist Zora Neale Hurston died in poverty in Fort Pierce in 1960.) 
During those three decades, this group of friends, relatives and neighbors produced and sold an estimated 50,000 to 200,000 landscape paintings for $10 to $35 a piece, so the paintings were readily affordable to the average middle-class white worker.
Mr. Monroe said that by the early 80's their work went out of fashion because of changes in the tourist industry and new trends in interior design, among other factors. Many of the artists continued to work, but few were able to make a living at it. Now, however, there is a revival of interest in them because of the current popularity of self-taught or outsider artists. The best of those paintings, especially works from the 50's and 60's, are collectibles whose prices now range from $1,000 to $10,000. Works by others among the artists fetch $500 to $1,000 apiece. Though several members of the group have died and others have drifted away from art, a few are trying to take advantage of this new interest. 
Mr. Monroe discusses the history and artistic contributions of the painters in his new book, "The Highwaymen: Florida's African-American Landscape Painters," published last month by the University Press of Florida. 
He identifies 25 men and 1 woman as Highwaymen, explaining that the name was first applied to the Fort Pierce painters in 1994 by James Fitch, a collector of regional art and founder of the Florida Museum of Art and Culture at South Florida Community College in Avon Park. Mr. Fitch, who was buying regional art, came up with the name from the painters' practice of traveling up and down U.S. 1 and Highway A1A, selling their work mainly to white residents as well as tourists, hotels and restaurants. Despite some objections because of the name's outlaw connotations, the painters have largely embraced it as a valuable marketing tool.
The group owes its inspiration to Albert Ernest Backus of Fort Pierce, known as Bean, considered the dean of Florida landscape painting by the time of his death in 1990, Mr. Monroe said. 
The story is that in 1954, Backus, who was white, persuaded a black 19-year-old, Harold Newton, to stop painting religious scenes and take up landscapes, which he quickly taught himself to do. Gallery representation was out of the question for black painters at that time in South Florida, and so Newton began selling his paintings directly out of his car, a practice all the painters would follow. For these young black painters it was basically a choice between work in the orange groves or another menial job, or if they had any talent at all, making art. 
A year later Backus began giving lessons to 14-year-old Alfred Hair, the only one of the group to receive such formal training, although many of the others had received some art lessons in public school. Hair struck out on his own three years later, ready to be an artist, Mr. Monroe writes. This charismatic young dreamer planned to be a millionaire by the time he was 35.
Newton and Hair are generally considered the two best Highwaymen artists, with Newton the more formal and technical of the two and Hair the more lyrical and spontaneous.
Newton inspired a number of artists, including Mary Ann Carroll, 60, the sole woman in the group. In a recent interview she recalled deciding to try landscapes after seeing a painting of a red poinciana under an oak tree in Newton's yard.
But it was Hair who set the tone for the group through the 1960's. He would tack up 20 boards at a time outdoors, then quickly lay down the color without sketches, as fast as he could, going from board to board, painting parts of sky, a tree or some other element. The essence of his paintings was spontaneity, bold colors, palm trees, surf, sand and incredible skies. 
"Painting fast was a prerequisite, not a deterrent to Hair's art," Mr. Monroe writes. "He simply 'threw paint' on his boards to miraculously achieve images that are more about being alive than about the manipulation of plastic values."
Hair drew into his orbit a small circle of friends who were similarly young, energetic and ambitious for wealth. Largely ignorant of artistic tradition, they learned from one another and spurred one another to paint rapidly and abundantly, often producing scores of oil paintings at a stretch, usually on Upson board, a common roofing material.
"Alfred was a competitive guy and lived for competition," said James Gibson, 63, one of the few members of that circle to have made his living solely through art for more than 40 years. 
The landscapes they created in their backyards or utility rooms were illusions that bore only an imagined resemblance to what existed in nature. "We improvised from something in our mind," said Hezekiah Baker, 61, during an interview in his Fort Pierce home.
Weekly they loaded their paintings into their cars and peddled them from Miami to Daytona Beach and inland to Lake Okeechobee and Orlando. They sold whatever they produced without difficulty.
Then Hair was killed during an argument over a woman in a local juke joint on Aug. 9, 1970, and much of the creative energy that held the group together died with him, Mr. Monroe said. 
The group continued to produce and sell paintings despite the recession in the mid-70's, but by the early 80's changing tastes and factors like the creation of Disney World and other corporate attractions helped reduce demand for the paintings. Mr. Gibson and Newton, who died in 1994, continued to paint and enhance their reputations throughout the period. 
Of the 23 remaining Highwaymen some stopped painting to raise families or pursue other interests. A few became addicted to drugs and alcohol. There were also financial irregularities involving their top salesman, Al Black, who was also an artist. He was sentenced to prison for fraud for action unrelated to the Highwaymen, and remains there, still painting. 
Mr. Fitch said that when he began collecting Highwaymen paintings in the 1990's, he would find them in flea markets, garage sales and garbage cans for anywhere from $1 to $450. Now the price for an Alfred Hair landscape approaches $10,000, Mr. Monroe said. 
Because the earlier paintings from the 50's and 60's are the most sought after, art dealers are primarily the ones who profit from the increased prices. Nonetheless the artists who continue to paint are gaining higher prices for their new work. With the current revival a number of the Highwaymen are attempting to resurrect their artistic careers and deal with a celebrity they never expected.
"I never thought of myself as being famous," said Ms. Carroll, who raised seven children while supporting herself as a carpenter, house painter, church musician and landscape artist. "I just give God the praise for what I got in my life."

HEADLINE: Airline Sees Sept. 11 as a Turning Point 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 21 

 BODY:
How could Sept. 11 have been anything but a calamity for the world's airlines?
 Passengers canceled reservations, airlines were forced to cut dozens of routes and lay off thousands of employees, and strict new security measures at airports turned routine trips into marathon ordeals. 
 Yet here in Taiwan, the state-controlled carrier, China Airlines, views the near collapse of the industry as an opportunity. Its reputation has improved at a time when those of other airlines are suffering. In the cold calculus of risk, it helps that China Airlines is not American. 
"People believe United Airlines is still a target," the chief executive of China Airlines, Christine T. Y. Tsung, said. "They can also see that we've improved our performance and safety; 9/11 could be a turning point for us."
Ms. Tsung said China Airlines had lured away some passengers who might otherwise have chosen United to fly between Taiwan and the United States. She hopes these jittery converts will become permanent customers.
When Ms. Tsung took over the airline in July 2000, the situation was almost the reverse. The major United States airlines were riding high, and China Airlines suffered with a dismal safety reputation. Three of its planes had crashed in six years in the 1990's, killing more than 450 people.
Two crashes were attributed to pilot error, which raised questions about the culture of China Airlines. Founded in 1959 by retired Taiwan Air Force officers, the airline was run like an old boy's club, and co-pilots rarely questioned the actions of their captains.
"I told them, 'You don't communicate well enough,' " Ms. Tsung said in an interview. "Sometimes first officers need to speak up."
Ms. Tsung, 52, was perhaps perfectly suited to shake up the airline's culture: she is a woman, had no previous experience in aviation and had not even lived in Taiwan for most of the last three decades. Born in mainland China and raised in Taiwan, Ms. Tsung left to attend business school in the United States in 1972 and did not move back until 1999.
After graduating, she held various financial jobs, including one at Columbia Pictures, and then became the finance director of Poway, Calif., a city of 32,000 that was carved out of San Diego in 1982. The job that brought her back to Taiwan two years ago was advising its second-largest city, Kaohsiung, on its mass transit system.
While in California, Ms. Tsung kept a hand in Taiwan's politics. After the main opposition leader, Chen Shui-bian, was elected president in March 2000, ending a half-century of Nationalist rule, he ousted the top executives of China Airlines and installed Ms. Tsung.
"At the time, I asked myself, 'Why do I always get the tough job?' " she said. "It's the story of my life."
Beyond the hidebound pilot culture, China Airlines is hobbled by the China Aviation Development Foundation, a quasi-government organization that owns 71 percent. Taiwan wants to privatize the airline, but its plans have been delayed because of the global downturn and investor antipathy toward airline stocks.
While Ms. Tsung cannot change her owners, she is trying to change the mind-set of employees. She is hiring fewer pilots with military backgrounds and sending more of them to be trained in the United States and Australia. She has culled the management ranks and encouraged rank-and-file employees to send her e-mail messages.
"Putting a woman in that position was the best thing they could have done," said Jim Eckes, a consultant at Indoswiss Aviation in Hong Kong. "It was a male-dominated culture, and the guys weren't doing a good job."
Industry executives say Ms. Tsung met resistance from the pilots and the officials at the China Aviation Development Foundation. But by all accounts, she has been undaunted. And as the airline's performance has improved, her management style has won more supporters in the ranks.
With a clean safety record since 1998, China Airlines is gradually regaining the trust of travelers. Passenger traffic and cargo tonnage reached new levels in 2000, before the Taiwanese economy began to sour.
The airline lost $2.3 million in the third quarter of 2001, largely because of the falloff in traffic after Sept. 11. Ms. Tsung expects the total number of passengers for the year to decline about 5 percent.
Still, China Airlines will earn about $40 million in pretax profit in 2001 -- no mean feat for an Asian airline in the current climate. Ms. Tsung has nudged profit up by aggressive foreign currency hedging; she also hedged against rising fuel prices by buying futures contracts.
But no amount of financial engineering can protect China Airlines from the troubled American market. Thirty-two percent of its passengers and 58 percent of its cargo go to or come from the United States. Ms. Tsung said the terrorist attacks would have a lingering effect on that business.
"This was the first time airplanes were used as weapons," she said, "which was truly devastating to the industry."
Given the troubles with trans-Pacific service, Ms. Tsung considers the future of China Airlines to be to the west, in mainland China. Beijing and Taipei were recently admitted to the World Trade Organization, which some analysts say will open the door for direct flights across the Taiwan Strait.
To prepare, China Airlines bought 25 percent of the cargo operation of China Eastern Airlines, a carrier based in Shanghai, and invested in a cargo terminal at Xiamen airport, in the coastal province of Fujian.
But direct flights are a more distant prospect, since they raise issues of sovereignty. Beijing insists that Taiwan is a breakaway province, not a separate country, and a recent proposal for Taiwan's airlines to avoid flying over Afghanistan by crossing Chinese territory foundered because of political concerns.
"You have to respect your government and the issue of eminent domain," Ms. Tsung said. Once the political issues are worked out, she said, she would be eager to take China Airlines to China, noting, "We have always had a policy of following Taiwan's merchants around the world."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christine T. Y. Tsung, chief executive of China Airlines, has worked to change the culture at the carrier and improve its safety record. (David Hartung for The New York Times)
