HEADLINE: Catching the Urban Wave 

BYLINE:  By D. J. Waldie; D. J. Waldie lives in Lakewood, on the margin of Los Angeles. He is the author of "Holy Land: A Suburban Memoir."

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD, Calif. 

 BODY:
The words "urban" and "Los Angeles" look uncomfortable in each other's presence, in the same way most Angelenos look uncomfortable in the shoulder-rubbing crowds that other cities take for granted. The region's anti-urban domesticity is its 100-year-old sales pitch, and the success of the pitch to waves of exiles from elsewhere has depended until now on maintaining the carefully planned suburban distances that separate me from my neighbors here. Even 800 square miles of cityscape have failed to evoke the loyalties that real cities demand of their residents.
 My father worked for the Southern California Gas Company at its downtown headquarters. When I was a boy in the 1950's, my father's city seemed as remote as any back East. I never felt his downtown was the center of anything, except in the noir films of the era, where Los Angeles looked like the capital city of regret. 
 Regret for the city that might have been still hangs over downtown, more durable than the layer of smog overhead that seems to begin just where the few tall buildings end. And yet, after 50 years of discarded opportunities, there are now new and hopeful signs that city life in Los Angeles has a chance of being revived.
Frank Gehry's stainless steel hall for the Los Angeles Philharmonic is warping into completion one block south of Jose Rafael Moneo's modernist cathedral complex for the Los Angeles Archdiocese. A 27-acre hotel and retail expansion of the Los Angeles Convention Center/Staples Center sports arena at the southwest corner of downtown has won City Council approval. The Los Angeles Center Studios, on downtown's western edge, has plans to add more movie sound stages to the six already completed. The Southern California Institute of Architecture will celebrate on Friday its relocation to a former freight depot along the gritty concrete channel of the Los Angeles River, 10 blocks east. The California state government and the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy are completing purchase of 38 acres of riverside land (called the Cornfield) to create downtown's only large park. New plans for Broadway, already the thriving mercado of Latino downtown, would renovate the street's pre-World War II movie houses to encourage night life.
Within the crooked square bounded by freeways and the river that broadly defines downtown, another 35 public and private projects -- some completed, others in active development -- are changing the expectations Angelenos have about their city. Three forces are driving change. Los Angeles is built out (experts here say that "sprawl has hit the wall"), and the suburbs resist more intensive development in neighborhoods elsewhere in the region: those two forces leave downtown almost the last place left to build in. The third force is the presence downtown of a new kind of developer/entrepreneur. The most passionate of them is Tom Gilmore.
Mr. Gilmore, a former New Yorker, wants to be a city maker for Los Angeles in the grand manner of William Mulholland, Abbott Kinney and Gaylord Wilshire. His sales pitch isn't freedom in the suburban sunshine, however. Instead, it's a loft in a renovated bank building and a chance encounter on a busy sidewalk after dark. This is what our urbanity will be like, appealingly noir but without the despair.
In the city's historic core -- the 200 acres of virtually abandoned office buildings from the turn of the 20th century that cluster near Pershing Square -- Mr. Gilmore and other developers hope to create hundreds of loft units to bring residential life to a downtown that has been dark for decades.
So far, the sales pitch has been most successful with singles in their 20's and 30's who are proud of living a block from Skid Row. If the economy climbs out of recession quickly, if state and federal redevelopment programs don't dry up and if the isolated dots of loft buildings become connected at street level by new businesses, it may be possible to support 8,000 new housing units by the end of 2005.
That downtown's residential population might grow by 50,000 seems minor by the standards of Manhattan. But the modest numbers don't really show the ambitions being worked out here. For the first time in 50 years, we have a chance to recreate truly urban residential neighborhoods, something that half a century of demolition and rebuilding downtown had all but erased. The challenge for developers and city officials is creating a sense that this downtown might actually be central to something -- though it won't ever be the center of Los Angeles.
It never was. But downtown can become a specialized, hipsterized district. And in time, its reinvented urbanness may set a different example of city life in this vast geography that has seemed to those who live here more fluid and hopeful and possibly better tuned to freedom than other places.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Decline on Pessimism Over Russian Production Cuts 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell yesterday on speculation that Russia would not reduce its output beyond the 50,000 barrels a day it has already set for this year, a 0.7 percent decline that is about a quarter of what OPEC wants to help counteract slowing demand.
 Chekib Khelil, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said prices "will collapse" without help from the Russians and other producers. 
 Russia said on Friday that it would establish 2002 production levels by Dec. 10. OPEC members agreed on Nov. 15 to cut back their output by 1.5 million barrels a day beginning in January, but only if nonmembers made equivalent reductions. So far, most producers outside OPEC have not made commitments on such a scale. 
Moscow "doesn't seem to want to insist on a bigger cut," said Ed Silliere, vice president for risk management at Energy Merchant L.L.C. in New York. "We have to see if OPEC goes ahead and makes its cuts without the full cooperation of other producers."
In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 27 cents, or 1.4 percent, yesterday to $18.69 a barrel. Commodity oil prices are down 47 percent from this time last year. The United States markets were closed on Thursday and Friday for Thanksgiving. In London, Brent crude oil for January delivery fell 92 cents, or 4.8 percent, to $18.36 a barrel.
"On Thursday, you saw a big rise in London on signs that Russia would make a substantial move," said Chester Irvin, a broker at ABN Amro in New York. "That was followed by the 50,000-barrel announcement, which has us moving lower."
Crude oil prices in New York have dropped 32 percent since the attacks on Sept. 11 as traders became more concerned about weakening demand than a possible disruption in Middle East supplies because of American military action in Afghanistan.
The demand for crude oil from the United States, the world's largest consuming nation, has slowed this year along with the economy. "If the economy starts to recover just as the OPEC cuts take effect early next year," said Aaron Kildow, an energy analyst at Prudential Securities in New York, "we could see prices jump. The cheap oil and gasoline we are witnessing now would be a major reason for the increase in economic activity."
The 11 OPEC countries, counting Iraq, pump 35 to 40 percent of the world's oil. Norway, the No. 2 non-OPEC exporter, has offered to reduce its output by as much as 200,000 barrels a day, while Mexico said it might contribute half that much. Oman has offered to cut production by 25,000 barrels a day, or about 3 percent of its total.

HEADLINE: The Name of Recession 

 BODY:
For most of us, economics is an experiential fact, not a matter of science or data or even market performance. We tend, at best, to know only what we feel, and this is never truer than when the national economy is troughing or peaking. The National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., acts as the semiofficial cartographer of those peaks and troughs. Yesterday it announced that the country was "officially" in a recession that began in March. That news is a little like going to the doctor and being told that the mild flu-like symptoms you've been feeling are actually the flu. The recession is real. Now we know why it feels as if we're in a recession. 
 There are genuine numbers and continuing trends behind the judgment that the economy has turned downward enough to give the downturn a name. But most Americans recognized the recession simply by the claims that were being made on their economic empathy. Even before Sept. 11, the news was full of job losses numbering in the thousands and tens of thousands. It was, and is, impossible to read those business articles, even if your own job is secure, without thinking of the individual stories they conceal, the lives and families turned upside down by the sudden disappearance of gainful employment at a time when the social safety net is considerably attenuated. 
 Certainly, this recession is just as perceptible as any of the 10 other American recessions since World War II. In a way, it should be even more keenly noticeable, because it measures a fall from what were truly dizzying heights. In normal times this would be the big news, the lead story. But these days there is bigger news, and the lead story is one that is not -- or not necessarily -- economic. According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, Sept. 11 may have worsened the economy enough to tip us into recession, sharpening existing downward trends. And yet knowing that this recession was brought about partly by causes extrinsic to ordinary business cycles seems to offset its psychological effect. That, and the fact that Sept. 11 gave Americans something else to think about, something to stiffen their spines.
Calling the current state of the economy by its proper name gives a concreteness to the felt mood, which was discernible even in the hectic flourish of post-Thanksgiving Christmas shopping -- a leading economic indicator for retailers and regular people alike. Every day the news tugs at us, implicating our reason and emotions in ways that are often contradictory. The thought of recession is only one strain in the intricate harmony, or dissonance, that each day produces. It's reassuring to know that most recent recessions have lasted a little less than a year, which means that we're well along in this one. We can only look forward to the next announcement from the economists in Cambridge, confirming the good news we will already have been feeling.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Three Major Indexes Reach Highest Points Since Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology shares helped drive the market to post-Sept. 11 highs yesterday as anticipation of an economic rebound next year took the sting out of word that the United States has been in a recession for most of 2001.
 "The market is clearly looking forward on the assumption of the return of the economy in 2002," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "But the near-term news still leaves a little to be desired. It's not the clearest picture of an oncoming bull market." 
 The economy slid into recession in March, snapping a record 10-year-long expansion on its anniversary month, according to a panel of economists that dates the nation's business cycles.
That panel, the National Bureau of Economic Research, said the Sept. 11 attacks only made an already ailing economy worse.
 Hopes for an economic rebound next year have pulled stocks well above the Sept. 21 lows reached in the wake of the assault on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
Chip stocks like Intel kept up their two-month rally yesterday, but oil stocks slumped on a fall in crude oil prices, and the retailer Home Depot fell on fears of slowing growth in sales. 
Intel rose 81 cents, to $31.87. Home Depot closed at $45.52, down $1.06.
All three major stock indexes ended the day at their highest levels since Sept. 11.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index climbed 38.03 points, or 2 percent, to 1,941.23. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.04 points, or 0.2 percent, to 9,982.75, inching closer to the crucial 10,000-point level.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.08 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,157.42.
 The Nasdaq has surged more than 36 percent since its late September lows, while the Dow has rallied more than 21 percent and the S.& P. 500 has climbed almost 20 percent.
Rapid-fire gains in the market have left many investors wondering if stocks are ready to pull back.
 "It's very possible things are getting a little too far ahead," said Edgar Peters, chief investment officer at PanAgora Asset Management, which manages $13 billion. "We have come an awful long way in a very short period."
 At least one of the six members of the National Bureau of Economic Research panel suggested that a recovery would be possible by mid-2002. That member, Ben Bernanke, a professor at Princeton University, said that based on patterns of recessions lasting 6 to 18 months, "we would expect a trough, beginning a recovery, by July next year."
Robert Baur, head of trading at Invista Capital Management, which oversees $24 billion, said: "I think, frankly, the market has already priced in a recession. It was shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks that almost all economists on Wall Street declared the U.S. in a recession."
The official declaration on a recession could add urgency to Washington's debate over a stimulus package for the economy, analysts said. Investor sentiment was also bolstered by more progress in the military campaign in Afghanistan. --------------------

Prices of Treasuries Mixed
By Bloomberg News
 Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday as a rise in stocks pointed to an economic recovery, dimming expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates for an 11th time this year.
 "The Fed is nearing the end -- how much further can rates fall?" said David Brownlee, who helps manage $7 billion at the National Life Investment Management Company in Montpelier, Vt. "If the economy does turn around," the rise in yields "could continue -- that's why the stock market is at these levels."
The 10-year Treasury note fell 3/32, to a price of 99 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.01 percent from 5 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 99 31/32. The bond's yield remained 5.38 percent.

HEADLINE: But for the Young and Brave, Love Conquers Fear 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
In countless ways, New York City is not the same place that it was before Sept. 11. But that has not kept some people away from the city that they have loved from afar.
 These newcomers are the hardy souls -- or the foolhardy ones, their relatives and friends might say -- who have moved here despite the terrorist attacks, the anthrax scares, and now, the recession. 
 Unlike native New Yorkers, they were not already bound to the city by longtime jobs, families, schools or real estate. They had a choice about where to go, and they came anyway. For them, the rigors of daily life have become both a challenge and a source of immeasurable pride. 
A few are transplanted New Yorkers who are returning when they feel most needed. Fran and Kaz Kuzui, executive producers of the television shows "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and "Angel," headed for the Hollywood Hills in 1991, but remained staunch New Yorkers in their hearts. Since the terrorist attacks, Mrs. Kuzui said, she has become more homesick than ever. She sold their house last month and has been looking at two-bedroom apartments near Central Park with her broker, Robby Browne of Insignia Douglas Elliman. 
"Physically, I don't know what I can do," said Mrs. Kuzui, who is in her 50's. "But certainly, I want to be part of it, and add my love of the city to the effort it's going to take to heal it."
Many others, though, had no connection to the city other than in their dreams and ambitions.
Damon Booth arrived here from Los Angeles on Sept. 15 to take his dream job as a talent scout for Warner Brothers Records. His wife, Angela, and their 2-month-old son, Wyatt, flew out on Sept. 10, but Mr. Booth was delayed by business and booked a flight for the next day. After the airports were closed, he drove across the country.
From his office in Rockefeller Center, Mr. Booth, 32, looks down upon the funeral processions entering St. Patrick's Cathedral to honor the victims. He hears the wails of the bagpipes. Every so often, he scans the sky for planes that seem to be flying too close to the Empire State Building.
"I feel like I've been baptized a New Yorker sooner than normal," he said. "Because of the intensity of the circumstances."
The Booths have rented a two-bedroom apartment in Murray Hill that they found through their broker, Scott Stewart of the Corcoran Group.
"I haven't had a single deal fall apart because of Sept. 11," Mr. Stewart said. "It has been really busy. People need a place to live."
In the old New York, calling oneself a New Yorker was often a sign that one had left behind small-town roots and arrived in a glamorous world celebrated in novels, movies and television shows. But now, it also means other things. For those who were already here on Sept. 11, it means being a survivor of one of the worst tragedies in history. For those who come afterward, it means not giving up on a city even when the good times are over.
"It's relatively clear that the fizz is off the Champagne," said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. "People are much more serious and determined, and I think that is to be expected. We had a terrible tragedy and the economy is changing."
More than ever, Mr. Schill said, New Yorkers and others are realizing just how much the city needs them, and how much they need the city. "There are enough ambitious people reaching to find the best in themselves that this city will never have a shortage of people wanting to be part of it," he said. "I hope I'm not sounding hokey, but I truly believe it."
Some aspiring New Yorkers, like Margaret Crisostomo, an events coordinator from Los Angeles, have closely followed the city's recovery. A week after the terrorist attacks, Ms. Crisostomo, 29, accepted a job with the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation in Manhattan, because she had wanted to live here for a long time. "When you read books and watch movies, it just seems like a cool, cool, cool place to be," she said. "It seems like the hub of everything."
Ms. Crisostomo, who moved to the city last Friday, said she was not sure what she would find now. "It's never going to be the same as it was," she said. "And that part really bums me out. But I feel it would still be a good time to be here and see the city rejuvenate and reinvent itself."
Just the logistics of moving to the city now can seem extra daunting. 
Stephen Collier, 30, had planned to fly out on Sept. 30 from Berkeley, Calif., to take a position as a research fellow at Columbia University. After the hijackings, though, he no longer wanted to get on a plane. He decided to drive instead, but his mother still worried about terrorists attacking the tunnels and bridges into Manhattan and tried to find a safer route for him.
"Her big plan was the Staten Island Ferry," said Mr. Collier, who eventually drove to Staten Island and then to Brooklyn.
But once here, many newcomers say they are finding a city that seems kinder somehow, and less intimidating, than what they had come to expect.
Dan James, 35, a computer engineer for International Business Machines, who is moving to the Upper West Side from Bloomfield, N.J., said he was recently invited to a party in Chinatown. Though he knew only one person when he arrived, he had made a dozen friends by the time he left. To his surprise, he said, people seemed to make an effort to mingle and dance with strangers. 
"There's more of a sense of kinship in the city," he said. "People seem to feel that they can't not speak to you, that they have to put on a friendly face."
Some newcomers like Jane Hart, a marketing executive for a pharmaceutical company, have even changed their minds about the city. Ms. Hart, who moved from Denver in late August, used to pull down the blinds and turn on the air-conditioner in her temporary housing in Chelsea to block out the city at night. On weekends, she looked at places in Hoboken, N.J., and in Westchester County.
Ms. Hart, 49, said she had been so impressed by the strength and spirit of New Yorkers in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks that now she would not mind being one of them. After making an offer on a two-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side last month, she flew back to Denver and loaded her two cats, two dogs and two horses into a trailer to drive to her new home (the horses will be boarded at a stable in Pennsylvania for now).
"What you hear when you don't live in New York is that people don't care about anything here," she said. "That has not been my experience. I found out that they care a lot about their city, and they're proud of it."

HEADLINE: Hamamatsu Journal; 
Sons and Daughters of Japan, Back From Brazil

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: HAMAMATSU, Japan 

 BODY:
Joining a flood of Brazilians lured here a decade ago to fill vacancies on Japan's assembly lines, Benedito Vilela Garcia came planning to make some quick yen then to go back home, hoping to open a pharmacy in his native country. 
 Now, after failing with his pharmacy venture, he is back with a permanent visa. No longer a temporary "aventureiro," he has opened two Brazilian schools, part of a move among 11,000 Brazilians to put down roots in this boxy gray industrial city, sandwiched between the Pacific Ocean and the Japanese Alps. 
 Japan, an insular nation that prizes ethnic and cultural homogeneity, has long kept its foreign workers at arm's length. 
But with a daunting demographic hump on the horizon -- by 2025 a quarter of the population will be over 65 -- it is changing its approach to the quarter-million Brazilians, largely of Japanese descent, who have moved here. 
Ten years from now Japan's baby boomers will start retiring, and the United Nations has recommended that Japan import 600,000 workers a year to keep the world's second-largest economy on track and its pension systems from collapsing. 
While Japan shows no intention of meeting that goal, last year the government began offering permanent visas to Brazilian migrants, turning them into immigrants and giving this country a foretaste of cultural diversity. 
"Japan has to come out of its shell," said Ivan Cannabrava, Brazil's ambassador. In contrast to the bitter colonial origins of Korean and Chinese populations in Japan, he said, "There are no historic resentments with Brazil."
"There is no desire among the Brazilians to isolate themselves," he added. "For Japan this is the unique experiment of a foreign community trying to integrate itself."
Japanese began arriving in Brazil in 1908 to work on coffee plantations. With the United States imposing anti-Asian immigration controls in the 1920's, the numbers grew faster in Brazil. 
Brazil now has 1.3 million people of Japanese ancestry, the largest such population outside Japan. The reverse migration began in 1990, when Japan liberalized its immigration laws to allow Brazilians of Japanese descent and their spouses to come to Japan on temporary work visas.
Until four or five years ago, Brazilians were here just to put together money to go home, Mr. Garcia said during a tour of his school here, a hilltop establishment echoing with the singsong of Brazilian Portuguese. Now many have come back, planning to stay.
In the last five years, the number of private Brazilian schools in Japan has mushroomed, from 4 to 41. There are two Brazilian television channels and four Brazilian weekly newspapers. 
Although Japan's Brazilian population has stabilized at 254,000, the amount of money sent home has dropped 60 percent since 1997, falling to $294 million last year, according to Brazil's Central Bank. Spending their salaries here, immigrants now tap into a network of Portuguese-speaking real estate agents and car salesmen.
"Before, they used to go by bicycle or buy a minicar -- now they all want a one-million-yen car," Mr. Garcia said, contrasting his sensible 1980's Toyota with newer $8,000 models.
But all is not smooth for new immigrants in a society that prizes conformity. At a meeting here recently for mayors of 13 Japanese cities with large Brazilian minorities, talk ranged over social problems, from cultural clashes to school absenteeism to crime.
Hidefumi Tanaka, mayor of Iida, home to 1,700 Brazilians, who make up 1.5 percent of its population, complained that foreigners failed to take seriously a municipal recycling system and a ban on picking apples from trees on the city's showcase boulevard.
There was also concern among the mayors about the crime rates among the Brazilians. Adelson Brito, a Brazilian who works for this city as a crime prevention coordinator, says there is some delinquency by the children of immigrants who fail to study Japan's language, laws or customs while working long hours in factories. "The Brazilian schools prepare people for their past in Brazil, not their future in Japan," he said. 
The new schools may ease alienation, though. Of Japan's 35,000 school-age Brazilians, only 7,000 attend public schools. Some of the mayors gathered here estimated that as many as half of the Brazilian children in their cities were not in school. Mandatory education and universal health coverage do not apply to foreigners.
"They treat you differently," Henrique Toshio, 14, a student at the Brazilian school here, responded when asked why he dropped out of Japanese school. "The Japanese don't like to hang out with Brazilians."
There are success stories, though, like Edson M. Tamada, who recalls how he dropped out of high school in Sao Paulo, moving here at 17 to work in an auto parts factory. 
Today he runs I. B. Fox, a multinational food company with a binational staff of 70 and revenues of $16 million. The key to success, he said, is for immigrants to embrace Japanese "culture, customs, language -- to integrate into the community, to create a new generation."
But for now the cultural gap is deep. 
To entertain the mayors, the Brazilian school here presented a show, starting off with a roll of drums and the shimmy of samba dancers.
"There is a tremendous cultural difference," observed Jacques Jobin, a visiting Canadian urban government expert, standing in a sea of black-suited Japanese city officials. "In that first dance, when the young girls came out in the bikinis and feathers, the majority of the men stared at their feet."

HEADLINE: Public Feuding At Pension Fund; 
Dirty Laundry Keeps Flying At Calpers, No. 1 Plan in U.S.

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 

 BODY:
If the governing board of the nation's largest and most influential public pension plan were being judged by the standards it sets for the companies it invests in, it might be calling for a shake-up.
 For two years running, the members of the board of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the roughly $150 billion pension plan commonly called Calpers, have been at one another's throats. 
 The state controller, an elected official who serves on the board, successfully sued Calpers to limit its investment managers' pay -- a policy that recently helped prompt the fund's chief investment officer to quit. Another member backed a separate suit challenging the board's election procedures; earlier, he had been forced to apologize for a remark about the ethnic background of yet another board member, the state treasurer.
Relations are so strained that the 13-member board ordered an internal review of its practices. After 10 months of study, the members last month adopted a "document of collegiality" that commits them, among other things, to following Robert's Rules of Order and trying to resolve disputes informally before taking the fund to court. 
"They were almost throwing things at each other," said Richard Koppes, a corporate lawyer in Sacramento who was the fund's general counsel from 1986 to 1996 and was called in to advise the board this spring.
The bickering has sullied the reputation of Calpers, which manages retirement money on behalf of 1.3 million state and county employees, including 370,000 retirees.
In the 1980's and 90's, the fund was one of the most influential investors on Wall Street, taking sides in takeover battles and demanding more involved, independent boards at companies like General Motors; Sears, Roebuck; and Time Warner.
But the boom years of the last decade gave Calpers less to complain about, its principles became more widely accepted in boardrooms and the fund focused more of its attention on private investments, including real estate and venture capital, as well as on activism abroad. Calpers executives took to offering their advice to American corporate executives in private.
The latter shift was one more cause for disagreement among board members, some of whom worried that Calpers appeared to be losing its edge.
"We don't seem as aggressive in the press," said William Dale Crist, an economics professor at California State University at Stanislaus who is president of the Calpers board. "Our decision to be more soft spoken, more quiet -- perhaps it's been a mistake."
So far, Calpers has managed to meet its investment benchmarks despite the turmoil. But some people worry that if the infighting continues, plan participants and pensioners will suffer.
"They are too busy fighting to take care of the people in these plans," said Perry Kenny, president of the California State Employees Association, a union that represents 140,000 workers.
Mr. Kenny said that he had told board members to shape up. "I tell them it is not about your personalities," he said. "Go fight outside."
The latest sign of trouble at Calpers came two weeks ago, when Daniel Szentes, the chief investment officer, quit after only 15 months. He told the board that his resignation was prompted in part by a recent court ruling that would force Calpers to trim the salaries and bonuses of some of its investment managers, making it harder to recruit talent. Salaries range from $88,000 to $105,000, according to Calpers, a fraction of what many money managers make in private industry. Calpers officials said that Mr. Szentes also simply found the board too difficult to deal with.
The state controller, Kathleen Connell, said she started the lawsuit over the Calpers pay practices because the fund's board had not followed state-prescribed procedures for giving pay increases.
"I am a fiscal watchdog as controller," Ms. Connell said in a telephone interview. When she was asked if some compromise could have been reached, her general counsel, Rick Chivaro, who was also on the call, jumped in to answer. "There is no amicable way," he said.
Therein lies one of the board's main problems, according to staff members, board executives and outside critics. Some of the elected officials on the board are more interested, they say, in pleasing voters than in the people who rely on Calpers for retirement income, and the board members who are elected by the plan participants pursue personal agendas, too. 
"They want to make a mark," Mr. Perry said.
Dr. Crist, who has been board president for 10 years, said that Ms. Connell was a special case. "Compromise is not a word she understands," he said. "She is pretty interested in her own image."
Ms. Connell dismisses the criticisms as "gender-based statements." The board, she said, is "cordial." 
Well, not exactly. Ms. Connell is barely on speaking terms with the state treasurer, Phil Angelides, a political rival with whom she has feuded over fiscal management of California's energy crisis.
For his part, Mr. Angelides, who declined to comment on Calpers, was the target two years ago of harsh words from Charles Valdes, a board member since 1984 who is a senior lawyer for the state Department of Transportation.
In October 1999, in a discussion of investments in emerging markets, Mr. Valdes, according to a published transcript, snapped at Mr. Angelides, "What we have here is a Greek treasurer who doesn't like Turkey."
Mr. Valdes rejected a call from several legislators that he resign from the board, but he did apologize to Mr. Angelides, a Greek-American.
More recently, Mr. Valdes endorsed a lawsuit that blocked the board's plan to follow new election rules for the six board members who, like himself, are chosen by plan participants. (The remainder of the board consists of four ex officio members -- the controller, the treasurer, and two state personnel officials; two members appointed by the governor, including a local elected official, currently the San Francisco mayor, Willie Brown; and a public representative appointed by the state legislature.)
Challengers had complained for years that the voting system, which gives board seats to the candidates with the most votes, favored incumbents. Over the summer, the board proposed requiring a majority vote, not just a plurality. At the urging of Mr. Valdes, its former president, the state employees union went to court and succeeded in blocking the proposal.
"I objected to the idea because I did not think it would accomplish anything," Mr. Valdes said.
But he also had the most to lose. Mr. Valdes is up for re-election in December, and there are 19 candidates running for two seats. Besides the Angelides episode, he has been tarred by the disclosure that he accepted gifts, including tickets to sporting events. A few years ago, when he was chairman of the fund's investment committee, he filed for personal bankruptcy reorganization.
Mr. Valdes said that his critics at Calpers had no grounds for being embarrassed by his conduct. "They have their own skeletons in their closets," he said.
Last December, matters got so bad that Dr. Crist appointed Sean Harrigan, a board newcomer, to lead a committee examining the way the board governed itself. It was just the kind of move that Calpers has often demanded of the companies in which it invests.
"What it really boiled down to was there were poor lines of communication and open expressions of hostility," said Mr. Harrigan, an official of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union.
Mr. Harrigan's committee came up with several initiatives. A protocol was established for board communication with Calpers staff members so that employees would no longer be whipsawed by the board members' competing interests. The board now gets together socially every month, part of an effort to address conflicts informally, rather than in courtrooms. Members and observers describe all this as just a start.
"It is probably not as big a mess as it looks," Dr. Crist said. "But maybe I'm just used to it."

HEADLINE: Massachusetts School Opens After Bomb-Plot Arrests 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 26 

 BODY:
Classes resumed today at New Bedford High School after a holiday weekend in which three students were charged with plotting an attack on the school that the police said was intended to be bloodier than the 1999 killings at Columbine High School. 
 But even though the authorities said the plotters had all been caught, and the school was searched locker by locker for explosives on Sunday, things were not entirely back to normal. 
 About 40 percent of the school's 3,300 students stayed home, said Joseph Oliver, the headmaster. About 40 met with guidance counselors and six students, who were especially troubled or concerned about safety, met with crisis counselors. Police cars and officers guarded the sprawling, mud-brown school complex and inside, between classes, teachers manned the hallways. 
"I still feel that it is not safe at all," said Kelly Oliveira, 16, a junior who did not go to school today. 
The police and school officials took pains today to assure parents and students that the school was safe. But as parents and friends of those arrested painted the charges as a drastic overreaction, the authorities cautioned a jumpy community that they had not exaggerated the potential scale of the killing spree they believed was planned.
"In all likelihood, they would have done what they said they were going to do," Chief Arthur J. Kelly III of the New Bedford Police said at a news conference. In threats overheard by a student, he said, "they talked about how they were going to outdo Columbine, detonate an explosive, shoot students and faculty and eventually commit suicide." 
Chief Kelly said summonses had been issued today for two additional teenagers, a 17-year-old girl and a 15-year-old boy, who were expected to turn themselves in this week. The authorities, who would not release the older teenager's name until she was formally arrested, believed the two knew about the plot. 
The three boys charged with plotting the attack, Eric McKeehan, 17, and two 15-year-olds whose names were withheld because of their age, pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to commit murder, conspiracy to commit assault and battery and illegal possession of ammunition in arraignments today. All three were held without bail, pending what is called a dangerousness hearing, at which a judge would determine if they posed a threat to themselves and others and should therefore continue to be denied bail. 
The authorities in this gritty seacoast town 58 miles south of Boston began investigating the possibility of an attack plot in early October when a girl in school told a teacher she had overheard boys scheming to bomb the school and shoot students. At that time, two students were charged with making threats; charges were dismissed against one student, but the other was among those charged this weekend in the attack plot. 
Later in October, a landlord of a building where one of the boys lives reported a suspicious box in the attic. The police said they found a nearly completed bomb, but because a crucial part was missing they could not file charges. 
Then, last week, a school janitor found a note outside a science room that referred to plans for an attack. The authorities said that after executing search warrants at the boys' homes and finding shotgun shells, knives, a notebook with bomb-making instructions and photographs of the boys holding handguns, the police arrested Mr. McKeehan and the two 15-year-olds on Saturday. 
Today, parents of the three boys defended their sons and portrayed them as harmless teenagers, somewhat troubled perhaps, but not capable of the violence they were accused of plotting.
"These kids wouldn't hurt any living thing, they just wouldn't," said Susan St. Hilaire, the mother of one of the 15-year-old boys and a kind of surrogate mother to Eric and several other teenagers. Eric had been living in Ms. St. Hilaire's third-floor apartment near downtown since August. The other 15-year-old, Eric's brother, had apparently been living with his mother in south New Bedford. 
Ms. St. Hilaire said her son had been going through a tough time in recent months. Last year, Ms. St. Hilaire, a former nurse who is now unemployed and on disability, called the Department of Social Services seeking help handling her son's pattern of taking her car and staying out at night. 
She said he failed at a vocational school last year and switched to New Bedford High School, where his grades were "horrible." She said he had gotten "in trouble at school for silly stuff." The hardest thing for her son, she said, was the unexpected death of his father from pancreatic cancer in September. 
Harold McKeehan, the father of Eric and the other 15-year-old, said today that the shotgun shells and the photographs with weapons were souvenirs from a family vacation in Ohio. 
"Neither one of my children has had any problems," Mr. McKeehan said. "This is way blown out of proportion."
Mr. McKeehan said that Eric's only difficulty was that he had learning disabilities, "and he was wanting to get out in the working world." He said he had ordered Eric to stay in school and graduate. 
"He's not a monster," he said. "He's a little kid in a big guy's body."
Mr. McKeehan, who is divorced from the boys' mother and lives in the Boston area, where he is a carpenter, declined to talk about his younger son. Ms. St. Hilaire said he was an honor roll student, and she said Eric worked four nights a week at an Italian restaurant. 
Teenagers and adults who were acquainted with the three boys said some or all of them listened to Metallica and other heavy metal music. Eric liked to skateboard, and sometimes brought his skateboard to school. At least one of the 15-year-olds wore a mohawk, black fingernail polish in the Gothic style and sported numerous body piercings. But in interviews today, the boys were not branded as outcasts.
"Everybody wears Gothic clothes," said Trisha Boucher, 14, a freshman at the high school, who showed up at the courthouse, saying she was curious about Eric's arraignment. "He looks like a normal kid every day when I walk by him."

HEADLINE: Sprawl Seen to Hurt South's Forests 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 

 BODY:
The Forest Service has concluded in a study released today that the biggest threat to Southern forests is urban sprawl, a finding that to some degree absolves the timber industry for the effects of a logging boom that has transformed the South in recent decades.
 "Among forces of change, urbanization will have the most direct, immediate and permanent effects on the extent, condition and health of forests," the study found. 
 The study, an assessment of Southern forests conducted over the last two years, forecasts that 31 million acres of forests in the region will be lost to urbanization from 1992 to 2040. But it estimates that the 13 states of the South will experience an overall decline of only 2 percent in forests because it expects much of what is now farmland to be converted to forests. 
Those new forests would largely be tree farms, which environmentalists say come at the expense of true forests and wetlands. And conservation groups said the way the Forest Service report was written masked the drastic shifts occurring in the Southern landscape.
Most of the urbanization is expected to take place along the South's coastline, while the new forests are expected to be grown in its western regions.
The report grew out of the increasing clash between environmentalists and the timber industry over land management and was meant to serve as a basis of information for future policy debates. It was conducted by the Forest Service, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Fish and Wildlife Service and several universities.
"Urbanization is the most immediate threat," said David N. Wear, a forest economics researcher for the Forest Service based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., and an author of the report.
The report also cited other factors, including pine beetle infestation and ozone pollution. Given the magnitude of the tree harvesting and changes in the environment, Mr. Wear said, "sustainability is not a foregone conclusion. It's not just going to happen; we need to make it happen."
Timber industry officials greeted the report as a vindication. They said it confirmed that they were managing forests carefully and showed that environmentalists had exaggerated problems caused by the industry as opposed to those caused by sprawl.
"The findings echo what our knowledge and experience has told us: that urbanization is a problem for forests," said Michael Klein, a spokesman for the American Forest and Paper Association.
He said the industry planted more than a billion new trees in the South each year. "We harvest trees, but it's in our best interest to make sure we replant them," he said. "Our livelihood is in the South. If there's a problem with sustainability, we need to know about it. We're pleased to see that there aren't a lot of problems."
But Lark Hayes, a lawyer for the Southern Environmental Law Center, based in Chapel Hill, N.C., said that while urbanization was clearly a factor in the destruction of forests, there were other major threats as well, particularly by what she called the "massive conversion" of forestland to pine tree plantations.
Such plantations, Ms. Hayes said, often involved the use of herbicides to reduce competing vegetation and supported less diverse species.
The industry likes the plantations because they grow quickly and generate quick revenue. Pine plantations in the South grew to 32 million acres in 1999 from 2 million acres in 1953. The study forecasts that pine plantations will keep expanding, to 54 million acres in 2040, while all other forest types decline.
The land expected to become pine plantations by 2040, Ms. Hayes said, is equivalent to the size of North and South Carolina combined. She said the report failed to discuss why tree farms were detrimental.
"It talks about imperiled critters, but it stops short of connecting the dots between the levels of timber harvest and tree farms and the declines in those species," she said.
Jon Evans, a professor of biology at the University of the South, in Sewanee, Tenn., said, "The report raises a number of red flags about the future of Southern forests."
He said the South was home to the highest number of endangered ecosystems and was experiencing the sharpest shifts in land use of any region in the country.
The South is now the nation's leading paper producer, providing nearly 60 percent of the wood supply.
Timber companies say the shift from the Pacific Northwest to the South occurred because of better growing conditions; environmentalists say that Southern landowners have encouraged the expansion by allowing the timber industry to use their forests, which, unlike those West, are primarily on private land.
In the last 50 years, the South's timber production has more than doubled and its share of world production has climbed from 6.3 percent to 15.8 percent. Timber is a major underpinning of the once-agrarian South, accounting for 6 percent of the jobs and 8 percent of the income. The South now produces more timber than any country in the world.
The study said the presence of imperiled animal species were cause for concern. And because nonfragmented swaths of forest are increasingly rare, it said, they have a disproportionately high ecological value.
As the South's population continues to rise, so will urbanization, the report noted, threatening the habitats of the 1,208 vertebrate species known to exist in the South, 132 of which are already of conservation concern and 28 of which are classified as imperiled.

HEADLINE: Nassau Democrats Form Plan to Cut Spending and Raise Taxes 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 26 

 BODY:
Facing a Wednesday deadline to balance Nassau County's budget or risk a state fiscal takeover, the County Legislature's Democratic majority agreed tonight on a package of spending cuts and a 15 percent increase in the county property tax. The increase would cost homeowners about $150 a year.
 But the budget for 2002 faces two more major hurdles: approvals by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and by the special state monitoring agency that oversees Nassau's finances. 
 A spokesman for Mr. Gulotta, a Republican who is retiring at the end of the year, said, "The county executive will review every aspect of the County Legislature's tax increase budget with the goal of cutting spending before consideration of additional tax increase." 
The size of the increase heightened the chance that he would veto it, as he did a 15.4 percent increase last fall. If he does, the Democrats do not have enough votes to override him, and such a stalemate could trigger a state takeover. 
Democrats say they hope to persuade Mr. Gulotta to support the tax increase to avoid what they say would be an even worse end to his career: giving control of the county to the state fiscal agency. 
For years Mr. Gulotta has resisted tax increases. That practice, coupled with his reluctance to curb spending, helped plunge Nassau into large deficits. The deficits in turn forced the county to seek a state bailout and accept the imposition of the state oversight agency, the Nassau County Interim Finance Authority, known as NIFA.
Mr. Gulotta and the legislators had already agreed to a 5 percent increase in the county portion of the property tax -- equal to about $1 a week for the average homeowner -- for each of the next three years.
But the next county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, a Democrat, has lobbied behind the scenes to accelerate the three annual tax increases into the first year. That was the same ploy he used in rectifying a deficit in the small city of Glen Cove when he took over as mayor there in 1994. 
"So this is the Suozzi plan!" the legislature's Republican minority leader, Peter Schmitt, said. "You're imposing a larger tax increase than NIFA would require. This is ridiculous."
But the presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat, said the plan would give the county "a stronger foundation" so that it "would not be on the verge of bankruptcy every time we turn around."
The state oversight agency, which set the Wednesday deadline, is planning its own meeting around Dec. 7. When Mr. Gulotta proposed his $2.2 billion budget for 2002, the state monitors found it out of balance by $55 million. The legislature then made revisions, but the monitors said the changes still fell short by about $45 million.
The Democrats say they believe their latest plan will win the agency's approval. Although they outlined the plan at a public meeting tonight, the formal paperwork was not ready for a vote until after midnight.
The new plan cuts sales tax estimates by $10 million because of the shaky economy, lowers estimated savings from job attrition by $8 million and reduces police spending by $7 million, mostly by eliminating a class of recruits. The plan also adds $1 million to pay county workers called up in the reserves and $1.2 million to give volunteer firefighters a partial tax break.
Mr. Suozzi issued a statement saying, "Nassau County is in the worst financial crisis of its history."
Furthermore, he said, "There is a looming recession and we still don't know the full impact on the economy of the September terrorist attacks.
"It's imperative that the legislature approves a solidly balanced budget that meets NIFA's scrutiny and is passed by the current county executive."
A spokesman for Mr. Gulotta, John Zaher, issued a comment on the budget that concluded, "Due to the fact the county executive will review the budget with the fiscal integrity of the county and the interest of the taxpayers foremost in mind, he cannot comment until he has received the final budget adopted by the legislature."

HEADLINE: Hungry and Poor (And Right Here) 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Hunger Emergency in New York" (editorial, Nov. 26):
Food pantries are indeed overflowing with pleas for help. 
Unemployment in New York City has dramatically increased over the last year. And the city's homeless shelters are beyond capacity, with more than 12,000 children languishing in often squalid and overcrowded conditions.
 These problems -- worsened by the attacks of Sept. 11 and a serious economic downturn -- will surely continue until we find ways to address the root causes of poverty and homelessness. 
 We still cannot ignore our affordable-housing crisis, or our serious need to ensure access to high-quality health care, education and real job training and skill building. But it requires government to be a partner in the larger antipoverty struggle, something that's been absent in the past.

ARNOLD S. COHEN
President and Chief Executive
Partnership for the Homeless
New York, Nov. 26, 2001

HEADLINE: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. ("Better Gas Mileage, Greater Security," Op-Ed, Nov. 24) may be right that reduced gasoline consumption should be a national goal. 
But I disagree with his proposal for how to achieve it.
 Command-and-control solutions like the corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, standards are rarely the best approach to correcting decisions made in a free market. Such regulation not only is intrusive but also gives insufficient incentive to car makers once the standard is met and gives no incentive for car owners to drive less. 
 It would be better to use a corrective tax, like the tax on gasoline. A higher gasoline tax could be coupled with lower income taxes. Politically this should be a win-win proposition, for it would appeal to Democratic environmentalists and Republican supply-siders, as well as those who believe that dependence on foreign oil is a threat to national security.

N. GREGORY MANKIW
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 24, 2001

The writer is a professor of economics at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (Op-Ed, Nov. 24) presents a convincing argument for legislation holding sport utility vehicles and minivans to the fuel economy standard for cars. 
He proposes that Congress raise the standards for all cars to 40 miles a gallon by 2012.
 But why do we need Congressional action? Why aren't American automakers meeting these standards now, or at least in the next two or three years? The technology already exists, as the Toyota Prius hybrid family-size car demonstrates, with 48 miles per gallon according to the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 Congress deserves criticism for its lack of action. But American auto companies deserve even greater criticism. And the news media, by not pushing our automakers to find out why they are ignoring their environmental and patriotic duties, disappoint all of us interested in an active and free press.

WARREN G. BOVEE
Milwaukee, Nov. 24, 2001

The writer is a professor emeritus of journalism, Marquette University.

HEADLINE: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (Op-Ed, Nov. 24) notes the threat to our national security caused by our reliance on fossil fuels. 
This vulnerability cannot be solved by more domestic production. That's why any credible energy plan must steadily reduce our fossil fuel consumption. Increasing the fuel economy standard would be a useful initial step.
 Beneficial energy plans would include measures to nurture energy resource diversity, promote energy efficiency and conservation, and ensure that the full social and environmental costs of energy use are included in its cost. 
 The alternative is a future featuring increased price shocks, greater reliance on foreign energy sources, mounting social inequality and more severe impacts from climate change.

CRAIG CHESLOG
Oakland, Calif., Nov. 24, 2001

The writer is director of communications and government relations, Redefining Progress.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 On the Ground

THE MARINES -- Just hours after establishing a base southwest of Kandahar, the Taliban stronghold, American marines helped direct air attacks on an armored column, inaugurating a new phase in the war that the Pentagon said would deploy 1,000 ground troops. A1

MILITARY ANALYSIS -- The dispatch of hundreds of American marines to an airfield near Kandahar is a calculated gamble intended to take the fight to southern Afghanistan, where the Taliban's support is greatest. B1

IN KUNDUZ -- As Taliban soldiers fled this northern city, they left behind several mysteries, among them the nature of several flights into the airport before the city fell. A1

TRIBAL GAINS -- As United States marines secured their position near Kandahar, anti-Taliban tribal groups made gains that deepened the Taliban's isolation in southern Afghanistan and cut off their main access points to Pakistan. B3

WILD HIGHWAYMEN -- Bus drivers traveling in southern Afghanistan describe the region as being ruled by wayward gunmen and local rulers beholden to no one. B3

The Fortress Battle

P.O.W. REVOLT -- Surrendered Taliban soldiers being held in a fort outside Mazar-i-Sharif were engaged in a fierce battle with the American-backed troops of the Northern Alliance. Five Americans were wounded trying to quell the uprising after they called in a bombing mission and the bomb exploded too close to them.. A1

PAKISTAN REACTS -- The spokesman for the Pakistan Foreign Ministry, Aziz Ahmed Khan, said the government would seek a complete report on the prison revolt that was believed to have killed many Pakistanis who had fought with the Taliban. B4

The Coalition

RUSSIA RETURNS -- Twelve Russian military cargo planes carrying equipment and troops landed at an airbase outside Kabul, in what President Vladimir V. Putin called a new stage in Russia's cooperation with the American-led anti-Taliban coalition. B3

IN LONDON -- Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon told Parliament that there was "absolutely no truth" to accounts of differences between Britain and the United States over how the war in Afghanistan was being conducted. B4

IN GERMANY -- The president of the Northern Alliance, Burhanuddin Rabbani, played down hopes of a breakthrough at a conference aimed at organizing a broadly based and representative government to replace the Taliban. He called the conference, which starts in Bonn today, a preliminary meeting of most of the key Afghan factions. B2

Questions of Security

FOREIGN PASSENGERS -- The United States has told Saudi, Russian, Chinese and other foreign airlines that their passengers arriving in this country will be put through extremely rigorous, lengthy searches, starting Thursday, if the airlines do not provide information needed to identify potential terrorists. A1

THE INTERVIEWS -- Instead of knocking on doors, Michigan authorities will send letters today to hundreds of young Middle Eastern men who have come to the United States on temporary visas in the last two years, inviting them to make appointments for interviews regarding the terror attacks. Critics have said the Department of Justice order to canvass 5,000 such visitors unfairly targets people based on religion or nationality and is too time-consuming for many local police departments. A1

DETAINED -- A Palestinian professor, Mazen Al-Najjar, who was held in custody for more than three and a half years on secret evidence, was jailed again this weekend in Florida after an appeals court ruled that the government could deport him. B7

SMALLPOX -- Should smallpox occur in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will recommend isolating victims and vaccinating a "containment ring" of people exposed to an infected patient rather than mass vaccinations. B7

LEAHY LETTER -- Forensic scientists and F.B.I. agents in full protective gear and in a sealed laboratory will open the anthrax-contaminated letter addressed to Senator Patrick J. Leahy. They do not expect to open the letter before Thursday, because of fears of losing or damaging evidence. B8

IN CONNECTICUT -- Dozens of additional samples taken near the home of Ottilie W. Lundgren, the 94-year-old woman who died of inhalation anthrax last week, all tested negative for the bacteria. B8

Warning Iraq

WEAPONS INSPECTIONS -- President Bush warned Saddam Hussein that if he did not allow United Nations inspectors into Iraq to determine if the country was developing nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, he would face consequences. When asked what those might be, Mr. Bush said, "He'll find out." A1

Suspicions and Suspects

STRAINED RELATIONS -- Saudi Arabia is balking at American requests to freeze the bank accounts of those the United States says are linked to terrorism, saying the Americans have not offered proof that the individuals and businesses named are linked to terrorism. The Bush administration is sending a delegation to Riyadh to discuss the standoff. B1

DEFENDING THE TALIBAN -- Before Sept. 11, the most vocal advocate in the United States for the Taliban was Laili Helms, a 38-year-old Afghan-American. Since the attacks, Ms. Helms has lived under siege in her house in New Jersey. B6

IN SPAIN -- Police officers carrying out surveillance of two Islamic terror cells tied to Osama bin Laden saw the groups' leaders talking on a Madrid street two weeks before Sept. 11. The police believe the meeting was a furtive attempt to coordinate the groups' actions. B6

IN BRUSSELS -- Belgian and French police detained 14 people suspected of being involved in the plot to assassinate Ahmed Shah Massoud, the leader of Afghanistan's Northern Alliance who was killed Sept. 9. B6

The Aftermath in New York

COMPENSATION FUND -- Kenneth R. Feinberg, a Democratic lawyer, was appointed to run the federal fund set up to compensate the families of victims in the terror attacks. B1

COMINGS -- The terror attacks, the anthrax scares, the recession -- none have kept some people from moving to New York. D1

GOINGS -- Plenty of anecdotal reports suggest that many people, particularly with young children, are leaving the city or at least began considering it after Sept. 11. D1

Science Times

BIOTERROR -- Government officials, ethicists and scientists are grappling with whether the nation's biologists and biotechnology companies should be regulated to restrict access to information and materials that might be used for biological weapons. F1

SMALLPOX VIRUS -- Some biological weapons experts fear that terrorists have already gotten hold of the smallpox virus, while others say a sophisticated adversary could make it from scratch. F6

HEADLINE: National Briefing West: Hawaii: Tourism Suffers After Attacks 

BYLINE:  By Michele Kayal (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The number of visitors to Hawaii fell more than 30 percent in the first full month after Sept. 11, putting the state's year-to-date figures 7 percent behind those of last year. 
Visitors from Japan were the scarcest, with 54 percent fewer than in the previous October. Tourism accounts for a quarter of Hawaii's economy, and analysts estimate that a 30 percent drop for the fourth quarter could cost the state 25,000 jobs and $1 billion. The state will spend an additional $10 million on marketing through March to try to stem the drop. Michele Kayal (NYT)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Ex-Penguin Putnam Chief Is Moving to Random House
The Random House division of Bertelsmann named Phyllis E. Grann, the departing chief executive of Penguin Putnam, to the new position of vice chairman, fueling speculation among editors and agents that she may seek to lure away some of Penguin Putnam's authors.
 Others, however, wondered how Ms. Grann will fit in among the internally competitive chiefs of Random House's many publishing divisions. Page C2. 

News Organizations Send Stock Ads
Stocks of companies that have no history that they have disclosed to the Securities and Exchange Commission have risen after news organizations distributed advertising e-mail messages promoting them. Floyd Norris and Gretchen Morgenson: Market Place. C6.

Job Changes for Wall Street Fixtures
Byron R. Wien, the chief investment strategist for the United States at Morgan Stanley, will step down on Dec. 1 but will remain at the firm. Separately, Wayne D. Angell will retire as the chief economist at Bear Stearns. Steve Galbraith will succeed Mr. Wien; no successor has been named yet for Mr. Angell. C2.

Turning Heat Pollution Into Power
Scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a small Salt Lake City company, Eneco, plan to announce today that they have developed technology that can efficiently transform heat pollution into electricity. C4.

Lernout & Hauspie Auction Starts
The bankruptcy auction began for the assets of Lernout & Hauspie, the Belgian speech technology company. The proceedings are expected to draw only a fraction of the hundreds of millions that Lernout & Hauspie owes. C4.

Stocks Rise on Technology Rally
Technology shares helped drive the market to post-Sept. 11 highs. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 38.03 points, or 2 percent, to 1,941.23. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.04 points, or 0.2 percent, to 9,982.75, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.08 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,157.42. C10.

Oil Falls on Reluctance to Cut Output
Crude oil prices fell on speculation that Russia would not reduce its output beyond the 50,000 barrels a day it has already set for this year, a decline that is about a quarter of what OPEC wants to help shore up prices. In New York, crude oil for January delivery fell 27 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $18.69 a barrel. In London, Brent crude oil for January delivery fell 92 cents, or 4.8 percent, to $18.36 a barrel. C10.

Provider of Geologic Data to Be Sold
Petroleum Geo-Services of Norway agreed to acquire the rival Veritas DGC in a $772 million stock swap, creating a big provider of geophysical data to the energy sector. C2.

Senate to Consider Rail Pension Bill
After lobbying by railroads and unions, the Senate was scheduled to take up legislation this week that would allow the railroad pension system to take its money out of government bonds and invest it on Wall Street. A13.

Crash Complicates Swissair Future
Switzerland's already fragile efforts to salvage a viable airline out of the remains of its bankrupt national carrier, Swissair, were set back substantially by the crash over the weekend of a plane operated by its designated successor, Crossair. World Business, Section W.

Airline Improves After Sept. 11
In Taiwan, the state-controlled carrier, China Airlines, views the near collapse of the industry after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as an opportunity. World Business, Section W.

Japan's Banks Face Bond Problems
Japan's largest banks, plagued by mounting bad loans and sinking stock portfolios, face yet another booby trap: losses on their bond holdings. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Top Companies Issuing Debt At a Fast Pace 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
In the weeks since the attack on the World Trade Center, blue-chip corporations have issued a torrent of debt.
 Ford, General Electric, I.B.M., Kraft, AT&T, General Motors and other companies have doubled and even trebled their initial plans for bond offerings as investors, disenchanted with the stock market, have all but begged to buy their debt. In all, companies have issued 31.5 percent more debt in the last 11 weeks than they did in the period a year earlier. 
 The companies are taking advantage of the chance to raise cash at bargain basement prices, thanks to low interest rates, and to retire more expensive debt.
But they may also have little-discussed concerns that money will be scarce in the future, particularly if the economic downturn persists and the recovery is less vigorous than economists now hope. Bank lending is at a 30-year low, according to the Conference Board, and buyers are hard to find for commercial paper, the short-term, cheap debt that corporate purebreds rely on. Standard & Poor's says the amount of commercial paper issued by nonfinancial companies has shrunk roughly 30 percent this year. 
"Companies now can lock in substantially lower overall borrowing costs," said William Cunningham, director of credit strategy at J. P. Morgan. "They have an opportunity to build a war chest to help them get through the hard times, and they're taking advantage of it."
Before the terrorist attacks, analysts were expecting the issuing of debt to slow late this year after a tremendous first half.
So much for expectations. Ford originally planned to raise $3 billion; it was able to raise $9.4 billion and is said to be thinking about trying to raise $7 billion more.
Kraft Foods, part of the Philip Morris Companies, had planned to issue $2 billion worth of bonds. Instead, it offered $4 billion.
AT&T raised $10.1 billion, twice as much as it originally planned. AT&T's and Ford's issues rank as the second- and third-largest ever.
All told, 573 corporations have issued $181 billion of debt since Sept. 11, compared with 692 companies that raised $138 billion in the period last year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
"When you look at other asset classes, the corporate bond market offers some of the better values," said Bob LoBue, head of the investment-grade fixed-income syndicate at J. P. Morgan, which has underwritten roughly half the issues that have come to market since Sept. 11. "There's still a lack of confidence in stock valuations based on the weakness we're seeing in earnings."
Issuers and their underwriters most often cite the low interest rates on Treasury bills as the reason for the surge in corporate debt. Corporate bonds are often priced in relation to United States government debt, and thanks to a cascade of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year, well-heeled companies can borrow at extremely attractive rates.
International Business Machines, for instance, recently sold $1.5 billion worth of five-year notes with the lowest coupon it has ever issued, 4.875 percent.
Others, though, read the stampede of premier companies to issue debt as a sign that credit is getting tight. Investment-grade companies typically juggle a smorgasbord of debt -- short, intermediate and long term -- but they are definitely skewing the mixture toward the long end these days. No doubt, that is because debt is cheap -- but it also suggests that they may foresee a time when money will be more scarce and are accumulating the war chests Mr. Cunningham referred to.
It was not so long ago, after all, that companies experienced a credit shortage. "A credit crunch was brewing last year," Mr. Cunningham said, "until the Fed stepped in and started aggressively lowering interest rates, which averted it."
But a cash problem persists in some ways despite the Federal Reserve's series of interest rate cuts. "We are in a cash crisis like none we have experienced in recent memory," said James Padilla, a Ford executive, in a recent memorandum to his staff.
Many companies with less-than-pristine credit ratings have trouble raising money and may be having more because of the stampede by blue-chip companies.
"When companies like Ford or General Electric come into the market, they squeeze a lot of other, somewhat riskier credits out," said Gail D. Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board. 
Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said that the economic recovery depended on companies' being able to get credit.
"My primary concern is the lack of available credit across the spectrum," he said. "We are forecasting an economic recovery in the middle of next year, but the one thing that could go wrong with that forecast is if the availability of credit stays where it is or gets worse."
Another concern is that debt is piling up with negative consequences. "The Fed is trying to prevent the bubble from bursting by keeping the forces of credit exuberance alive," Barton M. Biggs, chief global strategist at Morgan Stanley, wrote to investors earlier this month. "The trouble is, although it may work in the short run, in the long run the debt burden will be bigger and the adjustment process more painful."
The automakers, for example, are using the money they have raised in part to support the customer incentive programs that offer zero-interest financing. They are paying as much as 7.25 percent, in other words, to lend money to car buyers for nothing. 
Some of the new debt is being used to retire commercial paper. But companies are taking on more than they need to accomplish that goal.
The longer-term money they are borrowing is more expensive than the commercial paper, even if it is cheaper than it has been in a long time. The spread -- the difference in interest rates between Treasuries and corporate bonds -- has generally widened since Sept. 11, although not across the board.
"There is a cost factor involved, but we try to minimize that," said David Moore, manager of fixed-income investor relations at Ford Credit, which accounted for the bulk of the $9.4 billion that Ford borrowed last month. "We're mindful of our liquidity, and want to make sure we ensure it."
Like many of the companies issuing debt, Ford is curbing its dependence on the commercial paper market. For the year through Oct. 16, Ford had cut the amount of paper it had outstanding by almost 60 percent, to $17 billion. "That puts us in a very good position, given our rating," said Mr. Moore, who was one of the few executives willing to discuss his company's strategy.
Ford, like a host of other companies, has had its credit ratings cut. Many buyers of commercial paper, like money market funds, lend to only the highest-rated companies. So far this year, Standard & Poor's has knocked 57 companies out of the top ratings for commercial paper, compared with 49 last year.
The total amount of outstanding commercial paper has fallen 30 percent this year, according to Diane Vazza, head of global financial investment research at Standard & Poor's, thanks to that downgrading and to great caution among investors. "We've seen some issuers driven out of the market," Ms. Vazza said. 
According to several credit analysts, DaimlerChrysler was scheduled to roll over $7 billion of commercial paper in June but decided to take the offering to Europe, where investors are less particular about ratings quality.
Similarly, Enron careered into its crisis when it was forced to redeem commercial paper as its credit ratings fell.
The decline in AT&T's commercial paper ratings was one reason for its big issue last week.
But underwriters of corporate debt insist that the decline in the commercial paper market has more to do with companies' ability to borrow for the long term cheaply than with their inability to issue short-term debt. "Short-term financing does come with a maturity risk in that you constantly have to roll it over in order to maintain liquidity," said Mr. LoBue of J. P. Morgan.
The underwriters concede, however, that lending by banks has all but dried up, falling to its lowest level in three decades. Bank lending has been curtailed at the behest of Federal regulators like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency at the Treasury Department, putting them seemingly at cross-purposes with the Fed.
The chief executive of EchoStar, Charles W. Ergen, had to put up $2.75 billion of his own money to complete the purchase of the Hughes Electronic Corporation. The bankers at UBS Warburg, EchoStar's adviser on the deal, had offered to provide the financing, but only with a proviso that would have let the bank back out of the deal under certain conditions.
Although the company later got financing from Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Bank, many other bankers have privately applauded UBS Warburg's caution.

HEADLINE: Ailey Troupe Goes in Search Of Big Money 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
With the economy in decline and contributions flooding into charities related to the terrorist attacks, now is a tough time to ask people to think about donating money to cultural institutions. But the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is optimistic. The company plans to start asking the public to contribute to its $60 million capital campaign tomorrow, when it opens its five-week season at City Center. 
 Sharon Gersten Luckman, executive director of the Ailey troupe, said $47.5 million had already been raised, including $12.5 million from the city and a gift of $15 million from Joan and Sanford I. Weill. Ms. Weill is the chairwoman of the Ailey board; Mr. Weill is the chairman of Citigroup. The campaign seeks to raise $47.5 million for a new headquarters on the northwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 55th Street in Manhattan, to be called the Joan Weill Center for Dance, and $12.5 million for an endowment. 
 Ms. Luckman said that donors had been surprisingly generous given the bleak economic forecast. "They knew this would be one time only," she said. "We wouldn't be coming back again and again for the next building."
The Ailey company has not been alone in its quest for a new home base. The Mark Morris Group opened a new headquarters in Brooklyn in September. 
In Manhattan, George Faison, the Tony Award-winning choreographer of "The Wiz," has turned a former firehouse on West 124th Street into a dance studio and office building that will begin operations next month. Plans will be announced early next year for a newly renovated building to be opened by Mikhail Baryshnikov in the West 30's. And the Joyce Theater recently completed a study on the feasibility of creating a large dance theater. But the planned Ailey headquarters is said to be the biggest building in the nation devoted exclusively to dance. It is scheduled to open in June 2004. 
The new headquarters, designed by Natan Bibliowicz and Carolyn Iu, is to have 12 studios, two of which would open out to form a black box theater, and space for offices, a library, a physical therapy room and the company's archives. Other companies would be able to rent rehearsal studios, a dwindling commodity in New York dance today, at reduced rates. Passers-by would get a glimpse of classes and rehearsals through huge windows in several studios on upper floors and at street level, where scrims decorated with photographs of Ailey performers would offer dancers some measure of privacy. A huge banner of a dancer in the white skirts of Ailey's "Cry" is to hang on the 55th Street side. 
"We are trying to create a canvas for dancers to express themselves," Mr. Bibliowicz said. "A simple environment with all the amenities they need." Designs for the building will be on exhibit at City Center and at an open house on Jan. 16 at the troupe's current home at 211 West 61st Street. 
Two years ago the Ailey company planned to move into two more floors in the West 61st Street building that were expected to be vacated by the Postal Service, which had a post office branch there. At the time Ms. Weill told the board that Mr. Bibliowicz, her son-in-law, would be willing to join others who had volunteered to help the company with expansion plans. The search for a new space began after plans to move the post office branch fell through.
"We were very excited about Natan's work," Ms. Luckman said when asked why Mr. Bibliowicz was the only architect considered by the company. "It would have been disingenuous to open up the process."
The designs provide for 77,000 square feet of space, more than doubling the company's rental on West 61st Street. Judith Jamison, the artistic director of the Ailey company, said she began to see the need for more space several years ago. "There was Mickey Bord, our archivist, working in a closet with 40-some years of history around her," Ms. Jamison said. "Our second company was having to rent space because all our studios were rented."
Ms. Jamison said that having a new company home had a strong personal meaning for her. "This really means something about survival and about where I've come from," she said. "Along the way, there was this genius man, and I became a part of his life. I can't wait to see the astonishment of all the people who loved Alvin when they walk through the door."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A rendering of the Alvin Ailey company's proposed new headquarters. (Iu & Bibliowicz Architects)
