HEADLINE: McCall to Stress Education and Recall His Roots in Speech Ratcheting Up Campaign 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 26 

 BODY:
Harking back to his own poor-child-made-good life story, H. Carl McCall, in the first major speech of his run for governor, will promise to make education the centerpiece of his campaign.
 "Education was my salvation," says a text of the speech, which Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, plans to deliver Tuesday at New York University and again here in Albany. "Without it, I would not be standing before you today." 
 It goes on to make some bold pledges. "I guarantee that within four years of my taking office, 75 percent of the students in this state will pass the standardized tests in English and math," the speech says. It also vows that Mr. McCall, on his "first day in office," will abolish the state's arcane and politically charged way of distributing school aid.
Mr. McCall's speech also promises to demand accountability from teachers and administrators, and it blames the Republican incumbent, Gov. George E. Pataki, for some of the public schools' woes.
The speech assails the governor for a flagging upstate economy, an issue used to great effect by Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, a pair of Democrats who fared well with upstate voters, once the state's most reliable Republican bloc.
Mr. McCall will also accuse Mr. Pataki of lacking fiscal discipline, citing chronically late state budgets, rising debt and a current budget that all involved have described as a train wreck. 
But perhaps the most striking aspect of the speech is its use of a compelling and varied personal history that McCall partisans have long called his greatest political asset. The child of a single mother on welfare, he became an ordained minister, an ambassador to the United Nations, a vice president of Citicorp and the first black person to hold statewide office in New York. It is a history he has been reluctant to trumpet at times; Mr. McCall's own advisers joke that when he was elected comptroller in 1994, many of those who voted for him did not know he was black.
"My mother raised me and my five sisters all by herself," the speech says. "Times were tough. We didn't have a lot. But she told me that if I studied hard and worked hard, education would open doors of opportunity and make just about anything possible. My mother was right."
For much of this year, Mr. McCall's allies worried that his campaigning was too subdued, as his Democratic primary rival, Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary, and Mr. Pataki consistently drew more attention to themselves. Polls have shown Mr. McCall trailing in the primary, and both Democrats have run behind Mr. Pataki.
Mr. McCall's strategists counseled patience, insisting that the race would not really begin until attention shifted from the New York City mayoral contest. Mr. McCall stepped up the pace of his campaign in late summer, but he was largely ignored in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.
Tuesday's speech, his advisers say, reflects the start of a more intensive effort by Mr. McCall to put himself in the spotlight, and to draw contrasts with Mr. Pataki.
"The Pataki administration has allowed a huge educational canyon to form in this state," it says, between have and have-not districts. And, it adds, "New York has the most inequitable school aid distribution in America."
The speech attacks the governor for fighting a lawsuit charging that the state did not adequately finance New York City schools.
That is a potentially powerful issue, but it carries the risk that Mr. McCall will be seen as the city's standard-bearer, traditionally the kiss of death upstate.
His remarks could also be heard as an echo of Fernando Ferrer's theme, in the mayoral race, of standing up for "the other New York" -- a stance that was criticized as racially and economically divisive.
Mr. McCall's speech cites his experience as the former president of New York City's Board of Education, but Mr. Pataki's team is prepared to turn that on the comptroller, blaming him for the city schools' failings.
The pledge to have 75 percent of students pass standardized tests is also likely to raise eyebrows.
On the assessment tests that all New York fourth graders take, 60 percent passed the English portion this year, and 69 percent passed in math.

HEADLINE: Economists Make It Official: U.S. Is inRecession 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 

 BODY:
The group of economists that tracks business cycles made official today what has been apparent to laid-off workers and struggling businesses for months: the longest economic expansion on record gave way earlier this year to the first recession in a decade and the 10th since World War II.
 The group, the National Bureau of Economic Research's business-cycle dating committee, said the recession began in March, months before the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 or the sharp rise in unemployment. 
 The group's statement put a headstone on a remarkable period of economic vibrancy. The last decade included the emergence of the stock market as a national sport, the appearance (and subsequent disappearance) of huge federal budget surpluses, a heated debate about the merits of globalization and a surge of optimism about the potential of a technology-driven "new economy." 
It is unclear how much of the 1990's boom will survive this recession and the pressures of war, and economists are divided about how strong the rebound will be once the recession ends, which the consensus of experts holds will be in the first half of next year.
While today's announcement contained no news about the current state of the economy or any forecast of how long the downturn would last, it is sure to increase the pressure on both parties in Congress to break their impasse over the shape of a proposed economic stimulus bill. 
It could also force President Bush -- ever mindful that his father was defeated for re-election in 1992 because many thought he had neglected the economy for foreign policy -- to spend more time tending to domestic issues even as he focuses on the struggle against terrorism. 
After the business-cycle committee's announcement this morning, Mr. Bush called on Congress to complete work on the stimulus package by Christmas, setting aside his previous deadline of Nov. 30.
Republicans are pressing for a bill that is heavy on tax breaks for businesses. Democrats want a plan that would expand unemployment benefits and subsidize health insurance premiums for laid-off workers.
The president said the country had "the framework for economic recovery in place," including low interest rates, declining oil prices and the benefits of the tax cut measure he signed in June.
"But I am obviously aware that our economy is slow," Mr. Bush told reporters in the White House Rose Garden. "And we will do everything we can to enhance recovery."
By some measures, the economy was still growing as winter turned to spring, and some analysts had expected the recession's official start to be placed in late spring or early summer.
But the committee, made up of six prominent academic and business economists, said March was the month when employment reached a peak and began declining, a turning point it said it considered the most crucial in determining when an expansion has run its course.
Among the other factors that the committee said it considered most important in determining when the expansion had ended, industrial production has been declining since September 2000 and a broad measure of sales reached a peak late last year. Only one measure that the group said was important -- personal income minus welfare payments and other transfers from the government to individuals -- has continued to increase throughout 2001.
"The committee is satisfied that the total contraction in the economy is sufficient to merit the determination that a recession is under way," it said.
The committee said the terrorist attacks did not cause the nation's economic problems, but might have been enough to make the difference between a pronounced slowdown and a formal recession.
In particular, the group said, the rise in unemployment in October to 5.4 percent from 4.9 percent in September provided compelling evidence that employment was in sharp decline.
"Before the attacks," it said, "it is possible that the decline in the economy would have been too mild to qualify as a recession. The attacks clearly deepened the contraction and may have been an important factor in turning the episode into a recession."
The economists on the committee are Robert Hall of Stanford University, the group's chairman; Martin Feldstein of Harvard University, who is president of the National Bureau of Economic Research; Ben S. Bernanke of Princeton University; Jeffrey Frankel of Harvard; Robert Gordon of Northwestern University; and Victor Zarnowitz of the Conference Board, a business research group.
Just as in the last downturn cycle -- from July 1990 to March 1991, a period in which Iraq invaded Kuwait and the United States and its allies responded with military action -- the nation confronts the challenge of dealing simultaneously with war and recession.
Barring any new terrorist attacks, economists expect this downturn to be over in the first half of 2002. Recent signs that the rise in unemployment may be leveling off, plus generally positive reports about retail sales after Thanksgiving and a revival on Wall Street, have led some economists to predict a bounce back early next year.
But there is considerable disagreement about how robust a rebound can be expected, with some analysts predicting that growth will remain lackluster for a year or two after the recession officially ends.
Merrill Lynch, the investment house, forecast today that the recession would end by March. It said the combination of aggressive interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, tax cuts and government spending would lead economic growth to reach a red-hot annual rate of 5 percent in the second half of next year.
Some economists elsewhere said it could take much longer for the United States to get back to a semblance of the good times that it enjoyed through much of the 1990's.
"The official recession could be pretty short," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management, an investment firm. "But the real issue isn't when the recession ends. It's when do you get back to a sustainable growth rate of 3 to 4 percent, and on that count I think there's going to be disappointment."
Consumers have sated themselves on big-ticket purchases and pushed their savings rates to almost zero, leaving them an unlikely engine of economic recovery, Mr. Paulsen said.
The Federal Reserve's campaign of interest rate cuts may not be as effective as expected, he said, with long-term rates not falling as much as anticipated this year and the strong dollar making it difficult for manufacturers to sell products abroad.
Mr. Paulsen said it could be well into 2003 before the economy was really back on track.
If the recovery this time around is anemic, it would match the experience of the early 90's. The last recession formally ended in March 1991, but the recovery proceeded in fits and starts over the next two years. The economy contracted slightly in the first quarter of 1993 before returning to a sustained pattern of healthy growth.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Expansion, and Recession"Since World War II, the average recession -- measured from the month in which the previous expansion peaked to its trough -- has lasted a little more than 10 months. If that pattern holds, the current recession should end early next year. Graph tracks economic expansion and recession in months from the 1940's-2000. (Source: National Bureau of Economic Research)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 INTERNATIONAL A3-9

2 U.S. Envoys in Mideast To Press for Peace Plan
Anthony Zinni, a retired Marine Corps general, and William Burns, an assistant secretary of state, arrived in Jerusalem to begin the Bush administration's first intensive drive for peace between Israelis and Palestinians since negotiations collapsed at the end of President Bill Clinton's second term. A3

Battling AIDS in African Court
Lawyers went to court in Pretoria to try to force the South African government to widely distribute the AIDS drug nevirapine. The drug greatly reduces the risk that a pregnant woman will transmit H.I.V. to her newborn. The government now offers the drug through a program reaching only 10 percent of pregnant women. A8

State of Emergency in Nepal
King Gyandendra suspended most civil liberties and authorized the army to join the police in battling a five-year-old insurgency of Maoist rebels. The declaration followed a six-hour clash that left about 230 people dead. A6

Captives in Philippines Speak
Gracia and Martin Burnham, an American missionary couple held for six months by Muslim guerrillas, described the horrors of life in captivity in a videotaped interview broadcast during elections for governor of a predominantly Muslim region caught up in Islamic rebellion. A5

Colombia Rebels Shunned
Diplomats from Europe and Latin America who once viewed FARC, Colombia's largest rebel group, as a savvy political player with justified grievances are now dour about its commitment to peace after months of rebel violations and with talks at a standstill. The European Union has begun shunning the rebels and taking punitive actions against them. A9

Trouble for Quirky Hobbyists
A group of eccentric, mostly British vacationers whose hobby is prowling around airfields hoping to sight rare aircraft has been detained in Greece for snooping around a high-security installation near Athens. A9

Sprawl, Not Logging, Cited In Southern Woods' Decline
A Forest Service study has concluded that the biggest threat to Southern forests is urban sprawl, a finding that to some degree absolves the timber industry for the effects of a logging boom that transformed the South in recent decades. The report also warned that development threatened the habitats of numerous species. A10

Missing Virus Expert

HEADLINE: Hudson's Bay Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 26 

 BODY:
The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's largest department store chain by sales, had a loss of 2 million Canadian dollars ($1.3 million) after excluding the benefits of an accounting rule change in its most recent quarter, as shoppers bought less clothing. 
 The retailer's loss was 7 cents a share for the quarter, in contrast to net income of 19.7 million Canadian dollars, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Oct. 31 and was the third quarter of Hudson's Bay's fiscal year, fell to 1.76 billion from 1.77 billion Canadian dollars. 
 The retailer, which is based in Toronto, has cut prices because of growing competition and a slowing economy. Its Zellers discount chain is fighting to keep customers from shopping at Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The company's upmarket Bay department stores offered discounts on most items to compete with Sears Canada Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company; Sears Canada is the nation's second-largest department store chain by sales. 
Hudson's Bay's chief executive, George Heller, also cited "intense" competition from stores owned by the San Francisco-based retailers Williams-Sonoma Inc. and Gap Inc. Specialty stores are able to identify and obtain trendy merchandise more quickly, said Sean Mason, who analyzes retailers for Dominion Bond Rating Service Ltd. 
Mr. Mason said weather that was warmer than usual in the quarter also kept people from buying new fall and winter clothes. 
"They've got bad weather; the competition is discounting; they're looking at a soft economy; they're going into the most competitive time of the year," he said. "It's not going to be a good Christmas, for profits or sales." 
Hudson's Bay has said that fourth-quarter sales will be little changed from last year's 2.42 billion Canadian dollars.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
After Losing High Hopes, A Chance to Hope Again

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
There was a time when things looked promising for Gavin Dutchin. It was the early 90's, he had recently graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and had landed his first job on Wall Street, at Cowen & Company, an investment banking firm.
 "I saw great potential for myself," he recalled recently. "I just wanted to work for someone who would at least give me a chance to exhibit my talent, and that seemed like the ideal place to do it." 
 Four years later, far from his dream of making a name for himself on Wall Street, Mr. Dutchin was homeless, and shortly thereafter, he was taken to a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital Center. His downward spiral had begun in December 1994, when he was laid off from his job as an assistant managing director, he said.
By now, he has an apartment and medication to control his mental illnesses, and his life is improving with the help of a psychiatric treatment program run by FEGS, formerly the Federation Employment and Guidance Service.
At the program, he attends classes that help him improve his organizational skills, memory and concentration. FEGS is a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
After he lost his job, Mr. Dutchin worked from his parents' house in Jamaica, Queens, for two years, trying to set up a company, Mlishi, to foster development in his native Guyana. He supported himself mostly by tapping into his 401(k) retirement fund, and by tutoring high school and college students who needed help in algebra or calculus. But the company never prospered.
Then came 1998 -- the year, he said, that "things started to fall apart for me." Mr. Dutchin's father, Carlyle, died of prostate cancer at 70. "He was the cornerstone of the family," Mr. Dutchin said. 
So his mother, Carmen, then 68, moved back to Guyana, and he moved in with his older sister Loraine Dutchin, who was raising two children on her own in Flatbush, Brooklyn. In exchange for a spot on his sister's couch, Mr. Dutchin helped her two teenagers with their math homework. But eventually, she began to feel that it was an uneven trade, he said, and he had to leave.
He spent two years homeless. At night, he rode the F train back and forth between Jamaica, Queens, and Coney Island, learning that by the time a train made two complete circuits, it would be late morning, time for him to help a food salesman on Canal Street attach his food cart to his car. For his services, Mr. Dutchin would get three or four bagels that had not been sold that day, and would take them to eat in Washington Square.
After finishing his breakfast, Mr. Dutchin would walk to the Barnes & Noble bookstore at Union Square, where he read books about advanced mathematical theory in the fourth-floor reading lounge.
A quiet man who says he keeps to himself, Mr. Dutchin maintained a low profile. Nobody seemed to notice that he never bought any books. "All that I can remember thinking was that somebody would see me and tell my mother so that at least she could come and get me," he recalled.
Minnie Berman, director of the FEGS program in Manhattan, said his symptoms were consistent with someone with a history of psychosis and depression. "Since he came to us he's been very stable," she said.
One day on a crowded downtown street, someone stepped on the back of Mr. Dutchin's foot. He declined to discuss details of the incident, other than to say, "We had an exchange of words."
Whatever happened, it was serious enough to cause a bystander to call an ambulance, and Mr. Dutchin was taken to Bellevue, where he was placed in a psychiatric ward for three months. There he was treated for tuberculosis and began taking a mood stabilizing drug and an anti-psychotic, he said, both of which he still takes daily. 
Mr. Dutchin wants to become an economist. Staff members at FEGS are helping him apply for graduate school. "My short-term goal is to get my Ph.D.," Mr. Dutchin said, "and to complete my involvement with taking medication."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SPECIAL MASTER; 
Mediator Named to Run Sept. 11 Fund

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and DAVID BARSTOW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 

 BODY:
Attorney General John Ashcroft today appointed Kenneth R. Feinberg, a Democratic lawyer with extensive experience in mediating complex and emotionally charged disputes, to run the multibillion-dollar federal fund set up to compensate the families of those killed or physically injured in the September terrorist attacks.
 In making the appointment, which is not subject to Congressional review, Mr. Ashcroft also directed Mr. Feinberg, who has offices both here and in New York City, to begin making at least partial payments to families by the end of the year or sooner. 
 As special master of the Sept. 11 Victims Compensation Fund, Mr. Feinberg will be the final arbiter of how to distribute at least $11 billion in victim compensation, and possibly much more -- money that will be the single most important source of long-term financial support for thousands of families who lost a breadwinner in the attacks. The awards, based in large part on a victim's lost earning power, could well exceed $1 million per family.
Mr. Feinberg's powers are sweeping: he will help draft the fund's rules and procedures, will oversee its operations, and will personally sign off on all the awards made to claimants, who must waive their right to sue over the attacks and who cannot appeal the fund's decisions to any court.
The attorney general, to whom the special master reports, and Mr. Feinberg signaled that the fund should put victims' needs ahead of the ultimate expense to taxpayers.
Mr. Feinberg's political pedigree -- he was formerly chief of staff for Senator Edward M. Kennedy and was considered for the post of White House counsel in the Clinton administration -- makes him seem like an unlikely choice for the fund, which was created in September as part of the airline industry bailout bill.
But he has extensive experience in mediating complicated compensation disputes, including those that arose over the Agent Orange defoliant used in Vietnam and the Dalkon Shield birth control device.
Mr. Ashcroft called him a seasoned "legal counselor, prosecutor, manager and arbitrator" who has had extensive experience handling other cases involving mass casualties. "It's that experience and expertise which we anticipate will provide the basis for good decision-making on his part here," Mr. Ashcroft said.
Mr. Feinberg's candidacy was supported by both Democrats and Republicans, from Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, to Senator Chuck Hagel, a Republican from Nebraska. Mr. Hagel first worked with Mr. Feinberg on behalf of Vietnam veterans in the Agent Orange case.
"I went to the White House and said, 'I'm going to say as forcefully as I can that there is one guy out there you need to take a look at -- he was Ted Kennedy's chief of staff, but as you pick yourself up off the floor from that, let me tell you this guy is as fair and honest as anybody I've ever seen,' " said Mr. Hagel.
Although the fund is open-ended and must be financed by taxpayers -- some of whom have written to the Department of Justice in recent weeks to caution against using the United States Treasury to enrich victims and their families -- neither Mr. Ashcroft nor Mr. Feinberg cited the interests of taxpayers today.
Instead, each stressed the importance of ministering to the financial needs of victims and their families. Mr. Ashcroft said his "first instruction" to Mr. Feinberg was to provide partial "advance payments" to victims and their families to help them meet immediate financial needs.
"For those victims struggling to pay bills and make payments," Mr. Ashcroft said, "our message should be today: 'You are not alone. Help is on the way."'
Some fiscal conservatives have been extremely nervous about the ultimate cost of the victims compensation fund. Congress set no caps on either the total size of the fund or how much any one victim's family could get.
Today, some vowed to closely scrutinize awards made by Mr. Feinberg.
"All tax dollars come with some strings attached, and that string is Congressional oversight," said Jill Gerber, a spokeswoman for Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. "Any time Congress is doling out billions of dollars, it expects a full accounting of that expenditure, and Senator Grassley is certainly in that category."
By law, the fund must be up and operating by Dec. 21, and Mr. Feinberg said that he hoped to issue preliminary rules within 10 days. But first, he said, he plans to review the hundreds of written public comments about the fund and meet with victims' rights groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and officials from the leading charities.
"This is not an adversarial process at all," he said.
Mr. Feinberg, in a subsequent interview at his Washington law office, said his goal would be to create a program that would be "simple, efficient and clear." 
He also pledged to meet with as many claimants as possible. "I am, in a sense, a fiduciary for them," he said. "My role is to help them."
Some lawyers have cautioned that certain victim families may be better served going to court rather than seeking a quicker award from the fund, which might be less generous.
Mr. Feinberg, who said that he and several members of his law firm would be working for the fund without pay, said that he faced a formidable to-do list before he could start making awards.
He must determine whether the fund's awards should be reduced by any charity a family has received, which he called "a very big issue." He also must clarify, with greater precision than the statute does, who is eligible for the fund. And he must determine how to handle claims from fragmented families, and how to cope with the inequities that are sure to emerge in awards made to victims of such widely disparate economic circumstances.
His appointment was greeted with some surprise but general applause within the legal profession.
"Ken Feinberg has become the most important person on earth to thousands of devastated families, and he has exactly the right resume for this job," said Leo V. Boyle, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which is providing free legal counsel to every family that files a claim with the fund.

PROFILE -- Kenneth R. Feinberg

BORN -- Oct. 23, 1945
HOMETOWN -- Bethesda, Md.
EDUCATION -- Brockton High School, Brockton, Mass., 1963; B.A. University of Massachusetts, 1967; J.D., New York University School of Law, 1970.
CAREER -- Chief of staff, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, 1978-80; special master, Agent Orange litigation, 1984; special master, Shoreham Nuclear Plant closing, 1989; member, President Reagan's Commission on Catastrophic Nuclear Accidents, 1989; and member, President Clinton's Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments, 1994.
FAMILY -- Married June 21, 1975, Diane S. Feinberg; three children, Michael, 24, Leslie, 22, and Andrew, 19.
INTERESTS -- Classical music.

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 10; A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

LENGTH: 2969 words

HEADLINE: A Surfing Firefighter, a Thrill-Riding Hunter, a Mormon Composer

BYLINE: These sketches were written by Carla Baranauckas, Nichole M. Christian, Jane Gross, Constance L. Hays, Jan Hoffman, N. R. Kleinfield, Barbara Stewart and Robert F. Worth.

 BODY:
Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

PAUL BRISTOW
A Cheeky Blithe Spirit
 Blithe spirits come in all sizes: this one was about 5 feet 6, skinny, with a smile that asserts itself in Cathy Bruneau's snapshots. There he is, Paul Bristow, cocking his head, compelling you to cast off the grumps, wearing a fright wig, kicking up a leg. 
 The British-born Mr. Bristow, 27 -- ''a little cheeky person,'' says Ms. Bruneau, his fiance and companion for seven years, first in London and then in Brooklyn -- made sure that he never worked more than he needed to, which is not to say that he slacked off at the Risk Waters Group, where he helped organize conferences. It's just that he preserved time for the important things: shopping, friends, shooting pool, getting lost on a country road and savoring its beauty.
 Funny, endearing, he could charm even the crustiest. Here is Mr. Bristow, surrounded by Ms. Bruneau's non-English-speaking relatives, rolling in their seats at a wedding in France as he repeatedly tries out his one sentence in French: ''Another bottle of white wine, please?''
 Like a child, he would dance impatiently around Ms. Bruneau when he wanted attention. But he reciprocated in spades when she was blue, with giant hugs to help her ''get the cry out,'' as he would put it.

EMERIC HARVEY
A Memorable Voice
 As a young man, Emeric (Ric) Harvey sold truck rides to children with his friend Ray in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, where he grew up. ''Come swing and sway with Rick and Ray!'' he'd bellow. Eventually, that voice was heard on the trading floor of the American Stock Exchange, where he became a force as founder and president of Harvey Young Yurman Inc.
 His relentless energy made him a natural leader, though at times it was hard to keep up, said his daughter Jennifer Castelano. Part of it came from having lived through some close calls: as a young man in Texas, he nearly boarded an Air Force plane that crashed, killing everyone on board. And he narrowly missed being in the World Trade Center when it was bombed in 1993. On Sept. 11, Mr. Harvey, 56, of Montclair, N.J., was at a weekly breakfast meeting at Windows on the World.
 His drive and generosity remain an inspiration, a loud one. ''That's how I get out of bed every morning, because I can hear him yelling, 'What are you doing lying there crying?' '' said his wife, Jennifer Harvey.

ROBERT TWOMEY
A History and Science Buff
 There were no limits to Robert Twomey's love for history and science. Botany, entomology, viniculture, the Civil War: he was always reading something and loved talking about it. ''He retained everything,'' said his wife, Marie Twomey.
 Mr. Twomey, 48, did graduate work in biology in his 20's, but never finished his dissertation and got into finance when he and his wife had the first of their two boys 18 years ago. He worked as a trader on the American Stock Exchange with Ric Harvey, his brother-in-law, at Harvey Young Yurman, and dreamed of retiring to teach in public school. On Sept. 11, he was at a weekly breakfast meeting at Windows on the World.
 When he was not reading, he loved to ride his bike from his home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, to Breezy Point, Queens. He knew a lot about Sheepshead Bay, where his family had lived for more than a century. It was one of the many things he shared with his wife, whom he married when they were both 19. ''I'm living in the house my grandparents bought in 1905,'' Mrs. Twomey said. ''Bob's father played in the construction site of this house.''

THOMAS HASKELL
Creating Tiny Wonderlands
 In some ways, Thomas Haskell seemed like everyone's idea of a firefighter. The battalion chief for Ladder Company 132 in Brooklyn, he loved football -- ''God help you if you got in the way of the TV'' on Sundays, said Dawn Haskell-Carbone, his sister -- and he played on the Fire Department team, like his brothers, Kenneth and Timothy. Timothy Haskell also died in the World Trade Center attack.
 But he had another side. Every year just before Thanksgiving, Mr. Haskell, 37, would start disappearing into the basement of his home in Massapequa, N.Y., for hours, forbidding anyone else to come down. ''He'd stay up till 3 a.m.,'' said his wife, Barbara Haskell. Then, about two weeks before Christmas, his wife, daughters, friends and other relatives would be invited downstairs to see an elaborate winter landscape with hundreds of tiny ceramic figures, surrounded by ski chalets, with three separate train sets running through it all.
 Last year he built three miniature towns -- Meaghanville, Erinburg and Taratown, named for his daughters -- along with Barbara's Garden, for his wife. Behind them all was a dark blue night sky, lit up with electric stars.

LORENZO RAMZEY
King of Chess, Not Golf
 His nickname was Grandmaster. For anyone who dared to move a pawn against him, the reason was obvious. Lorenzo Ramzey played a daunting game of chess.
 Every day during his lunch hour, he challenged anyone to play. If no one was willing, that did not stop him. He dragooned an opponent into a game. Could you beat him? Forget it.
 When he went home to East Northport, N.Y., where he lived with his wife, Volteen, it was often back to the chessboard. He would log on to the Internet and play against cyberspace opponents, sometimes until 3 in the morning. Relatives would call, and the phone line would be busy for hours. Mrs. Ramzey's grown children were planning to get her a second phone line.
 Last summer, two relatives in Florida played an epic game against Mr. Ramzey on the Internet and, for the first time, beat him. ''They never let him forget that,'' said Jennifer Fontus, his stepdaughter. ''They said they had dethroned the Grandmaster.'' He was supposed to visit them for Thanksgiving for a rematch. 
 Mr. Ramzey, 48, came to America from Panama when he was in his late teens, and worked his way up in the insurance business, eventually becoming a casualty broker at Aon. He also loved golf, but was less proficient with woods and irons than with knights and bishops; friends who had been humbled at chess were quick to remark, ''Did he tell you about his golf game?''

GARY H. LEE
The Incurable Collector
 Bayonets. Eagles. Baseball cards. Hess trucks. Vinyl records. Matchbooks. Coins. Stamps. Old record players.
 These were some of the things Gary H. Lee collected. Just about anything might meet his criteria and turn into a full-blown collection.
 Mr. Lee, 62, and known variously as Uncle Dude, Big Gary or Pop Pop, lived with his wife, Eileen, in Lindenhurst, on Long Island, where the attic was very full. There is all this World War II gear up there -- helmets, uniforms, bayonets. He had something like 150 bayonets and swords, 40,000 baseball cards, dozens of statues and pictures of eagles, every birthday and anniversary card he ever received. ''He was collecting his whole life,'' said Gary A. Lee, his son. ''And he never sold anything.''
 Mr. Lee, a senior vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald, did not collect cars, but he always wanted a Studebaker. About 15 years ago, he bought a 1948 model that he lovingly restored and took to car shows, winning several first- and second-place trophies. 
 His wife and son are trying to sort through his myriad collections. Some of the bayonets are being donated to a new World War II museum that the town of Babylon is opening in Lindenhurst. As for the baseball cards, the eagles and the Hess trucks, his son is going to continue those collections. ''I think he would want me to,'' he said.

JOHN ERNST EICHLER
Magician and Joker
 John Ernst Eichler believed in bringing the world some comic relief -- not in a clownish way, but with his own brand of dry wit. ''He had one of the greatest senses of humor on the face of the earth,'' said his friend Edmund Redsecker. ''He could brighten your day.''
 Mr. Eichler, 69, of Cedar Grove, N.J., retired several years ago as director of administration for Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. He was at a breakfast at Windows on the World on Sept. 11.
 He was a man of multiple avocations. He joined the New York Academy of Sciences, attending lectures with rapt attention. (''But you don't understand what they're saying,'' his friend Gene Bloch would say. ''Yes, but I look like I understand it, don't I?'' Mr. Eichler would reply.) He was also a member of the Society of American Magicians, performing sleight-of-hand for friends, said Rod Eichler, his son.
 And he was known for his practical jokes. Once, he walked into a men's clothing store owned by a friend in Montclair, N.J. He took out a handful of black plastic ants and scattered them over the sweater table. ''He started making a commotion,'' his son recalled, ''saying, 'I can't believe it, there's an insect problem here, they're all over the sweaters.' ''

VINCENT A. PRINCIOTTA
The Essence of Cool
 First there was the blue van with the surfboard strapped to the roof. Then there were the bright Hawaiian shirts, the flowing hair, the perpetual tan. Soon there was no doubt: Vincent A. Princiotta was cool. 
 Starting in the late 1970's, Mr. Princiotta, a firefighter with Ladder Company 7 in Manhattan, led a band of surfers from their landlocked Bronxwood Avenue neighborhood into the big waves off Gilgo Beach. ''I think he watched too much Don Ho,'' said Dave Breiner, a Connecticut firefighter who knew him as Vinny Van. When he visited his sister Bernadette at college in Hawaii, her friends were amazed, she said, that a non-Hawaiian, ''this haoli from the Bronx,'' was so able on the longboard. 
 Even as the years rolled by, and he married the lovely Karen and became the adoring father of Christina, now 16 months old, Mr. Princiotta, 39, who lived in Orangeburg, N.Y., maintained his profile. He invested in phony winning lottery tickets, which he would distribute to his fellow firefighters and watch while they shrieked and kissed the firehouse floor. But he also helped the younger ones get familiar with firefighting tools, said Patty Boylan, a friend and colleague at Ladder 7, and cooked heaps of Italian food for the entire company. And he kept on surfing. ''He was just supercool,'' Mr. Boylan said. ''We called him the Vin Man.''

STEPHEN P. DIMINO
Generous From the Start
 When Stephen P. Dimino turned 9, his parents organized a special birthday trip into Manhattan from their home in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. They took Stephen and his sister to see ''My Fair Lady,'' and then they all stuck nickels and dimes into the slots at an automat to get their lunch. 
 But then the boy spotted an old man sitting by himself who looked hungry. He brought his sandwich over to him. Then the rest of the Dimino family followed suit, said Gigi Ebert, Mr. Dimino's sister. ''We ended up giving him all of our food,'' she said.
 Mr. Dimino, 48, who was a partner at Cantor Fitzgerald, continued to be generous. ''He was someone you'd want as your neighbor,'' said his cousin Robert Messina. He loved to give people presents, like venison steaks from the deer he shot and souvenirs from his travels abroad. At home in Basking Ridge, N.J., he showered his daughter, Sabrina, 15, with time, too, ''hunting together, playing video games together, riding roller coasters together,'' Mrs. Ebert said. ''He started taking her to Disneyland as soon as she was old enough to remember it. He really took delight in her and in her accomplishments. I thought he was going to burst the day she was born.''

GEORGE DiPASQUALE
Practiced What He Preached
 Melissa DiPasquale has told enough stories about her firefighter husband, cried enough tears before strangers. Now, she wants peace and privacy. Another article about George DiPasquale? His wife begs a reporter to use what has already been said about him in his local newspaper, The Staten Island Advance:
 His nickname at Ladder Company 2 in Manhattan was Holy Man, more respectful than many in the rough-and-tumble world of a firehouse. The 33-year-old firefighter, one of 10 from the company who raced to duty at 9:09 a.m. on Sept. 11 and never returned, was known for his faith.
 Mr. DiPasquale, an imposing 6-foot-5, was an elder at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses in the Mariners Harbor neighborhood, and shared his thoughts on religion and hope with his colleagues. He was a man who ''practiced what he preached,'' said his father-in-law, Michael Mattei. ''What he said, he meant.''
 Mr. DiPasquale and his wife celebrated their ninth wedding anniversary in Cape May, N.J., just days before the attack. ''A perfect weekend,'' Mrs. DiPasquale said. The couple have a daughter, Georgia Rose, who is 22 months old.

MICHAEL EMMETT BRENNAN
Mikey B. the Prankster
 His birth certificate said Michael Emmett Brennan, but everyone knew him as Mikey B. And if there was fun to be had, he would find it.
 Growing up in a large Irish family in Queens, Mikey Brennan, 27, would delight in throwing a bucket of cold water on his brother Brian when he was in the shower. When his brother retaliated by smearing Vaseline in his hair, he could see the humor just as easily. ''He looked like the Fonz for about three weeks,'' Mr. Brennan recalled. And he could keep a secret. ''I found out about all these little pranks after the fact,'' said his mother, Eileen Walsh. ''And I said, 'That's my Mike?' ''
 As a child he was fascinated with police officers and firefighters; his favorite television show was ''CHiPs.'' So it was no surprise to his family when he left college in 1995 to become a firefighter. ''He had a passion for it,'' Ms. Walsh said, adding that he was continually working to improve his skills. He answered the call on Sept. 11 with Ladder Company 4.
 ''I've never been in a fire,'' Mr. Brennan said, ''but if I were, I would want Mikey to bring me out.''
 Yet his hard work never took the twinkle out of the eye of Mikey Brennan, an avid snowboarder and surfer who lived in Woodside, Queens. About a year ago at a family gathering, Ms. Walsh said, one of her daughters was talking about body piercing. ''Oh, please, don't get your tongue pierced,'' Ms. Walsh pleaded. With that, everyone started laughing as Mikey Brennan stuck out his tongue to show off his brand-new stud.
 ''While living,'' Mr. Brennan said, ''he lived.''

OLIVER BENNETT
Attentive and Quick-Witted
 Oliver Bennett, the younger and taller of the two Bennett sons, was a passionate listener. Joy Bennett, his mother, remembers him at gatherings: his head slightly lowered and his eyes intent on the person talking to him. In his quiet way, he drew attention. ''You were always aware of Oli,'' a friend told Mrs. Bennett. ''He was a very, very vital presence.''
 And, sometimes, a rather intimidating one. His withering one-liners, Mrs. Bennett said, ''could take your breath away.''
 ''You didn't cross Oli lightly. He let you know just what he thought. At 13, he'd say, 'I don't agree with you, Mom, but let's don't argue about it.' '' His decisions, she said, were absolute.
 He loved to draw, she said. The Bennett home in London, where he lived, is ''littered'' with his portraits. But he studied economics and psychology and became a financial writer for the Risk Water Group. On Sept. 11, he was at its conference at Windows on the World. He planned to quit journalism in a year, at 30, and open a restaurant and bar where conversation would flow easily. He saw himself as his own boss, the quiet center of the bar's hubbub, with an ever-changing parade of people to watch and listen to.

SEAMUS ONEAL
Many Names, Many Faces
 For Seamus Oneal, the idea of having one career and one name was much too timid. By 52, he had worked in five widely different professions, using three different names. As James, he studied drama at the University of Oklahoma, and as Seam, he acted, danced and sang in Off Broadway shows. ''It would be fair,'' said John Oneal, his brother, ''to call him a hippie.''
 Seam Oneal the hippie joined the Army, became Captain Oneal and won medals for his work in hospital administration. Nevertheless, after converting to Mormonism, he and Janet Kaye, his wife, and their three children moved into a bed and breakfast by a big Maryland temple and ran it together. Eventually, though, he returned to college to study advanced computer science, moved to Manhattan and took a job with eSpeed, a division of Cantor Fitzgerald.
 Along the way, he composed liturgical choral works that were played by the Mormon temple's orchestra. And he dropped Seam and became Seamus. ''He said, 'There might be other Jameses,' '' said his brother, '' 'but there won't be other Seamuses.' He was something. A piece of art.''

JOHN PATRICK TIERNEY
Dedicated to Firefighting
 On Father's Day, as Helen Tierney heard the news that three firefighters in Queens had been killed on the job, her heart broke. For the men who died, she cried. For her son John Patrick Tierney, 27, a probationary firefighter training in Queens at the time, she rejoiced that he had had that day off. ''He always said, 'Don't worry, Ma. Everything will be fine.' And it was.''
 So, on Sept. 11, when his unit, Ladder Company 9 in Manhattan, was called to the World Trade Center, she clung once again to her youngest son's words. Her prayer was that he had headed home to Staten Island that morning. But Mr. Tierney had hopped a fire truck so crowded that he was forced to sit in a colleague's lap. ''The other guys told him he didn't have to come,'' Mrs. Tierney said. ''But from the first day he went to probie school, he worked hard, he really wanted to be part of the Fire Department.''
 And he was, for six weeks.

 Following are the names of the people most recently confirmed to have died in the World Trade Center disaster, according to the New York City medical examiner's office, which said the victims' families had been notified.

HEADLINE: TASTINGS; 
Vouvray, Going to Extremes

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
APART from its mellifluous name, Vouvray is a white wine with big marketing problems. First of all, it is not made from chardonnay, the world's most popular grape, or even from riesling, which has its devotees, or sauvignon blanc, which at least is well known. It is 100 percent chenin blanc, a versatile, fascinating grape that deserves to be thought of as among the world's elite, but instead is neglected. 
 There's a clear economic reason for this. Chenin blanc is more difficult than chardonnay or sauvignon blanc to grow and to make into wine. It seems to need a more precise combination of soil and weather than chardonnay, and is less easy for winemakers to manipulate with oak and other flavor-modifying tools. Though it is often used in California for jug wines and makes serviceable whites in South Africa, it reaches its full potential only in the Loire Valley, where in appellations like Vouvray it can range from steely to lusciously sweet. 
 Even so, the name Vouvray is no guarantee of a good chenin blanc. A lot of bad Vouvray is around, so chenin blanc lovers must find the best producers. Beyond that, while dry Vouvray, at times labeled sec, can be very good, I find off-dry, or demi-sec, Vouvrays to be better. Yet calling a wine off-dry can be a kiss of death in a country where people believe they like only dry wines.
If you feel this way, try an experiment. Next time you have a spicy dinner, say a Thai curry, try a demi-sec Vouvray like the Domaine du Clos Naudin from Foreau. The balance of refreshing acidity and moderate sweetness will stand up to those dishes.
The demi-secs also go well with creamy sauces, while dry Vouvrays are superb with light fish and shellfish dishes. Even sweet Vouvrays, labeled moelleux, can go well with food, though in certain vintages, like 1997, the grapes may have been subjected to botrytis, the noble rot, which renders them so lush and honeyed they are fit only for dessert.

FOREAU DOMAINE DU CLOS NAUDIN, DEMI-SEC 1997: $22
Deep gold with an almost oily texture; luscious and refreshing.

S. A. HUET, CLOS DU BOURG PREMIERE TRIE, MOELLEUX 1995: $60
Sweet, lively and well balanced, with a long finish.

THIERRY NERISSON 1998: $17
Floral and anise aromas; supple and pliant; honeyed yet acidic.

DOMAINE BOURILLON-DORLEANS, LA COULEE D'OR, MOELLEUX 1996: $37
Bright apple and anise flavors; surprisingly light.

FRANCOIS PINON, CUVEE TRADITION 1999: $17
Honey, apple and citrus flavors, well balanced.

LA VALLEE COQUETTE, DEMI-SEC 1999: $8
Pear, anise and honey aromas; fresh and balanced.

Listed in order of preference. Prices are those paid in wine shops in the New York region.

HEADLINE: The Workers on an Assembly Line of A's 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "A's Soar at Harvard, Nearing a Majority" (news article, Nov. 22): 
 Harvard is not the only university grappling with grade inflation. 
The trend is national and longstanding. Part of the problem is the unstable equilibrium: it takes just one professor, department or college to relax grading standards for everyone to experience pressure to inflate grades to maintain teaching evaluations and student enrollments and to keep graduates competitive against other campuses in the job market.
To help employers evaluate the effects of grade inflation, every graduate's transcript should include not only the student's grade point average but also the average G.P.A. of all graduates, broken down by department, college and campus. These averages should become part of departmental and college evaluations.

PAUL ROSCOE
Orono, Me., Nov. 23, 2001

The writer is a professor of anthropology at the University of Maine.

HEADLINE: In Chinatown, A Taste of Revival 

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
IF every day were the Sunday after Thanksgiving, Chinatown would almost feel like its old self again. But the bustling streets, crowded markets and long lines at so many restaurants last weekend were unlike what the area has generally experienced since Sept. 11, when the attacks less than half a mile away left the neighborhood sealed off and without phone service.
 For two months, Chinatown was the forgotten downtown as concerned diners headed to struggling but trendier places in TriBeCa. In addition to their empty dining rooms, restaurants were left with no way for customers to call in orders or make reservations, no system to process credit cards, no cash to buy fresh fish and produce. The road to recovery has been so rough that many restaurateurs in Chinatown still count themselves lucky if business is off only 50 percent. 
 But the restaurant business still appears to be the brightest spot in the neighborhood's economy, which has lost 6,000 jobs, according to the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields. Garment factories are struggling, and gift shops are often so empty that salesclerks can be spotted sleeping on their stools in midafternoon. Yet enterprises founded on food are surviving and, more than other types of business, showing signs of slowly coming back to life. 
Phone service has been partially restored, and most streets are open, with state troopers helping to direct traffic as best they can in unfamiliar terrain. Distress signals like "For Rent" signs and boarded-up storefronts are few below Canal Street.
Things do move a little slower -- soup dumplings at Goody's arrive in 20 minutes instead of 5, the cook hacking up ducks at NY Noodletown is languid at best -- but the compensations are everywhere for the few patrons. One recent afternoon a street vendor actually greeted me when I stopped to examine his greens. Waiters were unfailingly patient, even solicitous. With streets less clogged, I could walk on the sidewalk instead of in traffic and get close enough to the open-front seafood markets to see that one big barrel was full of squirming frogs, that a tank was slithering with eels, and that nearly all the fish gleamed with freshness.
Most restaurants have cut back in various ways. Dim Sum Go Go in Chatham Square has let go half its employees, and some days Sweet-n-Tart Cafe closes at 11 p.m. instead of midnight. Others are offering discounts, like the 10 percent reduction given weekdays at New Wonton Garden on Mott Street. A group of restaurateurs has banded with local and city organizations to run flashy campaigns in windows, newspapers and tourist literature to lure patrons back around the lazy susans.
Ms. Fields is organizing a "Manhattan Night Out" tomorrow to bring 300 to 400 business and civic leaders into Chinatown "to visit the shops and eat in the restaurants to boost the businesses that are still not coming back as quickly as the owners need." They in turn, she hopes, will spread the word that Chinatown is open. 
Unlike Little Italy, which it abuts and partially surrounds, Chinatown has evolved over the last 20 years, particularly as new immigrants from Hong Kong have invested in the neighborhood. A better name for the area, in fact, would be Asia City now that so many Malaysian, Thai and Vietnamese restaurants have opened in the congested blocks north and south of Canal Street. Many are lavishly designed, and they have been joined by sleek tea salons catering to a hip young crowd with pearl tea jazzed up with tapioca, and by very modern bakeries that would be at home on upper Madison Avenue if not for the steamed pork buns sold along with the French-inspired pastries.
Chinatown is now being promoted with Little Italy and Harlem in a get-out-the- diners campaign by NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau. Business in those other neighborhoods is also off by 45 to 50 percent, according to the bureau, but Chinatown is easily the most competitive restaurant environment.
That handy gazetteer the Zagat Survey lists 36 restaurants in the area bounded by Hester Street on the north, Lafayette Street on the west and Allen and Pike Streets on the east. But on Sunday I counted 26 restaurants open and one closed just on the four blocks of Mott Street between Canal and Chatham Square. And that did not include all the bakeries and tea salons on that stretch, or the Hong Kong cake stall with the long line at Mosco Street.
Even before Sept. 11, the ground had started shifting under Chinatown. Already more and more immigrants -- and restaurateurs -- were settling in Sunset Park in Brooklyn or in Elmhurst and Flushing in Queens, where rents are lower. The closing of the Grand Street subway stop last summer had slowed pedestrian traffic. And increasingly there was competition closer in, from trendy Asian spots in NoLIta like Funky Broome and Clay.
After Sept. 11, things got radically worse with restrictions on traffic and telephone service for weeks. The smell from the wreckage still lingers on some days.
Cooks and busboys had difficulty getting to work when the neighborhood was sealed off, and only those with identification were allowed in. "These workers don't have ID," said Eileen Leong, the manager of Canton on Division Street. Her restaurant had to close for two days after the attacks because it had no staff in place.
Worse, the courthouses were shut down initially. Most places in Chinatown operate on margins so tight that any drop in business is brutal. On a good day it's hard to make a profit on $3.50 beef. Lose a few days of jurors' lunches and things get scary. 
E. Charles Hunt, president of the local chapter of the New York Restaurant Association, said a drop of just 20 percent in sales could put a restaurant at risk, even if it laid off staff and cut purchases. The last quarter of the year is especially important, he added, because restaurants do 40 percent of their business then.
Many workers in Chinatown indicated that cutbacks had already begun. On the afternoon I stopped into NY Noodletown to buy a couple of roast ducks the place was so weirdly quiet that I could ask the usually swamped cashier how business had been. She gestured: down, down. "I work only four days now," she said.
Kenny Wong, the manager of Ping's, the acclaimed seafood restaurant on Mott Street, said he had had to lay off workers, especially while the phone service was out. "If no one knows you're open," he said, "you close."
Colette Rossant, a partner in Dim Sum Go Go, said that her sales had dropped from $4,000 a day to $1,500, which is not enough to pay the rent.
At Joe's Shanghai on Pell Street, Raymond Wong, the manager, said business was starting to build on weekends but was still down 30 percent overall. And so he had had to lay off 6 of his 30 waiters and cooks and cut hours for those still working.
While he, Kenny Wong and Ms. Leong all said business was virtually back to normal last weekend, they each attributed the rebound to the holiday and the resulting influx of visitors. "If hotels don't get full, I don't," Ms. Leong said.
Many Chinatown workers, Raymond Wong said, are relying on emergency cash from private groups like Safe Horizon. Immigration issues apparently keep some workers from trying to file for government benefits. Others were paid in cash, off the books, and are not eligible for help, according to John Wang, president of the Asian American Business Development Center. And their empty pockets have a ripple effect throughout Chinatown, in the butcher shops and fish stores as well as the restaurants.
Some restaurateurs have turned the disaster to advantage, though. Bo Ky, a Vietnamese place on Bayard Street that shut down for lack of business after losing its phone service, is now undergoing a complete renovation thanks to a $60,000 loan from the Small Business Administration. Chi Vy Ngo, an owner, said the restaurant had been heavily dependent on business from the World Trade Center, and on takeout orders picked up by car. After the streets closed, so did he. Meantime, he has asked his 11 full-time employees to hang on until he reopens.
Some of the biggest restaurants seem to be bouncing back fastest. Golden Unicorn on East Broadway has 600 seats, yet the general manager, Peter Yau, said sales are now down a mere 10 percent. At their worst, in September, they dropped only 30 percent, he said.
What made the difference was the restaurant's focus on wedding banquets. After Sept. 11, Mr. Yau said, "they didn't cancel, they postponed." Most of the guests come from the metropolitan area, he said, so he is not feeling the drop in tourism and travel.
For Thanksgiving, in fact, Golden Unicorn was fully booked, Mr. Yau said, since the holiday has become a popular occasion for Asian weddings. At 2 in the afternoon on the Sunday after the big day, every table on two floors of the restaurant was occupied, and lines of people waited to be seated.
My own experience at dim sum best brought home why so many in Chinatown are optimistic, even insistent that, as Paul Lee, an assistant to the president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, put it: "Business is going to come back, but whether it's sooner or later we can't figure out."
The places that live by the tourists may die by the absence of tourists. But those like Triple Eight Palace that depend on New Yorkers may be able to keep the woks fired for the long term. Even on the Sunday before Thanksgiving, the four people in my party were among the few Caucasians waiting to be seated while the M.C. at a big Chinese wedding shouted through a microphone in the sprawling restaurant, in the Broadway Mall under the Manhattan Bridge.
Considering the noise, the absence of English and the surfeit of tripe, chicken feet and pork balls, we could have been on an eating expedition to another continent. It felt as far from Manhattan -- and ground zero -- as we could possibly get without braving a river or an airport. And the credit card machines were working.

HEADLINE: Egypt Puts Up Vacancy Signs 

BYLINE:  By ABEER ALLAM

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
The developers who initially conceived of building Egypt's first private airport three years ago had visions of tourists by the thousands whisked every week from Europe's cold, gray winter directly to the warm sunshine and azure waters of a $1.2 billion resort on Egypt's southern Red Sea coast.
 But when the Marsa Alam International Airport opened earlier this month, it attracted just one weekly flight, from Germany. 
 Egypt's tourism and aviation industries are reeling from the aftershocks of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Foreign tourists are shunning the country, afraid of flying and of any possible spillover from the fighting in Afghanistan. Hotels are closed, international airlines are scratching Egypt as a destination, and sales are eroding markedly even in tangential industries like alcoholic beverages. 
Tourism is crucial to Egypt's economy. The country drew 5.4 million visitors in 2000 despite tensions and violence elsewhere in the Middle East, and with a number of luxury projects under construction, including the development at Marsa Alam, the government had hopes of bettering that figure by 400,000 this year. Tourism is the government's largest source of revenue -- $4.3 billion in 2000 -- and it accounts for 10 percent of Egypt's gross domestic product. About 2.2 million Egyptians have jobs related to tourism.
But the signs are grim. "Tourist activity in October dropped 40 to 45 percent," the tourism minister, Mamdou el-Beltagi, told the state-owned Middle East News Agency. "The coming months will witness a larger drop in reservations due to cancellations by a number of tourist companies."
Egyptian hotels and travel agencies are reporting thousands of group cancellations. Even the most famous hotels, once considered immune to recession, are reporting occupancy rates of 50 percent or less and laying off workers. Some beach hotels have closed entirely.
"It is the worst crisis since the gulf war in 1991," said Osman Abaza, public relations manager for Mena House Oberoi, a century-old five-star hotel at the base of the Giza Pyramids. "We have only 40 percent occupancy, although the hotel was fully booked until January."
So far, the hotel has closed 200 rooms, four of its eight restaurants, one of its bars and a nightclub, and it has laid off all part-time employees.
Mr. Abaza is at a loss to say how the cancellations might be reversed.
"We cannot do anything about it," he said. "Lowering prices or launching promotion campaigns will not help. People are simply afraid of taking airplanes -- they are not coming in the first place."
Aside from some of the wonders of the ancient world, the main tourist attractions in Egypt are the beaches and coral reefs of the Red Sea and Sinai Peninsula. Nearly 80 percent of the foreign visitors to Egypt have been Europeans; Americans make up only 4 percent.
Trouble started for the Sinai resorts in September 2000, when an outbreak of violent clashes between Israelis and Palestinians severely crimped the flow of the resorts' mainstay visitors, tourists from Israel; 430,000 came in the first half of 2000, but fewer than 37,000 showed up in the comparable period this year.
"Forty percent of our clients are Israelis," said Roger Tabet, managing director of Orascom Hotel Holdings, the owners of a plush Sinai resort at Taba Heights near the Israeli border. "We were hit badly after the Palestinian uprising had broken out."
The events of Sept. 11 have spread the pain to the rest of the country, with airlines and other transportation companies suffering heavy losses and Egyptian travel agencies and tour packagers reporting inbound trade down by at least half compared with a year ago.
"We spent the first 10 days after the attack doing nothing but refunding to clients," said Hisham Hassan, an agent at Star of Egypt Travel in Cairo. "In two days, 60 percent of the airplane tickets were canceled."
Both Orascom and the Kharafi Group, the Kuwaiti company that is developing Marsa Alam, say they are pressing ahead with construction despite the slump. They hope that by the time their projects are completed in a few years, tourism will have picked up again. Plans at Marsa Alam include the biggest marina in the Middle East.
Meanwhile, though, air service to Egypt remains profoundly disrupted. Delta Air Lines, which had been set to replace Trans World Airlines by January 2002 as the sole American carrier flying nonstop between New York and Cairo, now says it will not fly the route before March 15. Malaysia Airlines announced that it would stop flying to Cairo on Jan. 1.
The damage has also been severe at EgyptAir, the national airline, which employs more than 20,000 people. "Our passengers dropped by 40 percent, and our operations have been cut by 15 percent since the attack," said Abdel Azim Sedqi, a spokesman for the airline.
In early November the minister of transportation, Ibrahim al-Dumeiri, put the aviation sector's total losses since Sept. 11 at $82 million, with three-quarters of those losses at EgyptAir.
EgyptAir has cut the domestic fares charged to foreign tourists by 40 percent and fares for Egyptians by 15 percent. Scheduled flights to Karachi, Pakistan; Osaka, Japan; and Sana and Aden in Yemen have been dropped, and the airline's two weekly flights to Los Angeles have also been suspended temporarily.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Statistics, a Tool for Life, Is Getting Short Shrift

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

DATELINE: BOGART, Ga. 

 BODY:
MANY educators want all high school seniors prepared for calculus. That means taking algebra in the eighth grade and covering geometry, intermediate algebra and trigonometry by the junior year. This leaves too little room for study of statistics and probability.
 Yet students need grounding in data analysis. The push for universal calculus has relied on a false belief that colleges and future jobs would demand it. Yet while calculus is important for college students who major in science and for the scientific literacy of others, only a few jobs, mostly in technical fields, actually use it. 
 Nationwide, educators who recognize this imbalance are trying to get more statistics into the math curriculum. 
One place this is happening is Malcom Bridge Middle School, about 60 miles east of Atlanta. There, Jamie Parker recently taught seventh graders to make graphs called scatterplots in which an X depicted the relationship between two aspects of body size the students had measured. The graphs showed each student's wrist and ankle circumference, or height and arm span, or length of pointer finger and longest toe.
Mrs. Parker showed the 12-year-olds how someone (at a newspaper, for example) could report data accurately but display them deceptively -- for example, by changing the scale on one side of a graph to make an apparent correlation seem less important.
Meanwhile, down the road at Oconee County High School, Steven Messig's advanced placement statistics class used a list of random numbers to select five students from each of 20 math and science classes. The 100 subjects came to Mr. Messig's room for a double-blind taste test of Pepsi and Coke. Two students poured drinks in random order. Others gave out cups, not knowing in which order they did so and then recording the taste each subject preferred.
Wouldn't it have been easier to test a few complete classes rather than randomly select from many? Kelly Blount, a senior, explained that socially similar students might take the same classes, so each room might not be representative. For example, Kelly explained, students from wealthier families tend to value education more and might take more difficult classes. If those people also tend to have common tastes in what they drink, preferences of students in some rooms might differ from those of students chosen randomly.
Later, as these students analyze their data, Kelly may learn to say a "convenience sample" could be "biased" if drawn from a homogeneous subgroup. Students may be able to explain their "confidence" in the generalizability of results from a sample of the school's 1,800 students -- what the "interval," or range of results, might be if other groups were randomly selected. Using computers and graphing calculators, Mr. Messig's students will design several ways to display their findings.
In 2006, when Mrs. Parker's seventh graders are ready for an advanced placement class in statistics, they could already know much of this math. This knowledge will be important because common debates about health, justice, economic and legal policy all assume familiarity with statistics. It is no longer possible to serve competently on some juries without more data skills than most college graduates have.
Clifford Konold, a professor at the University of Massachusetts, counted data displays in The New York Times. Dr. Konold found that in 1972 there were four graphs or tables in 10 consecutive weekday editions of The Times, excluding the sports and business sections. There were 8 in 1982 and 44 in 1992. Next year, he could find more than 100.
Interpreting these requires not only different skills from conventional mathematics, but a different way of thinking. Geometry and calculus concern proof. Statistics describe uncertainty. This change in orientation makes it hard to expand statistics instruction. Math teachers often resist placing it in the regular course of study because, despite having math degrees, they do not know how to teach statistics. Parents and counselors also balk, wanting no time taken from calculus.
Mr. Messig's elective statistics course this year enrolled only nine students. Because their statistical backgrounds are weak, Mr. Messig is taking twice the typical time to cover the material.
But his students never benefited from Mrs. Parker's middle school instruction. Her math class includes data analysis because the State of Georgia, influenced by standards of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, now tests if seventh graders are learning it. Mrs. Parker's textbook this year includes more statistics than the old one.
If the trend continues nationwide, this newspaper could someday report that an apparently alarming cluster of cancer cases has arisen in an innocuous normal distribution, and students will be able to explain to their parents what that means.

HEADLINE: What New York Will Have to Give Up 

BYLINE:  By Steven Rattner; Steven Rattner is managing principal of the Quadrangle Group, an investment firm.

 BODY:
By now, only the most inattentive New Yorker could be unaware of the multibillion-dollar budget deficit awaiting the new mayor. Add to that well-known financial worry another, less visible one: an onerous $40 billion debt load.
 The city's quick flip from surplus to deficit -- exacerbated by the economic fallout from Sept. 11 -- may deserve the headlines, but the debt load limits what the city can do to address that deficit. 
 According to the city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, New York has 50 percent more debt per resident than any other major American city and nearly double what it had a decade ago. That's not even counting another mountain of debt used to finance activities like transit and the water system. 
Most confining, 15 cents of every dollar of city tax revenue must now go to make payments on the city's debts, almost as much as the combined cost of police, fire and sanitation. According to city budget projections, that debt service figure is headed for 20 cents in 2004, a level not seen since the early 80's, when the city was emerging from its worst fiscal crisis.
In the 1990's the city's leaders seem to have believed that unending prosperity would provide the resources to absorb the costs of the borrowing. That proved to be a bad bet.
In a period of growth, when the city should have been giving itself breathing room to prepare for the inevitable rainy day, the cost of its debt was growing faster than its sources of revenue, like citizens' incomes and the market value of its taxable properties. Well before the economic downturn and the Sept. 11 attacks, New York City's debt exceeded what Standard and Poor's considers to be high by several different measures -- even though the city continues to carry A ratings.
To be fair, the money went for an important purpose -- trying to address an infrastructure still creaking from the draconian cuts of the 1970's. While New York may still seem like an old city, billions have been spent on fixing roads and bridges, building schools and water treatment plants and the like. Using debt also provided room to pare back the city's maze of suffocating taxes. All of this helped improve the city's quality of life. But even in the late 90's, when the Wall Street boom brought a windfall in tax collections, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani resisted calls from fiscal watchdogs to pay some of the infrastructure costs out of current revenue rather than by borrowing.
Today's fiscal circumstances remain less worrisome than those in the 70's, when New York was near bankruptcy. So far, at least the city is not borrowing to pay its day-to-day bills. Its accounting practices -- once a grab bag of gimmicks and obfuscations -- now get deservedly high marks for clarity. And pension funds for city workers have healthy balances.
But building the debt to its current level has involved some maneuvering. In 1997 the city reached its debt limit under the New York State Constitution; to avoid being shut out from borrowing, it got the state to agree to the creation of a new financing authority to circumvent the limit. Two years later, another new legal entity was created to allow the city to borrow against its share of proceeds from a settlement of a federal lawsuit against tobacco companies.
What to expect now? Unfortunately, even more pain than the looming budget deficit implies. Convinced that further improvements to New York's infrastructure are urgent, the Giuliani administration this year reaffirmed long-term capital planning that raises spending on pressing infrastructure needs, particularly school construction and repair. This spending would be financed largely with debt, creating obligations that would, in turn, impose imprudent burdens on the city in a weakening economy.
The temptation to go forward with the capital spending will be high, but as we search for solutions to our problems, we must be careful not to exacerbate them. Even transitional borrowing must be repaid. And clever ideas for financial engineering, like financing infrastructure projects by selling new city bonds to the pension funds of municipal unions, will just add more debt, compounding the problem of how to pay all the interest and principal.
We can get some help from refinancing debt at today's low interest rates, as well as from tough discipline on spending. Even so, the city will need federal assistance -- in the form of grants, not loans or even loan guarantees.
New York's vibrancy, unique among American cities, must be maintained. But preserving it won't avert the necessity of another period of austerity and sacrifice. And we must be careful not to saddle future generations with unsustainable burdens.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall on Unexpected Drop in Consumer Confidence

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest loss this month, after consumer confidence slid to its lowest level in seven and a half years.
 The Conference Board reported that its index of consumer confidence fell to 82.2 this month, as Americans' assessment of current conditions declined. 
 "We got blindsided by the consumer confidence number," said Michael Lyons, a trader at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "It was orderly selling after a good run," he said. 
The Dow has gained 20 percent and the Nasdaq composite index has jumped 36 percent from the post-attack lows of Sept. 21 on optimism that the economy will recover because of lower interest rates combined with the spending increases and tax cuts Congress is considering.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 110.15 points yesterday, or 1.1 percent, to 9,872.60. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 7.92 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,149.50. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.26 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,935.97.
Analysts had forecast that the consumer confidence index from the Conference Board, an economic research group, would rise this month.
"We may be entering a period of a few weeks where companies will say that their fourth-quarter profits are lousy," said Stanley Nabi, who manages $1 billion at Credit Suisse Asset Management. While benchmark indexes may fall a few percentage points in reaction, "it's not a big new down leg," he said.
Home Depot, the home-improvement retailer, declined for a second day, falling $2.17, to $43.35. It accounted for the biggest share of the Dow's loss as investors and analysts expect its chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, to lower the forecast of profit growth for next year.
Bristol-Myers Squibb fell $1.35, to $54, amid expectations that it might soon lose its bid to persuade lawmakers to extend its exclusive rights to the diabetes medicine Glucophage, prompting some analysts to cut 2002 earnings projections.
Rambus, which licenses patented memory chip technology, slid 68 cents, to $9.41. Lawyers for the German chip maker Infineon Technologies said Rambus would be barred from filing patent infringement suits against Infineon under a judge's order.
Intel gained 44 cents, to $32.31, limiting declines in the Nasdaq after the company's chief financial officer said demand for semiconductors was meeting expectations at the company, the No. 1 chip maker. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, signaled that the Fed had more room to cut interest rates.
Mr. Meyer, known as one of the Fed's hawkish members on inflation, said that holding back on monetary easing because of low rates was a "misguided strategy."
The 10-year Treasury note rose 23/32, to a price of 100 20/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.92 percent from 5.01 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32, to 100 21/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.33 percent from 5.38 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Kmart's Adjusted Loss Almost Doubles but Is Less Than Forecast 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss yesterday as it struggled to reinvent itself in a shriveling economy, and its credit rating was lowered further below investment grade.
 The loss was $224 million, or 45 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31, compared with a loss of $67 million, or 14 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 2.2 percent, to $8.02 billion. 
 Adjusted for one-time charges, the loss was $127 million, or 25 cents a share, nearly twice as large as the loss in the quarter a year earlier. On that basis, the loss was less than the 27 cents a share expected by analysts, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
Standard & Poor's lowered the company's credit rating another notch below investment grade, to BB from BB+. "We had expected to see good improvement in operations as well as in credit measures," said Mary Lou Burde, a director of corporate ratings for the agency. Kmart was last at the BB rating in March 1999, Ms. Burde said. 
Shares of Kmart, which is based in Troy, Mich., fell 47 cents yesterday, to $6.38. The shares are down 53 percent from Aug. 8, when the price reached a high of $13.55. 
The chief executive, Charles C. Conaway, who was hired in May 2000, has promised investors a turnaround. In September last year, he set a two-year timetable for himself, but many analysts think he will be hard pressed to meet that.
Mr. Conaway spent $94 million to replace two distribution centers and to install inventory software. He also added self-checkout registers in more than 1,000 stores. 
A contract with the Fleming Companies, a distributor, that makes it the sole supplier of food and other products allowed Kmart to reduce the cost of stocking food. As a result, gross profit, or sales minus the cost of goods sold, widened to 20.6 percent from 20.5 percent a year earlier.
