HEADLINE: How Secure Is Pakistan's Plutonium? 

BYLINE:  By Mansoor Ijaz and R. James Woolsey; Mansoor Ijaz, a nuclear scientist, is chairman of Crescent Investment Management in New York; his father was a pioneer in Pakistan's nuclear program. R. James Woolsey, an attorney, was director of central intelligence from 1993 to 1995.

 BODY:
A deeply disturbing picture of terrorist intent has emerged in recent weeks as blueprints for building nuclear weapons have been discovered in the wreckage of abandoned Al Qaeda safe houses. These blueprints and other documents, while largely available in the public domain, sharpen the need for a vigorous American policy to deal with unsecured nuclear, chemical and biological materials. Even if terrorist manufacture of nuclear bombs is unlikely, substantial dangers remain of terrorists using radioactive material in low-tech "dirty" bombs. 
 The main nuclear security problem posed by Al Qaeda today is access to radioactive materials in Pakistan. However, for a decade we have focused on the former Soviet Union. Since the end of the cold war, approximately 175 incidents of smuggling or attempted theft of nuclear materials there have been thwarted. But the threat remains, as the Russian Defense Ministry reported on Nov. 6, when the last attempt at theft was made. 
 For Russia, a sensible solution is available -- the Nunn-Lugar "cooperative threat reduction" program to improve the security of Russia's nuclear materials, technology and expertise. This week, the House Republican leadership will decide whether to finance the next phase. The program is only 40 percent complete; finishing it will take another quarter of a century at the current rate of funding. It is past time to fully implement and finance this important legislation.
The Nunn-Lugar initiative can serve as a valuable precedent in addressing security problems in Pakistan. Neither Pakistan nor India has signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty or the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. Nor has either country engaged in negotiations, under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Disarmament, to protect against theft of fissile materials. This reluctance in India and Pakistan to recognize international norms, however, should not alter our resolve to improve the security of nuclear materials in South Asia.
While Islamabad is widely believed to have the material for 25 to 40 medium-yield bombs, most of its nuclear devices are kept in component parts, not as assembled warheads. The storage procedures, quite elaborate prior to Sept. 11, were altered again on Oct. 7 when the American bombing of Afghanistan began. Separately stored uranium and plutonium cores and their detonation assemblies were moved to six new secret locations around the country.
The new storage patterns were designed to allow for rapid assembly and deployment, but attackers will nonetheless find it much more difficult to confiscate Pakistan's nuclear weapons. Even if Al Qaeda obtained radioactive materials from a sympathizer at one of Pakistan's plants for making weapons-grade nuclear materials, as some reports have suggested, the material would still have to be shaped into a fissionable core with detonation switches and delivery housings.
Such a complex effort would be difficult to carry out in an Afghan cave. But we can hardly count on terrorists always being under bombardment in caves.
Pakistan's nuclear command hierarchy, overhauled in 2000, was also revamped on Oct. 7 in the wake of a broad military-intelligence shake-up. Pakistan's president and army chief, Pervez Musharraf, created the strategic planning division and appointed a moderate general, Khalid Kidwai, to oversee Pakistani nuclear assets.
Self-policing, however, is not enough. Since 1990, American sanctions have blocked sale or transfer of any technology that might have a military use -- including technologies that would improve nuclear security. American export license controls -- and, where necessary, Non-Proliferation Treaty and Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty compliance rules preventing United States exports -- should be waived to transfer the technology needed to protect Pakistan's nuclear arsenals and materials from unauthorized use.
The Bush administration should make available American vaults, sensors, alarms, tamper-proof seals, closed-circuit cameras and labels to identify, track and secure Islamabad's nuclear materials.
Such precautions would dramatically reduce the probability that even the most devoted bin Laden supporter inside a Pakistani nuclear enrichment facility would get very far in trying to deliver stolen uranium or plutonium to terrorists.
There is a real risk that Pakistan's fanatics might collaborate with Al Qaeda; the plans, recently discovered in Kabul, for a helium balloon armed with anthrax have been attributed to a Pakistani nuclear scientist turned Taliban philanthropist. But the risk is manageable if we can help the Musharraf government focus on this threat, as Russia has done in the Nunn-Lugar cooperative threat reduction program.
Unless we follow such a course, we face the very real possibility of terrorist militias obtaining not just blueprints but the materials to fashion and detonate weapons of mass destruction. We also risk sharpening the debate in Pakistani military and political circles about whether its nuclear expertise should be shared with other Muslim countries. It is hard to think of two developments that are less in our interest.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Jobs Lost, Found and Lost, But a Life Still to Be Led

BYLINE:  By VINCENT M. MALLOZZI 

 BODY:
David Johnson's Sunday morning routine was two-thirds complete. he had already phoned his two daughters to say "I love you," and he had already delivered an I-love-you in person to his mother, who lives near his South Bronx apartment. "And now," Mr. Johnson said, his fingers dancing in anticipation on his computer keyboard as he spoke, "it's time for The Times." Reaching beneath his keyboard for the classified section of The New York Times, Mr. Johnson began the third phase of his routine: looking for a job. As he held the section in his hands, Mr. Johnson's eyebrows went north. He lifted it into the air, then bounced it lightly as if he were weighing it on an imaginary scale. 
 "It's so light this week, there really aren't that many pages," Mr. Johnson said, a short smile running away from his face. 
 "I'd like to think that the people who post these jobs were all away for Thanksgiving," he said, "but I'm sure that the reality has more to do with the shape of the economy."
Mr. Johnson, 33, has been working at temporary jobs and looking for steady work since February of last year, when budget restrictions forced him out of a permanent job at the United Nations. He had worked there for three years as a video-imaging operator, processing passports for United Nations employees who traveled abroad.
Since he lost that job, Mr. Johnson has lost a lot more.
"I broke up with Lynette in May of last year," said Mr. Johnson, referring to his wife and childhood sweetheart, with whom he has been involved for the past 17 years. "And my house is a lot lonelier without my two little girls."
Separated but not divorced, Mr. Johnson still sees his daughters every day, but getting there is a little more difficult than it used to be. What was once a five-minute car ride to visit his girls -- Lyndaiza, 9, and Lyndae, 1, who live with their mother and maternal grandmother a few neighborhoods away -- has become at least a half-hour walk. 
"My 1987 Maxima is still in my mother's driveway," Mr. Johnson said. "When it broke down, I just couldn't afford to get it fixed."
By the time his car broke down in August, so had Mr. Johnson's financial state. His credit cards were canceled, and he had fallen two months behind in his rent. Though he had been getting an unemployment check of $353 each week since May, it was not enough to cover his bills.
"I was just juggling money, trying to pay one bill here and one bill there," he said. "I was doing the best I could, but then everything just sort of collapsed on me."
Mr. Johnson reached out to the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of the seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
The agency wrote Mr. Johnson's landlord a check for $998.27, which covered the rent for July and August. "It really helped," Mr. Johnson said. "It gave me a little chance to regroup."
In July, Mr. Johnson had taken a temporary job as a word processor for a law firm on the 89th floor of 1 World Trade Center. He had hoped the job would become permanent. Fortunately for him, that job ended before Sept. 11. 
"Eight morning people I knew, people who were 8:30 on-the-dotters," said Mr. Johnson, his voice trailing off into a whisper, "are all dead." And when Mr. Johnson realized he would lose his job at the United Nations, he applied for another one there that he really wanted -- to be part of an observation mission in Georgia, the former Soviet Republic. But shortly before that mission got under way, Mr. Johnson was informed that he lost out to another candidate. 
As it turned out, two members of that mission were kidnapped by armed men. (Marie Okabe, a United Nations spokeswoman, said this week that the two men were eventually released unharmed.) 
"With all the hard luck I've had, I look back at those two potential jobs and realize how lucky I was not to get either one of them," said Mr. Johnson, who was sending resumes out by e-mail as he spoke. "It makes you wonder if in this lifetime, God really does have a special plan for each and every one of us."

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
Private charters, although languishing this year, are expected to fill a future air travel niche.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AIR fares dropped 19.2 percent last month compared with October 2000, according to the Air Transport Association's Office of Economics.
 Cheaper fares didn't put more customers in the seats, though. Domestic passenger traffic was off 22 percent, and the number of people flying internationally on domestic airlines fell 31 percent in October, the airline trade association said. 
 Yet this sharp numerical drop in passengers occurred on an air transportation system that has about 20 percent fewer seats available than it did just a few months ago. "The airlines have basically taken a meat ax to capacity," said Jim Altschul, the president of Aviation Advisory Services, an airline financial consulting firm. 
So it's probably not the best of times to be laying down any heavy bets on any segment of the air travel market. Still, some industry experts are looking a bit farther down the road than this year or next and seeing signs of what could be a fundamental shift in business travel, which has long been the most profitable market for commercial airlines.
Here's one speculative observation worth considering, from Michael Dyment, a partner in Andersen, the financial consulting firm: "In my view, 10 years from now business travelers, generally speaking, are not going to be flying commercial. There will be alternatives that will be much more cost-effective," he said in a recent interview.
Mr. Dyment predicts that significant numbers of business travelers are eventually going to end up on private aircraft. They'll be transported on planes owned in whole or in part by their companies, or on charter flights, including some on fixed schedules, he said.
The reason, he said, is pure economics, underscored by a sharper front-office appreciation of efficient mobility and good employee morale as important components of shareholder value.
"One of the things we were working on prior to Sept. 11 was the issue of business-traveler productivity and the sort of anger that was becoming a real groundswell in corporate America" over deteriorating commercial airline service that routinely sentenced increasingly frustrated business travelers to spend many wasted hours getting to, and getting out of, airports.
"This had become utterly deleterious for business travelers," Mr. Dyment said. Since delays and frustrations began mounting in 1999 and 2000, he added, "people have been looking for alternatives."
"And they still are," he continued. "That's why this business aviation boom we've been seeing in recent years is not just a blip on the radar screen."
Currently, with the aviation system still reeling from the terrorist attacks, there are no firm data supporting any idea of an imminent major shift in the way people travel.
For example, recent surveys suggest that business travel has rebounded to near-normal levels, while leisure travel remains sharply off. But it's more difficult to identify the business travel dollar these days, because earlier this year corporations angry about high fares began sending many corporate travelers out on the less convenient, lower-fare advance-purchase tickets typically used by leisure travelers.
In recent years, the corporate jet industry grew about 30 percent annually, spurred by the increasing popularity of programs that allow corporations to buy fractional shares in private jets.
The airlines have been paying attention to that. Earlier this year, UAL, the corporate parent of United Airlines, set up a subsidiary called Avolar that plans to market private jets through fractional leases and also to operate charter and shuttle services for corporate and private clients. In a sign of the vitality of that market, Avolar, which plans to begin flight operations next year, announced last week an agreement with Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft manufacturer, to add 15 high-end, large-cabin Airbus Corporate Jetliner models to its fleet.
And Air Charter Guide, the publisher of a major directory for the air-charter industry, did a survey in late October that found charter bookings were up significantly among many operators after Sept. 11.
Jet Aviation Inc., a private-aviation services company that also describes itself as the largest supplier of charter flights in the United States, expects eventually to see a bigger shift to charter flights and other uses of corporate aircraft, once the terrorism emergency and the current recession wane.
"Are we seeing it right now? No," said Jamie Barrett, the senior vice president for charter services. "After the events of Sept. 11, we saw a spike in demand" partly attributable to getting stranded travelers back home, he said. "We had a quick boost there for about a 10-day or a two-week period." But Jet Aviation's charter business will probably be off 30 percent this year, he said.
"The unknown quantity is what the airlines are going to do" after the holidays, he said. "How much more are they going to trim to try to get to profitable levels?"
Along with regional carriers, the charter industry expects to be able to "take up the slack" if, as expected, money-losing airlines eliminate more routes and services even after robust travel resumes, Mr. Barrett said, adding that charters can offer prices that compete with premium airline fares.
"You take a corporate business jet and put 8 to 10 people in the airplane and, depending on the route structure, and it gets very, very close" to the cost of a first-class ticket on a commercial flight, and with better scheduling efficiency and fewer security problems, he said.
However the system finally shakes out, Mr. Dyment of Andersen says that the new era in air transport will have to be considerably different from the old one, where many business travelers were in open revolt in their companies about the travails of the air over the last two years.
At Andersen, "we have 85,000 people and on any given day in the U.S. and Canada, we have between 2,000 and 3,000 people on airlines," he said. "That's a large number of people. So we been examining very closely the productivity problems of our travelers."
Before the economy tightened up, Andersen, like other companies that do a lot of travel, found that "the No. 1 or No. 2 reason" that valued executives who left the firm cited for their departure "was always the travel, how terrible it was, and how nonproductive and frustrating."
He added, "Business travel is going to continue to grow in leaps and bounds" in years ahead. As companies assess future travel, "I think there's already a large new movement toward business aviation, though it's not public because companies aren't flaunting it now."

HEADLINE: Aquarium Bonds Worth 25 Cents on Dollar 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MARINELAND, Fla., Nov. 27 

 BODY:
Bondholders in the oceanside aquarium in Marineland, Florida's smallest town, are getting 25 cents on the dollar for their investment. 
 The Marineland Foundation Inc., a nonprofit corporation that the City of Marineland set up in 1996 to buy the vintage-1937 attraction, began paying investors $245 for every $1,000 invested on Nov. 9, according to a letter sent to investors this week by the bond trustee, the State Street Bank and Trust Company. 
 The Florida tourist attraction was refurbished with the proceeds of an unrated high-yield municipal bond. Sold during the 1990's to build everything from recycling operations to racetracks and theme parks, so-called economic development bonds have defaulted at a rate of more than 15 percent, compared with a rate of less than 1 percent for traditional municipal bonds, according to a study by Fitch Investors Service. 
The $9.7 million Marineland bonds were first sold in 1995 at yields of 8 1/2 percent in minimum denominations of $100,000. 
The feasibility study attached to the bond issue said that Marineland needed 150,000 visitors a year to break even. In 1997, the park brought in 118,000, and the prices of the bonds began their long slide. 
The agreement reached among bondholders, the bond trustee and Marine Park of Flagler, a company owned by the Atlanta real estate developer James F. Jacoby, allowed the park to stay open.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Fire Could Not Stop A Mill, but Debts May

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
It is another unhappy holiday season for Aaron M. Feuerstein, the widely admired New England mill owner whose textile company, Malden Mills, is again in crisis.
 After a December fire six years ago ravaged much of his factory in Lawrence, Mass., Mr. Feuerstein won plaudits for rebuilding the mill from top to bottom and for paying his idled workers for months. By the time the new factory -- which makes Polartec and Polarfleece, the warm, synthetic fabrics popular in outdoor clothing -- reopened nearly two years later, he had rehired most of his 2,700 employees. In an era of widespread corporate downsizing, his actions made Mr. Feuerstein a national icon of corporate sensitivity. 
 Now the private company, founded by Mr. Feuerstein's grandfather in 1906, is mired in debt and facing bankruptcy amid questions about whether Mr. Feuerstein's past benevolence helped bring the company to its present precarious state. 
"It may have been that the desire to take a principled action somehow blinded him to thinking long term," said Barbara Lee Toffler, an adjunct professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business and an expert on corporate responsibility.
Mr. Feuerstein could have retired with around $300 million in insurance payouts after the fire in 1995 or moved his company to a source of cheaper labor in the South or in Mexico.
But Malden Mills is the largest employer in one of Massachusetts' poorest towns, and instead he chose to spend a total of $430 million to build a gleaming updated textile mill next to the fire-damaged site. When the factory reopened, President Bill Clinton hailed Mr. Feuerstein as a model corporate citizen. Newspapers, magazines and television programs sang his praises.
Mr. Feuerstein, who owns Malden Mills with several other members of his family, also spent nearly $25 million paying tide-me-over salaries to idled workers. That is the size of an emergency loan he is now seeking.
"It is kind of ironic," Mr. Feuerstein said.
Malden Mills has debts of $140 million, held by nine lenders, including GE Capital, the financing arm of General Electric. The lenders are asking Malden Mills to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy before they will provide an emergency loan to pay salaries and finance operations in coming months.
A Chapter 11 filing would not necessarily be the death knell for Malden Mills, which went through bankruptcy proceedings in the early 1980's. But it would nonetheless be a savage blow to Mr. Feuerstein, 75, who as president and chief executive, is hoping that support from state politicians and the local community will help him rescue the company.
In the light of Malden's current distress, some are asking whether Mr. Feuerstein's moves after the fire made good business sense.
The rebuilding included reconstruction of a furniture upholstery unit which accounted for half the company's $400 million in revenue in 1995, the year of the fire, and employed 1,500 people. But impatient upholstery customers bolted to other suppliers and never came back. The upholstery unit was later closed, cutting the company's revenue sharply and forcing layoffs anyway. Malden Mills now employs around 1,200 workers, and takes on several hundred more during its peak manufacturing season in the spring.
There were other missteps. As Mr. Feuerstein focused on bringing workers back into the new plant, he and his top managers neglected the threat of inexpensive fleece imported from Asia and elsewhere that generally sells for only about half as much as Malden's products. "We weren't creative and aggressive enough," Mr. Feuerstein said.
An ill-timed reshuffling of the marketing team in late 2000 came too late in the season to promote the company's new electric fabrics, in which heatable wires, powered by batteries, are embedded in fleece.
Some experts contend, however, Mr. Feuerstein's humanitarianism may ultimately prove far-sighted.
"There was a lot of business savvy to his decision" to rebuild and pay idled workers, said David Weil, a professor at Boston University's School of Management and an investigator at Harvard's Center for Textile and Apparel Research.
Professor Weil said that Mr. Feuerstein's employees were highly skilled producers of top-quality products and would not have been easy to replace had they been permanently laid off. He said that Malden Mills' problems -- a weak economy and stiff competition in the textile industry -- were unrelated to Mr. Feuerstein's deep-pocketed spending.
The company also faces a downturn in the British market, where foot-and-mouth disease has stalled purchases of fleece outerwear for hiking in rural areas. Malden Mills sells about a third of its fleece to British and European suppliers.
Financially, Malden Mills is suffering. Its revenue for fiscal 2001, ended Oct. 30, was about $180 million, flat compared with the previous year and far below the $400 million of 1995. More serious, its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- a crucial measure of profitability -- plunged to nearly zero this year from $35 million in the previous fiscal year. Mr. Feuerstein declined to state net profits or losses. In 1995, the company earned about $30 million.
Much-loved Malden Mills has plenty of admirers. Local residents have organized a Web-based "Buy Fleece" campaign to support the company's customers, which include Patagonia, Lands' End, L. L. Bean and the United States military, whose Special Forces soldiers in Afghanistan wear fleece jackets.
Townspeople recently sent in checks, some as small as $10, as a token of support, said David Costello, a spokesman for Malden Mills. Senators Edward M. Kennedy and John Kerry, Democrats of Massachusetts, have lobbied G.E. in recent weeks not to force a Chapter 11 filing.
GE Capital holds about one-quarter of Malden Mills' total debt, including a chunk of $30 million in subordinate debt, Mr. Feuerstein said. In addition to GE Capital, the creditors include SAI Investment of Los Angeles; Firstar of Milwaukee; Finova Capital and Pilgrim Investments, both in Scottsdale, Ariz.; LaSalle Bank of Chicago; PNC Bank of Pittsburgh; and Van Kampen Investments of Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.
Peter S. Stack, a spokesman for GE Capital, declined to comment on Malden Mills.
Mr. Feuerstein, who speaks in dramatic tones, says he has no regrets about his past actions -- and no doubts about his factory's future. "There are times in business when you don't think of the financial consequences but of the human consequences," said Mr. Feuerstein, whose determination recently earned him the nickname "Old Aaronsides" in the local newspaper. "There is no doubt that this company will survive."
Malden Mills, he said, is moving into fast-growing markets for specialty products like electric fleece blankets and clothing for hunting and golfing. 
But survival under bankruptcy would undoubtedly mean that its finances, not its employees, come first. "When you are on the verge of bankruptcy, you have first duties to your creditors, and you lose a lot of freedom to act," said Ira Millstein, a professor at Yale University's School of Management.
Mr. Feuerstein may already have lost some leeway. On the advice of GE Capital, he recently installed an executive from Zolfo Cooper, a management consulting firm, as acting chief operating officer. The executive, Frank Budetti, declined to make himself available for comment, but he has been the principal negotiator for Malden Mills in its talks with its creditors, which began last month. The previous chief operating officer, Gerald Bowe, was sent to Gorlitz, Germany, to run a small Malden Mills factory there.
A test of whether Mr. Feuerstein's big heart will prove a financial boon is coming now, as 900 mill workers who are union members negotiate a new labor contract. The current three-year agreement is due to expire on Nov. 30, and Mr. Feuerstein said he had asked employees "to find ways to make materially significant contributions" to Malden.
Joseph Melo, who heads the mill's chapter of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, declined to comment on what sacrifices union members might make. But Ginette Gauvin, 48, who has worked at the mill for 24 years, said Mr. Feuerstein had asked employees not to bargain for a raise and to pay higher health insurance premiums.
"We're ready to make sacrifices for a little while," Ms. Gauvin said. "Whatever he asks us to do to keep the place going."

HEADLINE: Fed Official Backs Aggressive Rate Cuts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
An influential member of the Federal Reserve said today that it should not shy away from continuing to ease monetary policy aggressively just because its benchmark interest rate is beginning to approach zero.
 Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor whose expertise in economic forecasting often helps shape the debate within the central bank, said the economy should "gradually strengthen" next year, and he did not say whether the Fed would cut rates for an 11th time this year at its next scheduled meeting on Dec. 11. 
 But Mr. Meyer said it would be a mistake to rule out further rate cuts in an effort to preserve the flexibility to reduce rates should the economy not recover or encounter an unexpected shock like another terrorist attack. Among other things, he said, the Fed had to keep in mind the possibility of deflation, or a general decline in prices, a development that would require rapid rate reductions. 
Speaking to the National Association of Business Economics in St. Louis, Mr. Meyer said the Fed's aggressive campaign of interest rate cuts this year had not rippled through the economy and the financial markets as much as traditional economic theory would have predicted. As a result, he said, the Fed had been forced to cut rates more deeply than past experience would have suggested was necessary.
Mr. Meyer also said the outlook for a quick recovery would be tempered somewhat if Congress and the Bush administration cannot agree on a fiscal stimulus package in coming weeks. The long-term forecast, he said, was being dimmed a bit by the likelihood that federal budget surpluses would be smaller than previously projected, a development likely to push up interest rates. 
The Fed has already cut its benchmark federal funds target rate 10 times this year, by a total of 4.5 percentage points, leaving it at a 40-year low of 2 percent. Some economists have expressed concern that further rate cuts in coming months could lead the Fed to shoot off the last of its ammunition before the recession has run its course, leaving the central bank largely powerless should the downturn prove to be longer or deeper than anticipated.
"Does this mean the Fed should 'keep its powder dry,' as some have argued, holding back on further easing in case the downturn turns out to be more serious or in case there are additional adverse shocks?" Mr. Meyer said. "I believe such a strategy would be misguided -- indeed the reverse of what would be appropriate."
The issue has been of concern to economists because of the experience of Japan, which has pushed official short-term rates almost to zero, and now has few monetary policy tools to battle its stubborn, decade-long economic downturn.
Mr. Meyer, who has said he will not seek reappointment to his Fed seat when his term expires in January, said the right strategy for the Fed would be to continue moving quickly to cut rates if the economy required it, "substituting speed of the move for the cumulative size of the easing."
As one of the Fed's most aggressive inflation fighters, Mr. Meyer has never been known for advocating rapid-fire rate cuts. But he said the central bank had to keep in mind the possibility that inflation might drift lower, or even turn to deflation, making it harder for the Fed to push the "real" federal funds rate -- the nominal rate minus the inflation rate -- into negative territory. The Fed typically seeks a negative real fed funds rate in trying to nurse the economy out of recession.
"In the worst case, as in Japan today, inflation might turn to deflation, limiting the ability to lower the real policy rate even to zero," he said.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Drops, but Housing Sales Rise 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence unexpectedly slumped this month, but housing was a surprise bright spot in the economy in October, reports showed today.
 The Conference Board reported that its index of consumer confidence fell to 82.2 this month from 85.3 in October as Americans' assessment of current conditions declined. It was the lowest level in seven and a half years. 
 In housing, sales of existing homes surged a larger-than-expected 5.5 percent in October, to an annual pace of 5.17 million units from a 4.9 million rate in September, the National Association of Realtors said.
Brian Bruce, who manages $4 billion as director of global investments at PanAgora Asset Management in Boston, struck a somewhat optimistic note, noting that home and auto sales are up. "Consumers are most glum before the economy turns around," he said. "Things aren't as bad as the consumer confidence index suggests."
Moreover, consumer expectations for the next six months rose, the Conference Board reported. Retailers like Kmart said sales improved last week. And the 30-year mortgage rate is close to a record low. That is setting the stage for a gradual rebound from the first recession in a decade.
Federal Reserve policy makers "expect the recovery to improve next year, although the timing is uncertain," Michael Moskow, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said today. "Confidence will be an important factor."
Measures of sentiment have been mixed. The Conference Board's index of current conditions fell to 93.5, in November from 107.2. The index measuring consumers' six-month outlook rose to 74.6, from 70.7.
Most economists were surprised in the decline in the overall index. They had expected an increase to 86.5.
Home sales have been supported by falling mortgage rates. The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage has stayed below 7 percent for three months, the longest stretch on record below that level.
The 30-year rate fell to a record 6.45 percent this month, according to Freddie Mac, which buys mortgages. The average principal and interest payment on a $100,000 mortgage at that rate would be $628.78 a month. That compared with an average $778.86 in May 2000. 
The National Association of Realtors said it expected 5.19 million existing homes would be sold this year, second only to 1999, when 5.21 million homes were sold.

HEADLINE: Census Said to Misplace Many Prisons and Dorms 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
There are two basic mistakes you can make in a census: You can miscount people, and you can put them in the wrong place.
 The Census Bureau appears to have done the counting part pretty well in 2000. But the putting-them-in-the-right-place part, some demographers say, is something else again. 
 Across the country, demographers and planners say the Census Bureau appears to have misplaced entire populations of dozens of prisons and college dormitories. They say the bureau inexplicably removed those populations from census tracts or blocks where the facilities had sat for decades, and deposited them somewhere else. 
In New York State, for example, 2,192 inmates at Green Haven Correctional Facility, a maximum-security prison in the town of Beekman, landed mysteriously in Milan, a smaller town some 27 miles to the north, said Warren A. Brown, a professor of sociology at Cornell University.
In California, the inmates of Pelican Bay State Prison in Crescent City turned up outside the city limits, the city manager said. The city discovered the problem, he said, when a quarterly payment it receives from the state plummeted because the 2000 census showed the city's population had shrunk.
In Minnesota, the inhabitants of the Federal Correctional Institution in Sandstone turned up down the road "in a tract that should have almost no one in it," said Tom Gillaspy, the state demographer. And the tract that houses a state prison in St. Cloud was listed as having no population at all, he said.
"I think this is the tip of the iceberg," said Robert Scardamalia, chief demographer for the New York Department of Economic Development. "I think if they did a nationwide analysis, they'd find an unacceptably high number of errors. That's my speculation."
"The supreme irony," said Professor Brown, "is the census did a really good job on the hard-to-count population this time around. And they fumbled the ball on the easy-to-count. What could be easier than counting somebody in a prison?"
Census Bureau officials say any problems are few and relatively insignificant. They note that the bureau did not miss the people; it simply placed some on the wrong side of the street, for example. One official, Preston Jay Waite, said the number of these complaints from communities -- 85 so far -- was no surprise.
"All I'm saying is I'm not shocked at the level of appeals," Mr. Waite, the bureau's associate director for the decennial census, said of the official challenges filed with the bureau concerning prison and other institutional populations. "If anything, I'm surprised that it's not higher than it is. But it's still early."
The population in question is the so-called group-quarters population, the 7.778 million people who were living in prisons, dormitories and similar facilities at the time the census was taken. The bureau counts people in group quarters separately from the rest of the population.
When in March the bureau began releasing data from the 2000 census, planners started noticing unexpected shifts in the population counts in a number of places. When they looked to see what might explain surprise increases or drops, some began to suspect problems in the allocation of group quarters.
Lindsay Carille, a junior planner for the Department of Planning and Development in Dutchess County, N.Y., said the official count for one census block in the town of Milan had leaped implausibly to more than 2,000, from zero in 1990. She and others say they believe the Green Haven prison population ended up there.
In Ithaca, N.Y., where Cornell University and Ithaca College have dormitories, the population count for one census block jumped to 5,882, from only 110 in 1990, said Thomas Mank of the Tompkins County Planning Department. The count for another block, he said, dropped to 2 from 1,100.
In Crescent City, Calif., David Wells, the city manager, said the city's quarterly allocation of state revenue shrunk after the 2000 census. With the Pelican Bay prison population misplaced, he said, the city's official population count was down. So the city was supposedly entitled to less state money. It took special state legislation to restore the full sum, he said.
"A number of federal and state formulas are based on total population," said Mr. Gillaspy, the Minnesota demographer. "So when you have 500 or 1,000 people who are misallocated, it's a fairly substantial issue. For the nation as a whole, it might not be that big of a deal. But for that community, it's a huge issue."
It is unclear how many such problems exist. Since July 1, when it began accepting challenges under its new "count question resolution" program, the Census Bureau has received 161 challenges, Mr. Waite said. Eighty-five involve group quarters, and nearly all have yet to be processed.
In New York, Mr. Scardamalia, the state demographer there, said there were so many questions about the counts that he and others had begun looking more closely. Randomly examining areas with colleges and prisons, he said, they quickly found several dozen anomalies, including "what appeared to be some pretty gross errors."
Concerned, he asked the bureau to delay the release of other census data scheduled to be made public, a suggestion the bureau did not follow. He said the bureau should plan to correct and reissue not just the population counts but related data on race, age and the like. 
Mr. Waite, the Census Bureau official, said the bureau would investigate every challenge. If a population was misplaced, the agency will correct the counts and notify the communities in writing, he said. Those letters, he said, can be shown to other government agencies as proof of the corrected counts.
But he said the bureau did not have the resources to change all the other census data attached to those population numbers -- the data on age, race, household composition, income and so on. "The only thing we will send back is that 47 people were added," he said. "We will not show them detailed characteristics about those people."
As for how mistakes might have occurred, he said agencies might have given the bureau incorrect addresses -- the address of an administrative office, say, rather than that of a particular institution. Or census workers may have failed to go out and verify the address, or may have made clerical errors.
"The unfortunate aspect of it is that it does raise a lot of quality issues," Mr. Gillaspy said. "Rightly or wrongly, it's not a confidence builder. It sort of lowers your confidence in the whole thing. And that's sad. Because a great deal of effort went into the rest of the census."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RECOVERY PACKAGE; 
$38 Billion Tax Hiatus Proposed

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
Republicans in the Senate said today that they would support a new idea for giving the economy an immediate boost -- freeing employers and employees from paying Social Security payroll taxes for one month -- in an effort to break a partisan impasse over the proposed economic stimulus package.
 The plan would amount to a tax cut, split evenly between workers and employers, worth $38 billion if it were enacted in December, or about $43 billion if put in place early next year. For a worker earning $40,000 a year, the payroll tax holiday would mean an extra $207. The worker's employer would save the same amount. 
 Republicans put the plan forward as part of a revised package of tax cuts to help the economy recover from the first recession in a decade. The new package would cut taxes by about $100 billion in 2002.
It includes an immediate reduction in the current 27 percent personal income tax rate to 25 percent, a reduction that under current law would not happen until 2006. It would also provide tax breaks for business, a 13-week extension of unemployment benefits beyond the current 26-week limit and $5 billion that states could use for assistance programs, like helping laid-off workers get health insurance.
Democrats said they were open to the payroll tax holiday, which was first proposed by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico. But they insisted they would not negotiate a deal until Republicans agreed to consider additional spending for domestic security needs, like bioterrorism readiness, in conjunction with the proposed tax cuts.
"That's something that we would certainly be willing to consider, but again, not at the expense of giving up all of our commitment to homeland security," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader.
The two parties have been deadlocked over the economic recovery bill for weeks. Mr. Daschle and other Congressional leaders are expected to discuss the issue with President Bush over breakfast at the White House on Wednesday morning. 
But neither side has shown much inclination to budge from its basic principles. For Republicans, that means a bill primarily composed of tax cuts. For Democrats, it means that most of the help go to laid-off workers and low-income people and that the package be considered alongside their plan for additional spending on security.
In the package put forward by Senate Republicans today, the payroll tax holiday would replace an idea that both parties had agreed on, sending $300-per-person checks to low-income workers who had not qualified for the rebate checks sent out this summer under the tax cut Mr. Bush signed into law in June.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Lead Bidder for Red Sox Has The Times as Investor

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
One of the most intriguing sales of a team in baseball history is scheduled to reach its climax Thursday when prospective buyers submit their final bids for a majority interest in the Boston Red Sox.
 Not even the Red Sox can be sure how many bids they will receive, but half a dozen or so potential buyers have either identified themselves or been identified by others. A potential sale price of $350 million to $400 million has been widely talked about. If the price reaches that level, it will be the highest paid for a baseball team. Larry Dolan bought the Cleveland Indians for $323 million in February 2000. 
 The leading contender for the 53 percent that is owned by the Jean R. Yawkey Trust is a group that is headed by Tom Werner, former managing owner of the San Diego Padres, and includes, as a minority investor, The New York Times Company, owner of The Boston Globe as well as The Times.
Although the outcome could depend on the bids, especially if one bid is significantly higher than the others, the Werner group is considered the leading contender because of the people who are in it, many of whom are held in high regard by Commissioner Bud Selig and other baseball officials and owners.
First is Werner himself. He was close to Selig when he operated the Padres. Werner is joined by, among others, George Mitchell, the former United States senator from Maine, who was a member of the blue ribbon panel that Selig named to study the game's economics, and Larry Lucchino, former president of the Padres (not under Werner) and the Baltimore Orioles.
Lucchino, who left the Padres earlier this year, has been working with Selig on various economic matters and has developed a close working relationship with him. If the group is the successful bidder, Lucchino will be the Red Sox president.
According to a person close to the group, it also hopes to add John Henry, owner of the Florida Marlins. Henry has been negotiating to sell the Marlins to Jeffrey Loria, who owns the Montreal Expos, one of the two teams expected to be eliminated under baseball's contraction plan, whenever that happens.
Some reports have said that Henry has completed a deal with Loria, but Selig said today, "Mr. Henry does not have a buyer for his team." Henry would not be permitted to join a group bidding for the Red Sox as long as he owns the Marlins, although he did not sell his 1 percent share of the Yankees before buying the Marlins.
Others that may submit final bids are a Boston group that includes Joe O'Donnell, a Boston concessionaire, and Steve Karp, a mall developer; Charles Dolan of Cablevision, whose brother owns the Cleveland Indians; Frank McCourt, a South Boston waterfront land owner; Miles Prentice, a New York lawyer, who made an unsuccessful bid to buy the Kansas City Royals; and two concessions companies, Delaware North and the Aramark Corporation.
The Times Company's share in the Werner group is subject to final negotiations and acceptance of the group's bid, said Janet L. Robinson, the company's senior vice president for newspaper operations. "Neither The Globe nor The New York Times Company will be involved in operating the ball club," she said today.
Asked if even minority ownership of the Red Sox would represent a conflict of interest, Robinson said: "This minority investment would present a conflict of interest only if Globe or Times reporters and editors were required or encouraged to give the team favored treatment. This will not be the case."
The Times would not be the first newspaper company to be an owner of a baseball team. For example, The Tribune Company owns the Chicago Cubs. 
Robinson said the investment in the Red Sox was also attractive to the Times Company because it includes the New England sports cable network, which the Red Sox own. 
"This investment bid is being made as part of The Boston Globe's long-term strategic plan to solidify its position as the leading news and advertising media in New England," she said. "This investment in the Red Sox franchise, and specifically the New England Sports Network, would allow us to bring Boston Globe journalism from print to television by creating and producing Globe-branded sports programming. 
"The New England Sports Network would enable The Globe to extend its nationally recognized sports reporting franchise to the television medium, as well as allow it to better serve advertisers with combined print, television and Internet advertising sales."
The Times Company, Robinson added, also likes the plan the Werner group has for preserving Fenway Park as the Red Sox' home. The team, she noted, was once owned by Gen. Charles Taylor, whose son built Fenway Park in 1912. The Taylor family also once owned The Globe.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
Fordham's Hill Says He Is Feeling Well

BYLINE:  By RAFAEL HERMOSO

 BODY:
When Coach BOB HILL missed Fordham's first game, the university announced that he was having minor surgery. He has not missed either of the Rams' games since, but Hill announced yesterday that the surgery was anything but small.
 On Nov. 12, the night Fordham opened at DePaul, Hill had a melanoma removed from his back, a mole that doctors discovered was malignant. Hill pronounced himself cancer-free yesterday, saying he was not receiving any further treatment and that the only complication arose when the incision opened after stitches were removed. 
 "It was scary for a few days," Hill said. "It's under control. Everything is clear. It's slowed me a little bit, not a lot."
 Fordham (1-2) plays at Iona tonight and against St. John's on Saturday at Madison Square Garden in the second game of the inaugural Marty Glickman Classic. The doubleheader begins with Hofstra against Iona at noon.

FIGHT FOR THE GARDEN
 One of Bob Hill's goals has been to make Fordham a regular at the Garden. To that end, Fordham plays four games there this season, including Saturday's game against St. John's. Hill wanted to play three Atlantic-10 games at the Garden.
 "There's a problem with it right now," Hill said of the Garden. "They said St. John's doesn't want us to be part of doubleheaders. I don't really know."
 JOEL FISHER, the Garden's senior vice president for sports properties, said difficulties in scheduling, not St. John's resistance, prevented Fordham from playing more games at the Garden. Fisher notes that Fordham plays in next month's Holiday Festival with Manhattan, Iona and Seton Hall but not with St. John's.
 "It doesn't only have to be with St. John's," Fisher said, before adding, "There's no question St. John's is our main college basketball talent and we want to do everything possible to keep them happy."
 St. John's Athletic Director DAVE WEGRZYN said he had not asked not to be matched with Fordham, and that Big East rules affect when St. John's plays.

ST. JOHN'S
 St. John's returned from a long, dark and cold trip to Alaska with a 2-1 record in the Great Alaska Shootout in Anchorage and a new point guard. Coach MIKE JARVIS's experiment with the junior-college transfer MARCUS HATTEN at point guard appears over, for now. Jarvis started the freshman TRISTAN SMITH at the point in the team's third game in Alaska, against Tennessee, moving Hatten back to his natural shooting-guard position.
 The result was impressive. Smith had 9 points and 3 assists, and Hatten had 21 points, 7 assists and 8 steals as St. John's defeated the Volunteers, 69-55. The Red Storm (3-1) led by as many as 21 points in the first half. St. John's had lost to Gonzaga and then beaten Oregon State in the tournament.

SETON HALL
 Seton Hall (2-2) returned from Hawaii after producing one of the most talked-about performances of the early season. The Pirates led No. 1 Duke for much of their game last week before losing, 80-79, in the Maui Classic. Seton Hall followed that with a victory over Chaminade and a loss to Kansas, which had been upset by Ball State and was ranked No. 4. Some were not surprised by the Pirates' performance.
 "I thought they completely outplayed Duke, and Duke got lucky," Syracuse Coach JIM BOEHEIM said. Of Seton Hall's low expectations after losing forward EDDIE GRIFFIN, center SAMUEL DALEMBERT and Coach TOMMY AMAKER, Boeheim said, "I knew that was a mistake where they were picked because they have the best guard play in the league, by far." The Pirates are led in the backcourt by the sophomore ANDRE BARRETT, the junior DESMOND HEROD and the seniors TY SHINE and DARIUS LANE.

PRESEASON N.I.T.
 The Preseason National Invitation Tournament may have produced a final between Syracuse and Wake Forest worthy of the postseason, but it had few spectators. The event last week at the Garden drew announced crowds of 6,837 for the semifinals Wednesday night and 7,891 for the championship and consolation game on Friday.
 Three of the four teams were ranked in the top 25 (Syracuse, Michigan State and Fresno State), but the field lacked a name player, with Syracuse's PRESTON SHUMPERT the closest thing to one.
 That was not the problem, said Joel Fisher the Garden's senior vice president for sports properties. Fisher cited the ailing economy and the Sept. 11 attacks for keeping tourists out of New York and said Syracuse did not bring as many fans as it normally does. Fisher said scheduling the games around Thanksgiving was not the problem, since the Garden has historically done so and drawn well. RAFAEL HERMOSO

HEADLINE: For the Big Canadian Banks, Profit Is Retail and Domestic 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
After a decade of spreading their wings into investment banking and across the border into the United States, Canada's big five banks are growing to appreciate their own backyard.
 A common thread through the recent earnings reports from Royal Bank of Canada, Toronto-Dominion Bank, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Bank of Montreal is the relatively robust performance of their retail and small-business operations in Canada, where they dominate the financial services industry. The fifth big bank, Bank of Nova Scotia, reports next week. 
 James Keating, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Canada, said that "a combination of falling interest rates and pretty good pricing discipline" had helped the banks' retail operations. He said that the slide in interest rates had enabled the banks to borrow more cheaply and offer competitive loan rates.
Today, the Bank of Canada cut its bellwether overnight rate by half a percentage point, to 2.25 percent, the ninth reduction this year. 
Over all, the banks' earnings for the fiscal year that ended on Oct. 31 have contained few surprises. The returns on equity of all four that have reported so far have fallen over the last year.
Royal's return for fiscal 2001 was 17.1 percent, down from 20.2 percent in 2000. Canadian Imperial fell to 19.8 percent from 22.5 percent, and Bank of Montreal to 14.8 percent from 18.8 percent. Toronto-Dominion's return was unchanged at 18 percent for the year, but slipped to 16.8 percent in the fourth quarter. All figures exclude unusual items.
In most cases, the declines are a result of restructuring costs and significantly higher provisions for loan losses, especially in investment banking. Even before the release of the fourth-quarter earnings, four of the five banks had announced increases in these provisions.
In the case of Bank of Montreal, 60 percent of the 430 million Canadian dollars ($269 million) in extra provisions stemmed from business in the United States, and almost three-quarters was from investment banking activities. Several of the Canadian banks have a sizable exposure to the beleaguered North American telecommunications industry.
The retail business presents a brighter picture. Peter Godsoe, chairman of the Bank of Nova Scotia, said in a recent presentation that revenue growth in Canada had held up "reasonably well" since Sept 11. "It may be unexciting, but it's highly effective and, I might add, highly profitable," Mr. Godsoe said.
Royal Bank, the biggest of the five, said net income from personal and commercial banking grew 8 percent in the final quarter, compared with a year earlier. By contrast, Royal lost $8.75 million on investment and corporate banking in the quarter, in contrast to earnings of $70 million in August-October 2000.
Jacek Dzierwa, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney in Toronto, said that in spite of lackluster profitability, Canadian banking was "quite healthy" with one of the strongest capital bases of banks anywhere in the world.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Stayed Robust In November 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
Auto sales have remained surprisingly strong this month easing the recession, economists say, and possibly shortening it, with automakers beginning to announce plans to increase production more than initially expected early next year to rebuild inventories. 
 November's robust sales, after October's record pace, have been driven by a wave of interest-free financing offers from the Big Three, which have been good news for car buyers with good credit and have attracted many others to dealerships. And the incentives, by increasing consumer spending, have brought hopeful tidings to a bleak economy. 
 On Monday, the National Bureau of Economic Research said the country was indeed in a recession -- and had been since March. But many economists say the auto price war, regardless of its implications in Detroit, will help the broader economy. 
"It's going to be one of the key factors getting us out of the recession," said Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at Bank One in Chicago, noting that the auto industry accounts for 3 to 5 percent of the gross domestic product. "There's no single industry that's a bigger swing factor, quarter to quarter." 
What is good for the economy, though, is not necessarily good for the Big Three. Incentives have increased automakers' losses and drawn criticism from analysts, investors and even from top executives at Ford and Chrysler, which have followed the lead of General Motors in using interest-free financing. And much of the cost will be dumped onto auto suppliers, whose profit margins are narrowing. 
G.M. spurred the zero percent deals when sales stagnated after the terror attacks, but the company also saw a chance to gain market share after years of declines, because it had one of the newest crops of pickups and S.U.V.'s on the market. G.M. has started to ratchet down the incentives by excluding some vehicles and offering interest-free financing only on three-year deals. 
Ford officials said in their third fiscal-quarter report that incentive costs had risen from 11 percent of revenue last year to 16 percent this year. Each percentage point increase costs $1 billion in pretax profits, a chief reason Ford is expected to have its first year of net losses since 1992. 
"The industry did need a jump-start post Sept. 11, so that was good," said Martin Inglis, chief financial officer of Ford Motor, in an interview on Monday. "My only question is, Was this the way to jump-start it?" 
"Whereas October was ridiculous, now it's only horrific," he added, referring to the incentive costs.
Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, said in an interview this month that his company was weighing both the broad economic implications and its own self-preservation in leading makers into interest-free deals. 
"We thought it was good for us, but we thought it was good for the economy," he said. "We saw that we could get people to come in and buy when it seemed like there was no way to cross that bridge, so that's why we really feel strongly that the right kind of stimulus package would add a lot of value to the whole economy." 
A positive for the economic outlook next year is that the financing deals have greatly reduced inventories on car lots, meaning that production may increase in the first quarter. Officials at Ford, which cut production after the attacks, said this week that they had recently increased their projections for first-quarter production because inventories of cars and trucks were at their lowest level since March of 1992. 
"Having cut back sharply, now they have to start rebuilding those inventories," said David A. Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's DRI. "It helps us come out of the recession sooner, and it shows that the consumer is not as scared to spend as some had thought." 
Analysts project that November's annual sales rate, seasonally adjusted, will be 17.5 million to 18.5 million vehicles, compared with 16.4 million in November 2000. The official results will be reported by the industry on Monday. November's strong sales follow a 21.3 million rate in October, the biggest sales month in the industry's history. 
At the same time, analysts have been pessimistic about next year. Scott Sprinzen, managing director for corporate and government bond ratings for Standard & Poor's, said today that the big sales in October and November are "a direct trade-off" that will steal sales from 2002. 
"We are even more cautious about next year" as a result, he said. Standard & Poor's has downgraded the credit of G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler recently, as have other ratings agencies. Equities analysts have also been critical of the fiscal wisdom of incentives. But the overall wisdom of Detroit's strategy depends on whom one asks. Analysts see the bottom line. Economists see the economy.
"They have been highly criticized because they are losing money, but I think that's shortsighted," said Richard J. DeKaser, chief economist of National City Bank in Cleveland. 
"Had they not cleared out the inventory, they would have had to clear 2001 inventory in 2002, and you can't do that at full price," he said, adding that the interest-free financing plans were a "short-term positive" for the economy and "in the long term, close to neutral." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeff Jacobs of Jacobs Twin in Chicago has seen inventory dwindle thanks to zero percent financing. (Bloomberg News)(pg. C7)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Microsoft Move May Hasten Settlement of European Case

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR with PAUL MELLER 

 BODY:
Offering a strong signal that it wants to settle its antitrust case in Europe, Microsoft has told the European Commission that it will forgo its right to a hearing next month, company officials and European regulators said yesterday.
 The move is procedural, but it could hasten the path toward settlement in Europe by allowing talks to begin earlier and avoid a possibly confrontational hearing. 
 "We asked the commission to withdraw our request for a hearing," said John Frank, a legal counsel for Microsoft in Paris.
The Microsoft gesture follows two major settlement deals in the last month that went a long way to resolving the company's longstanding antitrust problems. The company agreed to a settlement with the Justice Department and 9 of the 18 states that had sued Microsoft in federal court, and it agreed to settle more than 100 private class-action antitrust suits. 
Though the Microsoft decision helps open the door to an agreement in Europe, there is no assurance that a deal will be reached. "This doesn't mean a settlement is automatically the next juncture," noted a government official close to the commission investigation.
The European case has a different emphasis from the antitrust suit brought in the United States, though they overlap. In a "statement of objections" presented to Microsoft in August, the commission said that the company had abused its monopoly power by withholding technical information that rivals needed to allow their software to run smoothly with Microsoft's industry-standard Windows operating system.
The issue of "interoperability," in industry parlance, is particularly important in the market for software used on big data-serving computers, which are connected to desktop machines running Windows. In the market for server software, Microsoft competes against Sun Microsystems and others.
The European Commission's statement of objections, issued in August, also contended that Microsoft had illegally bundled its media-playing software with Windows to undermine competition in the fast-growing new market for online music and video software.
A European statement of objections is not a final decision in a case. But it is a kind of final warning for a defendant company, strongly indicating where the commission is headed.
In the United States, the federal suit focused on an array of anticompetitive acts by Microsoft to protect its Windows monopoly and the practice of bundling its Internet browsing software with its operating system. Yet the proposed settlement with the Justice Department and nine states does include a provision requiring Microsoft to disclose more technical information to software rivals. And the nine states that did not join the settlement say they think that is one provision that needs to be stronger.
"The interoperability issues are significant, and it is an area that needs to be improved," said Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general.
Mr. Blumenthal, like other state attorneys general who did not join the settlement earlier this month, had still been reviewing the agreement. But he decided definitively yesterday to fight for stronger sanctions. "We've made our review, and we've decided to pursue this in court," he said.
The dissenting states will propose their own set of remedies to the court on Dec. 7.
Those states, in theory, could get some help from Europe. Microsoft's software offerings are global products. As a practical matter, any concession made to suit European regulators will be made worldwide, company officials acknowledge.
Indeed, the previous antitrust settlement Microsoft agreed to in 1994 -- a "consent decree" in the United States, and an "undertaking" in Europe -- was negotiated simultaneously in Washington and Brussels. But in the current round, the timing is not as coordinated and the antitrust climate may be different in Europe and America.
As an example, antitrust experts point to the European resistance earlier this year that derailed the merger of General Electric and Honeywell, even though Washington had approved. "We're not operating in as close harmony with Europe as we have at times in the past," said Herbert Hovenkamp, a law professor at the University of Iowa.
Still, the Microsoft decision in the European case to withdraw its request for a two-day hearing, which would have begun on Dec. 20, is another clear example that the company is moving aggressively to try to put its antitrust troubles behind it. The recent settlement-mindedness is in marked contrast to the rigid posture of denial and litigation that Microsoft held for years.
In an interview last week, Brad Smith, who was tapped to become Microsoft's new general counsel, said he was hopeful that a settlement could be reached in Europe. "The commission is concerned about interoperability issues, and we're committed to interoperability," Mr. Smith said.
Whether the details of Microsoft's commitment will satisfy the commission remains to be seen. The company filed its reply to the commission's statement of objections on Nov. 16. The commission staff is now studying the Microsoft document, which runs to 100 pages and is supplemented by reports from economic and technical experts hired by Microsoft. It also includes the testimony of 46 Microsoft customers, saying that in their experience Windows works fine with the server software of other companies.
In keeping with commission practice, the Microsoft filing, which is not released to the public, is nonetheless released to "third parties" to the investigation -- mainly rivals like Sun Microsystems that brought complaints against Microsoft.
In Europe, the third parties can also ask for a hearing. It is rare for a defendant to forgo its right to a hearing, said Amelia Torres, a commission spokeswoman on competition matters. But Ms. Torres added, "The right to a hearing applies both to defendants and complainants."
A spokeswoman for Sun Microsystems had no comment on Microsoft's move or whether it would seek a hearing.

HEADLINE: Landmarks Group Approves Bold Plan for Hearst Tower 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The Landmarks Preservation Commission gave its blessing yesterday to a remarkable architectural union that would permit the Hearst Corporation to complete the mid-Manhattan headquarters it began building 74 years ago. 
 Under the plan approved by the commission, Hearst would construct 36 floors atop its landmark six-story headquarters at 959 Eighth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets. The architect, Norman Foster of Foster & Partners in London, is renowned for his daring additions to the Reichstag in Berlin and the British Museum in London. 
 At first glance, the Hearst tower differs strikingly from the landmark through which it would rise to a height of 597 feet. The original is a sturdy cast-stone mesa entered by a grand archway, adorned by allegorical statues and pierced by fluted columns with urns on top. Its high-rise companion would be a faceted, dimple-edged, stainless-steel grid of cascading, colossal diamonds. 
But Sherida E. Paulsen, chairwoman of the landmarks commission, discerned a strong spiritual relation between the addition and the exuberant original, by Joseph Urban, whose early fame was as a set designer for the impresario Florenz Ziegfeld. 
"It really does complete the building," Ms. Paulsen said. "The very theatrical aspects of Urban's design are realized."
She was joined in supporting the plan by every member of the commission but Deborah S. Gardner, who abstained out of concern that the landmark would come to be seen as merely a screenlike facade around the base of the new tower. She also said the commission had not heard enough about how Hearst planned to restore the original architectural details, which is part of the project.
Hearst also needs approval from the City Planning Commission to take advantage of a zoning bonus that would permit a building of 720,000 square feet, 20 percent larger than would usually be allowed. In exchange, it would make improvements to the adjoining Columbus Circle subway station.
The base of the building would be turned into an atrium up to 70 feet high, with views through skylights to the tower above, though the question of how much of this would be open to the public has yet to be resolved.
Even with city approvals in hand, Hearst will consider the state of the economy before making a final decision to go forward with the tower, in which it would consolidate operations that are now scattered around Columbus Circle. In no event does it expect to begin building until 2003.
Nonetheless, the Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike, a member of the commission, said the timing of the proposal so soon after the attack on New York would send a hopeful sign that "the creative process goes on" in the city.
His enthusiasm was shared by the Municipal Art Society, the New York Landmarks Conservancy, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects and Community Board 4 in mid-Manhattan.
The Hearst Corporation and Lord Foster had so carefully cultivated support for the project that the entire formal review lasted only 2 hours and 40 minutes, from the opening statement by Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive of Hearst, through Lord Foster's presentation, public testimony, questions and answers, commissioners' remarks and the vote.
As such, this project represents the most striking evidence yet of a change in New York's aesthetic landscape, in which contextualism has long been the watchword when it comes to historic buildings and districts.
"Here comes somebody who's doing something that -- thank heavens -- doesn't look like everything else," said Frederic S. Papert, president of the 42nd Street Development Corporation and a board member of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, in an interview before the meeting. "Isn't that what we want?"
Not exactly, some preservationists answered.
" 'Isn't it a neat building?' is not the question," said Simeon Bankoff, executive director of the Historic Districts Council, which did not support the plan. "The question is whether it's appropriate. We feel it's not an appropriate building. It does not respond to, respect or even speak to its landmark base."
Supporters made it plain that their endorsement rested in part on the premise that the Hearst Building was envisioned from the first as the base of a larger structure. But no record exists of Urban's intentions for the tower.
That gave Lord Foster freer reign to devise his own composition. Working with the New York engineer Ysrael A. Seinuk, he devised a structural system of nine tiers of interlocking four-story triangles that resolve into larger diamond patterns; even stylized H's, looked at a certain way.

HEADLINE: A Saudi Prince With an Unconventional Idea: Elections 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 27 

 BODY:
A prominent member of Saudi Arabia's royal family called today for a transformation that would bring elections, "the faster the better," to a kingdom whose only bow to democracy has been the establishment of an appointed advisory council.
 Prince Walid bin Talal, a billionaire investor, said in an interview here that he was addressing the politically taboo subject to augment what he called intensive discussions within the royal family about what Saudi Arabia could be doing better to address domestic discontent -- particularly in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, in which 15 of 19 hijackers were Saudis. 
 "If people speak more freely and get involved more in the political process, you can really contain them and make them part of the process," Prince Walid said.
The remarks were unusually candid in a kingdom that almost always maintains a guarded public face, particularly on questions of internal decisions and any kind of political liberalization. 
They echoed loud but private calls by Saudi liberals, who have begun to speculate that the widespread Saudi participation in the Sept. 11 attacks was at least in part a consequence of a closed political system that allows little room for political expression.
For most of his career, Prince Walid, 47, has shunned a political role, focusing on a career in investing that has made him one of the world's richest businessmen. But he waded into political controversy last month, when he offered $10 million to the City of New York for victims of the World Trade Center disaster but also issued a press release saying American policy in the Middle East had helped to fan extremism.
The suggestion that United States policy might have been partly to blame for the attack inflamed anger among some Americans, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who rejected Prince Walid's gift.
In the interview, Prince Walid defended Saudi Arabia's monarchy as popular and resilient, and said he had quietly favored an eventual shift toward some democracy long before Sept. 11. But he also made clear his view that terrorism and its roots remained a subject of deep concern within the ruling Saud family.
"What I'm saying could be too much for Saudi Arabia," he said, "but I'm speaking my mind."
As laid down by King Fahd and his predecessors, the official Saudi line has long shunned democracy as an unwelcome imposition. It was not until 1992 that King Fahd even formed the consultative council, whose members are appointed in a mechanism that its chairman, Sheik Muhammad al-Jubeir, defended in an interview this week as far superior to popular elections.
In calling for change, Prince Walid made clear that what he had in mind was limited. He said the 120-member council should be chosen in elections that would be open, at least at first, to men only. The approach would be roughly similar to the one in place in Kuwait, which has had an elected Parliament since 1961.
Two of Saudi Arabia's other neighbors, Bahrain and Qatar, have also promised to hold elections by the end of next year. It is a sign of growing democratic experimentation in the Persian Gulf region, in which almost all power still lies in the hands of kings, emirs, sheiks and sultans.
But Prince Walid's remarks were extraordinarily bold by the standards of Saudi Arabia, where criticism of the royal family is prohibited -- and where some officials have continued to dismiss as unproven the idea of Saudi involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, for which the United States holds the Saudi dissident Osama bin Laden responsible.
"We should not take this matter for granted, the loyalty of our people," Prince Walid said. "People are very loyal as Saudis, very loyal. For sure they don't want bin Laden and the Taliban types to rule here, because they see how backward they are in Afghanistan.
"But we should really let them talk more freely. We should not be worried about that at all."
Advocates of greater political openness have argued that it would force Saudi Arabia to deal more quickly with internal problems, including a high rate of unemployment, while allowing moderates to drown out extremist voices like those of Mr. bin Laden, which they say thrive in a closed society.
Prince Walid has defended the remarks in his news release accompanying the offer of a donation to New York, which accused the United States of a lack of evenhandedness in the Middle East peace efforts. Spurned by Mr. Giuliani, he said he had divided the $10 million into donations in equal parts to Afghan refugees and "the Palestinian cause."
At the same time, he said his calls for changes in Saudi Arabia were a second step in trying to call attention to what both countries might do better.
A nephew of King Fahd, and also of Crown Prince Abdullah, the country's day-to-day ruler, Prince Walid is one of scores of grandsons of Saudi Arabia's founder, King Abdel Aziz. His own father, Prince Talal, who is widely regarded as one of the family's more liberal members, has long been sidelined from any role in government, but he has said that Prince Walid ought not to be excluded from the line of royal succession.
In the interview today, Prince Walid sounded another populist note by saying he favored an end to the system of royal allowances that provide even the youngest newborn prince with thousands of dollars a month. He said he donates his family's own relatively modest allowance of $180,000 a year to charity.
He said the idea of moving toward limited democracy was being "openly discussed" within the royal family, even though it was almost never mentioned in Saudi Arabia's government-owned or monitored newspapers and television.
"We're still in the process of saying yes or no," he said. He did not say what positions were being taken by other members of the family. The orthodox view was expressed this week by Sheik Jubeir, the chairman of the appointive council, in a separate interview. "In our opinion the people who would elect the members would not choose the right people," he said. "So therefore we prefer to appoint and to choose, but within certain specifications and the rules."
In a conversation, another grandson of King Abdel Aziz also referred to intense discussions about what if any changes within the royal family Saudi Arabia ought to consider in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. 
"You'd be surprised at the issues that are discussed," said Prince Bandar bin Khalid, 36, an investment manager, "and obviously debate increases in times of crisis, like now and the gulf war."
But Prince Bandar told a visitor to his home late one recent evening, "It's something for us, the leadership, to discuss and for society to discuss, but it is not something for outsiders to impose on us or to tell us what we should be thinking."
